NAME: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1098 words

HEADLINE: Weicker Rejects Re-election Bid In Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the one-time liberal Republican who built a career out of going his own way, announced today that he would not seek re-election to a second term.
Mr. Weicker, who is 62 and has more than 15 months left in office, said he wanted more time with his family, less intrusion by the demands of campaigning, and, perhaps, a job in private industry. He avoided the word "retirement" and vowed a vigorous final year in office. 
 "If anybody looks on this individual as a lame duck on a pond," he said, "you better think twice because you're going to find something coming out of Jurassic Park at you."
 
Entering the Post-Weicker Era
 If the announcement marked a turning point for Mr. Weicker, it was no less so for Connecticut politics. For much of his 30-year career in public life, including his 18 years in the United States Senate, Mr. Weicker has been both one of Connecticut's most admired and most vilified politicians, and one of the few with any claim to a national reputation.
A bearlike man with self-confidence that borders on arrogance, he defied the odds three years ago to become the state's first third-party governor in this century.
His determination in imposing an income tax in 1991, in particular, earned him the hatred of many residents, although, like Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, with whom he is often compared, Mr. Weicker has largely reinvented himself since then by plowing on with new initiatives, including an attempt to create regional efforts to end racial segregation in the public schools and a bid recently to attract the New England Patriots professional football team to the state. His withdrawal has also improved the fortunes of the handful of politicians who had already risen to challenge him in next year's election.
"For 30 years my neighbors -- three million plus -- have allowed me to be a part of history, and to shape history," he told a crowd of well-wishers and reporters in a speech that veered from sentimental reflection to stentorian denunciation of big-money, two-party political gridlock. "And I am still a total believer in what one man or woman can achieve when of a mind to do so."
 
He's Not Getting Any Younger
 Outweighing all of that, however, he said, was the growing realization of advancing time and age, and that his seven children -- the youngest of whom, Andrew, is 10 -- were also being forced to sacrifice for what the Governor called his own selfishness.
"We don't talk as much as we should about what went on in school, or what it is they'd like to go ahead and do, what are their dreams," he said. "The time has come to step aside and concentrate on them."
There is the question of money. Mr. Weicker, who gave up a job at a private health research foundation paying $300,000 a year to run for governor in 1990 -- a position that pays $78,000 -- used his early farewell to make an appeal for work when Hartford is behind him.
"I want the private sector to know that I'm available," he said. "I'm looking for a job. If anybody has any ideas, I'd like to hear it."
Although he comes from a family of some wealth, with ties to the Squibb pharmaceutical fortune, Mr. Weicker has said he is not wealthy.
In Hartford, Mr. Weicker's announcement shattered most expectations about next year's election. In recent months, as Mr. Weicker's popularity seemed to improve, two prominent Democrats, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly and Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, dropped out. Mrs. Kennelly, in particular, went out of her way to praise Mr. Weicker's achievements.
The Lieutenant Governor, Eunice S. Groark, who like Mr. Weicker quit the Republican Party to run on the Weicker ticket in 1990, said today that she was "very interested in running for governor." She said she would have a definitive statement in the next 10 days on her plans. United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican, has also said she will announce plans soon.
One of the few people who was already in the race, State Senator John B. Larson, Democrat of East Hartford, suggested today that his strategy would be to portray himself as a bit like Mr. Weicker himself: brave enough to have jumped in even when it didn't look too safe.
"Many have waited to test the political winds," Mr. Larson said. "It was never a factor in my decision."
 
No Endorsements
 Mr. Weicker, who said he made his final decision about a week ago, declined to make any endorsements but said that in the coming campaign, he would remain true to A Connecticut Party, the party he founded, and campaign for its candidate whether that is Mrs. Groark or someone else.
One goal, he said, is to dispel the notion that politicians who aren't running again can't get anything done. He said his agenda would focus on children, specifically in protecting them from what he described as a greedy conspiracy by older generations, his own included, to milk the economic and political system and leave nothing for the future.
"Regardless if the rest of the nation wants to have their children worse off than the generation before -- and it's the first time it's ever occurred in the history of the United States -- that isn't going to happen here in our state," he said.
Louise Hull, a longtime supporter of Mr. Weicker's who drove from New Hartford in northern Litchfield County for the Governor's announcement, burst into applause at the line.
Before he entered the room, she opened her hand to show a reporter a crumpled tissue. She was fully expecting him to say he would not run, she said, and was prepared for it. "I know I'll cry," she said.
 
Praise From Politicians
 Elsewhere around the state, politicians offered only praise for a man that many had not so long ago bitterly criticized as arrogant or worse.
The State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., a Democrat who is considered a potential candidate for governor, conceded that he and Mr. Weicker had had their differences over the years, notably over whether the state's fiscal health was really as good as Mr. Weicker claimed after the adoption of the income tax.
"But these have been differences over management and strategy, not values," Mr. Curry said. "The Governor is a great warrior. With his departure from the arena, the rest of us will seem boring by comparison."
One long-time adviser to the Governor, Peter Gold, said he believed that even people who detested Mr. Weicker would come to dislike the quiet when the Governor went on his way.
"He was always there to inspire us, if only to anger," Mr. Gold said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. after his announcement yesterday. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times) (pg. A1); His determination to impose a state income tax in Connecticut earned Gov. Chronology: "Independent and Proud of It"
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has announced that he will not seek a second term. His tenure will be remembered for several bold moves.
 
NOV. 8, 1988 Mr. Weicker is defeated in his bid for a fourth term in the United States Senate.
 
NOV. 6, 1990 He is elected Governor after forming his own party, A Connecticut Party.
 
FEB. 13, 1991 He proposes an income tax, setting off a battle within the General Assembly.
 
MAY 31, 1991 He vetoes a state budget without an income tax.
 
AUG. 7, 1991 He again vetoes a non-income tax budget.
 
AUG. 22, 1991 The legislature passes a budget with an income tax and he signs it.
 
JUNE 27, 1992 He calls for a special legislative session to rethink the state gun laws, leading to passage of a law restricting assault rifles.
 
JAN. 6, 1993 He proposes a desegregation plan, leading to a bill promoting racial integration in public schools across Connecticut.
 
JAN. 13, 1993 He signs an agreement permitting slot machines at an Indian tribe's casino in Ledyard, and the tribe agrees to contribute at least $100 million a year in gambling profits to aid cities and towns.
 
SEPT. 3, 1993 He summons the General Assembly for a special legislative session on building a stadium for the New England Patriots, leading to a measure he signed on Tuesday. (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: G.M.'s Canada Contract Sends Shares Falling

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Shares of the General Motors Corporation slid today in heavy trading as investors reacted to news of a tentative labor contract reached Wednesday night by G.M. and the Canadian Automobile Workers.
The stock closed down $2.125 a share at $41.75. It was the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange, with 7.8 million shares changing hands. 
 Analysts said investors were not troubled by the Canadian settlement itself, but by its implications for G.M.'s negotiations here with the United Automobile Workers union.
 
 
Protests Become Harder
 The Canadian contract includes a number of provisions, including pension increases and a fund to pay laid-off workers, that are similar to those in the 1990 American agreement. G.M. hopes to moderate some of those provisions in its next American contract to cut labor costs.
But G.M.'s Canada agreement may undercut the company's credibility in protesting the pattern contract already negotiated with the Ford Motor Company and under discussion today with the Chrysler Corporation here. Wall Street reached the same conclusion.
Chrysler negotiators were still talking tonight as the strike deadline of 11:59 approached. Each side said it was close to a settlement.
Once the U.A.W. settles with Chrysler, it will move on to G.M., which is expected to put up the biggest fight because of its financial condition.
The decline in G.M.'s stock today, said Harvey Heinbach, an auto analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, is "mostly the markets looking at the Canadian agreement and concluding from that the probability of getting significant concessions from the U.A.W. is low."
In a statement, G.M. suggested today that differences between its costs in Canada and America -- partly because Canada's national health care system lowers company health care costs there -- made the two contracts quite different.
"We have approached our negotiations in Canada and in the United States with recognition of important differences in underlying economics, as well as in the provisions of our labor agreements with the C.A.W. and the United Automobile Workers," G.M. said.
The pattern agreement written at Ford raises wages and pension benefits and increases the money set aside to pay laid-off workers. Itmaintains comprehensive health coverage fully paid by the company and it lowers wages for starting workers and lengthens the time it takes for them to reach the top of the pay scale.
 At Chrysler, the U.A.W. has been pressing for commitments to keep more parts production in-house to preserve jobs. Chrysler is the least vertically integrated of the Big Three, making about 30 percent of its parts. Chrysler was also hoping to avoid a large pension increase, because it has unfinanced pension liability estimated to exceed $2 billion.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Walkout at 5 Plants
 LAND PARK, Mich., Friday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A deadline for a new contract between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation passed Thursday night with no immediate strike called, but more than 5,000 workers at five plants walked off the job early today.
Negotiators remained at the bargaining table past midnight, but there was no official announcement that the old contract for 56,000 company workers had been extended. Chrysler officials said workers at assembly plants in Detroit; Sterling Heights, Mich.; St. Louis; Belvidere, Ill., and Newark, Del., all walked off the job at midnight, a half-hour to an hour before their shifts ended.
"They told us to keep them in, but mine are gone," said Frank Massey, local U.A.W. president at the Jefferson North factory in Detroit. Other locals that were contacted said they were able to keep workers on the job.

HEADLINE: $2.5 Billion Approved for Former Soviet States

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Senate passed a foreign-aid bill tonight that includes $2.5 billion for Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union. The vote was 87-13. President Clinton signed the bill just hours later.
The $13 billion bill was approved by the House on Wednesday when lawmakers speeded the process to show support for President Boris N. Yeltsin in his showdown with Parliament. 
 "Recent events in Moscow highlight the urgency of helping the momentum of democratic and economic reform," the President said in a statement.
Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, chairman of the subcommittee that oversees foreign aid, said, "I hope this is seen in Russia as a very, very strong signal from the United States Congress that we are supporting moves toward democracy."
As revised by the Administration over the summer, the aid package for the former Soviet Union emphasizes efforts to develop the private sector and get United States companies involved in reshaping Russia.
The package includes $250 million in export credits for United States business ventures, $125 million for grants to help in privatization and $60 million to help transport millions of dollars' worth of privately donated food and medicine for Russia.
The bill conditions the aid to the timely withdrawal of Russian troops from Latvia and Estonia, respect for territorial integrity within the former Soviet Union and the end of Russian aid for Cuba.
The bill includes up to $300 million for Ukraine.
Total spending in the bill was $1.4 billion below the Administration's request, and down from $13.9 billion in 1993. While cutting most programs, the maintains spending of $3 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt, the two biggest recipients since the 1979 Camp David peace agreement.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. to Defer Russian Payments
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States and Russia signed a formal agreement today to defer $1.1 billion in Russian debt payments. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen hailed the action as "another element in the international effort to assist Russia."
The deferral is for America's share of $17 billion in debt payments that the United States and other Western countries agreed last April to delay.
 That total represented the largest single element of a $43 billion aid package put together for President Yeltsin by the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
Russia has a total estimated foreign debt of $80 billion, with $4 billion of that owed to the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Clinton Administration proposed legislation to strengthen the Government's system of pension insurance by requiring companies with underfinanced funds to make larger contributions. "The financial future of many American workers and retirees may be at risk because their pensions are underfunded," Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said. [Page D1.]
Personal income rose strongly in August, and a measure of joblessness edged down last week -- two indications that the economy is doing better than during the first half of the year. But new-home sales dropped sharply. [D2.] 
 President Clinton gave Federal agencies greater authority to write regulations on pollution, safety, business practices and the like without White House intervention. Mr. Clinton said his order would "eliminate improper influence, secrecy and delay." [A16.]
The Senate rejected efforts to cut off money for the Supercollider, giving the project a temporary breath of air. [A21.]
The Government's top highway official proposed that private businesses operate portions of the interstate highway system to raise money to repair decaying roads and bridges. [A12.]
 
Companies
The different styles of two Apple Computer executives are raising questions about the company's vitality and ability to recover as it enters a crucial six-month period. [D1.]
The bidding war for Paramount has not had a significant impact on movie deals or film production, executives insist. [D1.] QVC is expected to present Paramount with proof as early as today of its ability to pay $9.8 billion for the company. [D5.]
Martin Marietta plans to close 12 plants and eliminate 11,000 jobs nationwide this year. [D1.]
Prudential Securities agreed to pay about $371 million to settle charges of securities law violations. [D1.]
The New York Post roared back to life, with a new issue and a new victory over unions on Rupert Murdoch's resume. [B1.]
G.M.'s stock slid in heavy trading as investors reacted to the company's labor accord with Canadian workers. [D2.]
Chemical Waste Management plans a broad revamping to reduce its size and sharply pare costs. [D3.]
Faconnable, the French men's apparel company, has entered the suit war raging in New York. [D3.]
USAir announced that it would eliminate 2,500 jobs by the middle of next year. [D3.]
Elizabeth Crow was named editor in chief of Mademoiselle, replacing Gabe Doppelt, who resigned. [D16.]
Berkeley Systems is taking Opus the Penguin to court for his potshots at flying toasters. [D3.]
 
International
Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned China that it risks losing favorable trade status with the U.S. if it does not make quick progress on human rights and arms issues. [A10.]
 
Markets
Stocks turned in a mixed session after a series of relatively good economic reports caused bond prices to slide. [D6.]
Merrill Lynch was No. 1 in competitive bidding for tax-exempt issues during the first three quarters of the year. [D14.]
The dollar surged amid nervousness over the political standoff in Russia. [D13.] Copper futures touched a six-year low. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
The Baby Bells are getting attention as potential partners in the battle for Paramount. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Murdoch Gets The Post Out Despite Strike

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Three days after a strike stopped its presses, Rupert Murdoch's New York Post roared back to life last night, with a new issue of the paper on New York streets and a new victory against newspaper unions on Mr. Murdoch's resume.
With the cooperation of the leaders of The Post's production unions, whose members had spontaneously supported the striking employees of the New York Newspaper Guild on Monday, Mr. Murdoch managed to isolate the striking union and demonstrate his dominance over the others. Through the day, the production union leaders walked many of their members through the picket lines as the strikers yelled picket-line epithets like "scab" and "traitor." 
 Choosing the security of jobs with Mr. Murdoch, who cultivates a reputation for toughness with unions, in place of their brief alliance with the single striking newspaper union, some of the production workers said the realities of a shrinking industry in a weak economy left them no choice.
They could not, they said, afford to side with the striking news, advertising and circulation employees because it could cost them their jobs.
 
The Turning Point
 The strikers at times appeared stunned by what they said was a betrayal by fellow unionists. Some of the guild members seemed uncertain what course their union could take as Mr. Murdoch consolidates his hold on the paper. Late last night, after it was clear that Mr. Murdoch would be able to publish this morning's issue, the president of the guild local at The Post, Harry Leykis, was asked what the guild would do now. "We stay out here," Mr. Leykis said.
The turning point in Mr. Murdoch's effort to isolate the guild from the other unions came about three minutes before 8 P.M. Following a plan set by Mr. Murdoch's aides and the production union chiefs, about 100 newspaper truck drivers, pressmen and mailers massed on Catherine Slip, on the south side of the newspaper's headquarters building. Police officers kept the strikers around the corner, near the newspaper's main entrance on South Street, where the other workers had entered during the day. At once, three loading dock doors on Catherine Slip opened and the production workers, some cheering and whistling, slipped into the building in a boisterous group, without having to face their striking co-workers.
Barry F. Lipton, the guild's citywide president, was arrested on a charge of disorderly conduct as he and other union members pressed to get closer to the loading docks last night. He was quickly released and returned to the angry picket line, where he predicted Mr. Murdoch would have a difficult time producing the newspaper without unionized reporters and editors.
 
'A Hollow Post'
 "They're not going to be able to get out a meaningful Post," Mr. Lipton said. "It will be a hollow Post. It will say Post on the outside, but it will be empty on the inside."
With the craft union members at their places, The Post's production schedule appeared to run smoothly. The first trucks, loaded with Friday's Post, began pulling out of South Street before 10 P.M. Across the bottom of the 96-page edition, it said: "Death-defying Post is back."
"This is, we hope, the preservation of The Post," said Patrick J. Purcell, The Post's publisher.
He said nonunion writers and editors prepared this morning's paper.
Through the day, the bitterness outside the building was palpable as George McDonald, the president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group of newspaper production unions, led workers into the building, with other union chiefs at his shoulder.
The situation was especially bruising, some of the striking guild members said, because they could remember a time not long ago when that umbrella included the guild itself. That alliance finally broke in a different labor dispute, at a different newspaper, The Daily News, last year and now, they said, the guild's ability to survive its isolation is to be tested.
Some of the line-crossing production-union members appeared embarrassed. Some looked ashen. "We're not scabs," said Gerard Bilbao, a union superintendent of newspaper drivers. The guild, he said, had to rely on itself for defense. "Their problems are their problems. We have to look out for our families."
 
A Powerful Weapon
 In bankruptcy court yesterday morning, Mr. Murdoch's lawyers said the new cooperation of the production unions meant he was prepared to complete his purchase of the newspaper as soon as Monday. But he retained a powerful weapon for use against reluctant union workers: he retained the option to walk away from the newspaper at any time before his purchase is complete if there are any new sympathy job action.
People in and out of the newspaper industry said the latest turn in Mr. Murdoch's confrontation with New York unions was reminiscent of his fierce and successful fight with London newspaper unions in 1986, when he opened a new plant -- and stripped the unions of their power -- in the London dockyards area of Wapping.
That confrontation helped create Mr. Murdoch's worldwide reputation for toughness with unions. Yesterday, some labor experts said Mr. Murdoch's stubborn insistence on union abdication at a newspaper with only 700 employees indicated that he was playing as much to his worldwide audience as to the comparatively small group concerned about the fate of The Post or the striking Newspaper Guild.
"It is an emblematic struggle," said Daniel J. Walkowitz, a labor historian and director of the metropolitan studies program at New York University. "It is as indicative as anything of what is happening in the changing American workplace."
For the guild, its members on the picket line said yesterday, Mr. Murdoch's demand that he should be permitted what the guild members call a four-month "free-fire zone" during which he could dismiss employees with impunity -- and without severance -- was so unacceptable that there was little choice.
To Mr. Murdoch's associates, it also appeared there was no choice. Without Mr. Murdoch and his willingness to lose several million dollars a year, there would be no newspaper, they asserted. Mr. Purcell, the publisher and a longtime Murdoch executive, last night dismissed the guild's assertion that it was fighting for job security. "Their job security," he said, "is Rupert Murdoch."
For the other unions, the battle left them with impossible choices. To side with the guild, rank-and-file members and leaders said, appeared to be suicide. To side against the guild, in addition to the painful symbolism of appearing to violate trade union fundamentals, would signal Mr. Murdoch that his dominance over all of the unions was virtually complete.
 
A Halfway Stance
 What turned out to be a halfway stance, with rank and file spontaneous support for the strike on Monday, followed by the leaders' organized effort to get members back to work, indicated how difficult the dilemma was for the unionized production workers.
Mr. McDonald, the trades council president, last night reacted with fury to assertions by Mr. Lipton, the president of the New York guild, and angry strikers yesterday that he had breached basic labor rules by working to get the production workers to satisfy Mr. Murdoch's demands.
Mr. McDonald contended that the guild leaders were behaving irresponsibly and were out of touch with modern realities in the newspaper industry. "They're acting like Never, Never Land -- way back," he said in an interview. "They're not in 1993. All I can say is we're going to save the paper for the people who work there."
As the guild strike continues, its members are likely to come under far more pressure than is usual in labor confrontations, even apart from the issue of support, or the lack of it, from other unions.
Because The Post is in bankruptcy and Mr. Murdoch is a new owner of its assets, he is under no legal obligation to recognize prior guild contracts. After he completes the formal purchase of The Post, Post executives are expected to take the view that Mortimer B. Zuckerman took last winter as the new owner of The Daily News: that all current guild employees could be viewed as applicants for the jobs they formerly held.

HEADLINE: Cuban Officials Don't Foresee a Thaw With the U.S. Anytime Soon

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Despite recent agreements with Washington on immigration and narcotics matters, senior Cuban officials say they do not foresee any imminent advance in relations with the United States, which have been marked by open hostility for 34 years.
Instead, the Cuban officials say, they hope that by cooperating in areas of mutual interest, the Clinton Administration will eventually strike a more positive attitude toward Cuba as it gains a stronger political foothold for itself. 
 In an interview in New York, where he was attending the United Nations General Assembly, Cuba's new Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, struck a friendly but cautious tone toward Washington, taking pains, as other senior Cuban officials have recently done, to lower expectations of a breakthrough.
"After so many years of tension you don't resolve the problems from one day to the next," said Mr. Robaina, a 37-year-old who until recently headed Cuba's Communist Youth League. A dramatic change in relations, he added, "is not on the next street corner."
 
A Basis of Equality
 "But I want it to be made clear that we are not the closed-minded people that some would like to make us out to be," Mr. Robaina said. "We want to hear other opinions, but we also want our opinions to be heard. If we move forward on a basis of equality, we can arrive at almost anything."
Mr. Robaina's comments, made on Tuesday, came on the same day as an announcement of an agreement between Washington and Havana to allow the gradual repatriation of 1,500 Cuban-born prisoners who are being held in American jails for crimes committed in the United States since the Mariel boatlift that brought 125,000 Cubans to this country in 1980.
Further speculation of a thaw in relations had been aroused when the United States accepted the extradition by Cuba this month of two suspected American cocaine traffickers. The suspects had been arrested by Cuban officers in Cuban waters after a fruitless sea chase by American drug enforcement agents. Under the Bush Administration, cooperation with Cuba in narotics cases was severely limited.
Conservative Cuban-American groups and their allies in Congress have reacted with growing alarm to the two recent gestures of cooperation, the first significant collaboration between Havana and Washington since the Carter Administration.
Mr. Robaina said that as long as the Clinton Administration showed "respect for our sovereignty," the Government of President Fidel Castro would continue to work on improving limited cooperation in areas like immigration, narcotics control and telecommunications. He also said that the Cuban Government was studying ways of expanding "cultural, scientific, sports and journalistic" exchanges.
 
A Three-Pronged Strategy
 Increasing cooperation in areas like these appears to be one part of a three-pronged strategy by the Cuban Government toward achieving eventual warmer ties with the United States. The other parts are increasing visits by Cuban-Americans to the island and rapidly opening up Cuba's economy to private investment from abroad and more free enterprise at home.
By removing most restrictions on visits by Cuban-American exiles, senior Cuban officials have made no secret of their hope of winning the sympathies of parts of the exile community that are moved by nationalist sentiments or simply by the desire to help relatives back home. The emergence of more currents like this, they say, could eventually soften political opposition in the United States to a diplomatic relaxation.
"This community is Cuban," Mr. Robaina said of the Cuban-American exiles. "No one can be more interested in these people than us. What have we told ourselves as we have made contacts with many segments of this community is that even if they dislike the program which we have carried out, they stand up for many of the same things which we defend."
By opening up the Cuban economy, meanwhile, the Government feels that it is doing more than simply averting a disaster by stopping the free fall of a failed system of rigid central planning. At the same time, it hopes that the arrival of increasingly large investments from Spain, Canada, France and elsewhere will prompt American businesses to lobby for renewed access to a natural market of 11 million people that lies only 90 miles from Florida.
Cuban officials are acutely aware that however bold their attempts to privatize the economy, foreign investment will be hindered by isolation from American markets for everything from tourists to agriculture and merchandise.
 
Americans 'Penalized'
 "We are opening our economy and many companies are in, but the Americans themselves are being penalized" Ricardo Alarcon, a Communist Party Politburo member who also heads Cuba's National Assembly, said in a recent interview in Havana. "What I am sure of is that these steps and new steps yet to come will have a positive impact on Latin America and the Europeans.
"What will happen in the U.S.? We would expect it would motivate people in the business community, but we'll have to wait and see."

HEADLINE: U.S. Blockade of Workers Enrages Mexican Town

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, Sept. 29

 BODY:
For years, as thousands of undocumented workers floated openly across the Rio Grande each day from this sprawling border metropolis to jobs in El Paso, Tex., illegal immigration became a symbol of tolerance, even brotherhood, between the two cities.
That immigration agents stopped relatively few of the nannies and gardeners and busboys was taken as a sign that Ciudad Juarez and El Paso understood each other's needs. Federal law, it seemed, was no match for the forces of economic interdependence. 
 Then, on Sept. 19, the United States Border Patrol began what it calls Operation Blockade. By deploying hundreds of agents along a 20-mile stretch of the international boundary, the Patrol has all but stopped a human traffic that it estimated at more than 10,000 people a day.
 
A Wave of Outrage
 While some impetus for the operation may have come from Washington, where the Clinton Administration has promised a tougher stand on illegal immigration, it has been received with clamorous applause in the tract homes and shopping malls that sit beneath El Paso's grey-brown hills.
"People here seem to think that all of their problems -- welfare, health care, crime, you name it -- have been solved," said Cheryl A. Howard, a sociologist at the University of Texas El Paso.
Across the border, however, the blockade and the stepped-up immigration checks that have accompanied it have brought a wave of outrage. Protesters have blocked the traffic on international bridges. Angry politicians and business executives are calling for a boycott of El Paso stores.
And in a cross-border community that is often cited as a model for the cooperation that is supposed to flower if the United States Congress approves a North American Free Trade Agreement, the conflict has shattered old assumptions about how well the two cities know each other and how well they get along.
"We were very much brothers," said Isabel Delgado, a jewelry store clerk who was born in southern Chihuahua State, raised in Ciudad Juarez and has lived in El Paso for the last 15 years. "But with this, we are going our own ways."
 
Job Losses Feared
 The border crackdown has affected two kinds of migrants. Border Patrol statistics on apprehensions suggest that it has nearly halted the flow of illegal undocumented workers who have usually waded, walked or floated on rafts across the border.
Second, there have been stricter checks to root out Mexicans who walk or drive across the international bridges here with temporary permits but who then work without permission. Many of those Mexican border residents have stayed home, some out of fear and some complaining of harassment.
On the United States side of the border, many people say approval for the blockade has underscored how the trade agreement has heightened fears of job losses even in American communities where integration with Mexico is a familiar reality.
On the Mexican side, the response may have less to do with present circumstances than with sensitivities over what has been seen as arrogant and unfair treatment from the United States in the past.
 
From Confusion to Anger
 More broadly, Mexicans say that their confusion at what they perceive as mixed American signals -- the invitation to join in a long-term economic partnership on one hand, a wave of anti-immigrant feelings on the other -- has begun turning to anger.
"Everyone recognizes that they are entirely in their rights to take measures to stop immigration," said Jose Luis Soto, a 21-year-old college student in Ciudad Juarez. "But right now? Just when we are about to get into a free-trade agreement with them? This is a humiliation."
Mexican and American officials both contend that passage of the trade agreement will ultimately help to raise wages in Mexico and reduce illegal immigration. The assertion has become central to their arguments for the pact.
At the same time, the Mexican Government has grown unusually open in its resentment at what it considers the scapegoating of hard-working Mexicans who sneak into the United States to find better lives.
Until Sept. 19, officers in the Border Patrol's El Paso sector had largely concentrated their energies on arresting undocumented immigrants after they crossed into Texas and New Mexico. On average, 800 to 1,000 were apprehended each day, but most of those who work in the kitchens and gardens and farms of the area were left alone.
 
Behind the Blockade
 In an interview, the sector's chief Patrol agent, Silvestre Reyes, gave several reasons for the blockade. After a rash of accusations of abuses against immigrants and others by El Paso agents, he said, he wanted to find a way to rebuild the Patrol's community support.
He said illegal immigrants had been responsible for crimes ranging from car thefts to transvestite prostitution, that members of a Mexican gang were "terrorizing" one South El Paso neighborhood, and that immigrant beggars and freelance window-washers had become a terrible nuisance.
Mr. Reyes, a 48-year-old native of the El Paso area whose paternal grandfather immigrated from Mexico, took up his post on July 4 after nine years in the Patrol's office in McAllen, Tex. He said he was "appalled" at what he saw.
"People seemed to think that that was all right, that that was the way it has always been, that that was the way it was always going to be, and that you had to live with it," he said. "I just don't agree with that."
 
Approved by Superior
 Beyond the local considerations, Mr. Reyes said the acting director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Border Patrol's parent agency, had authorized the operation and the $250,000 that it cost in overtime for the 400 to 450 officers involved during the first two weeks.
Mr. Reyes said he now planned to continue the operation indefinitely without a budget increase.
How widely residents of El Paso approve of the measure is not clear, but a majority of the telephone calls into the city's newspapers and television stations favor the boycott. Many of the complaints have come from people who have been unable to replace their undocumented domestic help.
In interviews, many people in El Paso complained, as many did in Mexico, that the undocumented migrants were largely honest, hard-working people coming to do low-paying jobs that American citizens did not want. More of those interviewed, however, expressed support.
"I don't want them over here," said Isabel Rodriguez, a 22-year-old woman who was selling baseball caps and "El Paso-Ciudad Juarez" T-shirts from a stand at the Cielo Vista Mall in El Paso, referring to the undocumented immigrants. "I know they're human like me, but I don't go trying to wash people's windows when they don't want me to."
In the huddles of would-be immigrants who gather now in the mornings and just stare across the Rio Grande levee, there were few printable words for the likes of Miss Rodriguez.
 
No Decline in Crime
 "The Mexicans over there are the worst," said a 45-year-old immigrant smuggler, or coyote, who is called the Cowboy. As the Cowboy turned back to his dogeared comic book (also called "The Cowboy"), Manuel Macias, 42, stepped in to defend the people he said he had been floating across the river for 15 years.
"These people aren't afraid to work," he said. "They are afraid of what they will earn here."
Despite the association made by Mr. Reyes and others between undocumented immigrants and illegal activities, statistics provided by a spokesman for the El Paso Police Department, Sgt. Bill Pfeil, showed that crime had not declined significantly since the blockade began.
Yet according to a half-dozen merchants in South El Paso, their sales fell sharply even before the Juarez Chamber of Commerce, its association of small industries and political groups, including the country's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, began calling on Monday for a boycott.
Henry P. King, the director of a University of Texas institute that studies small business, said Mexicans were estimated to spend about 30 percent of the $6.5 billion in retail sales in El Paso each year.
 
No Takers for a Bet
 Indeed, at the weekly poker game presided over by the Mayor of Ciudad Juarez, Francisco Villareal, a table full of prominent citizens spoke of their ire at the symbolism of the blockade, of their dismay at what they saw as shallow solidarity from El Paso, of wives who insisted they not buy their car tires in Texas.
Mr. Villareal, who has criticized the blockade but worked to calm his town's fury, counted up the $161 he had lost and laid down a last, hopeful bet.
Double or nothing, he offered, that the blockade would not last a month.
There were no takers.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Insurers Fear They'd Be the Big Losers in a World of Managed Health Care

SERIES: The Clinton Prescription: The Impact on Insurers -- Last of six articles

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Since the President gave his health care speech last week, employees have lived with fluttery stomachs in the offices of the Bartmon Shapiro insurance agency, a thriving business high above Central Park South whose windows offer panoramic views of the park and the midtown Manhattan skyline. Under President Clinton's health care plan, the profession of health insurance agent could virtually cease to exist.
"People are very, very nervous," said Joel Shapiro, whose 17-year-old company employs 10 people. "But we are going to have to adapt. We are going to have to change." 
 Such agencies are not the only ones in the $300 billion health insurance industry that face the future with trepidation. With or without the proposed Clinton changes, hundreds of health insurers are expected to leave the business in the coming years, but the President's plan would greatly accelerate the pace.
Even the survivors, which are expected to include several of the country's largest insurers, like Prudential and Aetna, may have to fire or retrain armies of claims processors, cutting payrolls as they try to become efficient, lower-cost companies that oversee networks of doctors, nurses and hospitals.
What remains unclear is whether the survivors in the nation's health insurance industry -- an industry much distrusted by the public and often attacked in recent months by Hillary Rodham Clinton -- would eventually flourish or wither under the White House plan. It is also uncertain whether the survivors would in the end serve consumers better, as the White House insists they would.
The Administration's proposal would increase the revenue of the insurance industry by tens of billions of dollars. It would have all employers contribute and the Government subsidize the private insurance premiums of the 37 million who are now uninsured. It would also shift most poor people on Medicaid into the private insurance market. But whether those revenues would translate into profits after all the claims are paid is a matter of debate.
Under the Clinton plan, many functions of today's insurers, like setting benefit packages and negotiating with employers, would be taken over by new, state-run health alliances. The plan would force companies to compete more aggressively on the basis of price and would place limits on the premiums health insurers can charge. Those limits, insurance industry executives and a number of economists say, could squeeze profits so much that it would destroy incentives for investment and innovation.
 
Some Insurers Expected to Do Well
 "Those insurance companies that can realize real efficiencies and economies of scale may be able to do very well under the Clinton plan," said Beth Morrow, an analyst for Standard & Poor's. "But will they become more responsive to what consumers want? I don't know. What I do think is they will try to save money by squeezing health care providers to reduce costs."
The Administration says the proposed new health care system would give consumers more power in several ways.
For one, the proposed regional health alliances would serve as broker, in effect, for hundreds of thousands of consumers. Once a year, consumers would receive a menu of health plans from which to select. They would also receive a report card on each of the plans that would rate them on, among other things, consumer satisfaction and medical performance.
In addition, the Administration's proposal would permit customers more easily to compare health plans on the basis of cost. That would force insurers, health maintenance organizations and other operators of health care networks to compete for market share on the basis of both quality and price. If an insurer's services are inadequate or too expensive, the Administration says, customers once every year can vote with their feet and change plans.
In the process, the alliances would make many health insurance brokers and agents obsolete and would permit many private companies to shut down their medical benefit departments. The savings, the Administration says, would be in the billions.
Consumers would be allowed to choose traditional fee-for-service health plans, in which patients can choose their doctors and the doctors are paid for each service they provide. But financial incentives may push many consumers toward less-expensive H.M.O.'s or other types of managed care plans. Since most insurance companies today, especially the smaller ones, offer mainly fee-for-service insurance, industry analysts say most of the nation's more than 500 health insurers would be driven from the field.
The President's plan would simply be speeding up a process that is already under way: the switch of customers into H.M.O's and other forms of managed care. Last year, 41 million Americans had already enrolled in H.M.O.'s, up from 19 million in 1985. Forty-two percent of all H.M.O.'s are now owned by insurance companies or Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, while some others are run by independent companies or nonprofit organizations.
Expected to benefit most under the President's plan are those insurance companies that have already invested large sums in building up H.M.O.'s and other managed-care networks around the country. The most prominent are the Cigna Corporation, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the Travelers Corporation, Aetna Life & Casualty and more than 60 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
But doubters inside and outside the insurance industry say the Clinton plan, as proposed, will not necessarily result in a more efficient and consumer-friendly health insurance industry.
Dr. David U. Himmelstein, an associate professor at the Harvard Medical School and an advocate of Canadian-style government-run health care system, said he was concerned that an increasing amount of health care money would fall into the hands of an ever smaller and more powerful group of insurers.
In many regional markets, he said, a small number of large companies would dominate the market, making the entry of smaller new health groups difficult.
"What I think you would end up with is a couple of large firms controlling the health care delivered to the American people," Dr. Himmelstein said "Oligopolies don't compete in this country. They don't lower prices."
Executives of the nation's largest insurance companies as well as a number of economists dispute Dr. Himmelstein's predictions. They say the greatest danger is not that the insurers will be too powerful but that the health alliances will.
 
Local Competition Expected to Thrive
 Many insurance executives say that within each region and alliance large numbers of local H.M.O.'s and other health networks would survive as competitors. Even the largest national insurers may not have the capital or market clout to wipe out such competition.
"It will mean separate competition in many, many local markets, instead of one large market," said Paul Cooper, vice president for health care policy for Prudential. "The winners in Houston will be different from the winners in Denver. It is going to become a very decentralized industry."
But insurance companies note that the alliances, under Federal supervision, would set caps on the premiums that insurers could charge. Those caps might squeeze profits so much, industry officials assert, that it might be difficult for private insurers to raise capital to invest in new and innovative ways of delivering care. The White House expects that competition among health plans will itself hold down costs, but in case that tactic fails, it proposes limiting average premium increases to about the overall inflation rate.
"If we are going to have real reduction in medical inflation, it is going to take a lot of ingenuity and risk-taking and new ideas," said Thomas O. Pyle, chief executive of Metropolitan Life's health care operations. "Those are not going to be called forth by a cap on costs, which will make everyone very cautious and risk-averse."
Amid the theoretical debate, executives and workers in the health insurance field have begun to think in practical terms about what the Clinton plan could mean for them.
In Marietta, Ohio, a city of about 20,000 that looks across the Ohio River to West Virginia, Mark B. Schewendeman is contemplating the future of the Schwendeman Sigafoos Agency, an insurance agency his grandfather founded in 1928. His company sells health plans to small employers, mainly on behalf of regional insurers that know the small towns and farm country of rural, southeastern Ohio well.
Under the Clinton plan, his customers would buy health insurance from an alliance, and the health insurers he deals with would be likely to leave the business.
Mr. Schewendeman has been reassuring his staff of 19 that the Clinton plan is bound to be transformed by Congress. But if the final legislation leaves little room for insurance agents, he says, he would turn his company into a consulting service, offering to help individuals and companies make their way through the new health care system. If that occurs, he acknowledges, his company's revenues would probably be reduced and some of his employees would have to be laid off.
Joel Shapiro, whose insurance agents in New York bring in more than $1 million a year in revenues from health and life sales, has told his workers that his business will survive, selling life insurance and perhaps offering health-insurance consulting services. There would still be a demand, too, for private supplemental policies for elderly people on Medicare, for example.
But, Mr. Shapiro said, he believes 45 percent of his revenue would disappear, and he would have to reduce his staff by four or five.
"I really dread this," Mr. Shapiro said. "The employers we work with and my friends in the business are very upset. I feel badly for my people."
 
Profitable Niches Are Being Sought
 Insurance companies, in turn, are exploring what new niches they may occupy as Federal legislation goes into effect. Some companies that offer fee-for-service policies foresee a lasting need for them, particularly in rural areas.
But the largest companies that have invested heavily in managed care networks say they hope to move swiftly to reduce the large and costly departments that process complex claims forms. The insurers say computers will permit doctors to transmit information on patients to them directly by computer without ever touching paper.
A top executive at one of the nation's largest health insurance companies, who asked not to be identified, said his company's goal was to reduce its work force in both claims and sales by half, and to replace highly trained sales people with less expensive young college graduates.

(Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Theory vs. Practice;
Clinton's Stated Foreign Policy Turns Into More Modest 'Self-Containment'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The contrast between the theory and practice of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy has never been more starkly apparent than in recent days.
In a series of four speeches this month, Secretary of State Warren Christopher; the national security adviser, Anthony Lake; the delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, and President Clinton himself laid out their "vision" of America's post-cold-war foreign policy. At its core was the idea that the old policies of containment of Communism should be replaced by a new policy of enlargement of the family of free-market democracies. 
 But from the actual behavior of the Administration, a very different picture emerges. In reality, this Administration wants to go from a policy of "enlargement" of American intervention abroad, as existed during the cold war when almost every regional conflict attracted the United States, to a new kind of "containment," in which the United States gets involved only in crises that are containable, manageable, cheap and closed-ended, except in the case of mortal threats to American security.
The real Clinton foreign policy is self-containment.
 
'Disjunction' Is Seen
 There is "a clear disjunction" between their policy and their vision, said Robert W. Tucker, professor emeritus of American foreign policy at Johns Hopkins University. "Their vision is the vision of preceding administrations: We have a certain position of predominance and leadership in the world. No administration wants to relinquish that, and so all of them assert their intention to remain engaged in spreading democracy."
But the Clinton team's emphasis is on domestic, not foreign policy. "Their dilemma is how to maintain the traditional position of leadership, yet keep their commitments as minimal as possible to concentrate at home," Mr. Tucker said.
Indeed, that very tension was laced throughout the President's speech before the United Nations, which seemed to be addressed to two audiences at once. To the small sector of foreign policy professors and foreign dignitaries, the speech offered reassurance that America would be true to its leadership heritage. Hence Mr. Clinton's declaration: "Many people ask whether the United States plans to retreat or remain active in the world. Let me answer that question as clearly and plainly as I can. The United States plans to remain engaged and to lead."
But to the American public and Congress the speech was less about activism and more about limits on future American peacekeeping abroad. The President put it bluntly. "If the American people are to say yes to U.N. peacekeeping," he said, "the United Nations must know when to say no."
 
Ambivalence Seen
 The tension in Mr. Clinton's speech only reflected the ambivalence in the public and Congressional moods, which can be summarized as a willingness to pay only some prices, fight only some foes, and to bear only some burdens in the defense of freedom, in a time when fears of nuclear war with Moscow have receded. It took only a handful of casualties in Somalia to prompt the House and Senate to pass a nonbinding resolution calling on Mr. Clinton to seek Congressional approval by Nov. 15 for keeping American troops in Somalia.
The President's natural response in trying to manage this tension is to tell the world that the United States will continue to play its leadership role, while assuring the Congress that he will not send troops to Somalia or any to Bosnia unless a long list of conditions are met, including a clearly stated time when the policy would be reviewed and a clearly stated "right to terminate" if things go badly. The problem is that such precision and predictability in foreign policy in general and peacekeeping missions in particular are impossible.
As former Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger put it: "If you have a clear exit point in a place like Bosnia, it is like telling all the parties in advance that when our people get killed, we will leave. And that is exactly what the opponents of our presence would like. Instead of reducing the danger to our forces, it invites attack."
An exit point in Bosnia is also impossible to define, Mr. Eagleburger said, because the peacekeeping role there means separating the warring factions, and the minute the United States leaves "they will be back at each other's throats."
 
'Worst Message to World'
 If the United States does not want to go into Bosnia, then it should say so and explain it, Mr. Eagleburger said. "But we should not set up a list of unrealistic conditions based on the experience in Somalia," he added. "That is a mistake, and it will send the worst message of all to the rest of the world."
The situation in Russia today is another example where the policy of enlargement does not fit the actual choices being faced by the Administration. President Boris N. Yeltsin may be at the beginning of a long process in which he will have to use undemocratic methods to transform Russia into a free-market democracy. The real choices for American policy toward Russia, and toward many of the former Soviet republics, are not between enlargement and containment, but between turning a blind eye to some of the methods being used to make the transition to some form of democracy -- and to keep the cash aid flowing while they do -- or to back away from them when those methods get ugly.
"At some point you have to stop, take a deep breath and say that in an imperfect world among imperfect choices, which one is the least atrocious and promises some sense over time that you will be able to accomplish some of your long-term wholesome objectives," Mr. Eagleburger said. "That is the choice now with Russia."
 
Not Performing Badly
 If the Clinton foreign policy is judged not in relation to its speeches, but on the basis of what it really is -- a minimalist foreign policy in an age when the American public and President are much more concerned about health care than warheads -- it actually has not performed badly at all. Many experts argue that its case-by-case priorities have been exactly right: supporting Russian reform and standing by Mr. Yeltsin; backing the North American Free Trade Agreement; recasting trade relations with Japan, and helping Israelis and Palestinians harvest the fruits of their own breakthrough, by organizing economic assistance.
Where the Clinton team has gotten into trouble is where it has tried to play the traditional American leadership role, in places like Bosnia and Somalia, without the real will or wallet to do what would be required for success.
"There is no such thing as humanitarian intervention," said Michael Mandelbaum, international relations professor at Johns Hopkins. "You can't intervene just to relieve suffering because suffering has political causes. Our real choices in Somalia or Bosnia are to stay out and let nature take its course or stay there and try to help create some reasonable order, with all the pain and costs that might entail."
In other words, there is no minimalist foreign policy for regions which have only maximalist options.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 11.18 Points to Close at 3,555.12

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The stock market turned in a mixed session yesterday, after suffering a little when a series of relatively good economic reports caused bonds to slide and bond-market performance affected stocks.
Technology stocks continued a retreat begun this week after a strong run-up, but beyond that there were few clear indications of what investors think about the economy or about the markets. 
 Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, said "the ghouls on the bond market" were apparently not pleased about the economic news. First, he noted, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago turned in a monthly report on economic activity that showed improvement to a point "considerably better than expected."
Then, first-time jobless claims dropped from last week, also better than many had expected and suggesting that "maybe the economy's O.K.," Mr. Canelo said.
Finally, personal income rebounded strongly in August, and personal consumption spending was also up. The bond market slid, and stocks responded with their own decline, he said, then finished mixed.
 
 
Transportation Index Falls
 The Dow Jones industrials closed at 3,555.12, off 11.18 points, while the Dow Jones transportations finished off a substantial 9.40 points at 1,628.13, still apparently suffering from Wednesday's announcement that OPEC ministers had agreed on a production ceiling at a meeting in Geneva -- news that is bad for fuel users. The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed down 1.18 points, to 458.93; volume on the Big Board was 294.4 million shares, up from 277.8 million on Wednesday.
The American Stock Exchange composite index closed up 2.74 points at 460.39 and the Nasdaq composite index was down 0.39 point to close at 762.78 on the technology slide.
Yesterday's market responses to economic news did not necessarily herald deep problems, Mr. Canelo said.
"My guess is that there's less to this day than meets the eye," he said, noting that there were few big moves outside of the technology sector. "I think we're heading toward some very positive news for the economy over the next two weeks."
 
 
Technology Stocks Lose
 Among technology stocks, the substantial losers included Intel, down 2 1/2 a share, to 70 3/4; Texas Instruments,which fell 1 1/8, to 75 1/2; Advanced Micro Devices, which slid 1 3/4, to 26 3/8, and Applied Materials, off 1 3/8, to 71 1/2. Also, Oracle Systems, lost 1 1/2 a share, to 61 3/8, and Cisco Systems, dropped 1 1/2, to 50.
Oil stocks were mixed after the OPEC announcement Wednesday caused them to skyrocket. Exxon closed yesterday at 65 1/2 a share, down 1 1/8, while Chevron was up 3/4, to 97 3/4, and Lousiana Land and Exploration jumped 1 5/8, to 44 5/8.
USAir Group said that it expected a third-quarter loss and that it planned to cut 2,500 full-time jobs. The stock closed unchanged at 12 5/8.
Stock in UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 3 3/4 a share, to 137 1/4, after flight attendants pulled out of a union attempt to buy the carrier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Hard Lessons on Competitive Bids

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
If the recent scandals in the municipal market force more states and local governments to rely increasingly on competitive bidding in the sales of their tax-exempt bonds, it appears that Merrill Lynch & Company may already have an edge on its Wall Street competitors.
This advantage is evident in the rankings of underwriters for the first three quarters of the year. Merrill's lead in its competitive bidding victories was enough to beat Goldman, Sachs & Company to the top slot, although Goldman was No. 1 in negotiated bids. 
 But the fate of the $800 million California bond issue this week, in which Merrill edged out Goldman in a competitive bid, also suggests that being No. 1 has its costs.
 
Won at a Price
 The California deal, which would have put Goldman on top if it had outbid Merrill, was won at a yield that some portfolio managers said was surprisingly low. Since then, the price of the issue has dropped and the yield has jumped because prices in the Treasury market also fell. In addition, the California offering also fell because of the unexpected announcement yesterday that the state would sell another $248.9 million of bonds on Oct. 14 and, some traders said, because the original Merrill bid was too aggressive with a yield that was too low.
And as a result, Merrill was adjusting the prices down and yields up yesterday on almost $200 million of bonds that were still unsold, leaving about $185 million in the account.
Through the first three quarters of the year, Merrill had $25.795 billion in competitive and negotiated deals when credit for each issue is given to the lead or book manager, according to the Securities Data Company. Goldman's total was $24.956 billion. If Goldman had won California, it would have had $25.756 billion in deals to Merrill's $24.995 billion.
Following these two in the top five are Lehman Brothers, $16.044; CS First Boston, $15.562, and Smith Barney Shearson, $14.785.
The pressure for local governments to shift to competitive bidding, in which the underwriter with the lowest interest rate wins the issue, has been generated by revelations of possible kickbacks, fee splitting and influence peddling on big negotiated deals, in which underwriters are chosen by the local government for a specific municipal bond issue.
In New Jersey, questions about a New Jersey Turnpike bond issue lead to the resignation of a top aide to Gov. Jim Florio and an order by the governor to make state bond issues competitively bid. Merrill Lynch is being investigated for its role in the deal.
The percentage of competitive bids have averaged only 20 percent of the total in 1991, 1992 and the first three quarters of this year. And the percentage has been declining, from 23.9 percent in 1991 to 18.6 percent for the first nine months of this year. In the third quarter, the percentage of competitive bids was down to 18.3 percent.
But the costs of being first in the rankings is something Merrill might be thinking about after the California bid. While a rally in the market could turn the numbers upside down and make Merrill's original aggressive bid look good, as of yesterday it had not.
The 30-year bonds that were priced to yield 5.24 percent at the sale on Tuesday were trading at around 5.35 percent yesterday in the secondary market, according to several traders. Bonds with maturities of 16 years and less that had not yet been sold were being offered at yields 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over their original yields. This means a sharp drop in prices, which move in the opposite direction.
"They came too high," said a member of the syndicate that Merrill Lynch led. In market jargon, "high" means the bid, made in interest rates, was too low.
This member of the syndicate suggested that winning has become too important for some of the big firms. "They are so intent on winning that they bid it too aggressively," he said, speaking on the condition that he not be named. "It looks like the account," he added, referring to all the firms in the syndicate, "is going to lose a lot of money unless the market turns around."
 
Treasury Market
 The Treasury market went through another volatile day of trading yesterday, as it got a dose of economic data that was a little more optimistic than some investors liked.
Since one of the foundations of the recent rally has been sluggish economic growth that can neutralize any inflation worries, signs of even a modest pickup can be disturbing when interest rates are already so low.
The price of the 30-year bond, which was down as much as 26/32 , ended in late trading at 5 P.M. down 12/32 as the yield rose to 6.02 percent, from 5.99 percent on Wednesday. Prices of Treasury notes also fell.
Among the four key pieces of economic data on the day, three were stronger than expected, while one, new-home sales, dropped a surprising 3.1 percent in August. The stronger reports included a drop in initial jobless claims last week, a rise in personal income in August and a jump in the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago index of manufacturing.

HEADLINE: Martin Marietta to Eliminate 11,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The Martin Marietta Corporation, which last year bought the General Electric Company's aerospace electronics division, said yesterday that it would close 12 production sites and eliminate 11,000 jobs nationwide this year to consolidate the two businesses.
The move, which had been expected for months, is the latest sign that the pain and layoffs of a shrinking weapons industry are far from finished. The announcement came the same day large layoffs were announced in the airline and hazardous-waste disposal industries. [Page D3.] 
 Military contractors, faced with deep cuts in the Pentagon's budget, have been selling off operations that show little promise and acquiring businesses in areas they can dominate. As a result, tens of thousands of workers have lost their jobs and dozens of plants have been shut down.
Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., said that the job cuts and plant consolidations announced yesterday would reduce its operating costs by $1.5 billion over the next five years and make the company more competitive.
Citing Federal budget cuts, the military contractor disclosed for the first time that it had already eliminated 9,000 jobs this year and that an additional 2,000 positions would be cut to consolidate operations. Martin Marietta plans to eliminate about five million square feet of excess capacity in seven states.
"These actions recognize the realities of a tough market place that demands low cost and high quality," Norman R. Augustine, Martin Marietta's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "As but one example, as a percent of sales, our corporate overhead will be the lowest in recent history and is typical of the factors that will position us to remain a leader in the market areas in which we compete."
When Martin Marietta acquired General Electric's aerospace electronics business for $3 billion last November, it became the world's largest military electronics company with 94,000 employees, $11 billion in sales and a backlog of more than $28 billion.
Industry analysts have said that they expect dominance and synergy to come from the combined company, which has a broad customer base and a diversified product line that make it less vulnerable to pending budget cuts. Martin Marietta's main competitors are Hughes, TRW and Lockheed.
To achieve the economies of scale it wants, Martin Marietta had to eliminate duplicative administrative, production and research costs, the analysts said.
 
Army and Navy Clients
 General Electric's major customer is the Navy, while Martin Marietta is a main supplier to the Army. Martin makes space equipment and electronics, information and missile systems, including the Titan radar and military and commercial space launch vehicles and products. From G.E., Martin gained satellites and other space systems, radar and sonar systems and simulation systems.
"Massive layoffs and plant closings unfortunately have become a way of life in the defense industry as contractors reduce labor costs at a rate consistent or higher than the declines in Pentagon budget," said Jack Modzelewski, a weapons industry analyst for Paine Webber.
Weapons industry employment, since its high of 3.66 million workers in 1987, has fallen to 2.73 million workers in 1993, according to the Defense Budget Project, a Washington-based research group. Industry analysts and experts predict that Pentagon budget cuts announced by the Clinton Administration will cost the industry an additional 700,000 jobs by 1993.
Martin Marietta officials said that the job reductions and plant closings would have no impact on the company's third-quarter results because a $500 million reserve was included in the purchase of General Electric's aerospace division to cover the costs of consolidation.

HEADLINE: Whitman Says Florio Policies Led to Crime

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman's campaign for governor took on a sharper edge today as she attacked Gov. Jim Florio for failing to stem the tide of violent crime in New Jersey.
At a news conference called to announce her own proposals for reforming New Jersey's criminal-justice system, Mrs. Whitman said that not only had Mr. Florio failed to halt violent crime, he had actually contributed to it. Trying to link crime to the issue of economic growth, Mrs. Whitman said Mr. Florio's economic policies had cost New Jersey residents thousands of jobs. The loss of jobs, she said, has, in turn, fostered the spread of crime. 
 "There is a relationship," she said. "His tax polices have helped make violent crime a growth industry in New Jersey."
Mrs. Whitman's news conference came a day after she realigned her campaign staff, removing her brother, Webster B. (Danny) Todd from his position as campaign manager and placing a Republican consultant, Ed Rollins, at the helm. Mr. Rollins, who orchestrated President Ronald Reagan's 1984 re-election campaign, is expected to steer the Whitman campaign toward a more vigorous attack on Mr. Florio's policies and political record.
 
Change Planned, She Says
 Mrs. Whitman said the change had been planned all along and was intended to allow Mr. Todd to return to the field and work with other Republicans who will campaign for Mrs. Whitman in the coming weeks.
"He never wanted a title," she said. "He took it because I asked him to. It's not a panic attack. Don't worry."
In announcing the report of a panel she appointed to study public safety, Mrs. Whitman sought to counter Governor Florio's contention that she is soft on crime.
She called for mandatory life sentences for criminals convicted of a violent crime for the third time, boot camps for nonviolent juvenile offenders and more community policing programs. She said that 17-year-old juveniles who commit homicide, carjacking, rape or armed robbery should be treated as adults, and that all violent juvenile offenders should receive at least some time in prison.
"First-time juvenile offenders cannot walk with just a slap on the wrist," she said.
 
Plan May Increase Costs
 Mrs. Whitman, who has promised to cut income taxes by eliminating more than a billion dollars in waste and mismanagement, said that some of her proposals may actually increase the state's criminal justice spending.
"That's the kind of investment we can't afford not to make," she said.
Mrs. Whitman said her proposals do not contradict her earlier opposition to mandatory sentences. Mrs. Whitman has said she opposes mandatory sentencing in general because it forces judges to act without considering the specifics of a case, leading to overcrowded prisons that force officials to release violent offenders who have not served their full time.
She sharply attacked Mr. Florio's record on several points, saying that he had failed to fulfill campaign promises to create boot camp programs for juvenile offenders and to create educational programs that would reduce crime among youths.
 
Crime Statistics Dispute
 "The impact of the policies he has supported have not done anything to make this a safer society, and in fact have exacerbated the problem," she said.
But according to the state's annual Uniform Crime Report, overall crime in New Jersey dropped 6 percent in 1992 to the lowest level since 1985 -- statistics that the Florio campaign rushed to point out.
"Mrs. Whitman has a habit of ignoring statistics if they don't fit the theme of her campaign," said Mr. Florio's chief spokesman, Jon Shure. "To blame the Governor for that is really outrageous."
Mr. Shure also criticized Mrs. Whitman for not mentioning semiautomatic weapons in her crime proposals. The state's ban on semiautomatic weapons is one of the most popular accomplishments of Mr. Florio's administration.
 
Question on Gun Stance
 Mrs. Whitman has said that she supports the state's gun ban in general. But earlier this year she told owners of a Jersey City gunshop called Gun-A-Rama that she would consider legislation to legalize certain weapons that are banned.
And in an unusual turn today, Mr. Florio selected Mrs. Whitman's principal rival in the Republican primary, Cary Edwards, as chairman of a commission to study the impact of gambling in New Jersey.
Both the Governor and Mr. Edwards, a former State Attorney General, played down any political significance to the appointment. "This has nothing to do with the election and shouldn't," Mr. Edwards said.
The appointment, nevertheless, raised an awkward political situation for Mrs. Whitman. Whether it was a calculated move by Mr. Florio or not, bringing Mr. Edwards back at this time will surely revive memories of the bitter Republican primary and the strident attacks Mr. Edwards made against Mrs. Whitman.
Mr. Edwards was Mrs. Whitman's harshest critic during the primary, calling her politically inexperienced, unqualified to be governor and unable to beat Mr. Florio. But after the June 8 primary, he stood beside her at a unity brunch and pledged to campaign for Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman said that would still happen.
"I think you will see Cary Edwards standing right beside this campaign in the very near future," she said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Higher As Russia Standoff Goes On

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged against all leading currencies yesterday amid nervousness over the political standoff between President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and besieged deputies in Parliament.
Gold rose as well. Bullion for December delivery, the most active December contract on the Commodity Exchange in New York, rose $2.40 an ounce, to $357.10. The Republic National Bank posted spot gold at $355.55 an ounce, up $2.30 from Wednesday. 
 "With the possibility of anything happening in Russia, it's not too wise to short dollars," said Tom Hoge, a corporate trader for Credit Suisse. "Some people think the Parliament deadline might degenerate into civil war." On Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin set a Monday deadline for the evacuation of Parliament.
The dollar also firmed against the yen on Japanese political jitters, amid news of a high-level Government bribery scandal.
The American currency was also bolstered by generally supportive economic data, including a rise in the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for September and an increase in personal income for August. Dealers said a 3.1 percent drop in August home sales was mitigated by an upward revision for the July data, which showed a decline of 1.7 percent from a previous 5 percent drop. The dollar was quoted at 106.30 yen in late New York trading, up from 105.10 yen Wednesday. In Tokyo, it slipped to 105.10 yen, from 105.23 yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar climbed to 1.6330 marks, from 1.6135 marks late Wednesday. Earlier in London, the dollar closed at 1.6305 marks, up from 1.6113 Wednesday.
The British pound fell to $1.4965 in New York, from $1.5115 Wednesday, in nervous trading ahead of the Conservative Party's annual conference next week. Earlier, in London, it eased to $1.4970 from $1.5110 on Wednesday.
The Bank of Canada intervened for the second straight day and exchanged Canadian dollars for United States dollars. By late trading, the Canadian dollar was quoted at 1.3333 for each American dollar, compared with 1.3294 late Wednesday. It was the Canadian dollar's lowest level against the United States dollar in six years.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.4255 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125; 5.6970 French francs, up from 5.6350, and 1,590 Italian lire, up from 1,585.
