HEADLINE: A New Ferry Out of L.I. May Yet Find A Developer

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 30

 BODY:
An advisory committee of officials from New York and Connecticut has tentatively backed a developer to operate a high-speed ferry between Shoreham, L.I., and New Haven.
But some committee members and one of the principals of the company, the Long Island Sound Shuttle Limited Partnership of East Haven, are afraid that a list of requirements outlined by the committee could kill the project or lead to significant delays. 
 To gain the panel's full recommendation -- which would be presented for approval to the Governors of both states and their transportation departments -- the developer will have to demonstrate that it has complete financing for the $60 million project, and leases with the Long Island Lighting Company, owner of the Shoreham property, and with the owners of the Wyatt Oil Terminal in New Haven, the intended dock sites.
The committee decided that another potential developer, Sound Express Ferry Services of New York City, a subsidiary of the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamship Company, which operates an existing ferry service, failed to meet the objectives outlined by the committee.
 
Wanted a Definitive Decision
 "I'm disappointed with the committee; I thought we should have moved ahead with a full endorsement now," said Leonard A. Liss, a member and New Haven's director of traffic and parking. "I think that some of the things being required are impossible without the committee's endorsement, especially securing private financing for the project and getting a lease with Lilco. I don't think the committee did its job."
John Acampora, an East Haven lawyer and one of three principal partners for the Long Island Sound Shuttle Limited Partnership, said he believes the partnership can meet the committee's requirements, but that it would be tougher and could delay the service, which could begin two years after all the approvals are issued.
"We haven't seen anything official yet, but it appears they have selected us with a lot of requirements we thought we already had addressed," he said. "I don't understand exactly what's going on here."
Mitchell Pally, a committee member and vice president for legislative and economic affairs of the Long Island Association, said the partnership had not yet met all the committee's requirements.
"I don't know if the provisions will or will not be possible to meet," he said, "but they are all things we believe are important. But we want to make it clear that we are very much behind the project working, because it is important to the economies of both Long Island and Connecticut."

HEADLINE: Personal Income Rises 1.3%, But New-Home Sales Falter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Americans' personal income rose strongly in August and a measure of joblessness edged down last week, two indications that the economy, while not in great shape, is at least doing better than during the first half of the year.
However, in a jarring note among reports issued by the Government today, sales of new homes declined unexpectedly in August. 
 Incomes jumped 1.3 percent in August, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.43 trillion, following rare back-to-back declines during the two previous months, the Commerce Department said. It was the largest rise in four months.
Meanwhile, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 11,000 last week, to 329,000. Analysts said that level was consistent with modest job growth.
Both reports were taken as positive signs that the economic growth rate during the second half of the year was improving from the moribund 1.4 percent annual rate during the first half.
"I think we're on the verge of a breakout from the siesta we went into in the first half," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "The economy's got some get-up, not a lot of go, but some."
But another Commerce Department report showed a 3.1 percent drop in sales of new homes in August, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 616,000. That was the second straight fall and the fifth this year.
Analysts had expected low mortgage rates would produce a sales increase, but sales fell everywhere except the Northeast, pushing the inventory of unsold homes up to 288,000 at the end of August, the highest since October 1991.
David Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said the housing report was "troubling if true." But he noted that the Government frequently revisedits initial estimate of new-home sales.
The average rate of 30-year fixed-rate mortgages was close to 7 percent in August and almost a full percentage point lower than a year earlier. Rates have since slipped further.
According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, they averaged 6.89 percent this week, close to a 25-year low and down from 6.95 percent last week.
Although home sales were worse than expected, the gain in income, and a rise in personal spending in August, were slightly stronger than anticipated by economists.
After adjustment to screen the effects of summer drought in the South and flooding in the Midwest, including crop and property damage, incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent in August and five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Government said.
In August, Americans' personal consumption spending rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $4.42 trillion annual rate. That marked the fifth consecutive increase and was the same as July's.
The August combination of a big rise in income and a modest increase in consumer spending produced an advance in Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of after-tax income -- to 4.1 percent, up from 3.1 percent in July.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Touches 6-Year Low As Oil and Rice Make Gains

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Copper futures hit new six-year contract lows yesterday but cut their losses in heavy late trading as speculators hunted for bargains.
On other commodity markets, oil futures extended their gains on an apparent OPEC production accord; rice futures rose on purchases by Japan; grains and soybeans were mostly higher, and pork bellies rose. 
 Copper for December delivery at the Commodity Exchange in New York closed 1.25 cents a pound lower, at 74.90 cents a pound, after setting a new contract low at 74.30 cents in early trading.
"It's a continuation of all the recent selling," said George Milling-Stanley, a Lehman Brothers metals analyst. "The market is back in the harsh realities of supply and demand."
A downward spiral in prices began three weeks ago when the the London Metal Exchange imposed curbs on dealings to end what traders widely believed to be a squeeze on prices by Asian traders trying to corner the market.
The price of copper, a base metal used widely in the electrical, communications and construction industries, has dropped by 14 percent since then. The global recession and the failure of producers to cut output have increased copper supplies, analysts said.
 
Oil in Modest Gains
 Oil prices closed with modest gains as the market digested Wednesday's OPEC accord, tensions in Russia and a coming United Nations check of Iraq's weapons destruction. November crude closed up 12 cents, to $18.79 barrel.
Rice futures on Chicago's MidAmerica Commodity Exchange ralled for a second day on hopes for sales of American rice to overseas customers. Japan announced overnight that it would buy 200,000 metric tons of foreign rice immediately to shore up supply.
November delivery rough rice closed up 33 cents at $7.08 per hundred pounds. Daily limits were expanded to 45 cents from 30 cents after Wednesday's limit-up close.
"There again was talk that Japan may buy rice from us and that was the main factor here," a rice pit broker said.
Coffee futures fell for a fourth straight session as the market continued to hedge uncertainties about the success of a producer plan to retain 20 percent of output starting today. December coffee closed down 1.15 cents a pound to 74.50 cents.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
California Bonds' High Yield Is 5.3%

 BODY:
A $213.2 million bond offering by California State Public Works was initially priced yesterday to yield a maximum 5.30 percent for a bond due in 2009 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The remaining serial refunding revenue bonds were priced to yield from 2.85 percent in 1994 to 4.05 percent in 1998, 4.80 percent in 2003 and 5.25 percent in 2008. 
 For investors in a 31 percent tax bracket, taxable bond equivalent yields would compute to about 4.13 percent in 1994 out to 7.68 percent for a bond due in 2009.
Proceeds from the bond sale, rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, will be used to refund previously issued debt when interest rates were higher.

HEADLINE: 2 Parties, 1 Goal

SERIES: HEALTH CARE SECOND OPINIONS -- An occasional series

BYLINE: By David L. Boren and John C. Danforth; David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, are members of the Senate Finance Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With each passing year, fewer members of Congress are willing to work with their colleagues in the opposing party. Those who do are met with increasing criticism and suspicion in their own party caucuses. The culmination of this 20-year trend was passage of the budget without a single vote in Congress from the opposition party. Party and partisanship have become more important than policy and partnership.
If this pattern is allowed to continue, no one has more to lose than President Clinton. He was elected as a centrist, a "new kind of Democrat." But he cannot succeed as a centrist if the Administration continues to follow a "Democrats only" strategy. Swings to the left, necessary for votes in the House, will only shrink the President's political base and damage his credibility. 
 Health care may be Mr. Clinton's greatest opportunity for bipartisanship. There is much on which Republicans and Democrats agree. We agree that Americans deserve health care security. We agree that health costs cannot grow at three times the rate of inflation. We agree that all Americans should have insurance coverage -- including those who become ill and those who change jobs. We also agree on some of the solutions: insurance market reform, managed competition and purchasing cooperatives.
So far the Administration has made great efforts to consult with members on both sides of the aisle -- notably the First Lady's three days of testimony before committees of Congress, including our own yesterday. But bipartisanship means more than consultation in the drafting of a plan. It means compromise in the passing of a bill. It means giving up policies desperately desired by members on one side of the aisle in order to gain support for a program on the other side of the aisle.
In the end, the Administration may have to give up votes from those Democrats who favor a single-payer system or massive regulation in order to gain a solid block of Republican votes. Republicans, for their part, may have to give up the votes of those who do not want Government to be a part of the solution at all. Bipartisanship means mare than just talk; real results require real sacrifice.
 We want to help build consensus -- to initiate a process of compromise between the two parties and the various plans, a compromise that contains costs and provides universal access. In the end, if we do not pass a credible, comprehensive health care reform package, both parties will lose. The proposals are on the table; now it is time to draw together the best from each of them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed; Series

HEADLINE: Expansion of Jury Rolls Needed in New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Justice for Jurors" (editorial, Sept. 22) applauds efforts by Judith Kaye, New York State's Chief Judge, to increase juror access and comfort. 
 But unless jury rolls can be expanded to include those whose names appear on unemployment and welfare lists, we will rapidly find the civil trial juror an endangered species.
Legislation to do this passed both houses of the State Legislature this year. It was vetoed for technical reasons, but we believe those problems are being solved. Community and consumer groups have joined with us to see this legislation signed into law this session.
 
STEPHAN H. PESKIN
President, New York State
Trial Lawyers Association
New York, Sept. 22, 1993

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Insurers Fear They'd Be the Big Losers in a World of Managed Health Care

SERIES: The Clinton Prescription: The Impact on Insurers -- Last of six articles

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Since the President gave his health care speech last week, employees have lived with fluttery stomachs in the offices of the Bartmon Shapiro insurance agency, a thriving business high above Central Park South whose windows offer panoramic views of the park and the midtown Manhattan skyline. Under President Clinton's health care plan, the profession of health insurance agent could virtually cease to exist.
"People are very, very nervous," said Joel Shapiro, whose 17-year-old company employs 10 people. "But we are going to have to adapt. We are going to have to change." 
 Such agencies are not the only ones in the $300 billion health insurance industry that face the future with trepidation. With or without the proposed Clinton changes, hundreds of health insurers are expected to leave the business in the coming years, but the President's plan would greatly accelerate the pace.
Even the survivors, which are expected to include several of the country's largest insurers, like Prudential and Aetna, may have to fire or retrain armies of claims processors, cutting payrolls as they try to become efficient, lower-cost companies that oversee networks of doctors, nurses and hospitals.
What remains unclear is whether the survivors in the nation's health insurance industry -- an industry much distrusted by the public and often attacked in recent months by Hillary Rodham Clinton -- would eventually flourish or wither under the White House plan. It is also uncertain whether the survivors would in the end serve consumers better, as the White House insists they would.
The Administration's proposal would increase the revenue of the insurance industry by tens of billions of dollars. It would have all employers contribute and the Government subsidize the private insurance premiums of the 37 million who are now uninsured. It would also shift most poor people on Medicaid into the private insurance market. But whether those revenues would translate into profits after all the claims are paid is a matter of debate.
Under the Clinton plan, many functions of today's insurers, like setting benefit packages and negotiating with employers, would be taken over by new, state-run health alliances. The plan would force companies to compete more aggressively on the basis of price and would place limits on the premiums health insurers can charge. Those limits, insurance industry executives and a number of economists say, could squeeze profits so much that it would destroy incentives for investment and innovation.
 
Some Insurers Expected to Do Well
 "Those insurance companies that can realize real efficiencies and economies of scale may be able to do very well under the Clinton plan," said Beth Morrow, an analyst for Standard & Poor's. "But will they become more responsive to what consumers want? I don't know. What I do think is they will try to save money by squeezing health care providers to reduce costs."
The Administration says the proposed new health care system would give consumers more power in several ways.
For one, the proposed regional health alliances would serve as broker, in effect, for hundreds of thousands of consumers. Once a year, consumers would receive a menu of health plans from which to select. They would also receive a report card on each of the plans that would rate them on, among other things, consumer satisfaction and medical performance.
In addition, the Administration's proposal would permit customers more easily to compare health plans on the basis of cost. That would force insurers, health maintenance organizations and other operators of health care networks to compete for market share on the basis of both quality and price. If an insurer's services are inadequate or too expensive, the Administration says, customers once every year can vote with their feet and change plans.
In the process, the alliances would make many health insurance brokers and agents obsolete and would permit many private companies to shut down their medical benefit departments. The savings, the Administration says, would be in the billions.
Consumers would be allowed to choose traditional fee-for-service health plans, in which patients can choose their doctors and the doctors are paid for each service they provide. But financial incentives may push many consumers toward less-expensive H.M.O.'s or other types of managed care plans. Since most insurance companies today, especially the smaller ones, offer mainly fee-for-service insurance, industry analysts say most of the nation's more than 500 health insurers would be driven from the field.
The President's plan would simply be speeding up a process that is already under way: the switch of customers into H.M.O's and other forms of managed care. Last year, 41 million Americans had already enrolled in H.M.O.'s, up from 19 million in 1985. Forty-two percent of all H.M.O.'s are now owned by insurance companies or Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, while some others are run by independent companies or nonprofit organizations.
Expected to benefit most under the President's plan are those insurance companies that have already invested large sums in building up H.M.O.'s and other managed-care networks around the country. The most prominent are the Cigna Corporation, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the Travelers Corporation, Aetna Life & Casualty and more than 60 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
But doubters inside and outside the insurance industry say the Clinton plan, as proposed, will not necessarily result in a more efficient and consumer-friendly health insurance industry.
Dr. David U. Himmelstein, an associate professor at the Harvard Medical School and an advocate of Canadian-style government-run health care system, said he was concerned that an increasing amount of health care money would fall into the hands of an ever smaller and more powerful group of insurers.
In many regional markets, he said, a small number of large companies would dominate the market, making the entry of smaller new health groups difficult.
"What I think you would end up with is a couple of large firms controlling the health care delivered to the American people," Dr. Himmelstein said "Oligopolies don't compete in this country. They don't lower prices."
Executives of the nation's largest insurance companies as well as a number of economists dispute Dr. Himmelstein's predictions. They say the greatest danger is not that the insurers will be too powerful but that the health alliances will.
 
Local Competition Expected to Thrive
 Many insurance executives say that within each region and alliance large numbers of local H.M.O.'s and other health networks would survive as competitors. Even the largest national insurers may not have the capital or market clout to wipe out such competition.
"It will mean separate competition in many, many local markets, instead of one large market," said Paul Cooper, vice president for health care policy for Prudential. "The winners in Houston will be different from the winners in Denver. It is going to become a very decentralized industry."
But insurance companies note that the alliances, under Federal supervision, would set caps on the premiums that insurers could charge. Those caps might squeeze profits so much, industry officials assert, that it might be difficult for private insurers to raise capital to invest in new and innovative ways of delivering care. The White House expects that competition among health plans will itself hold down costs, but in case that tactic fails, it proposes limiting average premium increases to about the overall inflation rate.
"If we are going to have real reduction in medical inflation, it is going to take a lot of ingenuity and risk-taking and new ideas," said Thomas O. Pyle, chief executive of Metropolitan Life's health care operations. "Those are not going to be called forth by a cap on costs, which will make everyone very cautious and risk-averse."
Amid the theoretical debate, executives and workers in the health insurance field have begun to think in practical terms about what the Clinton plan could mean for them.
In Marietta, Ohio, a city of about 20,000 that looks across the Ohio River to West Virginia, Mark B. Schewendeman is contemplating the future of the Schwendeman Sigafoos Agency, an insurance agency his grandfather founded in 1928. His company sells health plans to small employers, mainly on behalf of regional insurers that know the small towns and farm country of rural, southeastern Ohio well.
Under the Clinton plan, his customers would buy health insurance from an alliance, and the health insurers he deals with would be likely to leave the business.
Mr. Schewendeman has been reassuring his staff of 19 that the Clinton plan is bound to be transformed by Congress. But if the final legislation leaves little room for insurance agents, he says, he would turn his company into a consulting service, offering to help individuals and companies make their way through the new health care system. If that occurs, he acknowledges, his company's revenues would probably be reduced and some of his employees would have to be laid off.
Joel Shapiro, whose insurance agents in New York bring in more than $1 million a year in revenues from health and life sales, has told his workers that his business will survive, selling life insurance and perhaps offering health-insurance consulting services. There would still be a demand, too, for private supplemental policies for elderly people on Medicare, for example.
But, Mr. Shapiro said, he believes 45 percent of his revenue would disappear, and he would have to reduce his staff by four or five.
"I really dread this," Mr. Shapiro said. "The employers we work with and my friends in the business are very upset. I feel badly for my people."
 
Profitable Niches Are Being Sought
 Insurance companies, in turn, are exploring what new niches they may occupy as Federal legislation goes into effect. Some companies that offer fee-for-service policies foresee a lasting need for them, particularly in rural areas.
But the largest companies that have invested heavily in managed care networks say they hope to move swiftly to reduce the large and costly departments that process complex claims forms. The insurers say computers will permit doctors to transmit information on patients to them directly by computer without ever touching paper.
A top executive at one of the nation's largest health insurance companies, who asked not to be identified, said his company's goal was to reduce its work force in both claims and sales by half, and to replace highly trained sales people with less expensive young college graduates.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Hillary Clinton Raises Tough Question of Life, Death and Medicine

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she hoped the nation would engage in a serious discussion about what is appropriate medical care in cases where very expensive treatments do nothing for the patient's quality of life.
 The First Lady, completing her testimony before the Senate Finance Committee -- her fifth Congressional hearing in three days on the President's health care proposals -- was prodded by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri. He asked her whether the system would have "somebody at some level in a position to say no." 
Senator Danforth cited a baby who was kept alive for 11 months without a brain; a separation of Siamese twins of whom one was certain to die and the other had only a 1 percent chance of living; babies with low birth weights of whom only 15 percent will be functional, and expensive efforts to prolong life for three or six months at very high cost.
 Mrs. Clinton neither responded directly to the examples nor promised anything administratively in the health plan. But she predicted that there would be a more promising climate for serious discussions about such issues. If the plan creates "the kind of health security we are talking about," she said, "then people will know they are not being denied treatment for any reason other than it is not appropriate -- will not enhance or save the quality of life."
 
Makes Politicians Nervous
 The issue frightens most politicians, who fear that they will be seen as enemies of the elderly, who vote in high proportions. Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado drew widespread antagonism when he said in 1984 that the elderly, if ill, "have got a duty to die and get out of the way."
 Mr. Danforth has raised this issue from time to time since 1987. He has never addressed it as emphatically as Mr. Lamm, but he was re-elected after raising it. He has said he will not seek re-election next year.
 Mrs. Clinton has argued that the budgetary constraints the Administration plan will put on insurance companies and hospitals may reduce unnecessarily costly treatment. She has repeatedly cited the example of a 92-year-old man given a quadruple heart bypass because the surgeon had depended on a cardiologist who had referred that patient to him, and she suggests that if the system is changed such surgery will not be performed.
 She told that same story and offered the same hope today. Reflecting on her own days waiting at the hospital as her father was dying last spring, she said: "I would agree that for both moral and ethical reasons as well as economic ones, there has to be the kind of very difficult conversation that you are suggesting." Personal Reflections
 She said she had had a lot of time to think about the issue "on a personal level when I was in the hospital with my father and spending literally all day every day talking to doctors and nurses about the very kinds of cases that you are outlining."
 There were other tough questions for Mrs. Clinton today, more than she had before the earlier committees. The senators usually focused directly on financing and bore in with considerable detail. She frequently promised to consider Senatorial arguments for changes and delays.
 Senator John Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, contended that imposing limits on insurance premiums after just two years would not give competition a chance to start. She told him, "Whether we can get to where we need in two years or over a longer period of time, we are very open to talking with you about that."
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the committee, asked how she expected to hold health costs to the rate of inflation when such costs had grown more than twice that fast between 1960 and 1992. Goal of Zero Growth
 She replied, "We should be thinking zero growth as a budget target that this country should be moving toward." She insisted that vast savings could be made, citing the economies that some cities, states and health care systems had managed in recent years. And she referred to Mr. Moynihan's own writings on the "cost disease" to argue that health care has been made less productive because the payment system rewarded waste and inefficiency.
 When Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, asked whether some of the financing for health care could not come from steep taxes on guns and gun dealers, she answered that she liked the idea and that she agreed that shootings were a serious factor in health costs.
 Mr. Bradley replied, "Well, let me say that there is no more important personal endorsement in the country today, and I thank you very much."
 When the hearing ended, the senators applauded the witness.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
 An article on Oct. 1, reporting on Senate testimony by Hillary Rodham Clinton about health care, included a passage about former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado. It said Mr. Lamm "drew widespread antagonism when he said in 1984 that the elderly, if ill, 'have got a duty to die and get out of the way.' "
Similar characterizations of Mr. Lamm's speech of March 27, 1984, were published soon after it was given, and have appeared periodically. But that version of Mr. Lamm's remarks is a distortion, as Governor Lamm complained in 1984. He said then that insufficient attention to detail by the news media had led to a misinterpretation.
 An editorial in The Times on March 31, 1984, and articles on April 1, April 4, June 30 and Sept. 5 of that year reported on criticism generated by his speech or included accounts of his statements, but noted that his remarks had been misconstrued. Nevertheless incorrect accounts appeared in The Times on March 29, 1984; April 1, 1984; April 18, 1984; May 11, 1984; Jan. 5, 1985; Jan. 18, 1985; Aug. 18, 1985, and Aug. 20, 1985.
In a letter dated Oct. 8, 1993, Mr. Lamm provided excerpts from the 1984 speech, in which he spoke philosophically about the terminally ill of any age, about the extraordinary costs of high-technology medicine and about the ability of medical science to stave off death far beyond considerations of quality of life. After saying that society should be talking about the ethical implications, Mr. Lamm said, according to the excerpts:
"We've got a duty to die and get out of the way with all of our machines and artificial hearts and everything else like that and let the other society, our kids, build a reasonable life."
In his letter last month, Mr. Lamm wrote that he never said "the elderly or the terminally ill have a duty to die," and he added, "I was essentially raising a general statement about the human condition, not beating up on the elderly."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1907 words

HEADLINE: New York Rivals Differ Strikingly On Dealing With City's Poorest

SERIES: Mayoral Agenda
A periodic report on major issues
facing the election winner.

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
In the four years since they last ran for mayor, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani have refined their positions on what should be done for the city's impoverished multitudes and now present voters with distinctly different approaches to homelessness and welfare reform.
But even as they have become more sophisticated about the issues, the already staggering scale of the city's social ills has worsened, fueled by a deep, prolonged recession, rising numbers of people with AIDS, a virulent drug crisis, a persistent low-income housing shortage and the spread of tuberculosis. 
 The number of people on welfare has risen to almost 1.1 million, its highest level since the Depression. There are 273,000 more New Yorkers on welfare now than when Mr. Dinkins took office, a figure that equals the total population of Newark. The number of families in the city's shelter system has risen 54 percent, to 5,700, and dozens of families sleep each night on floors, chairs and tables in city offices.
 
Choices Affecting Life
 So as New York City moves into an era of deepening fiscal constraints, the mayor in 1994 will have to make hard choices that will affect the texture of life for those people, as well as for taxpayers who foot the bills and walk streets jostling with beggars, paupers and hustlers.
Both Mayor Dinkins and his challenger, Mr. Giuliani, say the city should encourage the jobless to work and take the homeless in from the streets. But the candidates' views about how to reach those goals differ in crucial respects. At bottom, their debate is an age-old one about how society should balance its duty to the poor with their responsibility to help themselves.
Mr. Dinkins, a liberal Democrat and the son of a maid and a barber, says he believes the poor will help themselves if given the chance. The city, he says, should rely primarily on incentives -- the promise of a subsidized apartment or higher income -- to give them a reason to seek education, training, drug treatment or a job itself.
Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate and a former prosecutor, argues that the poor need more of a push to get back on their feet. He would combine the carrots Mr. Dinkins uses with a few new sticks.
Managing the city's enormous welfare system involves excruciatingly difficult choices on how best to move single mothers from dependence on government into the work force.
During Mr. Dinkins's term, Barbara J. Sabol, who heads the city's Human Resources Administration, has emphasized giving welfare recipients choices. When they are called in to take part in the city's welfare-to-work program, they can either look for work immediately or choose education or training.
Under the Federal Family Support Act, adopted in 1988, an increasing part of the city's welfare caseload is required to participate in such programs. But while the percentage of eligible city recipients who are looking for work or pursuing education and training has doubled since 1989, to 12 percent, the number of job placements has increased only 13 percent, to 16,551 last year.
Under Mrs. Sabol, the city has also reduced the number of single parents whose welfare benefits are cut, or "sanctioned," for failing to participate in the welfare-to-work program. That figure has fallen almost three-quarters since 1989 to 8,542 last year.
"Clearly, her direction was to work hard to reduce sanctions because of the hardship on very poor people, and we try to be responsive to that," said Catherine Zall, the deputy commissioner in charge of the welfare-to-work program. "But she's not unresponsive to rigorous enforcement of the program. She wants to see people active, participating, going to work."
 
Current Emphasis Is on Education
 Mrs. Sabol, who rarely gives interviews, declined to discuss the administration's differences with Mr. Giuliani for this article. But in the past she has said that virtually every woman on welfare she has ever spoken with desperately wants to go to work. She has said that the city's current heavy investment in education and training will eventually pay off by enabling welfare recipients to get decent-paying jobs, rather than dead-end jobs.
Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales says the administration is also about to start a major welfare experiment in Brooklyn. It would let recipients of court-ordered child support keep more of their welfare benefits when they go to work than they would under traditional programs. The current system discourages work by docking welfare recipients' benefits almost dollar-for-dollar against their wages.
Mr. Giuliani has not issued a position paper or given a major speech on welfare policy, but his advisers suggested some of the ways his policies would differ from Mr. Dinkins's.
For instance, his principal social policy adviser is William J. Grinker, a Democrat who headed the city's Human Resources Administration under Mayor Edward I. Koch. Mr. Grinker helped found the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, which made its reputation researching welfare-to-work programs.
When Mr. Grinker headed the H.R.A., that agency began requiring welfare recipients to look for a job immediately or lose part of their welfare benefits.
Mr. Grinker criticized the Dinkins administration for letting people choose education and training over an immediate job search. "You end up with a lot of people going from training program to training program and never have any results," he said. He described Mrs. Sabol's message to welfare recipients as, "We're not going to really push you."
 
Sharp Differences On 'Right' to Shelter
 The mayoral candidates' contrasting approaches come into clearest focus on the issue of homelessness. Mr. Dinkins still fervently argues that the city owes the homeless shelter, though he has tightened access to the bulging shelter system with new eligibility rules.
But Mr. Giuliani contends the city should undo the right to shelter that is the foundation of its policy on homelessness -- a right that he says no other city guarantees.
He wants the city to challenge the consent decree the city signed in 1981, promising to shelter all homeless men. But he would also have to persuade the courts to modify a 1986 preliminary injunction requiring the city to shelter families. The courts have never ruled on whether the right to shelter is rooted in the State Constitution, but the state's Appellate Division has said it probably is -- hardly an encouraging harbinger for Mr. Giuliani's approach.
If his administration did succeed in the courts, Mr. Giuliani would fundamentally alter the shelter system, limiting many shelter stays to 90 days and requiring shelter residents to join programs.
Mr. Dinkins has attacked Mr. Giuliani for "suggesting we should turn pregnant women and peaceful children out on to our streets." But Mr. Giuliani insists: "We need people to help themselves, to reform their own behavior."
Both men's views have evolved in recent years. Mr. Dinkins has got some difficult on-the-job training. He tried to house shelter residents quickly in permanent subsidized apartments, assuming that that would empty the shelters. Instead, he now says, the policy boomeranged and attracted more families who were looking for a short cut to an apartment. He hopes the eligibility rules will screen out such families.
The candidates' views have converged on some issues, largely because both have been strongly influenced by Andrew M. Cuomo, the Governor's son, who headed Mayor Dinkins's Commission on the Homeless.
Like Mr. Cuomo, now a Federal housing official, both candidates say the city should stop running shelters and hire nonprofit groups to do the job. Both agree that many of the homeless have chronic problems like drug addiction and mental illness and need intensive social services.
And both candidates realize that homelessness has become an emotional issue for voters dispirited by the city's inability to end the presence of a raggedy, sometimes threatening army of street people, despite more than a decade of effort and almost $5 billion spent on the problem.
Mr. Giuliani has explicitly linked the presence of aggressive or demented homeless people on the streets to what he calls the degradation of the quality of life. "New Yorkers no longer want to look the other way when passing a needy homeless person on the street," he said in a position paper. "Nor are they required to be assaulted by menacing individuals."
Those statements leave unresolved whether either candidate has an approach that will actually reduce the number of people living on the streets and help the homeless attain self-suffiency, goals that can sometimes be contradictory.
 
Limiting Shelter To the Neediest
 For example, Mr. Giuliani's carrot-and-stick approach would require drug addicts to seek treatment as a condition of being sheltered, and would use workers to coax people off the streets. But failure rates for drug treatment are high, and some addicts simply refuse help. If Mr. Giuliani's policy is followed to its logical conclusion, the most hard-core addicts would be kicked out of shelter -- right back onto the streets.
In the late 1980's, Philadelphia imposed strict new rules requiring that shelter residents stay off illegal drugs and submit to random urine testing. The new policies helped push some people to get their lives back in order, but experts and advocates say they have also put more people on the city's streets.
The candidates' positions also raise questions about whose policies would be most successful in limiting shelter to the neediest. Both men say they believe that some families have entered city shelters so they can jump to the front of a years-long waiting list for subsidized housing, contributing to a near doubling of the costs of sheltering families to $292 million a year since Mr. Dinkins took office.
Mr. Dinkins has developed eligibility rules, scheduled to go into effect next month, that are supposed to exclude people who can still live with friends or relatives. But his administration has hedged when asked how it will enforce the new rules. Inevitably, the city will find it hard to turn away desperate families.
Mr. Giuliani goes much further, and some social policy experts credit him with opening up the debate about a subject that has been virtually taboo.
But Mr. Giuliani's proposed 90-day limit on many shelter stays could prove as difficult to enforce as Mr. Dinkins's eligibility standards. In the days after his plan was released, Mr. Giuliani said that if an individual still had no place to go after 90 days, "of course it can be extended, and it should be extended."
An even more striking proposal received less attention. Mr. Giuliani says the city should stop giving the homeless priority for permanent housing. This is a step he could probably take without the courts' approval.
In 1989, Massachusetts eliminated the housing preference for shelter residents. The number of families seeking shelter there has dropped from 5,700 in 1989 to less than 2,500 in each of the last three years.
 
The Series So Far
 The first article of the series, which appeared on Monday, discussed the city's approaching deficits and reported that whoever wins the mayoral election Nov. 2 will immediately face a major budget crisis. Fiscal experts say the city must find a strategy to guarantee long-term budget stability.

HEADLINE: Number of Cuban Refugees Called Highest Since Boatlift

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The United States Coast Guard has intercepted more Cubans escaping their homeland by sea in September than in any month since the Mariel boatlift of 1980, a Coast Guard spokesman said today.
The total of 522 refugees does not include Cubans who overstayed American tourist visas, illegally entered the United States or fled to neighboring islands or to Mexico, Chief Petty Officer Joe Dye said in a telephone interview from Miami. 
 Coast Guard cutters have intercepted 2,260 Cubans so far this year, Mr. Dye said. He said he expected the final figure for 1993 to surpass the total of 2,557 refugees in 1992.
The departures come amid worsening economic conditions in Cuba.
The Coast Guard total for September was the highest monthly figure since the Mariel exodus, in which 125,000 Cubans left on thousands of boats from April to June 1980.

HEADLINE: Clinton and China's President Will Meet to Discuss Disputes

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 1

 BODY:
As part of a strategy to improve the increasingly troubled relationship between Washington and Beijing, the Clinton Administration has scheduled a number of high-level meetings with Chinese officials.
President Clinton will meet with President Jiang Zemin of China for the first time at a meeting of heads of member states of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Organization, a forum devoted to economic cooperation, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in New York on Thursday. The meeting is planned for November in Seattle. 
 A senior Administration official said that the two Presidents would take advantage of the fact that they would both be attending the conference to meet, but that the meeting would not be a "summit." The fact that a meeting is scheduled, however, indicates the importance that both countries place on establishing a high-level dialogue.
 
Timed for Meeting
 "I don't want to minimize the importance of the two Presidents having a chance to see each other," the official said in a briefing with reporters Thursday evening. "I want to emphasize again to you that this was as a result of the APEC leaders meeting."
The Administration is also prepared to send Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen to Beijing to revive a bilateral Joint Economic Commission with China that was suspended after the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, a senior Administration official said today. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy is also likely to make a trip to Beijing, the official added.
Mr. Christopher announced on Thursday that China agreed to allow John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, to visit China next month -- the first such visit in a year -- to discuss China's poor human rights record and its continued use of prison labor.
But senior Administration officials stressed that they have no illusions that the visits will make an appreciable difference in China's behavior. In a meeting in the White House on Sept. 25, National Security Adviser Anthony Lake and Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, bluntly described the Administration's areas of concern to Li Daoyu, the Chinese Ambassador to the United States, in anticipation of Thursday's meeting between Mr. Christopher and Qian Qichen, the Chinese Foreign Minister.
 
Trade Status Issue
 The Administration is eager to reverse the downward trend in relations that will make it difficult for Mr. Clinton to renew most-favored-nation trade benefits for China in June unless the Chinese make substantive progress on human rights and weapons nonproliferation issues.
Another American official said that Mr. Lake told Mr. Li that the Administration would like to find a way to waive economic sanctions imposed on Beijing in August after China transferred M-11 missile technology to Pakistan. The official added that such a move would require a new commitment from China to adhere to the principles of the Missile Technology Control Regime, a 1987 international agreement restricting the export of missiles and missile technology.
"We made clear we were willing to negotiate a waiver of the sanctions, that given the evidence against China, we had no choice under the law except to impose them," the official said. He added that the Chinese would have to make a more formal commitment than the one that Mr. Qian gave to James A. Baker 3d, who was then the Secretary of State, in November 1992.
At that time, Mr. Qian wrote a letter agreeing to abide by the guidelines of the missile control agreement, but China has never signed the accord and China and the United States have never fully agreed on what constitutes a violation of the accord.
The United States is eager to improve relations with China, particularly to preserve and improve the trade relationship. In addition, the United States needs China's continued cooperation to oppose North Korea's nuclear weapons program and to bring stability to Cambodia.

HEADLINE: As Mormon Church Grows, So Does Dissent From Feminists and Scholars

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
The Mormon Church, whose early leaders feared the wrath of outsiders, has lately viewed its gravest threat as coming from within: intellectuals and feminists in the temples.
In what dissidents have described as a purge, church leaders took severe disciplinary action in September against six Mormon scholars and feminists. The transgressions fit into two categories: academic research that raises questions about official church history, and the call for opening the priesthood to women, which is granted to males over the age of 12. 
 "With the tremendous growth of the church, we have seen an emerging intellectual pluralism in Mormonism," said Elbert Peck, the publisher of Sunstone, an independent Mormon magazine. "And the church feels it must confront them."
The Church of Jesus Christ Latter-Day Saints, as the Mormon Church is known, is one of the fastest-growing in the world and now counts 8.5 million members in more than 120 countries. In 1950, when there were one million Mormons, nearly half of them lived in Utah; today, not even one in six live here. And growing numbers of women in the church, like those in other religions with male-only clergies, are chafing at what they regard as sex discrimination.
 
Independent Mormon Voices
 In the last decade or so, a flurry of independent Mormon publications and groups have emerged in Salt Lake City, including the Mormon Women's Forum, a feminist group that says it has about 2,000 members.
Its president, Lynn Kanavel Whitesides, was one of the six disciplined by the church authorities. She was "disfellowshipped," which means the loss of certain privileges like receiving sacraments. The other five were excommunicated, a more severe penalty, and their names were removed from church rolls.
Don LeFever, a spokesman for the Mormons, said that the church never discussed its actions but that anything that caused harm to Mormonism would be grounds for discipline.
While women sometimes deliver sermons and lead prayers, they are not allowed to baptize, bless or distribute the sacraments, or lead congregations.
It galls some Mormons that boys as young as 12 can become deacons, an office within the priesthood, and distribute the sacraments. At 16, boys can baptize. In their early 20's, men typically become bishops, the equivalent of priests or ministers in other Christian denominations, an office that is closed to women, as are other positions of authority within the church.
 
Motives Are Discussed
 "We are not trying to tear the church down," said Ms. Whitesides, who has called for leadership roles to be opened to women. "Instead, we are trying to give Mormon women a reason to stay in the church."
She said she believed that she had angered the Mormon hierarchy by organizing a protest when two liberal professors at Brigham Young University were denied tenure. The university is owned by the church.
She later appeared on a Salt Lake City television program and warned church leaders that they would be unable to quell the rising tide of feminism in the Mormon ranks.
"If you excommunicate one of us, there will be 10 more to step up and take her place," she said. "Excommunicate those 10 and there will be 100 to take their places."
A long-established doctrine of Mormonism, not widely known outside the church, gives the debate a tantalizing twist: the belief in a female as well as a male deity as the spiritual parents of humankind.
In recent years, Mormon feminists have pointed to a female diety as logical grounds for opening leadership to women. Indeed, some women have begun praying to "our Mother in heaven" as well as "our Father."
 
Leadership Point of View
 A church leader, Gordon Hinckley, delivered a speech in 1991 that forbade prayer to a mother in heaven but did not challenge the concept of a female diety. Citing the Sermon on the Mount by Jesus, he said prayers should be offered to "our Father." Another church leader, Boyd Packer, told a Mormon conference in May that feminists posed a serious threat to the faith, along with homosexuals and "so-called intellectuals and scholars."
"Our local leaders," Mr. Packer said, "must deal with all three of them with ever-increasing frequency."
The existence of a female God is underlined in a popular church hymn, written in 1843 by Eliza Snow, an important church figure who called for equal rights for women. The hymn, "Oh, My Father," is still sung in Mormon meeting houses on Sundays. It includes these verses:
In the Heavens are parents single?
No. The thought makes reason stare.
Truth is reason.
Truth eternal
Tells me I've a Mother there.
Throughout the 20th century, leaders of the Mormon Church have sought to move the faith toward the mainstream of Christianity, and at the same time to preserve the distinctiveness of its religious culture. Mormons are expected to tithe, or donate 10 percent of their income to the church, abstain from coffee, tea, tobacco and alcohol, and adhere to conservative family values.
But the profile of church members has been changing: statistics on family size, working women and divorce rates show that Mormons are looking more like the rest of America.
Through the 1970's, the size of a typical Mormon family was about 50 percent larger than the national average, said Tim Heaton, a sociologist at Brigham Young University, but that gap has been shrinking in recent years.
The typical married couple in Utah today has 2.5 children, compared with the national average of 1.9.
 
Same Economics for All
 "Mormons respond to the same kinds of social and economic conditions that others do," he said. "And the fact is, it's gotten to be very expensive to have a big family."
He said that the percentage of Mormon women who hold paying jobs virtually mirrored the national average and that the divorce rate in Utah was only slightly lower than elsewhere. The Mormon Church encourages women to stay home with children, rather than work. "But that is an ideal," said Mr. LeFever, "and the church understands it's just not economically possible for many families to do so."
Along with the Mormon Tabernacle and the other majestic church buildings, the city has its share of avant-garde places, like Club DV8 and bands with names like Nudeswirl and Maggots Head.
Professor Heaton said, "Salt Lake does not look appreciably different than any other big city in America except, of course, that it's almost all white."
 
Speaking Out for Women
 One of the women who was excommunicated, Maxine Hanks, said, "Feminism is embedded in our Mormon history, our culture."
Ms. Hanks, who edited the book "Women and Authority: Re-emerging Mormon Feminism" (Signature Books, 1992), added, "Mormon theology is potentially very empowering for women. But the police and the practice of the institutional church has been very damaging and confining to women."
Michael Quinn, a Yale-educated scholar who formerly taught at Brigham Young, believes that he was expelled from the church for his research. In 1985, Mr. Quinn unearthed evidence that Mormon leaders continued to practice polygamy for 14 years after the church officially ended the practice in 1890, known as the Great Accommodation, to win statehood, which came six years later.
He also wrote an essay for Ms. Hanks's book, "Women Have Had the Priesthood since 1843." It explored the notion that women were spiritually invested with the priesthood by Joseph Smith in a ceremony the church calls "Endowment in the Temple."
The others who were disciplined were Avrhami Gileadi, a conservative Biblical scholar; Paul Toscano, an author and lecturer, and Lavina Fielding Anderson, a writer and scholar.
 
'Incompatible Categories'
 "I am an orthodox, believing Mormon and a feminist," said Ms. Anderson, who was deeply shaken by her excommunication, "and my church has informed me that those are incompatible categories." She said she had been excommunicated for writing critically of certain Mormon bishops and for speaking out about the church's treatment of scholars.
"This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me," Ms. Anderson said. "My people have been Mormons for six generations."
The debate over feminism in the Mormon Church comes at a time of growing research by scholars exploring the roles of women in ancient Christian and Jewish culture.
Jan Shipps, a religious scholar and author of "Mormonism: The Story of a New Religious Tradition" (University of Illinois Press, 1985), said the idea of a Mormon feminist has long been regarded as an oxymoron.
"But in fact, their history gives them more resources, more inspiration, to draw upon, for feminism," she said.
The Mormon notion of "a Mother in heaven," she said, as it becomes more broadly discussed in American feminist circles, "will be exciting to those who are trying to figure out where they belong in the scheme of Christianity."

HEADLINE: Inquiry on Commerce Secretary Finds Vietnam Bank Account Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Federal investigators examining a Vietnamese businessman's assertion that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown sought $700,000 to help end a trade embargo against Vietnam have uncovered evidence that the Vietnamese were preparing to establish a special bank account in Singapore, Administration officials said today.
The evidence, in the form of transfers of an undisclosed sum of money in East Asian banks, appears to corroborate portions of the account of Ly Thanh Binh, the businessman who told the Federal authorities that a former associate approached Mr. Brown last fall to enlist his help to improve trade relations between the United States and Vietnam. 
 Mr. Binh has said the Vietnamese Government was trying to use the Indosuez Bank in Singapore as a conduit to pay Mr. Brown. But it is not clear whether the transfer of funds being scrutinized by the Federal authorities involved Indosuez or, indeed, whether the financial records drew any connection between the funds and Mr. Brown.
Mr. Brown has denied any wrongdoing, but he acknowledged through his lawyer that he had met three times with Mr. Binh's former associate, Nguyen Van Hao, a former Vietnamese official. Mr. Brown's lawyer, Reid H. Weingarten, has denied that the Commerce Secretary ever discussed accepting money from the Vietnamese. The lawyer said that two of the meetings occurred before Mr. Brown was appointed Commerce Secretary and the third took place in February, after his confirmation.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying to learn whether Mr. Brown took money as a public official in return for favors.
 
Authorities Hear of Plans
 Mr. Binh has said that Mr. Brown was to receive $700,000, plus a percentage of new business he generated for Vietnam, in addition to concessions from oil and gas reserves opened as a result of ending the embargo.
Mr. Binh said the money was to be funneled from Vietnam through a Hong Kong bank to a Singapore bank. In Singapore, he said, it was to be deposited in an account in the name of Mr. Hao or Marc Ashton, a Haitian friend of Mr. Brown's who first introduced Mr. Hao to the Commerce Secretary, or Lillian Madsen, Mr. Ashton's sister-in-law and a friend of Mr. Brown's.
Mr. Binh said a total of $1 million was to be deposited in the account, $700,000 for Mr. Brown and $300,000 for the Vietnam Development Corporation, the entity that Mr. Hao intended to establish to funnel American investment to Vietnam.
U.S. News & World Report said tonight in a news release describing an account in next week's issue that the F.B.I. was looking at NVH Associates, a company that Mr. Hao incorporated in Hong Kong and the United States. The magazine said Federal agents were seeking to determine whether the company might have been involved in directing any payments to Mr. Brown.
Thus far, no evidence has emerged to indicate that Mr. Brown received any money from the account, nor is there any evidence that he engaged in any unlawful act, the Administration officials said. A telephone call to Mr. Brown's lawyer today was not returned.
This evening, ABC News reported that Mr. Hao had sent at least two faxes from his house in Florida to the chief of staff for Vietnam's Prime Minister, Vo Van Kiet. The communications summarized Mr. Hao's meetings with Mr. Brown and described the meetings as positive and indicated that Mr. Brown had agreed to work with the Vietnamese representatives.
Today, the head of a Vietnam veterans' group that opposes normalization of relations with Hanoi pending a full accounting of all missing Americans said that Mr. Brown should resign because of the accusations swirling around him.
Mr. Brown's supporters have said that opponents of improved ties with Vietnam have quietly helped spread Mr. Binh's accusations in order to maintain the trade embargo.

HEADLINE: Gas Tax Hits, and Drivers Aren't Happy

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With resignation and skepticism, the public began making its first contributions to reducing the Federal budget deficit today when around the country motorists woke up to President Clinton's new gasoline tax and slightly higher prices at the pump.
There was chaos at some service stations Thursday night before the 4.3-cents-a-gallon increase went into effect, with some people idling in lines to save a dime or two. There were reports of truck drivers protesting the tax and disrupting traffic by driving the speed limit in tandem on highways in the Midwest. 
 And today, business was anemic at many stations as motorists, accustomed to below-average prices, balked at the increase and others bought the minimum in vain hope that this would all go away.
"I'm mad, I'm mad, I'm mad," said Lula Curtis, a Philadelphia motorist as she paid for gasoline at a downtown Amoco station. "I didn't profit when all these people made these bad debts. The business people who made money off the deficit should pay. Let Ross Perot pay."
 
Protest by Truckers
 It was not enough to make drivers sell their cars or Democrats leave the party. But it was one more burden to people still waiting for the economic recovery and an irritant to people who had no choice but to pay.
In addition, today was the start of the the Federal oxygenated fuel program, increasing the price of gas a few more cents per gallon in about 40 metropolitan areas, including the New York City region. Oxygenated gas, a cleaner burning fuel, is used to help reduce carbon monoxide levels.
"It's horrible," said Meggos Tesfamarian, an Oakland cab driver filling up at a downtown British Petroleum station, where prices rose five cents to $1.22 today. "We'll have to see how we'll survive. It's kind of a weird time now. Everything is going up. People don't have jobs, don't use taxis."
The biggest protests so far have come from truck drivers, whose industry stands to lose $1.5 billion a year because of the tax, according to the American Trucking Association, an industry trade group.
Some truck drivers have taken out their frustration on the highways. There have been spontaneous slowdowns on the Ohio Turnpike since Tuesday, when a convoy of 18-wheelers slowed to 40 miles an hour on the highway just west of Youngstown.
 
Grumbling at the Pump
 On Thursday night, before the tax took effect, 250 semi-tractor trailers heading west clotted traffic near Toledo, when they drove single file in the righthand lane at 55 m.p.h.
The trucks that highway patrol officers could stop were given citations for impeding traffic. And sometimes when a truck was pulled over other truck drivers would stop, too, to give the trooper a piece of their mind, said Rosemary Hoelscher, radio dispatcher on the Ohio Turnpike.
"We don't condone those actions," said John Collins, senior vice president of government affairs at the American Trucking Association. "But we can understand them."
He said the tax was "really a rifle-shot tax at transportation users, and we think it falls unfairly on the trucking industry."
Ordinary motorists were on their own, left to grumble to cashiers and gas attendants. Some stations had posted signs in their windows for weeks warning motorists of the new tax, but it apparently did little good today.
"We have a lot of screaming customers out there," said Sina Ierome, manager of an Amoco station on Chicago's northwest side, where prices went up a penny a gallon. "One customer said: 'This is ridiculous. Pretty soon I will have to take the bus.' We are telling them, it's the President not us."
To make up the 4.3 cents, most stations added five cents to the price of regular and mid-grade gas and three cents to the price of premium. Some stations facing stiff competition decided to absorb the tax for now, according the Service Station Dealers of America, a trade association and advocacy group. The American Automobile Association said some stations might phase in the tax or wait for the competition to raise pump prices first.
 
Some Pay Willingly
 Many motorists said they could handle the tax, welcome it even, if they could be assured it would go to reduce the deficit. "But we really don't know where the money is going to go, do we?" said Merrill Ringold, a Seattle social worker, as he pumped unleaded gas into his Mercury Grand Marquis.
Some fully accepted the idea and were ready to take their castor oil. "I drive, and I'm a smoker," said Joseph Lombardi, driving his Honda Accord around Boston. "It's a sin tax, and I'm a sinner. I'm sorry they didn't put a tax on alcohol, too."
The American Automobile Association said the tax could be a blow to the travel industry, already struggling after the recession.
But with peak automobile travel over since Labor Day, and retail gasoline prices down by about 10 cents from a year ago to an average of $1.06 a gallon for self-serve regular unleaded last week, this was perhaps the least painful time to impose a gasoline tax, some industry officials said.
Today, there was customer resistance in part because motorists have grown used to lower gasoline prices in recent years. Because of an oversupply and lower demand during the recession, the price of crude oil has been stable or declining in recent months, and this year pump prices have been lower than they were a decade ago, even as taxes have risen.
In 1982, the average gallon of gas cost $1.28, of which 24 cents went to taxes. In 1992, without accounting for inflation, that same gallon of gas cost $1.19 with 35 cents going to taxes, according to the American Petroleum Institute, an advocacy group.
To many motorists, though, all that matters is how much they have to pay. And today they had to pay more. "Some people launched into a tirade," said Bob Randall, who runs a station in Denver. "They just see it as another way for Government to get into their pockets. And they don't think it's going to go for deficit reduction."
At the Gastown Service Station in Garfield Heights, Ohio, motorists loaded up on gasoline until the minute the station closed late Thursday to put off paying the tax. Some waited through exhaust fumes to save eight cents.
"People were getting $2 or $3 of gas even if they were already practically full," said Lynn Sibly, the station manager. "They went into a panic mode. It was a zoo."
 
Remembering the 70's
 But some motorists remembered the fear and gas lines in the 1970's and kept the numbers in perspective. "Four cents is nothing," said Wiston Arguello, a cab driver who was filling up at a service station in Manhattan. "I use premium, and I'm not going to change."
With all the talk of the President's health care plan and the fight over the Federal budget seeming like a bad dream, the gasoline tax sneaked up on some motorists. "I didn't know that it was going up," said Ken Nordine, a 73-year-old Chicagoan at a gas pump. "They don't tell the people anything."
To be sure, the Clinton Administration is probably betting that necessity will be the savior of the new gasoline tax. It has already figured into the calculus people like Betty William of Oakland, who was too busy this morning to care what price she paid.
"All I know is that I have to get to work, and I need the gas," she said.

HEADLINE: Oils Lead Stocks Rally, With Dow Rising 25.99

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Following a weak performance in its previous session, the stock market bounced back yesterday, rallying ahead of a firm bond market that was reacting to a batch of economic reports that confirmed the economy was still on a slow-growth path.
The smaller-than-expected September rise in the index of the National Association of Purchasing Managers, helped lift bond prices, which generally rally on weak economic reports that, traders think, may influence the Fed to keep interest rates low. 
 Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst with MMS International, a Wall Street economic analysis and research firm, said he attributed yesterday's blue-chip performance to cyclicals, which reversed their recent trend of trailing the market.
"Oil stocks paced the advance, spurred by recent increases in oil prices and an announcement by the White House offering energy incentives that will include tax breaks to bolster the natural gas and domestic oil industry in development and exploration," he said.
 
Cyclicals Making Gains
 Among the big cyclicals making gains were Alcoa, Caterpillar, Goodyear and paper stocks, while Intel moved up again on positive comments by Merrill Lynch.
A sharp drop in several health care issues kept the market's most recent leadership, the Nasdaq composite, in check. Shares of health maintainence organizations, or H.M.O.'s, dropped sharply after the New York State Insurance Department's decision to decrease U.S. Healthcare's New York H.M.O. premium rates by an average of 3.9 percent. The company, whose stock fell 4, to 46 3/4, plans to file an action seeking to annul the decision.
Also under pressure were Oxford Health, another publicly traded New York H.M.O., down 3, to 78 3/4; Healthsource, down 2 3/4, to 46 1/4; United Healthcare, down 2 3/4, to 65 7/8, and Coventry down 1 1/4, to 36.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 25.99 points on the day to 3,581.11, while gaining 38 points for the week. Volume on the Big Board was heavy at 260.4 million shares traded, as gainers outnumbered decliners by 1,102 to 886.
With the onset of a new month and new quarter, money managers seem eager to put cash to work after kicking out at the end of the last quarter, and that also provided the support in the market yesterday.
Autos gained as the result of the agreement between Chrysler and the United Automobile Workers union. Chrysler rose 1, to 49; General Motors, was up 3/4, 42 1/2, and Ford Motor gained 1 1/4, to 56 1/2.
Elsewhere in the market, C. J. Lawrence initiated coverage of wine maker Robert Mondavi with a buy recommendation, as the stock closed up 3/8, to 9 7/8.
Gtech Holdings gained 1, to close at 37. The company says it is part of a consortium formed to bid for operation of a national lottery in Britain.
Hechinger Company, a home-improvement retailer, had its Prudential Securities rating cut to hold from buy, as the stock dropped 2 1/8, to 9.
Stocks affected by lower earnings estimates included Xyplex Inc., which dropped 10, to close at 18 3/4. The data communications equipment maker said it sees earnings per share at 30 cents to 32 cents for the third quarter, below the 41 cents a share consensus.
 
Applied Magnetic Down
 Applied Magnetic fell 2 1/4, to 6 7/8, when it announced expectations of a fourth-quarter operating loss, citing continuing turmoil in disk drive industry.
Shares of Sonat Inc. rose 1 3/8, to 36 3/8, as Mobil Gulf Properties sold an interest in 13 gas producing properties and three associated pipelines in the western Gulf of Mexico to Sonat Exploration for $133.6 million.
In Tokyo yesterday, stocks moved higher on buying spurred by the start of the new fiscal half-year. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 177.42 points, or 0.88 percent, to 20,283.13.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
TWO APPROACHES TO HOMELESSNESS
 In the four years since they last campaigned to be mayor, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani have refined their positions on what should be done for the city's impoverished multitudes and now present voters with distinctly different approaches to homelessness and welfare reform. Page 1. 

CRITICS DISMISS STADIUM PLAN
 Opposition to a proposal to build a new stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan sprouted yesterday like mushrooms on Miracle-Gro, with community advocates predicting almost endless lawsuits that would delay the project for years, perhaps decades. Page 26.

 SCHOOL CONDITIONS PROTESTED
 Parents of public-school children recounted dismal accounts of dilapidated school buildings at a City Hall rally, one of several recent outpourings of anger by parents who have begun to express broader concerns over the crumbling state of the city's school buildings. Page 26.
 
 POLICE WATCHDOG UNIT CRITICIZED
 As hearings into corruption in the New York City Police Department resumed, two former narcotics officers described the department's watchdog agency as disorganized, incompetent and so ineffectual that honest officers feared reporting their crooked colleagues. Page 27.
 
 GIULIANI CALLS COMMENT A SLUR
 Rudolph W. Giuliani asserted that a prominent black minister's charge that Mr. Giuliani is supported by "fascist elements" seemed intended as an anti-Italian slur and that it may have been part of a coordinated effort by the Dinkins campaign to use supporters to inject race into the campaign. Page 28.
 
 POPULAR DINKINS PROGRAM ATTACKED
 By saying he would eliminate New York City's affirmative-action program for minority contractors, Rudolph W. Giuliani has waged his most direct assault on Mayor Dinkins's economic development policies and targeted a program that has won wide support among black, female and Hispanic voters. Page 28.
 
REGION
 
MORE QUESTIONS IN STRANGLING
 For a second day in Superior Court in Paterson, James P. Wanger was bombarded with tough questions about inconsistencies and gaps in his accounts of where he was and what he did on the day that Robert A. Solimine Jr. was strangled. Mr. Wanger is charged in the slaying of Mr. Solimine. Page 29.
 
 BIAS CHARGES IN TEANECK INCIDENT
 Bias charges have been filed against the man suspected of hiring someone in a gorilla suit who disrupted a Teaneck, N.J., Township Council meeting by presenting the only black member with bananas and a toy monkey. Page 29.
 
 PARKING TICKET VICTORY AND DEFEAT
 Ira J. Raab won't have to pay the $15 parking ticket he received last March when he pulled into a crowded lot and parked in a spot reserved for the police, a judge has ruled. But the decision was a defeat for Mr. Raab, who thought he had found a way to challenge the validity of every parking ticket Nassau County has issued for years. Page 29.
