HEADLINE: Hotel Business Is Waking Up

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
After 11 consecutive years of losses totaling more than $33 billion, the United States hotel industry is heading for its first profit since 1981. Occupancy rates are rising almost everywhere, with many hotel chains reporting their best year for a long time.
"Our forecasts indicate that the lodging industry will show a profit of a half-million to $1 billion this year," said Bjorn Hanson, the industry analyst for the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. 
 The 240-hotel Hilton chain, for example, received a record one million calls last month and also booked the most reservations in its history.
 
Optimism for Decade
 Industrywide, the latest available figures show that room occupancy rose to 74.4 percent in July, almost 4 percent above July 1992 and the highest in the seven years that the American Hotel and Motel Association has tracked such figures. Room sales in that period were more than $12 million a day higher than in the similar 1990 period, when the industry lost a record $5.2 billion.
"I think the whole decade is going to be profitable, because as the U.S. economy evolves from manufacturing to service, those types of jobs tend to involve a lot more traveling," said Mark Lomanno, research manager at Smith Travel Research in Gallatin, Tenn., which compiles the occupancy figures for the hotel association.
Atlanta, for example, has experienced a surge in business travel, bringing its hotel use up 9.4 percent this year. Nationwide, Hilton says its business travel increase is 23 percent this year over last.
 
 
Gains in Leisure Travel
 But in some areas, like Phoenix, the industry's resurgence is being led by increased leisure travel. And the Richfield Hotel Management Company, which manages 170 hotels under 23 names in 38 states, finds business travel still in the doldrums but a big surge in leisure travel.
Phoenix occupancy rates are up almost 7 percent this year over last, Denver is up 8.6 percent, Detroit 7.5 and Washington 5.7. New York is up only 2.8 percent, in part, analysts say, because of its 21.25 percent room tax -- the highest in the nation.
Average occupancy levels are expected to hit 64 percent this year, a figure that Mr. Hanson described as the break-even point necessary for hotels to cover fixed costs, and occupancy should rise to 68 percent in 1995, he said. In 1990 it was only 61 percent, and it was 62 percent last year, despite record air travel last summer because of the half-price fares.
The hotel industry's improving fortunes may be a mixed blessing for consumers, who for several years have been waiting until the last minute to make travel plans. Higher occupancy rates are likely to mean no room at the inn for those who neglect to reserve in advance.
Yet the good news for consumers, if not hoteliers, is that room rates are expected to lag behind inflation for at least the next year, meaning bargains should still be readily available. But by 1995, room rates are expected to exceed the rate of inflation.
Many analysts have predicted that the lodging industry will finally turn a slender profit in 1994, or perhaps 1995, as the economy picked up and demand increased, at the same time the supply of excess hotel rooms dwindled. Thousands of the nation's 3.1 million hotel rooms have been taken off the market each year. Mr. Hanson said only about 23,000 new rooms are being added this year, compared with 111,000 in 1988. In addition, 100,000 rooms are changing affiliations, he said, suggesting that they are changing to lower-end brands, which require fewer employees and have lower overhead.
Much overbuilding occurred in the days when many hotels were built as tax shelters, rather than in response to market demand. But the Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated most real estate tax shelters, and hotels have since lost a third of their value.
 
 
'Tough Couple of Years'
 "It's been a tough couple of years, but the industry has benefited from the restructuring," said Mack Koonce, senior vice president of sales and marketing for the 50 Wyndham Hotels in the United States, Caribbean and Bermuda. "It has made it leaner and a more profitable business."
Paul Sistare, executive vice president of operations for Richfield, the hotel management company, also said that hard times had made the survivors more competitive than ever. "Hotels have finally recognized that being a hotel means being in business," he said. "In the past, the industry was often driven by ego and operated as a tax break."
The restructuring and the trend since 1988 toward opening limited-service hotels, which now make up 65 percent of the total, are reflected in these statistics cited by Mr. Hanson: The number of employees for each 100 hotel rooms has dropped to 50.5 today from 54 in 1988. That drop, he said, has enabled the break-even occupancy rate to fall to 64 percent from 65.8 percent in 1990.
Nevertheless, while occupancy levels are inseparable from industry health, the biggest spur to profitability has been a series of belt-tightening decisions -- most notably, the restructuring of an estimated $2 billion worth of annual interest payments in the last four years.
In addition, as hotel values have plunged, some 40 percent of hotels have appealed their property taxes. About 80 percent of the appeals were successful, Mr. Hanson said, resulting in reductions of 15 to 20 percent.
Hotels have saved an estimated $500 million a year in management fees, which are down to 5 to 8 percent of total revenues today from a high of 10 to 12 percent a few years ago, though often with incentive clauses tied to cash flow available for debt service. Many occupancy rates have climbed because of new vigor in group meetings and conventions.
"They're helping Atlanta have a great year," said Mark Woodworth, director of the Hospitality Consulting Services Group in Atlanta. "Close to 70 percent of all the upscale hotels here are enjoying the benefits of the return of the group meetings and convention segment. But most Atlanta hotels have shown improvement." Occupancy in Atlanta is up 9.4 this year.
The expansion of the Moscone Center in San Francisco, a convention center, has been a boon to that city's hotel industry. The July occupancy rate was 81 percent. "By year's end, occupancies will wind up flat," said Susan Ernst of Horwath Hospitality, "but that's good news out here, because the trends have been so sour for so long."
San Francisco is the lone bright spot on the West Coast, according to Mr. Lomanno of Smith Travel Research. Los Angeles occupancy is off 1.5 percent; San Diego, 4.5 percent, and Honolulu, 7.7 percent, largely because of weak economies in California and Japan, from which Hawaii draws most of its visitors.
What has especially hurt West Coast hotels, analysts say, is the drop in Japanese and European visitors because of recession, and residual fear from the Los Angeles riots of spring 1992.
 
Improvement in Miami
 But elsewhere, the hotel industry is booming.
Even in Miami, occupancy rates rose 7.6 percent through July, and while the recent rash of tourist murders is likely to deter vacationers, analysts say the city will continue to do well because of the construction workers, insurance adjusters and others who descended on the area in the wake of Hurricane Andrew in 1992 and are still there.
Room rates have lagged behind for several years, bedeviling the industry, and this year rates have increased only 2.3 percent, to $61.29 from $59.91. "But any increase in demand will help push hotels over their break-even number," Ms. Ernst said, "so whether the increase is from higher room rates or more heads in the beds, they all add to profitability if the operators can contain expenses."
Analysts say that assuming there is a gradual economic recovery, rather than the brisk recovery many analysts had thought likely several years ago, the industry will continue to strengthen, at least for several years -- by which time money for hotels should again flow freely, and new hotels and motels will be under construction.

HEADLINE: 43 Nations Promise Palestinians $2 Billion in Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Delegates from 43 nations today promised about $2 billion in aid over the next five years for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, as Saudi Arabia put aside its anger at the Palestinians for supporting Iraq in the Persian Gulf war and pitched in $100 million.
Recognizing that peace is firmer when buttressed by prosperity, the nations promised $600 million in aid for this year alone, and American officials said they were confident that the contributions would ultimately far exceed their $2 billion goal. 
 The delegates, often from countries that have been bitter adversaries for decades, agreed that the economies of the occupied territories were in deplorable shape and needed a quick burst of aid to minimize tensions after the peace accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
At a conference held at the State Department, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, said: "We must help them demonstrate the tangible benefits of peace, and we must do so quickly if the advocates of peace are to be strengthened and the enemies of peace are to be isolated and discredited."
 
U.S. Pledges $500 Million
 The United States pledged $500 million over five years, three-quarters in grants and one-quarter in loans and loan guarantees from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Israel pledged a grant of $25 million and a loan of $50 million.
"This is really an important moment because it continues the momentum of peace that was created in this signing ceremony at the White House on the 13th of September," said Nabil Shaath, chief political adviser to the P.L.O.'s chairman, Yasir Arafat. "It's a commitment from the international community to support that peace process and to turn it from a starting point into a full, just, lasting and comprehensive peace."
[Mr. Arafat, speaking from Tunis, told Britain's Independent Television News: "At least, we are in need of five billion dollars," Reuters reported.]
But Arab delegates rebuffed an American plea to abandon their boycott of Israel, which Vice President Al Gore said had "no place in a world seeking peace."
Yasir Abed Rabbo, a member of the P.L.O.'s executive committee, said the boycott should remain until Arab nations recognize Israel and numerous disputes are settled, including the competing claims of Israel and the Palestinians over East Jerusalem.
Before today's five-hour conference, Saudi Arabia had left the Palestinians -- and the United States and Russia, which sponsored the conference -- guessing as to whether it would bury its anger at the P.L.O. and enlist in the international aid effort. Several officials at the meeting said Saudi Arabia promised $100 million over the first year and indicated similar amounts could be expected in subsequent years.
The European Community pledged $600 million over five years, and Japan $200 million over two years, and the Nordic countries $150 million over an unspecified period. "This is an incredible response that you've seen in such a short period of time," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen. "I'm confident that we will exceed the $2.4 billion that the World Bank estimates to be the needs over five years."
The World Bank estimates that the Palestinians need $400 million this year and $475 million in each of the subsequent four years. According to the bank, these sums are needed to finance a civil administration, pay back salaries for teachers, pay police salaries, and finance investments in basic services like schools, hospitals and sewers.
Officials at the conference are eager for the aid to make a quick, visible difference, partly to defuse radicals who are seeking to undermine the P.L.O. and derail the peace agreement.
Lewis T. Preston, the World Bank's president, painted a dismal picture of the Palestinian economy today. "Incomes have stagnated for a decade, and living conditions are appalling, especially in Gaza," he said. "Unemployment is high -- and increasing."
Mr. Gore gave the opening address to the conference, where Israeli officials sat alongside delegates from Arab nations that refuse to recognize Israel. Like many officials at the session, he said the Palestinians ultimately had to rely on private investment, not foreign aid, to achieve long-term prosperity.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
When Laurence O'Connnell was told one day last February that the White House was calling, he thought it was a practical joke.
If Dr. O'Connell had been a medical economist, he might not have been surprised. But instead he is a medical ethicist, president of the Park Ridge Center, a Chicago institute that studies the intersection of health care and religious beliefs. And the call, he says now, "came out of the blue." 
 That was also the case for most of the 30 other people working in the field of medical ethics who were invited to join the 500 or so experts that President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, put to work this year forging a plan to overhaul the nation's health care system.
Highlighting ethical issues and submitting them to careful moral analysis are activities that mix uncomfortably with the rhetoric and roughhouse of politics. Medical ethicists drawn into the world of lawmakers often complain that their work becomes fodder or window dressing for political agendas.
Now, as health care finally takes center stage in American politics, a lot of the ethicists who tore up their normal lives and moved or commuted to Washington for two months of mind-wearying discussions are asking what they accomplished.
Conversations with about a third of them draw out stories of deplorable working conditions, heated debates, intellectual frustration and even financial loss (they covered their own travel and living expenses). But almost all say they would do it again.
As one of the last working groups to be appointed, the ethicists found themselves without a permanent meeting room of their own, and their sessions became a kind of floating crap game in the Old Executive Office Building.
"There was a particularly lovely stairwell we found very comfortable," said Nancy Neveloff Dubler, a lawyer and professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx who directs the division of bioethics at Montefiore Medical Center. She was not exaggerating.
The group was assigned neither telephones nor computers. "She who had a laptop got to write the draft or make the revisions," said Carol Levine, only a bit whimsically. Ms. Levine heads the Orphan Project at the Fund for the City of New York, a research project on the effects of AIDS on surviving children.
The working group's only explicit mandate was to write a preamble for eventual legislation that would spell out the values motivating the proposed changes in the health care system, linking them to the nation's moral and religious traditions.
The ethicists were divided about the wisdom of the mandate, and eventually about its execution. As director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota, Arthur Caplan drew a lesson from that state's success in passing a significant health care measure, as well as from the experience of Britain and Canada.
The lesson was that only a strong, clear consensus on guiding principles, like universality of coverage, would keep the effort on track. "First, argue values, then debate the mechanics," Dr. Caplan said.
The President took this approach in his Sept. 22 speech before Congress, and some members of the ethics working group saw their efforts reflected in his language.
The ethicists put tremendous energy into writing the preamble. There were sharp disagreements, too, not so much about its substance as about whether it should be an easily accessible, inspiring statement or a carefully argued set of principles.
"Some wanted it to sing opera, and some wanted atonal music," said Ronald Bayer, who teaches public health at Columbia University. He was among those who doubted whether preamble-writing was the best use of the ethicists' skills. "I can't believe they needed us to write the speeches," he said.
A preamble, or "values framework," Dr. O'Connell said in response, would become the standard by which any new system could be evaluated and held accountable.
The ethicists soon took up other tasks as well, often at the request of other working groups. Some analyzed privacy problems linked to the proposed issuing of a national health security card. Some worked on ethical issues related to malpractice claims or to organ transplants. The group produced more than two dozen position papers on such topics.
Most frustrating was the Administration's clear signal that it did not want the ethicists discussing guidelines for medical rationing. Most of them doubt the Administration's conviction that removing inefficiencies will make limits on services unnecessary. They want the grounds for those limits openly examined.
None of the ethicists sound totally confident about their impact in Washington. Professor Bayer calls it "very modest." Yet most of them describe the experience, for all its travails, as one of the most intense and exciting of their professional lives.
Many also express admiration for the moral passion and ethical sensitivity that they encountered throughout the Administration's choice of health care experts.
Paradoxically, that fact could support the argument that medical ethics made its real contribution to health care changes not by joining the Clinton effort in 1993, but by more than a decade of drawing attention to the inequities and irrationalities in the health care system.

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Affirmative-Action Plan Steps Up Policy Fight

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
By saying he would eliminate New York City's affirmative action program for minority contractors, Rudolph W. Giuliani has waged his most direct assault on Mayor David N. Dinkins's economic development policies and targeted a program that has won wide support among black, female and Hispanic voters.
Mr. Giuliani, who is campaigning on a platform of cutting city spending and taxes, has also underscored a personal philosophy that precludes the use of economic incentives to promote social advancement at the expense of government efficiency and free-market competition. 
 "What this program says to minority contractors is that they don't have to be efficient, and City Hall will absorb the extra cost," said Stephen Kagan, the chief economic adviser to Mr. Giuliani, who has proposed the creation of more community development banks in the poorest sections of the city as an alternative means of aiding minorities.
Few economic incentives have been advocated more vigorously by the Dinkins administration than the affirmative-action contracting program. Started a year ago, it directs city agencies to award 20 percent of the city's $3 billion in contracts for goods and services to companies with Asian, black, female or Hispanic owners, even when their bids are as much as 10 percent higher than those of other companies.
 
A Supreme Court Ruling
 The program was established after the United States Supreme Court ruled in 1989 that cities and states -- many of which already had affirmative-action contracting programs -- could not retain them unless they showed that there had been discrimination against minorities and women.
To protect itself from legal challenges, the city commissioned a study in 1990, which found that 25 percent of the companies bidding for contracts in 1989 had been owned by women or minorities, but only 8 percent of the public money went to those firms.
"This is going to be a big negative for the Giuliani campaign," said Mariel Serafin, president of the New York National Bank, a minority-owned commercial bank in the South Bronx that serves a largely black and Hispanic clientele. He added that Mr. Giuliani's comments might hurt his campaign the most among Hispanic voters, whom he has courted.
"Mr. Giuliani has put his foot in it," said Diane Welsh, president of the New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women. "This program is about pulling the city together, and I am dismayed that he would dismantle it."
Mayor Dinkins remains firmly committed to the program, which he first advocated in his 1989 campaign.
"We are not only surprised but offended" by Mr. Giuliani's criticism of the program, said Wallace L. Ford 2d, the Commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services, which determines what firms qualify. Other officials said the number of firms that have been awarded the affirmative action contracts, and the amount of money the contracts are worth, has not been tabulated.
Mr. Giuliani said he would support, as an alternative, an investment from the city's pension funds in what he said might be a growing number of the small community development banks in poor neighborhoods.
Such banks, sometimes organized as credit unions, have been advocated by President Clinton as a way to provide small-business loans and mortgage lending in depressed areas.
Under Mr. Giuliani's plan, city pension fund money would be made available even if Congress fails to provide Federal money, said Richard Bryer, a Giuliani spokesman.
Response to the proposal was mixed, even among some of the staunchest supporters of the community-development lending banks.
Clifford N. Rosenthal, executive director of the National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions, based in Manhattan, said his group, which assists community development lenders in several cities, would welcome pension fund investments. But he added that there are "technical problems to overcome."

HEADLINE: Herschel J. Brown, 88, A Leader at Lockheed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Oct. 1

 BODY:
Herschel J. Brown, one of the founders and eventual leaders of the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a division of the Lockheed Corporation, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Altos. He was 88.
Robert Burgess, a company spokesman, said he died of natural causes. 
 Mr. Brown was one of a handful of Lockheed executives who banded together in 1953 to start the operation that later became the Lockheed Missile Systems Division. He become general manager in 1959. Lockheed Missile Systems Division was later renamed the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company.
Born in Washington, Mr. Brown rose from service station attendant to manager in charge of sales accounting and office operations at Shell Oil Company in Southern California. He established the oil industry's first computer operation west of the Mississippi River.
He joined the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in Burbank, Calif., in 1940 to work in manufacturing, engineering and financial operations. He later rose to chief accountant.
During the years he worked with Lockheed Missile, it grew from 150 employees to 31,000.
Mr. Brown earned his bachelor's degree in mathematics and economics in 1926 from the University of Oregon.
He is survived by his wife, the former Margaret Mary Cleveland; a daughter, Peggy Olson of Portland, Ore.; a son, Dennis, of Southern California; eight grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Indicators Post Broad Gain of 1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
In another sign of a possible quickening of the economic recovery, the Government said today that its main forecasting index posted a broad 1 percent advance in August, its biggest rise of the year.
The manufacturing sector appears less robust, however, with two other reports showing relatively little improvement. 
 Despite the unevenness, various analysts said that when combined with other figures over the week, today's results seemed to point to some strengthening in what has been subpar expansion. Housing starts, incomes, help-wanted advertising and even consumer confidence have moved up lately while first-time claims for unemployment insurance have eased.
 
Toward 'Better Growth'
 "It's all pointing in the direction of better growth," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at the Midland Bank in New York.
The jump in the index of leading indicators, which is assembled by the Commerce Department and is meant to forecast the direction of the economy, was not only the biggest since a 1.7 percent surge in December, but it was also the broadest advance in six and a half years.
And since what had initially been reported as a one-tenth of 1 percent decline for July was revised today into a one-tenth of 1 percent increase, there have now been three straight advances. The index also rose one-tenth of a percent in June. Previously there had been seven straight months in which the index had reversed direction from the preceding month.
Ten of the 11 components of the index contributed to the August rise, while only the money supply, which many economists think has become irrelevant as an economic indicator, declined.
Today's second report, from the National Association of Purchasing Management, showed its chief index edged up to 49.7 percent in September from 49.3 percent in August, a bit less than expected.
This was the fourth straight month the index has been below 50 percent, the point that divides an expanding factory sector from a contracting one. Yet as long as the purchasing managers index remains above 44.5 percent -- and it has averaged 51.7 percent during the first three quarters of 1993 -- this indicates an expansion of the economy at large.
 
Factory Orders Climb
 Anticipated growth in new orders failed to appear in September, resulting in a working off of backlogs, said Robert J. Bretz, head of the trade group's survey committee. "However, there was some sign of life in employment and encouragement that prices were decreasing," he added.
In still another report, the Commerce Department found that new orders for factory goods climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent, or $2.2 billion, in August. This was the second increase in the last three months but was not enough to offset July's sharp, 1.9 percent decline.
"We believe the economy is growing, but slowly or moderately," said Edward Guay of the Cigna Corporation, predicting continued drag from higher taxes and uncertainty over health care.
Unfilled orders for factory goods slipped six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the 21st decline in 24 months. The level of unfilled orders is now at the lowest point since July 1988 and the orders-to-shipments ratio is at the lowest level in 15 years.
Shipments, meanwhile, rose 1.5 percent, partly offsetting a 2.6 percent July skid.
The three biggest contributors to the rise in the leading index were higher building permits, lower claims for jobless benefits and higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment. Lesser factors were a rise in companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers, higher stock prices, a longer workweek, rising backlogs of orders for durable factory goods, greater consumer optimism, new orders for consumer goods and higher prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle.
 
Lagging Indicators Rise
 A companion index that usually moves at the same time as the economy rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in August while the department's index of lagging indicators moved up two-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed.
Safian Investment Research, a White Plains firm, reported that its composite index of the real, or nonfinancial, economy gained eight-tenths of 1 percent in August after two flat readings. "It seems we're ready for another step up," said Kenneth Safian of the economy's prospects.
Another private forecasting gauge, one created by David B. Bostian Jr. of Herzog Heine Geduld in New York, rose only to 199 in August from 197. Mr. Bostian said growth would continue "subnormal" as tax increases more than offset the benefit of low interest rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lufthansa And United Deal Is Set

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Culminating a lengthy courtship, United Airlines and Lufthansa will announce on Monday that they are joining forces as marketing partners.
The latest in a long line of airlines to pair off, the two carriers will end months of guessing about which of America's two largest carriers -- United or American Airlines -- Lufthansa would pick. 
 Although the terms of their deal could change before Monday, the plan is for passengers of either carrier to share in the other's frequent-flier program and use either's airport lounges, according to people familiar with the accord's details.
 
 
Code Sharing
 More important, however, the two airlines will also "code share," a term to describe how United would use Lufthansa for the German leg of a trans-Atlantic trip, while Lufthansa would use United for the American leg. By coordinating flights, passengers would receive one flight number for the entire trip, easing travel. Code sharing also gives carriers a competitive advantage on reservation systems, because their flights are the first choice listed on trips that previously required connections with one or more flight numbers.
A decision by Lufthansa was expected, particularly after negotiators for the United States and German Governments settled their disputes last week over an aviation policy that dictated the frequency of flights between the two countries.
That bilateral agreement created provisions for code sharing, rising from 140 flights a week in the first year to 350 a week in the third year.
The United-Lufthansa accord, which is subject to Government approval, adds to the long roster of alliances between United States and foreign airlines seeking to guarantee themselves a percentage of passengers on established routes closed to them by law or on routes that they can enter only at enormous expense. Other partnerships, but with large investments by foreign carriers into United States airlines, include British Airways and USAir, and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Northwest Airlines.
United's stock rose $2.625 a share, to $139.875, yesterday. But industry analysts said that with the sluggish economy in Germany and Europe, the partnership would probably not yield a noteworthy increase in business for the two carriers until late next year. Because the two carriers are not investing money in each other beyond the costs of establishing the partnership, the risk appears minimal. Continental Airlines and Air France have a marketing agreement but no investment or code sharing.
 
 
'Not Much Left'
 Analysts also said the pending announcement left American Airlines with few candidates with which to form a similar alliance. "American is kind of looking for a bouquet, but there's not much left out there that would benefit them," John Stodden, an airline analyst at Duff & Phelps, said.
United and Lufthansa expect to begin code sharing on Jan. 10. Their partnership will present a new competitive threat to Delta Air Lines, which has a large but unprofitable hub in Frankfurt.
United is also expected to announce shortly that NBC News and NBC-TV will begin producing customized news, sports and entertainment programming to be shown on United flights.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Down in Busy Day; Gold Closes Mixed in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell in active trading yesterday with the selling propelled by concerns about the political standoff in Russia and weakness in the domestic manufacturing businesses.
Gold prices closed narrowly mixed in New York trading after falling in Europe. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $355.00 a troy ounce, down 10 cents from Thursday's closing quote of $355.10. 
 Traders said a closely watched report on national business activity contributed to the dollar's demise. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its September index of economic activity was 49.7 percent, which is up slightly from August but still below 50 percent, a sign that the manufacturing sector is declining.
"A lot of people were focused on the U.S. data," said Curtis Perkins, currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation.
Mr. Perkins said many traders sold dollars to readjust their trading positions ahead of the weekend. Conclusion of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings in Washington and signs that President Boris N. Yeltsin may be diffusing a political crisis with the Russian Parliament reduced demand for the dollar, he said.
The dollar has gained as investors sought a safe haven for their investments during the tense 11-day standoff in Russia.
Also hurting the dollar were signs that Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, may not cut interest rates for at least another month, said Earl Johnson, vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
In New York, the dollar closed at 1.6315 German marks, down from 1.6329. In Europe, the dollar fell to 1.6308 German marks, from 1.6350 late Thursday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 106.38 yen, up 1.28 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 106.05 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 105.90 yen, down from 106.30 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.5050, up from $1.4955 late Thursday. In New York, the pound closed at $1.5050, more expensive than $1.4968 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates at 4 P.M., compared with late Thursday, were: 1.4240 Swiss francs, down from 1.4251; 5.6930 French francs, down from 5.6943; 1,593.00 Italian lire, down from 1,592.00, and 1.3379 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3338.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Settles on a Tentative Labor Pact

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation reached a tentative agreement on a three-year labor contract shortly before dawn today.
The pact, which mimics an agreement reached by the Ford Motor Company last week, sets up the union's final round of bargaining, scheduled with the General Motors Corporation next week. 
 Thomas Gallagher, Chrysler's vice president of employee relations, said that with the agreement the auto maker had achieved "a basis for producing world-class vehicles and a basis for discussion of ongoing issues."
Spokesmen from the union, who declined to speak for attribution, acknowledged that the contract approximated terms reached last week with Ford. In that agreement, workers won higher wages and pension benefits, maintained health coverage fully paid by the company and had more company money set aside to pay laid-off workers. But Ford won lower wages for starting workers and longer periods before those workers reach the top of the pay scale.
The Chrysler agreement was reached after the expiration of a strike deadline of 11:59 P.M. Thursday. Last-minute wrangling over the union's insistence on timely notification by Chrysler of any plan to buy parts from nonunion subcontractors caused a short walkout by 6,000 hourly workers at seven Chrysler factories across the nation.
Karen Stewart, a Chrysler spokeswoman, said the walkout cost the company lost production of about 500 vehicles. Work at the affected plants resumed this morning, she said.
Given the average wholesale price of a vehicle, the walkout could mean $5 million to $10 million in lost revenue. But the auto maker said it would try to make up the lost production.
The union is seeking as much notice as possible about plans to buy outside parts. The U.A.W. believes that if it given enough notice it can come up with ways to make outside production unnecessary, like adjusting work rules. Chrysler, seeking lower costs, wants the flexibility to hire new suppliers without having to consult the union. Chrysler makes only 30 percent of its parts, the least of the Big Three. It was not immediately clear whether Chrysler conceded the point or a compromise was reached.
Chrysler union locals must now vote on the contract, probably by early next week. Afterward, negotiations will begin at G.M., the largest auto maker and perhaps the most needful of cost savings among the Big Three.
G.M., which has thousands of workers on long-term layoff, has said it cannot afford extensive job security benefits, which cost it $3.5 billion to $4 billion in the last three years.
Ford and Chrysler have apparently agreed to job security benefits, though it is not clear whether these would apply to G.M. in the same way they did in the last three years.
The opinion that G.M. may have no choice but to accept the union's terms -- reinforced by its tentative settlement with Canadian workers on Wednesday -- was cited as a possible reason for a 10 percent slide in the value of G.M. shares on Wednesday and Thursday.
Gerald Knechtel, G.M.'s chief negotiator, warned of "important differences in underlying economics" between the two G.M. work forces.
The stock recovered some of its value today, however, gaining 75 cents, to $42.50; Chrysler gained $1, to $49, and Ford gained $1.25, to $56.50.

HEADLINE: New Issues Were at Record Pace in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Corporations issued new stocks and bonds at a record pace in the third quarter, producing more than $2.2 billion in fees for securities firms that are in the midst of their third consecutive year of record profits.
After three years of rising stock prices and falling interest rates, the financial markets are as hospitable as many corporate treasurers have ever seen. Increasingly, American investors' strong demand is attracting foreign borrowers. Italy, for example, sold about 30 percent of its $5.5 billion global bond offering to Americans earlier this month, and YPF Sociedad, the Argentine oil company, had a $3 billion stock offering in late July that was bought largely by investors in America and Europe. 
 "The usual seasonal slowdown in late July and August was not much of an issue this year," Samuel Liss, a brokerage industry analyst at Salomon Brothers, said. The heavy financing volume and increased trading indicated that third-quarter profits for securities dealers would be well above last year's, and probably slightly better than the records set in the second quarter of this year, Mr. Liss said.
 
 
Same Firms
 The new business has largely been handled by the same firms that have long dominated Wall Street. Merrill Lynch; Goldman, Sachs, and Lehman Brothers ranked first, second and third, respectively, in corporate stocks and bonds -- the same as a year earlier. Kidder, Peabody remained the leader by a wide margin in handling new issues of mortgage-backed securities, while Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette was the leading underwriter of junk bonds by a narrow margin, up from an eighth-place ranking a year earlier.
In the stock market, according to Securities Data Company, new corporate share offerings continued at a near record pace, although the third- quarter total of $20.6 billion was down slightly from $21.3 billion in the second quarter. Through the first nine months of the year, share offerings, including new issues of closed-end mutual funds, totaled $59.2 billion, up 29 percent from a year earlier, while the number of stock offerings rose to 931 from 760.
Among 171 companies making their debut in the public stock market last quarter, new issues totaled $9.4 billion, down from $10.9 billion in the second quarter, when 153 companies came to market. Through the first nine months of this year, however, initial public offerings totaled $27.6 billion, up 43 percent from the 1992 period.
In the bond market, issuance of all kinds of securities was at or near record levels, with $252.9 billion of securities sold in the quarter, up 19 percent from a year earlier.
 Although new corporate bond issues totaled a record $346.1 billion in the first nine months, investment bankers noted that many companies have still not taken full advantage of bond interest rates, which are the lowest in more than 20 years. Many strong potential issuers are on the sidelines, happily borrowing in the commercial paper market or from banks at less than 3.5 percent, rather than selling new bonds at rates of 5.25 percent to 7.25 percent, depending on maturity and the company's rating.
With many economists predicting continued low inflation and low interest rates, "a lot of people are very comfortable and think they can delay their bond financings with impunity," the head of bond underwriting for a big Wall Street firm said.
Investment bankers noted that some industrial companies were not refinancing their old bonds because the terms of the old, high-interest issues would require a company to incur a one-time charge against its earnings. That is less of a problem for electric and gas utilities, whose regulators allow them to include that cost as part of the new issue.
There is a strong herd instinct in the corporate bond market, where one financing pattern will quickly be imitated by many companies. Securities dealers are now waiting to see if more companies will follow the GTE Corporation, which recently announced plans to refinance $2.1 billion of existing bonds even though it means a $90 million charge for the third quarter. The company expects eventually to save $250 million by selling bonds with lower interest rates.
 
 
Yankee Bonds
 While some some American companies are waiting, more foreign borrowers are coming to the American market. Yankee bonds -- those offered in the American market by foreign governments or companies -- totaled $48.2 billion in the first nine months, up 52 percent from a year earlier. Stock offerings by foreign companies also increased, with a record $3.1 billion sold in the third quarter. The total for the first nine months was $6.9 billion, 47 percent greater than the 1992 period.
Bradley Jack, head of bond underwriting at Lehman Brothers, said foreign issuers are finding "that in the American market their securities get placed with real institutional investors, as opposed to the Eurobond market, which is more retail."
Jessica A. Palmer, a managing director at Salomon Brothers, said that many foreign companies were attracted to the American market because American investors' experience with junk bonds had made them more accustomed to evaluating risk, and American investors were not so enamored of well-known corporate names as investors in foreign markets.

HEADLINE: Japanese Starting to Link Pay To Performance, Not Tenure

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 1

 BODY:
In Japanese festivals, dozens of people together hoist a heavy portable shrine, known as a mikoshi, and chant as they carry it through the streets. Since it is impossible to tell who is actually doing the lifting, it is only natural that some shrine carriers shirk off, shifting more weight onto others.
Japanese companies, too, have what is called "mikoshi management." People work as a group and the achievers often carry the laggards along. Salary depends much more on how long one has worked for the company than on how much one contributes to it. 
 Now, however, Japanese companies are departing from the seniority-based pay system and introducing merit pay, in which those who perform better are paid more and promoted faster. The idea is both to save on labor costs and to promote individual accountability.
 
 
Setting Specific Goals
 It is a drastic change for corporate Japan, where job responsibilities are usually defined vaguely and management is by consensus. Now managers at companies like Honda, Fujitsu and Fujisawa Pharmaceutical are having to write specific goals for the coming year and are being held accountable for how well they meet them.
At Honda, merit pay now affects 4,500 managers, about 10 percent of its Japanese work force. Starting last December, bonuses, which can account for 40 percent of annual salary, were linked to performance, with the difference between the best and the worst performers being about 1 million yen, or $10,000.
"Japanese employees have never been faced with their own performance in such a direct way," said Shigeru Tanaka, general manager for Japan of Hay Management Consultants, a Washington-based consulting firm that develops corporate compensation plans.
Merit pay is only one of the changes sweeping Japan as a result of a severe economic slump. While Japanese companies are known for factory-floor efficiency, they are realizing that their white-collar work forces are too big and inefficient.
The annual raise, also something of a tradition, is under attack as well. Some executives are saying that unions should accept a wage reduction when contracts are negotiated next spring.
And Japan's most famous labor institution, lifetime employment, is also fraying. Companies are finding it hard to continue to keep "window-sitters," people who are given no useful work to do but collect a salary anyway. More people are being asked to retire early, and some analysts expect that if the current slump continues large companies will announce sweeping layoffs, as in the United States.
"These unique Japanese systems were a plus during the era of high economic growth," said Toru Katsurada, a director and head of personnel for Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer company. "But now we are going into an era where we can't expect growth anymore."
If merit pay catches on, some executives say, it could allow companies to better use their high achievers, who now have to wait in line for promotions and raises behind older but less capable people. At some companies, inefficient workers actually take home more pay than efficient ones because they have to put in more overtime to finish their tasks.
 
 
Concern About Cohesion
 But others warn that merit pay could ruin group harmony. And it could lead to more short-term thinking -- something Japanese executives have long criticized American companies for -- as managers shift their attention from long-term planning to meeting next year's targets.
In Japanese companies, new recruits enter directly out of high school or college. Each member of the class tends to start at roughly the same salary, now about $33,000 a year, including bonuses, for male college graduates, and advance up the scale together. By age 55, their salaries are roughly three times what they started with. Salary is so closely tied to seniority that securities analysts can get a good idea of a company's labor costs just by looking at the average age of its employees.
Promotions are also geared to seniority, although there is some latitude for high achievers to rise faster. At Fujitsu, for instance, there are cases in which younger people are in charge of older people. But the older subordinates still get paid more than their younger boss, in line with the seniority system.
The seniority system works best in the system of lifetime employment. Young workers tend to receive lower salaries than their abilities would dictate. But they make it up later in their careers, when salaries rise to help them cope with family expenses, even if they are no longer working at their peak.
Now, with fewer young people entering the work force because of Japan's low birth rate, companies are finding their overall work forces are aging.
"If we keep the seniority system, the weight of wages in our cost will become larger and larger," said Koichi Sejima, director of human resources development for the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company.
Still, traditions in Japan die hard and the movement toward merit pay is gradual. A survey of 500 companies by the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations found that 14.6 percent of such companies had merit pay systems in 1992, up from 10.4 percent a year earlier. Most companies that are trying the system are limiting it, for now at least, to top managers.
One of Japan's largest manufacturers this year started a merit pay system for workers at the general manager's level and above, one official at the company said. Next year's pay for these managers will be 80 to 120 percent of this year's, depending on performance. But the company is keeping it a secret because it does not want to alarm younger workers.
There has also been some resistance from older workers, who say they put up with lower salaries when they were young and expect their payoff now. Unions have also expressed concern about the fairness of the evaluations.
"We think salaries have to be at a level to support one's family, which cannot vary drastically among individuals," said Hideaki Narikawa, deputy head of the labor policy bureau of the Japanese Trade Union Confederation. He also said unions were concerned that salary reductions under a merit-pay system would be used to harass employees, forcing them to quit.
So far, however, it has been difficult for companies to actually cut salaries, since this would be a crushing blow to an employee. The result has been that for companies introducing merit pay, labor costs actually go up, not down, because they pay more to good performers without penalizing bad ones.
"It is a Japanese characteristic that people do not tell others that they have low ability," Mr. Katsurada of Fujitsu said. "The tendency is that everyone should be at the center of the scale. There would be some A's, but mostly B's and C's, and very rarely a D or E. Japanese people cannot take a D or an E."
He said Fujitsu viewed its new merit pay system not as a way to reduce labor costs, but as a means of improving productivity.
Even between the A's and the D's there is not a great salary difference. Japanese companies are still far from the situation that might be found, say, on Wall Street, where a 30-year-old might make millions of dollars after developing a sophisticated computerized trading program for his company.
Fujisawa Pharmaceutical started its system in 1990 and applies it only to its 130 department heads. Salary is based on three evaluations: rank; expectation, a somewhat vague concept having to do with responsibilities, and achievement.
For two managers of the same rank and expectation, the one who gets a top grade in achievement (S, for "super") will earn about $20,000 more than one who gets the lowest grade, a C.
 
 
Rating the Boss
 To try to preserve group harmony, one criterion for evaluation is often how well a person works with others. NOF, a chemical company, seeks the opinions of a manager's subordinates as well as those of his boss. Five underlings of each department head are asked to rate their boss anonymously on questions like whether he keeps his temper and whether he scolds subordinates when necessary.
Merit pay could unleash a bigger change in the Japanese work force -- encouraging workers to move from one company to another.
The seniority system rewards people for staying with one company and limits a company's ability to offer special incentives to snatch an employee from another company. The exception has been foreign companies, which often offer higher pay and greater rank or responsibilities to recruit employees of Japanese companies who are frustrated with their low pay and slow advancement under the seniority system.
But merit pay in a sense begins to put a market value on mid-career employees. If a worker bargains with his own company, why not with others?

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REVIEW: TAXES;
Watch for Distributions As Year Winds Down

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
NOVICE mutual fund investors can slide into tax traps, particularly in the fourth quarter. But with a modicum of knowledge about how funds work, they can play the tax laws to their own advantage.
Funds distribute three kinds of income to shareholders: capital gains the fund has received selling securities in its portfolio, dividends paid by securities it holds and interest earned on bonds or similar holdings. An investor who sells fund shares at a profit also earns capital gains directly. 
 Conversely, an investor who sells fund shares at a loss will have a capital loss. But if the fund itself incurs a capital loss in selling securities, it cannot by law distribute that loss to shareholders. It must carry the loss forward to offset future capital gains.
Once a mutual fund distributes capital gains and dividends -- most funds do so late in the year -- its net asset value, which is the price at which it trades, drops by the amount distributed.
This simple fact is at the heart of tax planning for fund investors. Say a stock fund's net asset value is $20 a share. It distributes capital gains of $1.50 a share and dividends of 50 cents a share, both of which are taxable, and its net asset value immediately drops to $18 a share.
"Someone who buys into a fund just before a distribution can get hit with a big tax bite without any economic benefit," said Joel S. Isaacson, president of his own financial and tax management firm, Joel Isaacson & Company, New York. Consequently, he advises calling a fund and checking on the distribution date before buying shares.
Mr. Isaacson also recommends that shareholders check with theirfunds in October or November to find out what the outlook is for capital gains distributions. If a distribution is coming, they may want to take an offsetting loss before the end of the year on any stocks or fund shares that are lagging, he said.
"A lot of funds sold growth stocks this year -- Philip Morris, Wal-Mart, drug companies -- in which they had a very low basis, so there will be significant capital gains," Mr. Isaacson said. "A lot of novice investors have gone into funds this year," he added, and they may be surprised to get a Form 1099 in January reporting a significant capital gains distribution even though their fund's net asset value has changed little. The distribution is taxable, of course, even if it is automatically reinvested in fund shares, unless an investor has offsetting losses.
Tax-free bond funds may also have taxable capital gains distributions if they have traded bonds profitably. Only the interest on the municipal bonds they hold is tax-free.
Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based fund manager, said his firm, like several other large fund managers, now provides shareholders with an October advisory on the outlook for capital gains distributions. It also provides taxpayers with calculations on their average cost for use at tax time, a real time-saver for people who have failed to keep records.
Taxpayers are allowed to report share sales using several methods, including average cost; first in, first out, and specific shares. For the third method investors need careful records of each fund purchase, including shares bought through reinvested dividends and capital gains. Vincent D. Vaccaro, the partner in charge of personal financial planning for the New York office of Coopers & Lybrand, said that "specific identification gives you the best ability to pick and choose a gain or loss." He also observed that funds' annual distributions offered upper-income taxpayers "a technique of converting ordinary income into capital gains."
Buy right after the dividend distribution date, he said, "and ride up, then sell right before." "Of course, there is market risk, but it is attractive for an upper-income taxpayer," he added, because the top rate on ordinary income is 39.6 percent, while that on capital gains is 28 percent. A no-load growth or aggressive growth fund would be appropriate.
Sam Freedman, chairman of Oppenheimer Shareholder Services, said that because of the higher tax rates, upper-income investors were moving into growth stock funds to get as much income as possible from capital gains, and in the bond area were turning to municipal bond funds. But Social Security recipients need to be careful, he said, because even tax-exempt income is included in determining whether Social Security is taxable.

HEADLINE: The Real Costs of Mideast Peace

 BODY:
After a rousing sermon, the astute preacher passes the plate. So, after the historic Rabin-Arafat handshake, the Clinton Administration yesterday raised more than $2 billion in pledges of international aid for Palestinians, including an unexpected $100 million offer from Saudi Arabia.
That's a splendid start. But open borders and freer trade are what will truly make the West Bank bloom. On that score, Israel's Arab neighbors still seem unwilling to take the smallest risk for peace. 
 In talks at the United Nations, Secretary of State Christopher was rebuffed when he urged Arab states to end their 45-year economic boycott of Israel. All Arab states are supposed to boycott any company doing business with Israel, though the stricture is often circumvented. Even so, Israel loses around $1 billion a year.
Israel long ago learned to work around the boycott; it has nurtured a high-tech economy with a vibrant growth rate. Fortified by Russian immigrants, the Israeli work force has an excess of doctors and engineers in a region where such skills are sorely needed.
So whom does the boycott most punish? The moderate Arab states that persist in maintaining it deny their own people jobs and trade, and deepen the despair that breeds pro-Iranian zealots.
The West Bank urgently needs schools, roads, hospitals. Nearly a million people are crammed into the impoverished Gaza Strip, where only the population seems to grow. The World Bank estimates that annual aid of $400 to $500 million is essential to show quick benefits from peace.
On paper at least, yesterday's pledging party has reached that target. In addition to Saudi Arabia's generous offer, the European Community promises $600 million over five years, Japan pledges $200 million over two years, and the Nordic countries have earmarked $150 million in several years.
The U.S. pledge of $500 million in five years was achieved by juggling grants and loans, shuffling programs and assuming that Congress will concur. Yet close legislative scrutiny is needed. Americans have already provided a disproportionate share of the aid flowing to Israel and Egypt after the Camp David accord; this mustn't become a habit. And Congress must make sure the aid reaches West Bank Palestinians, not the P.L.O.'s bureaucrats.
In a glowing moment, an elected Government of Israel has offered a $75 million down payment to help a Palestinian people whose very existence was once denied by Israeli leaders. When will other Persian Gulf states follow the Saudi lead in offering aid? And when will all Arab states end a pointless and self-punishing boycott?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Legislative Infant, Needing Care

 BODY:
Two years ago Congress established a modest but imaginative program to underwrite the overseas study of critical non-Western languages like Arabic, Chinese and Japanese. It would plug a huge hole in America's education system.
Some Congressmen voted for the bill in the belief that America's intelligence failures over the years had been caused partly by the shortage of people qualified in non-traditional languages and area studies. Others, looking to the future, hoped the program would sharpen America's skills in a competitive global economy. 
 The bill, the National Security Education Act, authorized a $150 million trust fund from which $24 million would be drawn the first year and distributed in three parts: as scholarships to undergraduates; as fellowships to graduate students, repayable with a year of teaching or government service, and as grants to universities and other institutions for foreign language and area studies.
The legislation was conceived and shepherded through Congress by Senator David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma; indeed, the scholarships will bear Mr. Boren's name if they are ever fully funded. Right now, that's a very big if. The Senate has approved the program, but the House Intelligence Committee, in a fit of pique in June, voted to scrap it. Many of the negative votes were aimed not at the program but at Senator Boren, who had made enemies among fellow Democrats for his opposition to President Clinton's economic program.
Mr. Boren was fair game for criticism, but America's students hardly deserved the committee's chosen retribution. The program addresses an obvious shortcoming. If administered with care and exacting standards, its monies will fall like rain on a desert. Senate and House conferees are scheduled to meet early next week. The hope here is that the House conferees will accede to the Senate, thereby allowing an exceptionally sound idea to go forward.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REVIEW;
A Sizzling Third-Quarter Performance, at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Investors may be living dangerously, but what a living. As skepticism mounted in the third quarter about whether the rallies in the stock and bond markets could continue, mutual funds posted especially strong returns.
They were aided by a surge in stocks of small companies and continuing declines in interest rates, both domestically and abroad.
Funds that invest in stocks of American companies turned in their best performance of the year. The average domestic stock fund had a total return of 5 percent in the latest quarter, more than twice the return in the second quarter. Foreign stock funds did even better, returning 8.8 percent. 
 Taxable bond funds returned 2.1 percent in the third quarter, the same as the previous quarter. And municipal bond funds returned 3 percent, down from 3.3 percent.
The total return figures, which are calculated by Morningstar Inc., a research company in Chicago, combine the gain or loss on the mutual funds' shares with the dividends or interest the funds paid in the quarter. The returns omit sales charges.
The stock funds again did better than the Standard & Poor's 500 index, a broad gauge of large company stocks, which returned 2.9 percent in the quarter. While most mutual funds underperformed this index during the 1980's, they have beaten it more recently by investing in smaller companies, the most active segment of the market. In fact, the Wilshire Small Capitalization Index, representing stocks of 250 smaller companies, had a total quarterly return of 7.1 percent.
It's no surprise then that among domestic general stock funds, those that invest in small companies posted the best performance in the quarter, with a total return of 8.6 percent. Aggressive growth funds, which also largely invest in smaller companies, were a close second. Growth funds, which can invest in any stocks, returned 5.1 percent, up sharply from 1.1 percent in the second quarter.
Among specialty stock funds, the winners were financial services funds, which rose 9.9 percent. Precious metals funds were the big losers, falling 10.4 percent. The two groups effectively reversed positions from the second quarter, when metal funds shot up 31.4 percent on a gold bubble and financial services funds fell by 1.8 percent because of a temporary correction in bank stocks.
Technology stock funds did well in both quarters and racked up the best one-year return figure.
The fall in European interest rates after the summer currency turmoil helped funds that invest in European stocks post an 8.7 percent return in the third quarter, nearly as high as the 9.6 percent return for Pacific stock funds. In the second quarter, European funds lagged far behind Pacific funds.
Among individual stock funds, the top performer was Smith Barney Shearson Special Equities, which invests in small rapidly growing companies. Its major holdings include Calloway Golf, a club maker, and Electronic Arts, a video game company. Although the fund is up 72.2 percent in the last 12 months, George Novello, the fund's manager, says he expects the trend to continue. "We try to buy companies that transcend the market and won't be sensitive to the current economic malaise or potentially higher interest rates," he said. Moreover, Mr. Novello, a former food analyst for E.F. Hutton, said he expected the bull market in small company stocks to continue for several years.
Many of the top-rated funds have what is called a momentum strategy that searches out rapidly rising stocks, often looking for earnings that have exceeded expectations. The fourth-rated Twentieth Century Giftrust, which is meant for long-term gifts to minors or charities, uses such a technique.
The Invesco Strategic Leisure fund, ranked No. 2 for the quarter, invests in a wide range of companies related to leisure time, including the fast-growing cable television and cellular phone industries. Fidelity Select Home Finance, No. 3, has ridden the revival in fortunes in savings and loans and banks. GAM International, ranked fifth, focuses on blue-chip foreign stocks, mostly in Europe.
Before rushing out to buy one of the top-rated funds, investors should consider the fate of Lexington Strategic Investments, the No. 1 fund last quarter, when it returned 82.5 percent. A gold fund, Lexington lost 12.8 percent in the third quarter, finishing fourth from last. Despite that loss, it remains the top-performing fund for the last 12 months.
Investors interested in a purely contrarian play might consider the Yacktman Fund, the worst-performing fund over the last year, with a negative total return of 9.7 percent. Founded a little over a year ago, it is managed by Donald Yacktman, who had run the highly successful Selected American Shares fund. Mr. Yacktman likes pharmaceutical, food and tobacco companies, the sort of blue- chip stocks that are out of favor now.
Among bond funds, the best performance continued to be by funds with the longest maturities, because these investments gained the most as interest rates fell. Treasury funds, which generally invest in long-term bonds, led the domestic category.
The Benham Target Maturity 2020 fund, which buys only long-term zero-coupon Treasury bonds, gained 17.5 percent in the quarter. Zero-coupon bonds are the most sensitive to interest rate movements because they pay no current interest, and they are sold at deep discounts to their face value.
International bond funds performed even better because of falling interest rates.
 The article also misstated the third-quarter performance of Lexington Strategic Investments, a gold fund. Lexington Strategic lost 10.87 percent in the quarter, not 12.8 percent, finishing 10th from last in mutual fund performance in the period, not fourth from last.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Your Money on Oct. 2 about the quarterly performance of mutual funds misstated the average return on taxable bond funds in the second quarter of this year. It was 2.6 percent (2.1 percent was the average return posted in the third quarter).

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REVIEW;
A Pioneer of Mutual Funds Takes a Look at Today

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLEY FORGE, Pa.

 BODY:
Walter L. Morgan, a young Philadelphia accountant, had just founded one of the first American mutual funds when stocks rose to dizzying heights in the summer of 1929. His portfolio was heavily invested in common stocks, including such speculative favorites as Curtis Publishing at about $125 a share and U.S. Steel at more than $250.
Applying the then-novel idea that adding bonds to stocks for "balance" would create a fund that could better withstand bear markets, he and his fledgling Wellington Fund survived the ensuing stock crash and Depression. 
 "We had chosen the worst time in the financial history of the United States to launch a new investment vehicle," Mr. Morgan observed many years later. "Yet in another way what good fortune we had to launch a conservative fund just a few brief months before the merits of conservative investing were to be so amply demonstrated."
The founder not only of the first balanced mutual fund but also of the Vanguard empire, whose 76 funds now have $120 billion in assets, Mr. Morgan has been a keen observer of market gyrations. Though he retired from active management in 1970 and his pace has slowed, the 95-year-old mutual fund pioneer still spends two mornings a week at the Vanguard Group's new building here.
 He boasts of no particular skill in predicting market turns nor does he believe that anybody can do it consistently. But he talks -- and to some extent, acts -- like a bear nowadays.
 The Wellington Fund, a $7.4 billion giant, is riding the crest of decade-long bull markets in both stocks and bonds after an era of high-flying stocks and rising interest rates in which its performance was lackluster and its image stodgy.
Yet Mr. Morgan, like many others, is feeling a bit queasy from the securities markets' lofty heights. The events of recent days remind him a bit of the summer of 1929, when he watched stocks become "hysterically" overpriced and then decided to sell heavily at prices that many issues have not seen since.
The proceeds from those sales were put into bonds. Fixed-income securities accounted for about 40 percent of the fund's assets when the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted in October 1929.
Not even bonds, his one-time savior, can be counted on for stability now, he said in a recent interview.
 "I'm scared to death of bonds, as a matter of fact, with the low yield they have now," said Mr. Morgan, a salty, eighth-generation descendant of an early Welsh colonist with family ties to David Rittenhouse and other prominent regional families. "Anybody going into 30-year bonds, they may lose their shirt."
An occasional confidant of Warren E. Buffett, the fabulously successful Omaha investor, Mr. Morgan also frets about the money pouring into "speculative" stock mutual funds at price-earnings multiples that remind him of the 1920's.
"The main difference, I would say, is everything was leveraged then," he said. "They not only bought stocks at 60 times earnings," Mr. Morgan observed, but setbacks were magnified by margin calls that generated fresh waves of selling.
Since a far smaller proportion of stock is bought with borrowed money these days, a self-reinforcing crash is less likely. Unless, of course, panic sets in among the millions of investors who, shunning minuscule yields on certificates of deposit and money market funds, have been lured into stock market purchases for the first time.
Mr. Morgan's own fortune, which he conservatively puts at "several million" dollars, remains mainly in the Derwell Company, a personal holding company whose investment portfolio reflects Mr. Morgan's advanced age and tax bracket as much as his view of the various securities markets.
His personal assets are about 80 percent in "seniors," mostly tax-exempt notes and bond issues, and 15 to 20 percent in equities, Mr. Morgan said.
"That doesn't mean I think the market is going to hell," he said, only that a man in his mid-90's who was at Princeton with F. Scott Fitzgerald tends to put a premium on liquidity. Indeed, Mr. Morgan says continued corporate restructuring in America may result in profits "better than people think."
Mr. Morgan obviously has made his share of stock coups over the years. Derwell shares, worth slightly more than $200 each by recent calculations, carry a cost basis of a mere 10 cents, he said. That performance, in a percentage increase, appears to put him in the same league as the acclaimed Mr. Buffett.
Among the stocks that have treated him well over the years, he said, are the insurance companies Geico and Safeco as well as the oil giants Royal Dutch/Shell and Texaco and various bank companies.
His adroit handling of the 1987 crash didn't hurt either. Repeating his successful pre-Depression strategy, he reduced Derwell's equity exposure just before stocks dove in October that year.
Although Mr. Morgan, who has endured what he describes as 11 "major" operations and nine eye operations, has had to give up hunting and fishing as well as driving, he keeps well versed on the political and financial issues of the day.
Earlier this year, when Congress was considering a measure it eventually passed to exempt gifts of appreciated stock from the alternative minimum tax, Mr. Morgan wrote to Hillary Rodham Clinton, then drafting the Administration's health care plan, to point out that this proposal would benefit health-oriented charities. He has also spoken against taxing capital gains at death.
Asked to give some market advice, Mr. Morgan demurred. When pressed, however, he said that as a general principle, younger investors "might want to have 50 percent in stocks."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Your Money on Oct. 2 about Walter L. Morgan, a pioneer in the mutual fund business, misstated his relationship to the Vanguard Group. Mr. Morgan founded the Wellington Management Company, which ultimately became part of Vanguard. John C. Bogle established the Vanguard Group.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REVIEW;
Latin America. Eastern Europe. Smaller Investors Expand Reach

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
Americans' hot romance with foreign stock funds shows no sign of cooling off.
"The American investor has always had an interest in foreign funds, but it's been heightened," said John R. Horseman, investment manager of Global Asset Management's International Fund, in a telephone interview from his London office. "As we go into 1994, increasingly, that investor is looking around and putting bigger shares of money outside" the United States. 
 Witness the popularity of foreign and global stock funds this year. Funds that invest only abroad have taken in $12.3 billion through August, versus $4.1 billion in the comparable period last year, the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, said this week. The funds held $44.2 billion at the end of August, double their level a year earlier.
For global funds -- which invest in the United States as well as abroad -- the cash inflow more than quadrupled during the first eight months to $5.6 billion from $1.2 billion in the period a year earlier. The global funds' assets rose to $32.2 billion from $18.3 billion during the 12 months ended in August.
"Foreign funds have gotten the eye of the small investor," said John Collins, a spokesman for the Investment Company Institute in Washington, the mutual fund trade group.
Several factors make foreign funds attractive. As more countries switch from socialist to free-market economies, stock markets all over the globe are springing to life. Government-run utilities, oil companies and banks are going private, carrying with them all the possibilities and pitfalls of capitalism. Developing countries are also harnessing inflation and showing glimmers of economic growth.
During the third quarter, funds invested in Latin America and developing countries generally surged, as did funds with diverse international holdings, according to a list of top foreign funds compiled by Morningstar, the mutual fund rating company in Chicago.
 The sizzle in emerging markets, which are defined by the World Bank, came from stocks in Brazil and in the Pacific Rim. Emerging markets funds remain heavily weighted to the Pacific Rim and, to a lesser extent, Latin America.
"A lot of them are nibbling at Eastern Europe," said Eileen Sanders, who follows the category for Morningstar. A few are even looking to Africa.
Over all, developing countries are expected to post average economic growth of 5.2 percent this decade, compared with 3.1 percent for developed countries. Those higher growth rates are expected to translate into higher corporate profits and thus stronger stock market performance.
The emerging markets funds surged last year because of economic growth in the Pacific Rim, Ms. Sanders said. The Fidelity Emerging Markets fund, for example, had $213.5 million in assets at the end of August, up from from just $6.8 million at the end of 1991.
Because many of these funds are new, it's difficult to draw any conclusions about their long-term performance. "They can be risky, but total returns can be quite attractive," Ms. Sanders said. "One of these funds has a place in an investment portfolio, but only a small portion."
In the developed world, the loosening of Europe's currency controls in July led to select stock and bond market rallies in the third quarter. Fund managers expect investor interest in Europe to continue as more countries cut interest rates, spurring economic recoveries and making stocks and bonds more attractive.
Mr. Horseman of Global Asset Management said his International Fund was focusing on the German housing industry, expecting it to benefit from falling interest and inflation rates and construction in the former East Germany. In the last quarter, the fund benefited from investments in water utilities in Britain.
Among the top-performing foreign funds, the International Fund is one of the most heavily weighted in Europe. About three-quarters of its assets are in Europe, with the remainder in Asia.
Latin American stock funds are having a strong year, driven by the privatization of industries and the easing of trade restrictions. Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc.'s Latin America fund has zoomed to the top five among foreign funds since its debut in December.
William F. Truscott, a Scudder vice president and co-manager of its Argentina fund, attributed the new fund's performance mostly to heavy investments in Brazil at the beginning of the year. "The market is probably up 100 percent," he said. "What also helped us in August was an increasing weighting in Argentina, which is doing well, and in Mexico."
The next markets of interest in Latin America will be Venezuela, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Chile, Mr. Truscott said.
Although the North American Free Trade Agreement remains controversial in the United States and far from a sure thing in Congress, fund managers play down its importance.
J. Mark Mobius, director of Templeton Funds' Far East division and manager of its emerging markets portfolio, said, "The integration of the United States and Mexico economies is taking place already and will continue regardless of what Congress says."
Mr. Truscott referred to Mexico as a great long-term investment. "Quite frankly, in the long run, Nafta is meaningless," he said. He conceded, however, that "if Congress is not enlightened enough to pass it, it may create some volatility in the Mexican market."
While interest grows in foreign funds, investment managers emphasize that their funds are for investors with a long-term horizon, and equities in Latin America and emerging markets have a history of volatility. In addition, returns depend in part on exchange rates between the dollar and local currencies.
"Potential investment in Latin America has to be thinking in terms of five to seven years," Mr. Truscott said. "We think this is going to be the beginning of a very strong story, but there could be some bumps along the road."
