HEADLINE: World Markets;
A New Coffee Cartel Tries Its Hand

BYLINE: By James Brooke

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
WORLD coffee producers could well have cheered last week: "King Coffee is dead -- long live King Coffee."
On Monday, the United States pulled out of the International Coffee Organization, driving a coffin nail into the 30-year-old consumer and producer forum. 
 Rising two weeks ago to take the place of that forum, the Association of Coffee Producing Countries started Friday to shore up prices by holding back 20 percent of its planned exports. Formed in Brasilia, the group of 28 coffee-growing nations produces 85 percent of the world crop.
But will a coffee cartel bring stability and stronger prices to a volatile market?
After the last International Coffee Agreement expired in July 1989, prices plunged, hitting a historic low of 48 cents a pound in August 1992. Prices rallied to 84 cents last December, then fell to 52 cents in April.
After the Association of Coffee Producing Countries started to take shape three months ago, prices increased by about 40 percent. Last week, prices declined 9.4 percent, with coffee for December delivery closing on Friday at 73.50 cents a pound, compared with 81.10 cents a pound a week earlier.
"It's been a case of buy on rumor, sell on fact," said Lawrence Eagles, a coffee analyst for GNI Ltd., a London futures broker. "Now the market is looking at the negative side, saying stocks are high. We don't know if this retention scheme will hold."
Mr. Eagles predicted that coffee prices would hover around 70 cents a pound during the next few weeks.
From New York, Sandra Kaul, an industry analyst at Smith, Barney Shearson, predicted that coffee would rise to the 90-cent level in November and December, peak demand months in the Northern Hemisphere.
"Last year, there was a low crop," Ms. Kaul said. "This year, production did not rebound as expected."
Indeed, more powerful than a retention plan run largely on the honor system, international coffee supply is drifting down to meet demand. In Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer and a nation in which 10 million people work in the coffee industry, low prices have had catastrophic effects. Since prices started to tumble four years ago, an estimated 2 million coffee workers have lost their jobs and about 20 percent of the nation's coffee bushes have been uprooted. Economists here say Brazil has lost $2.5 billion because of low prices.
Protesting worldwide producer losses of an estimated $10 billion since 1989, demonstrators last week marched outside the London headquarters of the International Coffee Organization. The protesters carried an enormous, empty coffee cup.
Brazil has seen its production drop by about 23 percent in four years, from 31 million sacks to an estimated 24 million sacks in the crop year that officially ended on Thursday. Each sack weighs 132 pounds.
Colombia, the world's second-largest producer, has registered a drop of about 19 percent. From a record crop of 18 million bags three years ago, Colombia's crop this year was 14.6 million bags, the country's National Federation of Coffee Growers said on Friday.
In Africa, the world's second-largest coffee producing area, production has fallen by about 17 percent over the last six years. Production in Asia and Central America has remained relatively stable over recent years.
"World coffee production is now inferior to world consumption," said Manoel Vicente Bertone, president of Brazil's National Coffee Council, a producers' group.
Mr. Bertone said he was not fazed by the high level of coffee stocks in consumer nations. These stocks are currently about 19 million bags, virtually double normal levels.
"This excess is concentrated in the United States," he said in reference to stocks that are considered adequate to supply American coffee drinkers for a six-month period. "But the Europeans and the Japanese will have to buy. World coffee prices will easily rise to 90 cents."
At that level, coffee producers will not have to worry about the enforceability of their retention plan.
Under the plan, which was adopted on Sept. 24, member countries are expected to retain 20 percent of what they exported between last Friday and Oct. 28. After that, the plan will be regulated by a 20-day average of coffee prices.
If the average price falls below 75 cents a pound, countries plan to continue to hold back 20 percent of their anticipated exports. If prices are between 75 cents and 80 cents a pound, they plan to hold back 10 percent. Above 80 cents, they plan no retention.
"We want stability and prices above 80 cents -- below 80 cents, we lose money," said Salim Janna, North American representative of Colombia's coffee growers' federation. About 10 percent of Colombia's 33 million people depend on coffee for their livelihood.
To put teeth into the plan, the Association of Coffee Producing Countries plans to select an auditing company in October to monitor whether each member country is complying. Under a punishment system, a producing country that violates the agreement would have to retain twice as much coffee during the next quarter.
"The market wants to see how solid the retention scheme really is," said Mr. Eagles, who noted that the International Coffee Organization used to involve consumer countries in policing producers' export quotas. "Without consumer involvement, this is an honesty plan."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 26 - October 1

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Can Anything Resist Hillary Clinton? Time Will Tell
 
An irresistible force met an immovable body last week; at press time, the world had not ended. First, one very powerful force, Hillary Rodham Clinton by name, stormed Capitol Hill in search of support for "health security," and even the crustiest of pols were moved to applaud her. But a day later the health plan hit a wall called the American Medical Association. After working quietly to shape the plan, the A.M.A. suddenly went public with a long list of gripes, complaining, for example, that "physicians will be given financial incentives to provide less care." Lawmakers no doubt heard this loud and clear, for doctors are big political contributors. Well, no one said it would be easy. 

The Open Road Inc.
 
This doesn't make sense. Our Government tells us that a private health care system has failed and that Washington can do it better. But in the next breath the Government -- in the person of Rodney Slater, its top highway official -- proposed last week that private businesses run parts of the Interstate System, using tolls to pay for repairs. In other words, bureaucracy-laden Uncle Sam cannot possibly do it as efficiently as the private sector can. So, does the Government know how to do things or not? Maybe this is the answer: All involved say privatizing the highways -- which has the backing of Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena -- would mean higher tolls. So when drivers start yelling, Washington -- which gets yelled at for everything else -- would be able to smile innocently and point the finger at Acme Tunnels and Tolls Inc.
 
Mending the U.S. Pension Net
 
First, health security; now the Administration wants citizens to have pension security, too. They certainly don't have it now. Pension underfunding -- the gap between pension promises and pension cash -- stands at about $45 billion, mainly in industries like steel and autos. And if the burden falls on the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, that badly drained Federal agency could be ripe for a bailout. Last week Labor Secretary Robert Reich proposed legislation to strengthen pension insurance by raising premiums for the weakest plans. But the delicate problem is that companies with the weakest plans can least afford a premium increase.
 
Efficient Cars: The U.S. Signs On
 
As you pay your income taxes, do you ever think wistfully of those billions that vanished into "Star Wars" or other ultrafancy cold-war weapons? The Government wants to do a bit of recycling. Last week the White House and the Big Three auto makers put their wrenches together and said that if Washington gave Detroit that weapons technology and other help, Detroit would try, within a decade, to build cars with triple the current fuel mileage. That's quite a vision. After all, fuel economy hasn't really budged in eight years. But that just shows the old ways don't work. This is different, said Al Gore. "It's an act of patriotism but also an act of good business sense." But will Washington ways work on an assembly line? And with gas fairly cheap, is there any clamor for a fuel-efficient car?
 
. . . and Bass Created Biosphere
 
What can you buy with billions in oil money? Almost anything you want, which Edward Bass proved by financing Biosphere 2, a bizarre sealed-off world in the Arizona desert. Last week eight people emerged from that world, a lot thinner, after two years. What did Mr. Bass's $150 million investment prove? That this pocket planet needed no outside air (except for 600,000 cubic feet pumped in). That biospherians needed no outside food (except for some they'd tucked away) and were self-sufficient (except for emergency supplies). If this "laboratory for the study of ecology" proved one thing, it was that cockroaches, which did just fine, are better equipped to inherit the earth. But we knew that.
 
Economy May Be Set to Budge
 
The economy has been neither fish nor fowl lately -- recovering, yes, but with the gains often invisible to the naked eye. It could get a bit better. The Government's index of leading indicators -- designed to show where we're heading in six months or so -- posted a strong 1 percent rise in August, the broadest rise in six and a half years. But not all numbers were so good. A purchasing managers' index rose less than expected, while factory-goods orders recovered only modestly. What it adds up to is that "the economy's expanding, but not at a rate that will make us feel good," as one economist put it. The stock market felt a bit better, though, as the leading indicators helped the Dow to a 25-point rise on Friday.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Mint Juleps for Mercedes
 
Mercedes-Benz. Tuscaloosa, Ala. They just don't sound right together. The glamour, the coldly efficient German engineering, just don't seem to fit at the down-home heart of the American South. But look at it this way: Cheap land, skilled workers, a beehive of auto-parts makers nearby, the huge American market all around. That's the way Mercedes looked at it, announcing last week that it would build its first American automobile assembly plant near Tuscaloosa. Its labor costs will be much lower than in Germany, and since it will build sport-utility vehicles at the plant, it will avoid 25 percent tariffs. And it was a prize for Alabama, which won out over many other states. The plant will employ 1,500, plus create thousands of other jobs.
 
Rice to Newcastle
 
The symbolism must have been painful. As if its economy didn't have enough troubles, Japan said last week that its rice crop had let it down. Japan has always protected its politically powerful rice growers, whose farms are so small and inefficient, and whose prices so high, that they would never withstand true competition. But poor weather hurt the crop, and Japan said it would have to import a million tons of rice in the next year. It's a risky precedent, because America would love to get its fork in this particular door. But that's not what Japan has in mind. "This is absolutely, positively an emergency measure," said Agriculture Minister Eijiro Hata.
 
COMPANIES
 
New York Post (the Mini-Series)
 
There's a new suspense show on prime time, "Will The New York Post Survive?" Each week, after six minutes of sex and car chases, a crisis erupts -- the latest owner is bankrupt, a union goes on strike, you name it. A familiar montage: Presses shudder to a stop, editors clean out desks. Drum roll, with cellos. Is it over? First, this commercial. At the last minute, a deal is reached, the presses roll. In last week's episode, the Newspaper Guild, balking at a contract that would leave members open to dismissal without severance pay, went on strike, other unions refused to cross picket lines, and Rupert Murdoch said it was all over. Presses stopped. Commercial. Then Mr. Murdoch got other unions to cross guild picket lines, and The Post came out again. Next: "Revenge of the Guild"?
 
Everyone, it seems, is angling to be a guest star on this show. (Various local comedians have done cameos as prospective owners.) After Gabe Doppelt resigned last week as editor of Mademoiselle, she was asked of her plans and replied, "Oh, a hostile bid for Paramount. Maybe buy The New York Post."
 
A Law Firm Pays Its S.& L. Dues
 
Ever since the savings and loan mess unfolded, the Government has been trying to recoup a few cents on each of the billions of lost dollars. It has turned over stone after stone, suing savings officials with sticky fingers, going after accountants whose magnifying glasses were smudged. It has pursued lawyers, too, and last week Resolution Trust reached one of its largest settlements with a law firm, as Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison agreed to put $45 million into the kitty. The deal involved the firm's role in junk-bond investing by Centrust of Miami, which went down in $1.5 billion of flames.
 
Opening South Africa's Floodgates
 
American companies can't stand the thought of passing up a sizable foreign market, so many did not wait for an official invitation to go back to South Africa as apartheid started crumbling. But the official invitation just came, when Nelson Mandela formally called for the end of trade sanctions, and now American investment could turn into a flood. Last week came the first drop in that flood, as Pillsbury said it would create a joint venture with Foodcorp, a leading South African food company, to make and market Pillsbury products. The deal had been negotiated in recent months, but Pillsbury held back on making it final until Mr. Mandela spoke.
 
The Battle for Paramount
 
So where do things stand on the big-bucks race to buy Paramount? Let's see. Paramount still wants to merge with Viacom, but Viacom needs to do better than $7.6 billion. It did get Blockbuster Entertainment to chip in $600 million, but that still leaves it short of QVC's $9.8 billion rival bid. Paramount, perhaps stalling, told QVC to prove it can pay, and QVC may be about to do so. Stay tuned.
 
Little Airline, Big Lessons
 
Here's one tail that just keeps wagging the dog. Every discussion of the airline industry, it seems, comes down to Southwest Airlines: We have to learn from Southwest. We have to find a way to compete with Southwest. Here it goes again. Last week United's flight attendants, criticizing the carrier for opening a base for flight attendants in Taiwan, pulled out of a union coalition formed to gain control of the carrier. Though the pilots and machinists could go ahead on their own, the move deals a heavy blow to that effort, one that would lead to quick, badly needed savings in labor costs. Why is that so vital just now? Because, yes, United has to compete with expanding low-cost carriers -- like Southwest.

LENGTH: 1855 words

HEADLINE: In a Bid for Casinos, Chicago Comes Up With Snake-Eyes

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE tune is familiar, but instead of the lyric "Chicago, Chicago, that toddlin' town . . . ," the advertisement radio listeners throughout the upper Midwest are hearing says, "Aurora, Aurora, that Hollywood town. . . ."
The advertisement aims to lure gamblers to the Hollywood Casino's two new river boats based in a middle-class suburb about an hour's drive west of here on the Fox River. But the casino's snatching of Chicago's semi-official theme song is a grating reminder that the city's political and business leaders have thus far been powerless to win Chicago a piece of the action as casino gambling spreads throughout the Midwest. 
 Not that Chicago hasn't tried mightily to put itself at the center of the gambling map. The city's effort has been led for the last two years by some of the most powerful gambling and hotel companies in the nation, and Mayor Richard M. Daley, who once opposed downtown casinos, is backing it. Their initial plan, introduced nearly a year and a half ago, was for a $2 billion gambling and family entertainment complex to be built by Caesars World, Circus Circus Enterprises, Hilton Hotels and other private investors. Lately, there have been more modest proposals too, like putting casinos on local river boats.
But the plans have disappeared into the political swampland of Springfield, the state capital, where Gov. Jim Edgar has firmly opposed lifting a ban on casinos on land and, at best, has shown lukewarm support for their floating cousins.
Chicago will try again when the state legislature reconvenes late this month or early in November following a special session; the legislature is currently wrestling with a financing gap that threatens to close Chicago's schools. The city will be pushing for permission to license up to five river boats.
In the long run, industry analysts figure that Chicago is bound to secure at least river boat gambling. With about 8 million residents in its metropolitan area, its status as one of the nation's top destinations for tourist and business travelers, and its location about halfway between Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Chicago has jackpot potential for the $10 billion casino gambling industry.
"People realized that New Orleans would open up next after Atlantic City because of political support, but there is no comparison with Chicago," said J. Terrence Lanni, president of Caesars World. Mr. Lanni said Chicago's pluses also include the renown of its sports franchises.
Wall Street analysts made preliminary estimates that the $2 billion complex proposed last year -- if it had been quickly approved -- could have added 10 percent to Hilton's earnings per share by 1995, in part because of cross-marketing with the three major hotels here. Some saw the potential for a 20 percent increase in earnings per share last year for Circus Circus, a smaller company that now owns and operates casinos in Las Vegas, Reno and Laughlin, Nev.
The spillover from such profits would be thousands of new jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars annually in tax revenues. That promise has become steadily more tantalizing for Mayor Daley and other civic leaders as other development schemes, such as a proposed airport at the southeast edge of the city, have encountered roadblocks.
"It's not a question of if Chicago emerges as the third major center -- it's just a matter of when," said Marvin Roffman, a Philadelphia-based investment adviser who has followed the gambling industry for 15 years. He said the city will lose out on becoming such a center if some scandal, perhaps involving organized crime, restores the political clout of those morally opposed to gambling.
But timing may make all the difference in the extent of downtown development. Indiana recently approved licensing of 11 river boats, including 5 that will serve the Chicago region by sailing on Lake Michigan from cities in the northwest corner of the state. Other projects are also nibbling at the fringes of the market the gambling industry sees Chicago serving. There are plans to develop a land-based casino in Windsor, Ontario, just across the Detroit River from Detroit; Missouri's decision last spring to legalize river boat gambling at several sites, including St. Louis; the rapid growth of casinos on Indian reservations in Minnesota and Wisconsin, and New Orleans' entry into gambling.
"If you have 20 regional places, the one grand one may never get built," said Michael Sloan, the general counsel at Circus Circus and a key negotiator for the plan presented to Chicago last year.
Ceasars, Circus Circus and Hilton originally proposed developing more than 100 acres in an unspecified area near the heart of the city. Each partner planned to build a major casino and counted on a fourth casino being built by local investors or another big gambling company. About 80 percent of the site was to be set aside for parks, restaurants and sporting facilities, such as ice rinks and miniature-golf courses, and for such family entertainment as the "Back to the Future" ride at the Universal Studios park in Orlando, Fla.
The earliest versions of the plan also envisioned new hotels. That element was scaled back to win the support of Chicago's current hotel owners, many of whom are suffering from occupancy rates below 65 percent.
A series of conceptual designs was created by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the Chicago architectural firm famous for such skyscrapers as the John Hancock Building and the Sears Tower. Skidmore said it drew inspiration from Copenhagen's Tivoli Gardens, Les Halles market in Paris, the Galleria shopping district of Milan and Midway Gardens, the entertainment complex that became one of the city's major attractions shortly after World War I and that was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.
"This was going to be an international tourist attraction as opposed to just another amenity, which is what you have with the river boats going in at St. Louis now," said Mark Grossman, a spokesman for Hilton.
The three gambling companies also emphasized that International Entertainment Center, as they called the plan, could be financed entirely by private investment. They released a study by Arthur Andersen asserting that the project would bring 10.2 million new visitors to the city annually, encourage the nearly 12.5 million tourists who already visit (and who stay longer than those visiting on business), lift state and local tax revenues by $625 million and create 66,000 jobs. An additional 37,500 workers would be employed in construction.
Such figures won over Mayor Daley and impressed many local business executives.
"It wasn't a full-court press, but it was a pretty serious effort," said Jerry Pearlman, chairman and chief executive of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, recalling the business community's lobbying for the plan.
It was not serious enough to shake Governor Edgar's firm stand against repealing Illinois' ban on land-based casinos. He and other opponents quickly responded with surveys of their own suggesting that the benefits to Chicago would be largely offset by losses to the already licensed river boat operations, the state lottery, and restaurants and other businesses that would face new competition.
"When you looked at it on a statewide basis, there was good reason to be suspicious," said John Rau, an economic development adviser to Governor Edgar who recently became dean of the Indiana University School of Business. "The support was broad because the Mayor had cast it as a vital issue, and a lot of people have to live with him -- but it wasn't deep. There was more income transfer than wealth creation."
The drive to lift the ban died in November without reaching a vote in the legislature after Democrats realized they would not be able to override Governor Edgar's threatened veto. Attention then focused on the Governor's hints that he might be receptive to a river boat proposal.
Mayor Daley responded derisively, questioning the difference between land-based casinos and gambling on boats that are essentially immobile. This year, though, as Chicago's schools face a widening budget gap, the Mayor endorsed the plan for up to five casino boats that is about to go before the legislature.
The Mayor's $800 million plan for an as yet undetermined Chicago River site envisions building some of the same types of entertainment facilities sketched out in the Skidmore drawings, then docking the gambling boats next to them. Others simply argue that Chicago should get one or more river boats into the water, and worry about related development later.
Thus far, the prospects that any plan will emerge from the Byzantine wheeling and dealing this fall in Springfield look dicey. Suburban and downstate legislators in districts with river boats want more time for those operations to build a regular clientele before Chicago is allowed to compete. Chicago's lobbyists also must contend with the determination of other legislators to load any bill authorizing river boats for the city with projects for their districts. That could create such a pork-laden bill that Governor Edgar, a Republican who is expected to seek re-election next year, could veto it without appearing to be unconcerned about the economic plight of heavily Democratic Chicago.
"All you can say about Chicago is we gave it a good shot," Mr. Lanni of Caesars World said, "and we'll be back."
 
 
 
PLAYING THE RIVERS OF CASH
THE more than 20 river boats already plying the Mississippi and other rivers in the Midwest are expected to generate more than $1 billion in revenues this year -- 40 percent more than is generated in Atlantic City.
The first successful river boat in the Chicago region was the Empress, which cruises the muddy Des Plaines River in rundown Joliet, less than an hour's drive southwest of Chicago's Loop.
The Empress has been taking in more than $15 million a month.
The Promus Corporation, which is based in Memphis and owns two other river boats based in Joliet -- the Northern Star and Southern Star -- expressed mixed feelings about Chicago's drive to get in on the action.
"When you think about how big the Chicago market is, the demand is nowhere near being satisfied," said Ralph Berry, a spokesman for Promus.
"Opening up downtown Chicago would accelerate the splintering, but it would be a different product from Joliet," Mr. Berry added. "We hope it would be open for competitive bidding because we would want to participate."
Mr. Berry noted that one reason for the state to go slowly in Chicago was that the other river boats have not been open long enough to fulfill Illinois' goal of "building up rural tourism."
The Joliet boat owners' perspectives are no doubt influenced by their plans for river boat gambling in Indiana.
Promus is bidding for a license in Indiana, and the investor group that owns the Empress hopes to grab another chunk of the Chicago market with a $100 million river-boat and shore-based casino and entertainment project, scheduled to go before the voters in Hammond, which is just east of Joliet, in November.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Health Care: Loser With a Future?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
SO far this year, the only losing group among domestic stock funds has been the health-and-biotechnology category.
All the other 15 stock fund categories tracked by Morningstar Inc., a research company in Chicago, have produced positive returns since January. In the latest three months, the average domestic stock fund rose 5.3 percent, yielding a gain of 10.5 percent from January through September. 
 Gold funds were the biggest winners over the nine months, up 45.3 percent, although gold began losing ground in the third quarter. Following them were the Pacific stock funds (up 36.8 percent since January), foreign stock funds (up 25.7 percent) and natural resource funds (up 23.1 percent).
But health-and-biotechnology funds fell 5.3 percent in the last nine months. Since July, the health-and-biotechnology group rose only 2.6 percent, as investors waited out the uncertainty of the Clinton health care plan.
Health care stocks have been laggards since January 1992, after a stunning run that yielded average returns for health care funds of nearly 45 percent a year from 1989 through 1991.
Now the managers say the bad news may be over. "There's a good chance that underperformance has run its course -- the economy is not strong and health care is resistant to the economic cycle," said Edward P. Owens, who runs the $540 million Vanguard Specialized Portfolio: Health Care.
Moreover, the Clinton plan "was the event that Wall Street was waiting for," said Joanne Soja, who took over the $765 million Putnam Health Sciences Trust in August. "Now that we know what the worst case is, we can start looking at stocks again."
The plan probably will not have an immediate impact, the managers say, because it takes a broad approach and "the devil is in the details," Mr. Owens said. Also, it's likely that the plan will take the same tortured route through Congress as the Federal budget, yielding to compromises along the way.
Here is what the fund managers have to say about turning their group around:
Given that many large-capitalization health care stocks are near record lows, "I'm relatively sanguine," Mr. Owens said. Still, he finds foreign companies most attractive now. He noted that international stocks have underperformed for the last three years, so their valuations are better. A favorite: Zeneca, a British drug company created when Imperial Chemical Industries split into separate drug and chemical companies in June.
Jordan Schreiber, who manages the $120 million Merrill Lynch Healthcare Fund, has also been moving outside the United States. About 41 percent of the fund is invested overseas; its biggest holding is Roche Holding, the Swiss drug company. In the United States, he said, "large-capitalization drug companies have already been hit, probably more by market forces than the Administration's plan," and the damage is "ongoing and permanent." Some that he feels might survive an industry restructuring are Warner-Lambert, Merck and Carter-Wallace.
Mike Yellen, co-manager of the $4 million Franklin Global Health Care Fund, said he has avoided large-capitalization consumer drug companies because "their pricing flexibility is gone forever." Instead, he buys health maintenance organizations and generic drug companies to benefit from cost-containment trends. He likes Healthsource, a Concord, N.H.-based H.M.O.
Charles A. Mangum, manager of the $550 million Fidelity Select Health Care fund, compares the health care industry today to "the oil industry of the 1980's, one time perceived as strong growth companies." About half the fund is invested in drug companies; the three largest holdings are Schering-Plough, Warner-Lambert and Imcera. Lately, Mr. Mangum said he has been buying biotech stocks -- "which I've avoided for quite some time" -- bringing that sector up to 10 percent of the fund. He said he liked Chiron, which is preparing to market a treatment for multiple sclerosis, and Genentech, which has a cystic fibrosis drug up for approval by the Food and Drug Administration.
Ms. Soja, of Putnam, is focusing on companies that have a track record of dealing successfully with intense Government intervention. One favorite is Vivra, a dialysis company that has managed despite declining Government reimbursements. She has increased the fund's H.M.O. position and likes companies that will benefit from the trend to managed care. One favorite: Value Health, a specialty managed care company that helps corporations reduce the drug and mental health portions of their insurance costs.
Louis E. Salemy, who runs the $90 million Fidelity Select Medical Delivery fund, says H.M.O.'s and health insurers are likely to feel the most immediate impact from the Administration's plan. As a result, he is buying shares in companies that dominate local markets "because you have to control the market to maintain pricing power," he said. Hospital companies account for 30 percent of the fund. The biggest are the Hospital Corporation of America, Health Management Associates and Columbia Health Care.
The worst performer in the health-and-biotechnology category, the $529 million Invesco Strategic Health Sciences (down 15.9 percent since the beginning of the year), was hurt this year by a big position in Synergen. Still, fund co-manager John Kaweske is moving slowly back into biotech again, with a position in Creative Bio-Molecules.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
From the Practical to the Fantastic, Books for the Beleaguered

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
THERE is no reason, as millions of Americans head back to the classroom, that executives should not be hitting the books as well. Here are suggestions for what to do on long flights when the laptop battery, as usual, fails to fulfill its promised life.
"No Excuses Management: Proven Systems for Starting Fast, Growing Quickly and Surviving Hard Times," T. J. Rodgers, William Taylor and Rick Foreman ($35, Currency/Doubleday). 
 "A computer chip is the result of literally a thousand interdisciplinary tasks," the authors of this business boot camp manual assert. "Doing 999 of them right guarantees failure, not success."
There is nothing warm and fuzzy about the management philosophy of Mr. Rodgers, the founder of Cypress Semiconductor, and his co-authors. In Mr. Rodgers's neighborhood, the computer chip industry, the phrase "we're tough" was literally part of his company's original credo.
"No Excuses Management" is a fascinating look behind the scenes at a semiconductor company at a time when semiconductors are the strongest segment of the domestic economy. It is also intended to be a blueprint for other companies that want to be lean and mean.
Simply put, the management principles enumerated here are based on no, rather than yes: no secrets, no surprises, no politics, no distractions, no confusion, no waste, no illusions. And above all, no excuses. This philosophy loves winners and hates whiners.
A few years ago, when many people were wringing their hands about the suspected threat to America's high-technology industry posed by Japan, Mr. Rodgers was fixing bayonets and developing management systems that took no prisoners, even among his own staff. These systems have been encoded into computer programs that streamline the management process of setting goals and tracking progress.
A diskette containing demonstrations of two No Excuses Management programs is included with the book.
"Things That Make Us Smart: Defending Human Attributes in the Age of the Machine," Donald A. Norman ($22.95, Addison-Wesley).
The computer-driven, no-excuses management style espoused by Mr. Rodgers and his colleagues might strike some observers as cold and mechanical, which is exactly how some people view the information technologies that are entering the office and home.
Mr. Norman, one of the senior researchers at Apple Computer Inc. and the author of "The Design of Everyday Things," argues that we too often design systems around technology rather than around human qualities that are less precise and less repetitive than those of computers.
While Mr. Rodgers portrays executive decision-making as a logical process, Mr. Norman says it is often illogical, drawing on personal experience, analogies and serendipity. Automating the decision-making process in a company hinders the informal channels of communication that are, he contends, just as valid as purely logical systems, if not more so.
Unlike some thinkers, Mr. Norman does not advocate reducing the role of information technologies in the office. Rather, he suggests, these technologies must be redesigned to put humans, rather than computers, at the center.
"The Electronic Invasion: A Survival Guide for the Brave New World of Business Communications," Cheryl Currid ($26.95, Brady Books).
Many books advise technically savvy executives how to scale down their corporate computing to client-server networks, or similarly eyeball-glazing topics. Other books are aimed at "dummies," or novice PC users. Here is a book for executive dummies.
Some people may find it hard to believe that there are still some executives who have managed to remain untouched by local area networks, electronic mail, facsimile machines, voice mail, video teleconferencing and other electronic office tools.
Yet that is the audience Ms. Currid addresses in this friendly guidebook, which finds the neutral ground between the seemingly opposing philosophies of Mr. Rodgers and Mr. Norman.
Ms. Currid, a former director of applied information technology at Coca-Cola Foods, has written for the technologically timid. The book has all the warmth and fuzziness lacking in Mr. Rodgers's spartan tome, and the practical advice missing in "Things That Make Us Smart."
In other words, this is not a book for executives who write their own Lotus 1-2-3 macros or who travel with a bandoleer belt slung with EO Personal Communicators, cellular phones and digital beepers.
Instead, "The Electronic Invasion" addresses the things that make us feel dumb. There are basic explanations of how local area networks work, how to send effective electronic mail ("Don't send it when you are angry"), step-by-step plans to master the fax machine, and how to record a meaningful voice-mail message ("Write out your phone mail message before recording it").
Some advice will surely amuse or annoy seasoned computer users. But it will provide comfort to those executives who have been waiting for something like "Everything You Wanted to Know About Office Electronics but Were Afraid to Ask."
"The Joy of Cybersex: An Underground Guide to Electronic Erotica," by Phillip Robinson and Nancy Tamosaitis ($24.95, Brady Books).
It was inevitable that personal computers would become a medium for sexually explicit material, just as print, film and video technologies did before them. Computers add an extra dimension of interactivity, however, and have become hosts for a surprising variety of so-called adult services.
About the best things that can be said about this book are that it illuminates what has for years been a shadowy area of the personal computer culture and that it shows how computer erotica appears to provide many people with a "safe" alternative to real, personal relationships in a world where H.I.V. is deadlier than computer viruses.
The book comes with a diskette (DOS) that contains the "PG" versions of two games common on underground networks.
"Virtual Light," by William Gibson ($21.95, Bantam Books), and "A Philosophical Investigation," by Philip Kerr ($20, Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
These are ripping yarns for executives who have a fondness for computers, science fiction and mystery (and who have a stomach for crude language and human bodies in various stages of disassembly).
The chilling visions of corporate information systems in a virtual realm called cyberspace were first put forth by Mr. Gibson nearly a decade ago in his science fiction classic "Neuromancer." After that first novel, Mr. Gibson became something of a cult figure because so many of the supposedly fantastical technologies in the book were plausible.
It was even more amazing when Mr. Gibson revealed that he was not particularly computer literate. His vivid descriptions of the dimension called cyberspace, to which one gained access through "the Net," were simply extrapolated from his observations about the information systems of today. The future was darker, raunchier and more sinister than we might imagine, but it was also disturbingly believable from a technological perpective.
In Mr. Gibson's new novel, "Virtual Light," executives looking for more guidance and insight into the dazzling but dark future of information systems will find, instead, a more mundane world, a decaying San Francisco of 15 years hence. This is a good detective story; again, a piece of technology (the "virtual light" of the title) plays a key role. But this time the technological vision is not the main attraction.
Mr. Kerr's "A Philosophical Investigation" is another example of fiction with a plausible technological undercurrent. It is also something of a departure into science fiction by one of Britain's best young mystery writers. The caper takes place in London about 25 years from now, and involves an intuitive homicide detective, a subverted biogenetics experiment, a computer system gone awry, a madman who thinks he is the reincarnation of the philosopher Wittgenstein, and a team of serial killers.

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Report: Highbridge;
A Bittersweet Season

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
The growing doubts about the Yankees' future in the Bronx have been especially painful for the small merchants in the shadow of Yankee Stadium. That's because the new talk comes after a year in which the Yankees played well for a change and helped drum up business for their neighbors along the way.
Indeed, the team's unexpected run for first place, down to the very last days of the season, kept fans and revelers flooding into the economically struggling neighborhood in greater numbers, and for far longer, than in less-competitive years. 
 "When the Yankees win like this, we're busy," said Louie Diamontis, the manager of Ball Park Lanes, a bowling alley at 810 River Avenue where the bar and restaurant served roughly 100 more people on game days this year than last. "This year, it seemed like a longer season because they were in the running."
On Thursday, though, New York State officials added new fuel to the uncertainty about the team's future in the Bronx, unveiling their bid to keep the Yankees from moving to New Jersey: a 50,000-seat stadium on Manhattan's West Side.
George M. Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, has persistently complained that fans have shunned the stadium because of problems with parking, traffic, sanitation and security -- a complaint that seems cruelly ironic to the merchants around the stadium, given that game attendance increased by more than half a million fans this year.
"This season's been bittersweet," Mr. Diamontis said. "While the Yankees are doing great, people are saying they're going to leave. I don't understand."
Steve Manesis, manager of the Unity Coffee Shop at 58 East 161st Street, is equally puzzled. As far as he is concerned, the team's old inability to draw fans had far less to do with the Bronx than with the team itself..
"This year, they won and people came," Mr. Manesis said. "But when they lose, people stop coming."
Joseph Bastone, owner of the Yankee Tavern at Gerard Avenue and 161st Street, says business has more than doubled of late. "This year," he said, "has been just like the old days." R.H.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Honda Rolls Out Its New Accord

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
IT was noon and traffic was oozing on New York's 42d Street. I was pointed west, momentarily moribund in front of Grand Central Terminal when an eastbound 5.0-liter Mustang crept alongside.
"Hey," the driver said, "is that thing smaller than it used to be? It looks smaller." 
 New Yorkers don't usually talk to each other, at least not in civil tones, so I was surprised. But I was surprised, too, at the perception that the car -- the new '94 Honda Accord -- had shrunk.
Because, in truth, the wedge-shaped fifth generation of Honda's amazingly popular and important sedan is taller, wider and heavier than its predecessor. It is also rounder, stiffer and higher in the rump than the car that was America's leading seller for three years running.
But what I said to the guy in the gray Mustang was: "Uh, no. Don't think so."
You really don't want to get into specs when you're trying to push undented through the midday madness.
In fact, the new Accord sedan is 1.2 inches shorter than the '93 model, but that is not something you can spot. The big thing that skews perception and makes the car look shorter is its width, which has been increased a full three inches. That allows an inch more shoulder room and helps encompass the new side-impact protection, which now meets the Federal safety edict that will take effect in 1997.
Along with its new design, the midsize Accord has also been reengineered, with more power and a refined suspension, and the company plans a strong effort to regain the No. 1 spot that it held in 1989, '90 and '91.
Ford's Taurus put an end to that dominance with its '92 cars through aggressive marketing and through fleet sales, but it should be said, too, that Honda has felt the need to update the Accord and to broaden its appeal. The old car's market consisted primarily of people between the ages of 35 and 45, and a company spokesman said the new design is aimed at buyers from 30 to 45.
In addition, Honda is trying to put a more American stamp on its cars. It announced last week that, as of next April, all Civic four-doors for North America will be built at the company's plant in East Liberty, Ohio. And by April 1996, all Accord four-doors for the American market will be produced in Marysville, Ohio, which currently turns out more than three-quarters of the 400,000 sedans sold here each year.
Right now, the four-door is the only Accord in the showrooms, but the sportier coupe will make its debut in November, and a good-looking four-door wagon will come along next February.
Like Honda's other new models, all Accords are equipped with standard dual air bags. Antilock brakes, standard or optional, are also available, depending on the model. The sedan and coupe come in three flavors, the base DX, the LX and the top-of-the-line EX. The wagon will be available in LX and EX trim.
All Accords also have 2.2-liter aluminum fours under the hood, mounted sideways and driving the front wheels. DX and LX models deliver 130 horsepower, but the EX has a new version of Honda's VTEC engine (VTEC being an obscure acronym that stands for variable valve timing) which puts out 145 horses.
The white test car was, predictably, a well-equipped EX with an automatic transmission and leather upholstery whose odd purple-tan color I couldn't quite figure out.
With leather and the automatic, it was the most expensive of the new Accords, carrying a sticker that said $21,550. Honda has, however, kept prices pretty much at 1993 levels, and that means you can still buy a base DX for $14,330, while the LX starts at $17,230.
The EX rides on 15-inch alloy wheels, an inch bigger than those on the cheaper cars, and the tires are Michelins, newly designed to provide low rolling resistance and thus greater fuel economy, which ranges from 23 miles per gallon, city, to 31, highway.
Trim on the tester was of the blackout variety, set off around the side windows by a narrow band of chrome. A black air dam has also been added under the steeply sloping nose. The halogen headlights are narrow and slightly smaller than on the previous model, but they are superior to earlier headlamps, using multiple reflectors to turn the darkest night into a splash of sunlight.
At the other end of the car, the fairly deep trunk has a liftover at bumper height, and its lid rises on gas struts to an angle of more than 90 degrees, getting it out of the way so you have easy access to the 13 cubic feet of cargo space. The locking rear seatback is split 60-40 to allow stowage of long objects.
Glass is nearly flush, and seams between panels have been narrowed to enhance appearance and aerodynamics. In addition, the corpulent new body is more rigid, with stiffness increased by 25 percent. But the extra girth and the girdling against side impacts add only about 50 pounds to the sedan's weight, which varies from 2,800 to 3,075 pounds, depending on trim and transmission.
A five-speed manual is standard on all Accords, but a refined version of Honda's four-speed automatic is available. For '94, the transmission employs what the company calls "Grade Logic" control, which senses driving conditions. On upgrades, the system reduces the hunting between gears that is common to automatics. Downhill, the transmission stays in a lower gear to take advantage of engine braking.
As for the brakes themselves, four-wheel disks and an antilock system are standard on the EX and are available on the lesser cars. Without the ABS option, the DX and LX models are equipped with power front disks and drums at the rear.
Inside, the new car offers Honda's usual neat arrangement, although everything has been redone for '94. The EX sports full power equipment, including a flip-or-slide sunroof, and there are dual cupholders and a bin for toll change.
Incidentally, the color of that leather interior bothered me, so I asked Honda. It turns out to be two-tone taupe. Try to say that three times fast.
 
 
 
AND NOW, IN-DASH DIALING
FORD likes to say that it has a better idea. But its archrival, Honda, has now come up with a better idea of its own.
And what a good idea it is.
For 1994, all Honda Accords and Preludes -- as well as Acura Integras -- offer the first hands-free, in-dash cellular telephone, located right above the radio for convenience, easy dialing and a measure of disguise against theft.
The in-dash phone kit, installed by dealers and costing $500 to $600, has three components, a small antenna in the upper right corner of the windshield, a small talk-and-listen handset that resides in the console between the front seats and a transceiver with a large keypad mounted in the middle of the dash.
The phone has a large vacuum-fluorescent display that is bright enough to be read in direct sunlight. A built-in microphone offers speaker-phone performance, allowing the driver to keep both hands on the wheel.
When a call is received, the phone mutes the sound system, and the telephone can be set to answer automatically. The caller's voice is heard through the stereo system.
The keypad is illuminated and offers seven function keys as well as "on," "in use," "no service" and "roam" indicators. In addition, the phone has one-touch dialing that allows the driver to call the nine most frequently used numbers at the push of a button.
Twenty-one more numbers can be stored and recalled with a few keystrokes. Other features include last-number recall, scratchpad dialing, automatic redial and call timing.
As an added fillip, the phone can be set to detect a thief. If the car is started by someone who doesn't know the proper code, the phone automatically dials its owner and emits a tone that can be thought of as an electronic cry for help.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Supply-Side Economics Play New Jersey

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
IF she is elected Governor of New Jersey, Christine Todd Whitman says, she will join in the latest revival of supply-side economics, the theory preached by President Ronald Reagan and now proselytized by a small band of G.O.P. Governors.
But first she must beat Gov. Jim Florio on Nov. 2, and so she has taken a gamble that few in recent political history have dared. 
 Nearly two weeks ago, she put before voters a plan, albeit short on specifics, to cut their taxes by about $1.5 billion. It would, over three years, reduce state income taxes 30 percent on everyone with taxable income under $80,000. The rich would get smaller breaks. She also promised to eliminate the state telephone sales tax, which raised $312 million last year, the fuel tax on heavy trucks, which raised $9 million, and the corporate tax surcharge, which raised $40 million.
Not since the glory days of Mr. Reagan's first campaign has a candidate placed so much stock in supply-side economics -- the belief that lowering tax rates allows the economy to improve, meaning that workers and companies earn more, so have more income to tax (at the lower rates), so government takes in the same revenue and therefore does not have to cut services.
There's a good reason, political experts say, that no one else is campaigning on a supply-side platform.
"People just aren't willing to buy tax cuts anymore as a panacea," said Howard J. Gold, who teaches government at Smith College. "The public has grown increasingly skeptical of election year tax-cut promises."
Mrs. Whitman has said she is simply following the lead of other Republican Governors: William F. Weld of Massachusetts, Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, John Engler of Michigan and Fife Symington of Arizona. But none of those incumbents pushed the envelope as far as Mrs. Whitman has.
By the end of the Reagan Presidency, supply-side theory had been widely discredited. Even some authors of the Reagan plan, including the former budget director David A. Stockman, had disavowed it. But that did not end the debate, nor efforts like those of Governor Weld of Massachusetts to try the idea. He has reduced income and capital gains taxes by about $200 million a year.
"Since the Reagan era, voters look at anyone who is claiming to be offering a tax cut very carefully and they look at the plan with a jaundiced eye," said Michael P. Ettlinger, tax policy director for the Washington-based Citizens for Tax Justice. "The problem that an anti-tax candidate faces after Reagan is that they are called upon to deliver specifics on what they are going to cut to pay for tax cuts. Mrs. Whitman has decided to brave that world."
But she need not heed that warning from a Washingtonian. There are others closer to home. A New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll released a week after she announced her plan showed that only 10 percent of the voters believed that their taxes would go down if she were elected. Thirty-six percent said their taxes would go up; 38 percent felt they would stay about the same.
And there is precedent to watch out for too. Raymond H. Bateman ran in 1977 for the office Mrs. Whitman wants. One newspaper account called him the Republican Party's "bright young man, its heir apparent, its best bet to someday capture the governorship."
His Democratic opponent was Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, who had earned the public's wrath and the nickname "One-Term Byrne" by introducing the state's first income tax.
Mr. Bateman said he had a plan to roll it back. His co-author was former United States Treasury Secretary William Simon, and it was called the "Bateman-Simon plan."
On the stump, Mr. Byrne took to referring to it only by their initials.
 
Inglorious Defeat
 That, and hard questioning about how the state would make up the money led to an inglorious defeat. Mr. Bateman went into the last six weeks of the campaign leading by 14 percentage points; he ended up losing by 300,000 votes.
Sixteen years later, Mrs. Whitman finds herself in a fascinatingly similar situation -- but without the poll numbers. In Jim Florio, she has an opponent who until recently was highly unpopular. He was thought to have killed any chance of re-election back in 1990, when virtually his first act as Governor was to push through a record $2.8 billion tax increase.
Then on Sept. 21 -- two days short of the 16th anniversary of Mr. Bateman's announcement -- she announced her tax-cut plan. Her co-authors are Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., editor-in-chief of Forbes magazine, and Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist for Bear Stearns & Co. in New York. As deputy budget director during Mr. Reagan's first term, Mr. Kudlow was a chief proponent of supply-side economics. He has brought that passion to this campaign.
"My prescription was a big-think, big-bang solution," he said of the Whitman plan. "This was not going to be tinkering around the edges. I've always been interested in the last couple of years to see if the Republicans can sell this message successfully."
But the plan that was intended to lead the offensive instead backfired. Most of the newspaper editorials that followed its release sneered with the same cynicism that voters seem to be expressing.
And Mr. Florio worked hard to undermine Mrs. Whitman's credibility. He brought Mr. Byrne out of retirement to proclaim the plan "B.S. II." And he himself, taking a rhetorical cue from George Bush's early campaign against Mr. Reagan, called it "voodoo redo."
Selling the plan may be the least of her problems. The latest Times/WCBS-TV poll had her trailing Mr. Florio by 50 to 31 points. Last week, she demoted her brother, who had managed her campaign, and laid plans for "going negative" about Mr. Florio, a style of campaigning that friends say she has never liked.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Charles W. Adams;
The Rise and Fall of Civilization According to Tax Collection

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
THE Constitution and the ballot may protect Americans against overreaching tax collectors, but some of the ancients enjoyed even better security.
An extortions court created by the Romans enabled Cicero and others to prosecute overzealous tax men. The code of laws (313 A.D.) under Constantine provided civil remedies for judges derelict in defending taxpayers against abuses. The penalty: 30 pounds of gold assessed against the judge and payable to the taxpayer. 
 Those are but a few of the facts that Charles W. Adams, a former California lawyer who is a research historian at the University of Toronto, has culled on the influence of taxes on history.
He concludes that perhaps in no other era were taxpayers as blessed as in the Middle Ages, when God was on their side. The medieval system was divine supply-side economics, he says, based on the belief that a king who taxed excessively incurred sin punishable by God, whereas a king who taxed justly would find gold in his treasury.
"Isn't this what supply-siders are telling us the laws of economics will do?" asks Mr. Adams, eyes twinkling, lips slightly arced in professorial omniscience.
Mr. Adams, a lean, graying man of 63 who earned his doctor of law degree from the University of California at Los Angeles and taught history at the International College of the Cayman Islands before migrating to Canada, believes much of history is defined by efforts in various civilizations to curb tax collectors. His views often seem to reflect a political conservative's natural crankiness about having the Government's hand in his pocket. But he does quote former Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes about the necessity of taxes, and likens the tax gatherer to a bureaucratic Robin Hood taking wealth where he can and often doing much good with the loot.
But Robin Hood is less Mr. Adams's hero than is St. Thomas Aquinas, the 13th-century theologian and philosopher, who defined the tax limits of the medieval state. According to Aquinas, rulers were entitled to tax their subjects for only what was necessary to safeguard the common good. Anything in excess was the equivalent of robbery. "Wherefore they are bound to restitution just as robbers are," Aquinas wrote in his "Summa Theologica."
 
Potentially Destructive
 Montesquieu, another hero, who influenced the framers of the United States Constitution, echoes Aquinas. "The real wants of the people," wrote the eminence of the Enlightenment, "ought never to give way to the imaginary wants of the state."
The history of taxes has been Mr. Adams's passion since 1968 when as a jack-of-all-trades lawyer in Hollywood, he scoured the card catalogue at the U.C.L.A. library for works on the historical role of taxes. He couldn't find a single listing.
Mr. Adams abandoned what became mainly a tax law practice to teach and write. His works on the subject include his own recently published summa theologica, 20 years in the making -- "For Good and Evil: The Impact of Taxes on the Course of Civilization" (Madison Books, 1993).
If taxation sustains civilized society, it also represents a potential danger to civilization, Mr. Adams believes. "When we tax," Mr. Adams says, "we are dealing with fire, and without proper controls and care, we can easily burn down everything we have built."
Income creates jobs, he argues. When the state takes away income from an enterprising man or woman, it takes away his or her capacity to generate employment and wealth for society.
The lessons he derives from history are more than economic. The ancient Greeks, who developed the concept of liberty, discovered that excessive taxation bred despots.
Unfortunately, Mr. Adams says, when the need for revenues collides with ideals of freedom, ideals give way. During the reigns of certain pharaohs and late Roman emperors, tax collectors became virtual slave masters. He's worried the situation may recur in the United States today.
"I believe we've lost something when we tolerate the degree of public intrusion that we do," he says. "Our tax system is now a spy system." The problem, he argues, is that American taxes have lost their sense of fairness. "When you feel the system is a rip-off on you and a loophole for somebody else, then it loses its moral persuasion, and the Government has to fall back on heavy criminal penalties."
No revolution was more deeply rooted in taxation than the revolt of the 13 Colonies. The rallying cry, taxation without consent, was expressed in the Declaration of Independence.
Over two centuries, Mr. Adams says, this country has replaced colonial tax oppression with a home-grown version few understand, let alone consent to, which falls hundreds of billions of dollars short of paying the bills.
Mr. Adams says the Internal Revenue Service takes a leaf from the scribes of the pharaohs, who taxed almost everything. Sales, slaves, foreigners, imports, exports and business were all fair game. Snooping reached the point where scribes regularly inspected kitchens to make sure women were not using free drippings instead of the taxable oil they were required to use.
 
Like Ice Melting
 Yet 3,000 years of Egyptian history are filled with moments of humane tax administration, including remitting taxes during hard times.
Mr. Adams, pointing out the classic gaps in the system, recounts how Frederick the Great, the 18th-century ruler of Prussia, asked his finance minister during a cabinet meeting why the treasury was so low when his subjects were paying such high taxes. The minister requested a piece of ice, handed it to the minister farthest from the king and told him to pass it on to the next person, on up to the king. All Frederick received was a wet hand. He promptly instituted greater frugality in his Government.
The Greeks developed a progressive revenue system wherein richer citizens paid the larger share of Government costs. Their voluntary approach, known as the liturgy or public service to the gods, involved a sense of responsibility to the community, something that Mr. Adams feels is lacking in the United States.
When public improvements were needed, leading Athenians competed to finance them. Those with wealth "held it in a kind of voluntary trust for the city," he said.
The Islamic tax policy is one reason for Islam's spread, he says. Vanquished peoples were given three choices: convert and pay no tax; keep your own religion and pay a head tax, or be put to death.
A shortage of revenue developed, Mr. Adams notes wryly, because of a shortage of infidels. Islam's head tax antedated our own sin taxes, which President Clinton proposes to raise on cigarettes to pay for health care.
The dawn of tax history is recorded on clay tablets excavated at Lagash, a city state 6,000 years ago in what is now Iraq. Little is known about Lagash, except that it instituted heavy taxes to fight a war. That war ended, but the tax burden did not lighten.
On a tablet, an anonymous citizen had scratched a complaint: "You can have a Lord, you can have a King, but the man to fear is the tax collector."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles W. Adams, a historian at the University of Toronto. (Elisavietta Ritchie for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1017 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Looking to Courts for Catharsis

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE land of the endless summer seems to have become the home of the endless Rodney King trial as one legal proceeding unfolds from another like waves rising in the surf. Beating begets trial begets acquittal begets riot begets trial. Suit spawns countersuit. Victim becomes plaintiff, plaintiff becomes defendant. Appeal counters appeal.
All flow from an 81-second videotaped beating of a black motorist by white police officers more than two years ago. And yet there is no closure, only periodic strokes of theater that inflame a city that continues to seek, and fails to find, a catharsis in the legal system. In the absence of successful social programs or economic renewal or inspired political leadership, the city has sought to come to terms with its ailments through courtroom drama. 
 The attempt is futile, said Peter Arenella, a law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "We have come to look at our criminal justice system as more than a mechanism to decide guilt or innocence but also as a mechanism to somehow resolve fundamental rifts in the community," Mr. Arenella said. "People naively expect that a trial can somehow give them justice, but that is literally impossible because people in the community have different substantive expectations of what justice demands."
After many months of trials, retrials and appeals, there is a possibility this week that some partial resolution may be at hand. Tomorrow a jury is to resume deliberations in the case of two black men charged with attempted murder in the vicious beating of a white truck driver during the riotingthatfollowed the April 29, 1992, acquittals of four white police officers accused in state court in the beating of Rodney King.
Also this week the United States Supreme Court may determine whether two of the officers, who were convicted of violating Mr. King's civil rights in a second, Federal trial this April, must soon begin serving their two-and-a-half-year prison terms. The judge who sentenced them, John G. Davies of Federal District Court, last week gave them two extra weeks to take their request for bail to the high court, extending until at least Oct. 12 the date on which they must report to prison. The judge's extension, on marginal grounds that surprised most legal observers, was merely the latest jolt.
As the legal cases unfold, they generate more tension and more anger. They also generate big money and visions of bigger awards. Legions of lawyers are now involved, and almost everybody, it seems, is suing somebody. Justice and race are the vocabulary; the currency is in the millions.
 
Raining Lawsuits

 
 On top of the previous trials, with their controversies and their now-routine riot preparations, a third Rodney King trial is scheduled as Mr. King seeks $9.5 million from the city in a civil suit. That case, which is scheduled to be heard next March, singles out as targets the former Mayor Tom Bradley, the former police chief Daryl F. Gates and a score of officers who were at the scene of the beating -- which includes a police helicopter pilot -- as well as the four officers who have already stood trial twice.
City officials say that Mr. King's case has been weakened by his own conduct. He has been arrested four times since the beating, once when surprised in his automobile with a transvestite prostitute, once on a complaint of domestic violence and twice for drunken driving.
"We could have endless trials," said Mr. Arenella, "and it still wouldn't change the tragic place we're in." The problems of Los Angeles cannot be solved by anything as simple as a verdict.
And the realities of the courtroom, as the Rodney King beating trials sometimes surrealistically illustrated, can have little connection to the realities of the outside world. Few participants in the beating can have any very clear memory of that night after countless viewings of the videotape and seemingly limitless self-interested courtroom interpretations of the events it shows. Almost every one of the more than 51 baton blows has been subjected to contrasting explication.
And the re-showings and re-interpretations continue. The two men who were riding with Mr. King on the night of the beating have also sued for redress, though they were not beaten, kicked or stunned with Tazers as he was.
Reginald O. Denny, the white truck driver who found himself in an intersection that became the epicenter of the disturbances, has sued the police, asking $40 million for their failure to protect him during the riot. Thousands of other riot victims have brought lawsuits against the city.
As the legal repercussions continue, the two convicted officers, Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officer Laurence M. Powell, are appealing their conviction. The Justice Department is appealing back again, claiming that the sentence imposed by Judge Davies was too short. At the same time, Los Angeles Police Department administrative hearings are under way to dismiss formally three of the officers (the fourth, a rookie at the time of the beating, was fired outright).
 
Blame Away

 
 In this arena, it is Officer Theodore J. Briseno, who seemed the most passive on the videotape of the beating, who has suddenly become the most aggressive in wielding the legal system. The only one of the four officers who has an actual possibility of regaining his job, he is pointing fingers at everybody. In an administrative hearing that began briefly in August and will resume in December, he is blaming the department for the incident and the department in turn is blaming him.
The officer with the most imaginative defense during the trials (he said he was actually trying to protect Mr. King, not hurt him), Officer Briseno has found unexpected grounds for a counter-suit against Mr. King. The officer is accusing him of assault for his struggles during the beating.
For good measure, he is also suing his convicted colleague, Sergeant Koon, saying the sergeant should have stopped the beating and thereby saved him, and the entire city, from this endless legal roundelay.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Hopeful Future That Never Arrives

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
OVER the last several months, economic forecasters have arrived en masse at a somber conclusion: the American economy, with its daily reminders of hard times, won't show a noticeable improvement until next summer, at the very earliest, and perhaps much later.
Only last January, the economy seemed to be shaking off its funk. "It seemed to many of us to have a nice rosy glow of health about it," said Lyle Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "And all of a sudden that nice rosy glow was gone, and I don't know why."
But as the forecasters are scaling back their optimism, they leave two issues unsettled. 
 One is this: Is it so bad for the economy to grow slowly? After all, slow growth avoids inflation. And even slow growth can gradually create jobs. Eventually, enough jobs might appear to make Americans feel comfortable again. But not before 1995 or 1996.
Marvin Kosters, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, states the second issue. "The real question," he says, "is not whether the present situation is good or bad; the real question is, if we are unhappy with our situation, what price are we willing to pay to make it better?"
More to the point, if Americans don't like the current economic growth rate, which is less than 3 percent a year, what can they do about it? Apparently very little. One solution would be to pour money into Government spending, mainly for public works and other tangible items that require hiring a lot of workers. But the Clinton budget for the fiscal year that just began, with its emphasis on deficit reduction, forecloses that avenue.
With Government sidelined, consumers could strengthen the economy by borrowing and spending vigorously. But with raises and job security hard to come by, millions of Americans decline to take this road, although consumer spending has risen somewhat recently.
Another avenue for stronger economic growth is selling to foreigners. Rising exports, in fact, were billed last winter as the tactic that would lift the economy. But the Japanese and the Western Europeans, big buyers of American merchandise, have been having their own hard times -- and because of this, American exports have fallen, not risen.
Low interest rates -- the lowest in years -- have encouraged people to buy cars and appliances on credit and to build or buy homes. But as Mr. Gramley notes, the rise in home construction, of key importance for economic growth, has not been enough. "If you had asked last winter what would happen if rates dropped as much as they have, I would have predicted a boom in housing; that has not happened," Mr. Gramley said. "The only explanation that I can give you is that people are very worried about the future."
Just one of the nation's economic pillars, business spending for machinery and equipment, particularly computers, has been strong. But much of this spending results in automation that eliminates jobs.
The forecasters, in sum, see no wind on the horizon that will blow away the hard times. Or, as Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, puts it, with exasperation: "We live in this world in which the current quarter never seems to pan out as well as people thought it would, and then they say the upturn will be in the next quarter. And it is like waiting for Godot."
That is evident in the forecasts. The Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly newsletter that polls 51 forecasters for each issue, shows them scaling back their forecasts a little each month since April. Then they said the gross domestic product would grow this year at an annual rate of 3.3 percent and next year at 3.1 percent. That means that the value of all the new goods and services produced in a particular year would rise by these percentages.
 
Private Pessimism

 
 Now the Blue Chip forecasters have reduced their estimates to 2.6 percent this year and 2.7 percent next year. Mr. Reischauer's office has taken a similar action, and so has President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. Neither, however, is quite as pessimistic as the private forecasters, although everyone seems to agree that the economy is somewhat stronger than it was in the dismal first half of the year.
Still, only Mr. Clinton's economists expect the economy to manage a 3 percent growth rate in 1994. More than the others, the Administration is counting on the low interest rates to get people borrowing and spending, although Alan Blinder, a member of the Clinton Council, acknowledges that nervous Americans are not responding to low rates as they have in the past.
"It is one thing to say that the unemployment rate is only 6.7 percent and another to say how many Americans are suffering from job insecurity," Mr. Blinder said. "We have no measure of that."
A 3 percent annual growth rate is a sound barrier of sorts, most economists agree. The thinking goes this way. The economy has to grow at least by enough to create jobs for the people entering the work force, most of them young. Then additional growth is needed to create jobs and even new industries for all the people who are laid off at companies that manage to become just as productive with, say, 5 employees instead of 10.
The minimum annual growth in the G.D.P. to accommodate these two groups is thought to be 2.2 percent, roughly the 1992 growth rate. But no one really knows. If there are too many layoffs, the economy might have to grow by 2.5 percent to create enough jobs for everyone who wants one. Whatever the exact number, the gray area between 2.5 percent and 3 percent, the new range for the scaled back forecasts, is considered just enough to create jobs slowly, too slowly for most Americans to notice.
Only when the economy is growing at 3 percent or more for at least a year, an achievement last experienced in 1988, do labor shortages begin to develop, prompting employers to hold onto their workers, which improves their mood. "Until we get over 3 percent," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant, "there will be very little dent in the unemployment rate."
