HEADLINE: Israel's Right Wing in the Wilderness

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: TEL AVIV

 BODY:
FROM his spare seventh-floor office here, Ariel Sharon can see a thin gray line in the distance that is the Mediterranean. "The way things are going," the old general and Likud Party elder said, grimly joking, "I'm afraid that's where the Jews of Israel will be pushed."
Actually, if any back is to the sea, it is that of Israel's right wing, dominated by Likud and its young American-style leader, Benjamin Netanyahu. The right is convinced that Israel has put itself in mortal peril by accepting the legitimacy of the Palestine Liberation Organization and agreeing to Palestinian self-rule in the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. But it has yet to figure out how to respond effectively to this dramatic new situation, which caught it unawares and underlined how out of touch it is despite having run the Government for 15 years, until displaced last year by the Labor Party and its leader, Yitzhak Rabin. 
 In Israel, the words "right" and "left" have almost nothing to do with economic or social policies. Here, the core issue is whether territories captured in the 1967 war can be given up in the name of peace with the Arabs. And while definitions are imprecise, Israeli leftists generally favor concessions and rightists say no, whether out of security concerns or religious convictions that God promised those lands to the Jewish people. The more rightward one moves -- from Likud to small but important parties like Tsomet, the National Religious Party and Moledet -- the more hawkish views tend to be.
Since the deal with the P.L.O. first became known five weeks ago, rightists have marched against it, calling Mr. Rabin a traitor and a liar. Some of them have evoked the Holocaust and warned that a comparable disaster awaits Jews again. They have damned the Government as illegitimate. Citing Mr. Rabin's reliance on Israeli Arab parties to win parliamentary approval of the agreement 10 days ago, they have accused him of lacking "a Jewish majority," a catch phrase that strikes moderate Likudniks as morally racist and politically dumb. But what the right has conspicuously failed to do is provide a plausible alternative for the majority of Israelis who are exhausted by conflict and are ready to give this plan a chance, no matter how many doubts they may have.
"There is an intellectual vacuum," said Yossi Olmert, a spokesman for the last Likud Government. "People expect a new agenda from Likud, and all they're getting is the same old ideological slogans."
And for all the slogans, the accord has prompted a flurry of progress toward peace. On Friday in Washington, Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, and Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan shook hands at the White House to confirm that they are normalizing relations. Blocks away, a 43-nation conference pledged $2 billion to the occupied territories to insure the accord's success.
Perhaps no one has been more undercut by recent events than Mr. Netanyahu, who has come across as Dr. No, focusing on what he is against, not using his ample verbal skills to articulate what he is for. He bills himself as a pragmatist. Yet he strikes even some in his own camp as having been taken hostage by extremists and messianics, by doctrinaire small-party figures.
In recent days, Mr. Netanyahu seems to have heeded the complaints of internal critics like Mr. Sharon, who say Likud should stop flailing its arms at a done deal and focus its fire on specific perceived dangers in the accord. It must appeal more to the broad center where most Israelis reside, they say, and the Likud leader agrees, promising proposals soon to safeguard Israel's "military and demographic security" when the territories' final status is negotiated. One possible idea is to carve up the territories to protect certain Jewish settlements and keep the Israeli Army perched on strategic high ground.
 
Fervor and CashExtremists Only
 The right's difficulties were apparent at recent anti-Government rallies. Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of Jerusalem in the largest demonstrations in years. But they were top-heavy with young yeshiva students, settlers from the territories and black-hatted adherents of the Lubavitcher Hasidic sect, who have given this campaign the fervor and cash once devoted to proclaiming their spiritual guide as the Messiah.
It is significant who was not out there en masse: secular Israelis who form the backbone of Likud support, working-class people, business owners, yuppies. They are as tired as anyone else of dangerous army reserve duty in Gaza. Surveys suggest that fully a third of Likud voters endorse the agreement. When the plan went before Parliament, 3 of Likud's 32 members broke ranks with Mr. Netanyahu, abstaining rather than voting no, and several other colleagues were with them in spirit.
Not that these Likudniks have full faith in Mr. Rabin. But they cannot accept that this former army chief, who captured the territories in 1967, is guilty of treason. And they want nothing to do with the handful of fire-breathing visionaries threatening to gun down the first soldier who tries to evict them from their West Bank enclaves.
"When you put yourself in the same square with some of these people, you're saying that you're against peace, and nobody's going to vote you back into power," warned Meir Sheetrit, one of the Likud abstainers.
Even the protesters seem wary about going overboard at this point. Threatened acts of wide civil disobedience have failed to materialize.
It is still early, though, in the battle for Israeli hearts and minds. The latest polls show that while there continues to be majority support for the agreement, it is thinner than a few weeks ago. Mr. Netanyahu says this heartens him. But it is also worth noting that Israelis generally take their Government at its word on national security. Imagine, for example, hard-nosed Israelis agreeing not to retaliate against a sworn enemy who, unprovoked, fires nuclear-capable missiles at them. Yet that is precisely what they did during the Persian Gulf war. Polls showed overwhelming public support then for the Likud Government's decision to absorb Iraqi Scuds and, at Washington's behest, do nothing about it.
"People basically go with the flow," said Gadi Wolfsfeld, a political science professor at Hebrew University. "And if it looks good and the Government says it's all right, they say, Amen."

HEADLINE: Planners Say That Early Retirees Might Add Billions in Health Costs

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Clinton Administration health planners have begun to acknowledge that a politically important part of their plan could cost billions of dollars a year more than they anticipated.
The proposal would have the Government pay for most of the health insurance for early retirees, or those who retire before the age of 65, at which point they become eligible for Medicare. The plan is intended to win support from large manufacturers saddled with skyrocketing health insurance bills. 
 The Government would assume most of the health costs not only of these early retirees from big industry but also of any longtime worker who decided to retire early. And many would be expected to under the new health entitlement program.
 
Cost Estimate of $6 Billion
 Hillary Rodham Clinton said in Congressional testimony on Thursday that the proposal would cost about $4.5 billion a year, but Ira C. Magaziner, the President's top health adviser, said in an interview this week that the Administration planned to raise its official cost estimate to $6 billion.
Several other Government officials said that some internal Administration estimates suggest that the cost of assuming early retirement health care could reach $10 billion a year, a big difference for a plan with financing that has already been criticized as shaky.
The proposal could ultimately cost considerably more than even the upper-range estimates if far more people take advantage of it than now anticipated.
Some officials say the proposal, when effective, would lead 150,000 more Americans to retire before the age of 65; others put the number at 600,000. The more early retirees the provision produced, the more it would cost.
As with dozens of aspects of the Clinton health proposal, the estimates on early retirements are educated guesses about how Americans will change their behavior in response to it. Any time the Government sets out to restructure one-seventh of the economy, there are bound to be consequences that are unintended or fiendishly hard to predict or measure, economists say.
To help the big manufacturers with their health costs, the President proposed that companies pay 20 percent of health insurance for early retirees who now receive health coverage from their former employers. The Government would pay the rest. Many companies now pay 100 percent.
Mr. Magaziner's $6 billion-a-year estimate remains considerably lower than the General Accounting Office's calculation that American companies now pay $8.6 billion a year to provide health insurance for 2.5 million early retirees. The accounting office assumed that early retirees, on average, pay 20 percent of their health coverage themselves. The G.A.O. estimate does not include the surge in early retirements that is expected to result from the provision.
 
Some Retirees Would Pay
 For an early retiree whose former employer does not provide continued health coverage, the Government would pay 80 percent of the average cost of the insurance premium in the retiree's region and the retiree would pay the rest.
By guaranteeing health coverage for all Americans, the proposal would encourage workers to retire early because many who are at least 55 years old are believed to be working mainly because they need health insurance for themselves or their families. The proposal is also expected to give companies an incentive to push some older workers into retirement.
Under the proposal, a company that pays 80 percent of the health insurance for its employees might conclude that it could achieve significant savings by pushing some workers into early retirement, since the company would then have to pay only 20 percent of an early retiree's health insurance. The company might make such a move to reduce its work force or to replace the employee with a younger worker, perhaps at a lower salary.
Mr. Magaziner argued that the cost of the proposal could be held to $6 billion by the Administration's plan to reduce annual inflation in health care costs and by not discriminating by age in health insurance premiums. Administration officials said, for example, that the annual premium for a retired worker who is 60 years old and single would fall to $1,800 a year, down from perhaps $5,000 paid by his former employer under current premiums based on age.
"We've discussed this thoroughly, and I don't think there is disagreement now on what the numbers should be," Mr. Magaziner said.
In many ways, this proposal is a response to complaints from Ford, Chrysler and other large manufacturers -- and from the auto workers' and steelworkers' unions -- that their competitiveness was endangered by the huge burden of providing health insurance for their large number of early retirees.
Mrs. Clinton told the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday, "Those companies that are continuing to provide retiree benefits are doing so at an extraordinary cost that we think should be more broadly shared by the general public because their commitment to retiree health care is taking out of investment, wages, wage increases, profits -- money that should rightly go there instead of taking care of the work force that is no longer working."
One White House official said the proposal was so generous to these companies because they had got the President's ear early, when his health care proposals were being formed. Administration officials also noted that in most other industrial countries the governments, and not companies, pick up the health insurance costs for early retirees.
"There is a competitiveness issue here," Mr. Magaziner said. "You could argue that the thousands of manufacturing companies for which this is an issue got themselves into this problem by agreeing 15 years ago to support early retirees. But you could also say they had no idea that health care costs would skyrocket."
 
'A Big, Wet Kiss'
 While there is general agreement within the Administration about the importance of making American manufacturers more competitive, there is considerable debate about just how generous the Government should be with taxpayer dollars in pursuing this goal.
"This proposal is a big, wet kiss for large manufacturers," one Administration official said.
To reduce any windfall effect that manufacturers would enjoy, Mr. Magaziner said, the Administration is considering changes in its health proposal so that companies would have to pay 30 percent of the cost of the health insurance for early retirees rather than 20 percent.
In light of the hundreds of thousands of early retirees the plan would produce, the Administration is worried that by drawing from the Social Security trust fund rather than contributing to it, these retirees could endanger the fund.

HEADLINE: In Hanoi, U.S. Goods Sold but Not by U.S.

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Wandering the narrow streets of what was the enemy capital in the Vietnam War, American visitors to Hanoi can find themselves wondering, what American trade embargo?
Vietnam Airlines flies many of them here on its shiny new Boeing jets. The city's electronics stores carry I.B.M. and Apple computers, and even the computers that bear Taiwanese or Korean brand names are powered by a computer chip manufactured by the Intel Corporation. Those familiar yellow boxes of Kodak film are on sale in plenty of photo shops and for Hanoi teen-agers, Coca-Cola is the soft drink of choice. 
 Not far from Ho Chi Minh's hulking gray marble mausoleum, video shops are promising the first pirated copies of "Jurassic Park" some time this fall.
 
Foreign Middlemen Profit
 To a degree that the United States Government seems unwilling to admit, the 18-year-old American trade embargo on Vietnam is crumbling.
After generations of Communist central planning, the Hanoi Government is opening its economy to the world. And the technology that Washington had fought for so long to keep out of Vietnamese hands is getting here, usually through third-country middlemen who are delighted to profit from the sale of technology that Americans pioneered but cannot sell in Vietnam themselves.
American business executives eager to profit from one of the developing world's most promising markets insist that they -- not the Vietnamese -- are now the chief victims of the embargo.
 
'Losing a Market'
 Many Vietnamese agree. After years of accusing Washington of using the embargo to force this nation into submission, Vietnamese officials acknowledge that they are now getting most of the technology and foreign investment money that they can use, at least for today.
"Americans are losing a market of 72 million people that we don't need to lose," said James Rockwell, an American business consultant based in Hanoi whose clients include the Chrysler Corporation.
"Vietnam is not waiting for us anymore," he said, the American flag flapping in the humid breeze outside the window of his company's offices here. "Capitalism has run amok here, and the Vietnamese have decided to put together an economy with or without us."
Mr. Rockwell is helping Chrysler prepare to open car manufacturing plants in Vietnam when the embargo is lifted. But there is no guarantee that President Clinton will lift the embargo any time soon.
 
Japanese Open Factories
 And as Mr. Rockwell and Chrysler wait anxiously, Japanese car makers, unencumbered by the embargo and eager for a new beachhead in southeast Asia, are opening their first Vietnamese factories.
The complaints of American businesses ring hollow to the families of some of the more than 2,000 Americans still listed as missing in action from the Vietnam War.
Their fate is the issue that continues to divide Washington and Hanoi, and organizations representing some of the families say the Vietnamese Government is still giving only grudging cooperation to American military investigators.
Larry W. Rivers, a Vietnam veteran who is the executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said in a telephone interview from Washington that "our only concern is whether Vietnam is giving us a full accounting on the missing -- whether the embargo helps or hinders the American business community is not our focus."
 
Call for Brown to Quit
 On Thursday, an umbrella organization of 75 groups that represent Vietnam veterans or the families of missing Americans called for the resignation of the United States Commerce Secretary, Ron Brown, because of accusations that he accepted $700,000 from a Vietnamese businessman to lobby for an end to the trade embargo.
While Mr. Brown has denied the accusations, the controversy could further delay the lifting of the embargo. A group of Republican members of Congress has asked President Clinton to hold off on any move to improve relations with the Vietnamese Government until an investigation of Mr. Brown by a Federal grand jury in Miami is completed.
The American embargo was imposed when the Communist forces of North Vietnam overran the South in 1975. For more than a decade, the sanctions were undeniably effective in punishing Vietnam. Its economy stagnated, both because of the embargo and because of inept Government policies, and Vietnam remains one of the world's poorest nations.
But that is changing rapidly. Vietnam's fortunes began to improve in the late 1980's, when the nation's leaders abandoned Marxist economic theory and accepted free markets under a policy known as doi moi, or renovation.
At the same time, Vietnam moved to placate Washington. It released most of its political prisoners, pulled its troops out of Cambodia and, most important of all, expanded its cooperation in trying to determine the fate of Americans missing from the war.
 
Embargo Gradually Eased
 Washington has gradually eased the embargo. Shortly before he left office, President Bush allowed American firms to open representative offices in Vietnam.
In July, President Clinton decided to lift the American veto that had blocked billions of dollars in loans to Vietnam by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations. Those loans are expected to permit the Vietnamese to begin to rebuild their road network and power plants, and to create a modern telecommunications system.
When the embargo came up for renewal in September, President Clinton decided to allow American businesses to bid on projects financed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
But he kept in place what for most American businesses is the heart of the embargo. With few exceptions, American companies cannot manufacture or sell their goods here, even as their foreign competitors, mostly from Japan and elsewhere in Asia, move quickly to sew up the Vietnamese market before the Americans arrive.
 
Fear of Antagonizing Veterans
 More than 500 international investment projects, worth more than $5 billion, have already been approved by the Vietnamese Government. Only about $55 million of that directly involves American companies.
While eager to move into Vietnam -- with its well-educated, low-wage workers and great natural resources, including oil -- many large American corporations do not take a formal position on the question of whether the United States should lift the embargo.
Their reluctance to fight for an end to the sanctions reflects in part a fear of antagonizing veterans groups or the families of missing Americans. So far only three large American corporations have sent representatives to live in Vietnam -- International Business Machines, General Electric and Price Waterhouse.
I.B.M. is among the companies that take no formal position on the embargo. Still, the company's Hanoi representative, William Howell, who has lived in a hotel room here for the last five months, cannot hide his frustration at having to turn down so many inquiries from customers who are eager to buy his computers.
 
Frustration Over Lost Sales
 "It's very frustrating to look at a big market that we can't sell to," said Mr. Howell, who figures that I.B.M. could reap $50 million in annual sales in Vietnam by the end of the decade if the embargo is lifted.
That is not to say that the company's computers are not for sale in Vietnam. I.B.M. personal computers -- as well as computers made by big American competitors, including Apple and Compac -- are sold openly in both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, the southern Vietnamese city once known as Saigon, and can be found in use in Government ministries.
"It's easy to buy an I.B.M. in Vietnam, but we're not the ones selling it," grumbled Mr. Howell. American computers are imported by Asian middlemen who rake off much of the profit the manufacturers would otherwise make if they were allowed to sell and service their own computers here.
Among those who cannot buy I.B.M. computers in Vietnam are the large non-American foreign corporations -- banks, airlines, construction companies and the like -- that have set up offices in Hanoi. Many of them are loyal I.B.M. customers elsewhere in the world. But in Vietnam, they are usually forced to buy I.B.M. clones made outside the United States, often in Taiwan or Korea.
Boeing has a similar problem. Under the embargo, it cannot sell its jets to Vietnam Airlines, so the American company's planes must instead be leased to Vietnam by a non-American company that takes much of the profit that would otherwise go to Boeing.
 
Embargo Hurts Oil Companies
 Foreign middlemen bring to Vietnam a vast range of American brand consumer goods, from Eveready batteries to Kleenex tissue, by transshiping them through other Asian countries. Because the embargo has prevented the Hollywood studios from policing the video market here, the latest films are widely available on black market cassettes, smuggled across the border from Cambodia and translated into Vietnamese.
Almost certainly the biggest corporate losers as a result of the embargo are American oil companies, which have been barred in Vietnam from bidding on rich offshore tracts in the South China Sea.
For several years, Vietnamese officials had hinted that they were willing to set aside some of the most promising tracts for the American oil giants. But soon, all of the best oil-drilling zones will be committed to non-American companies.
"The opportunities for American companies are getting very narrow now," said Do Duc Dinh, an economist with Hanoi's Institute of World Economies. "We want to do business with the Americans. But Vietnam cannot wait forever."

HEADLINE: Canada's U.S. Trade Experience Fuels Opposition to the New Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRANTFORD, Ontario

 BODY:
Debbie Annis came to the door of her gray two-story, vinyl-sided house on Ninth Avenue, in the shadow of the industrial skeletons on Mohawk Street that used to make tractors, electric blankets and woolens in Canada's manufacturing heartland.
Michael Smith, candidate on the political left for Brantford's parliamentary seat in the federal elections on Oct. 25, told her that his New Democratic Party, which has held the seat for 22 years, would jettison both the North American Free Trade Agreement and free trade with the United States. 
 Ms. Annis, 41, who used to be a real estate agent, said that would suit her just fine. "Free trade is killing Canada," she lamented. "Brantford is turning into a ghost town."
 
Effect on Property Values
 A house across the street, she noted, was put on the market two years ago for $95,000, and is now being offered at $76,000. "You can't buy a house here because you don't know whether you'll have a job tomorrow," she said.
A few doors down, Dennis Garvey, 37, has been unemployed since the Massey-Ferguson farm equipment plant closed in 1986, except for three years he spent as a bartender.
"All the jobs have gone to Mexico," he said. A year after the closing of the Massey plant, he was divorced. "My ex-wife is now out of work, too," he told Mr. Smith. He supplements his welfare check by working as a handyman. He blames free trade as well.
 
Opposition to Free Trade
 The comments of Ms. Annis and Mr. Garvey, two of Brantford's 82,000 citizens, go far to show why free trade, which dominated the last federal elections in 1988, after Canada and the United States worked out free trade between themselves, is unpopular with many, if not most, Canadians.
Once one of the brightest names in Canada's industrial firmament, Massey ended all farm equipment manufacturing in the late 1980's, cut its staff by tens of thousands, diversified into auto parts and moved its headquarters to Buffalo.
It is just one of scores of heavy-duty manufacturing enterprises around the western end of Lake Ontario and southwestern Ontario that have either closed or shrunk in Canada's prolonged recession.
Because this retrenchment has come as Canada has been adjusting to lower trade barriers with the United States, Mr. Smith, with the bouncy step of the Fuller Brush man and a bundle of fliers, has found that many on Ninth Avenue share the views of Ms. Annis and Mr. Garvey, and his own, and are ready to scrap free trade.
Now with Nafta geared to opening both countries' dealings with Mexico and intensifying the breakdown of trade walls between Canada and the United States, anxiety about job losses from increased trade competition has increased in Ontario, which accounts for nearly half of Canada's population and economic output.
The disquiet is shared in most other provinces. Some 55 to 60 percent of Canadians continue to tell poll takers they do not like free trade.
Some of the western beef and grain-growing regions, dependent on export markets, are less hostile. In Quebec, which often takes a contrarian view on much in Canadian life, sentiment in favor of free trade is also stronger -- linked, political analysts say, to separatist feelings. An independent Quebec would count on hardy trading relationships to the south.
With national elections scheduled for Oct. 25, Canadians -- whose unemployment rate of 11.3 percent is half again as high as that of the United States -- are fretting more about employment than any other issue. They worry about jobs lost not only to Monterrey and Mexico City, but also to Buffalo, Spokane or Nashville.
 
Factors in Jobless Rate
 Although the Canadian jobless rate was only 7.5 percent on Jan. 1, 1989, when free trade with the United States went into effect, economists caution against attributing all of the rise to the trade agreement. Canada has also suffered in the period from one of its most severe postwar recessions. The Canadian economy is more heavily resource-based than that of the United States, and thus has been hurt more by declines in prices in recent years for such raw materials as lead, zinc, copper, nickel, timber and petroleum.
Canada's economic size, measured by gross domestic product, is about a tenth that of the United States. And its dependence on the United States for 80 percent of its trade made the bilateral free trade pact far more sensitive here than in the United States.
Also weighing heavily was the perception that free trade further erases Canada's distinctness and more deeply reinforces the power and influence of American multinational companies and American culture.
Organized labor led the fight against free trade in 1988 and, like labor in the United States, is vehemently resisting the North American Free Trade Agreement today. The farm community is divided. The favorable stand of the big wheat and beef growers is countered by the opposition of small farmers who fear increased competition and erosion of their subsidies. Farmers, though representing only about 3.5 percent of the population, are a potent political force, as in the United States.
 
Five Years of Building Support
 But circumstances are different from what they were five years ago, when the two main political parties, Conservatives and Liberals, were at each other's throats over trade. Despite free trade's unpopularity, it is deeply enough entrenched now to build support groups.
Old manufacturing industries have been clobbered, but new high-technolgy export industries like precision instruments, telecommunications, computer parts and specialized machinery are starting to flourish.
"If you look at the last two and one-half years," said John Kirton, a specialist in international economic policy at the University of Toronto, "you'll see that virtually 100 percent of our growth has come from exports. Given the deficit, the debt load and the decline in income tax revenues, where would the Canadian economy be today if we hadn't had that growth?"
In Brantford, Mayor Bob Taylor put it this way: "We have a shadow that sits over the city, yes, but people are also seeing that companies can come in and prosper." Those companies include Gates Canada Inc., with 600 people making automotive belts and hoses, Eagle Precision Technologies Inc., with 200 workers producing machines that make auto mufflers, or Western Foundry Company Ltd., a manufacturer of exhaust manifolds with a work force of 100.
A study by the C.D. Howe Institute, a policy research group, found that free trade has so far cost Canada more jobs than it gained, but the study concludes that the tide will soon turn and that the new jobs already created are better paying.
 
Losers Are Labor-Intensive
 The losers -- old-line businesses like food processing and makers of furniture, appliances and clothing -- tended to be labor-intensive. The winners are high-technology companies that pay more because of higher skills that add greater value to the end product. On average, the study found pay to be 20 percent higher in the expanding industries.
"In the first couple of years the employment impact was very negative," said Daniel Schwanen, a Howe policy analyst. "Now we're close to seeing a turnaround because of exports. In terms of dollars and cents, we're already getting positive results."
The political configurations have changed as well. In fighting free trade five years ago, Liberals gave the Tories a second term. Today the official Liberal stand supports free trade, but the party leader, Jean Chretien, wants the North American trade pact "improved," specifically to define trade subsidies and set rules more precisely for retaliatory action when trade laws are infringed.
The Clinton Administration, struggling for Congressional approval of the existing accord, voices little sympathy, even though Mr. Chretien is only emulating President Clinton, who insisted on the recently negotiated side deals related to labor and the environment when he took office.
Asked if the United States would go along with a request for negotiations by a new Canadian Government, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said: "No, we're interested in putting this into effect. It's in the best interest of all three countries."
 
Awaiting the Elections
 The pact has already been approved by the lower house of Parliament. Former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, free trade's champion, made sure of that before leaving office in June. One tiny step remains before full Canadian ratification -- the formal promulgation of a final order by Governor General Ramon J. Hnatyshyn, which now awaits the outcome of the elections.
Should Mr. Chretien become Prime Minister, and the United States Congress pass the deal, analysts predict some face-saving approach for Canada that would probably not involve full-scale negotiations or a resubmission to Congress.
The popularity of two other parties contesting the elections -- the populist Reform Party with its base in the mid-continent, and the Bloc Quebecois, which wants to prepare the nation for Quebec's separation, raises the strong possibility of a minority government.
Without an absolute majority, Mr. Chretien, 59, who is now favored in public-opinion surveys, could be dependent on the New Democrats. But their leader, Audrey McLaughlin, has said her price for support is renunciation of Nafta and the existing pact with the United States. So the outlook is for much political uncertainty.
Kim Campbell, 46, the former Vancouver lawyer who replaced Mr. Mulroney as Prime Minister and leader of the Conservatives, strongly defends Nafta and the agreement with the United States.
 
Too Many Promises
 Many, including Ms. Campbell, believe that free trade would have had an easier ride here had its advocates promised less. "Some areas of Canada's manufacturing industry were perhaps too optimistic about their ability to be competitive in the short term," Ms. Campbell said recently in a campaign swing through southern Ontario.
Another factor was the rejection by the Government of programs of trade adjustment assistance, which have been enacted in the United States, giving workers special help if imports wipe out their jobs.
Interviews in Brantford found general agreement even among supporters that the process came about too abruptly and for many did not leave an adequate cushion.
Christine Monks, 36, a school bus driver, who was eating at the Sub Tub luncheonette, across the street from the carcass of an old textile plant not far from Ninth Avenue, said, "Free trade is bound to happen globally, but for us there was too fast a transition."
Diane Russell, 47, who works in the reconditioning department of the Johnson's Wax company, which employs 220 people, added: "I think free trade did a lot to devastate this country. But we can't go back. We've paid our dues."

He spoke with Dennis Garvey, who is opposed to the free trade programs. (Elisavietta Ritchie for The New York Times) (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: 2 Largest Hospital Chains in U.S. Merge

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In the latest consolidation reflecting powerful pressures for change in health care, the nation's largest hospital chains, Columbia Healthcare Inc. and HCA-Hospital Corporation of America, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge. The new company, which would operate 190 hospitals, would be the largest investor-owned hospital chain in the world.
Richard L. Scott, the chairman and chief executive of Columbia, who will be the president and chief executive of the new company, said the value of the deal was $10.25 billion, making it the seventh-largest merger in any industry since 1981. He said it would be accomplished in a tax-free exchange of shares. No cash will be involved. 
 The merger is the largest in a wave of health care industry consolidations across the country in anticipation of President Clinton's health care proposals and growing pressure to slow increases in health costs.
Only last month, the Columbia Hospital Corporation, as it was known then, completed a merger with the Galen Health Care Inc. hospital chain, which had been owned Humana Inc., a large health maintenance company. Columbia changed its name after the merger.
 
Approval Needed
 And Merck & Company, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, is awaiting regulatory approval of a merger valued at $6 billion with Medco Containment Services, a mail-order and discount drug distributor.
Subject to approval by shareholders and Federal antitrust regulators, the new company formed by Columbia and HCA, which will have 125,000 employees in 26 states, will be called Columbia/HCA Hospital Corporation. The executive offices will be in Louisville, Ky., and Nashville.
"The Government ought to love this one," said Dr. Thomas A. Frist Jr., the chairman of HCA, who will be the chairman of the new company's board. "This is exactly what the Clinton Administration is seeking."
Dr. Frist, a physician, was the highest paid executive in the country last year as the head of HCA. He received $127 million in compensation, mainly through options to buy and sell stock at steep profits.
Dr. Frist, 55, whose family still owns HCA shares worth $409 million, said he would be "in no way retiring."
 
A Surprise to Analysts
 The merger, coming so soon after the Columbia-Galen merger, surprised Wall Street securities analysts. "It is very unusual," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "After companies make a major acquisition, they usually digest it for one or two years before moving on."
But John F. Hindelong, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said "the time is right" for hospital mergers. "The Clinton Administration is encouraging consolidation, networking and cost reduction -- all of which will result in the Columbia-HCA merger," he said.
Mr. Scott said in a telephone interview yesterday that the new company would be in a stronger position to compete for national business and to offer lower prices at a time when both the Government and private purchasers were insisting on economies.
"Nobody is succeeding unless they are reducing costs," he said. "We will save at least $138 million a year," by eliminating duplication in hospital administration and other costs that do not affect patient care, he said.
 
Good Relations with Doctors
 He added that both companies have reputations for good relations with physicians. Columbia, which was started in Fort Worth, has a policy of offering local doctors a chance to buy minority ownership in hospitals where they work.
In a joint statement, Mr. Scott and Dr. Frist said "health care delivery in the future will focus on quality results and cost efficient operations." They said the merger would strengthen their efforts toward this goal.
Although the new company would have revenues this year exceeding $10 billion, that would be only 3 percent of the widely scattered $325 billion hospital industry, Mr. Hindelong said.
Columbia operates 94 general and specialty hospitals with 21,627 beds. HCA-Hospital Corporation operates 96 general and specialty hospitals with 20,485 beds, including 20 psychiatric hospitals. Both companies also operate diagnostic, outpatient and other treatment centers.
Columbia will dominate the board of directors of the new company with 11 members including Carl F. Pollard, a former Humana and Galen hospital executive, who will be the chairman of the new executive committee. HCA will have four board members.

HEADLINE: For 3 Tabloid Papers, Some More Tightrope

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
With the successful completion of Rupert Murdoch's long struggle to buy back The New York Post, newspaper analysts and executives say New York City's three money-losing tabloid newspapers appear to be poised on the brink of a strange new era of resilient nonprosperity.
It is shaping up, these experts say, as an extended period of unaccustomed stability for The Post, The Daily News and New York Newsday, based on the deep pockets of their owners -- a period of labor peace and financial security that seemed highly unlikely even a few months ago. 
 But while The Post and The News have survived bankruptcies, labor strife and repeated brushes with death, they and the more even-keeled New York Newsday, the analysts say, face continuing losses or at best marginal profitability for years to come in an anemic advertising market battered by prolonged recession and dominated by The New York Times.
And the new era promises to be one of fierce competition among the feisty tabloid papers, with intense battles for limited numbers of readers and retail advertising dollars -- a fight that experts say is still likely to end, sooner or later, in the long-predicted death of one or more of the newspapers.
 
'Not All Three'
 "There is simply not going to be room for three tabloids, along with The New York Times, in New York City," Gerald D. Reilly, a consultant on newspaper investments, said in an interview. "I think the city can support one and a half tabloids, or maybe two can get by. But not all three."
Each newspaper faces a different set of problems. But the problem for all, say Mr. Reilly and other analysts, is that many big retail stores have gone out of business, limiting a prime source of advertising revenue, which is the lifeblood of newspapers. Moreover, the combined circulation of the three papers, just under 1.5 million, is unlikely to grow much, if at all.
The Post, which has been losing $14 million to $18 million a year recently and has been battered by bankruptcy, staff rebellions, repeated shutdowns and a succession of wound-be owners, emerged from the graveyard on Friday when Mr. Murdoch, who owned the paper from 1976 to 1988, reacquired it in a $25 million deal to pay creditors, back taxes, pension claims and administrative costs.
There is no question that Mr. Murdoch, whose holdings under the News Corporation had a profit of $605 million in the year ended June 30, has the money to keep The Post going indefinitely. And industry analysts say that while he usually discards money-losing properties, he may be willing to run The Post at a slight deficit because of the prestige and fun of being a New York publisher.
Mr. Murdoch, industry analysts say, is a shrewd businessman with the muscle to handle unions and the streetwise tactics to run newspapers. In a showdown last week, he virtually destroyed the Newspaper Guild unit representing The Post's news and advertising personnel, who will have to apply for their own jobs this week. And having signed nine craft unions to contracts cutting The Post's deficit by millions, Mr. Murdoch now plans a fight for readers and advertisers.
 
Formidable Challenges
 He faces formidable challenges, analysts say. The Post has no Sunday paper, limiting its circulation and advertising potential. Even the daily Post has become all but irrelevant to major advertisers; two-thirds of its readers take another paper, so advertisers can reach them without The Post. And the paper must confront a huge loss of readers, down to about 440,000 from a million a decade ago.
Patrick Purcell, The Post's publisher, declined in an interview to discuss what is expected to be a sharp paring of the staff of 700, but he said The Post planned to "go upmarket and be very issue oriented" in its quest for readers and advertisers.
The survival of The Post, fiscal analysts say, may have the most impact on The Daily News, which itself seemed doomed in recent years by strikes, bankruptcy and other troubles, including the loss of $100 million over the last decade and drastic declines in circulation.
Once the nation's largest daily, with 2.4 million readers in 1947, The News epitomized tabloid journalism with its news coverage and snappy pictures, headlines and writing. But many of its readers were lost to television and the suburbs; by 1990 its daily circulation had dropped to 1.2 million, and today it is about 770,000. The Sunday News circulates about 977,000 copies.
Sold in 1991 by the Tribune Company of Chicago to Robert Maxwell, the British publisher whose death at sea and postmortem bankruptcy left it in turmoil, The News was bought for $37.3 million last January by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the multimillionaire real-estate developer and owner of U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic magazine.
Mr. Zuckerman's promise to revitalize The News by practicing street-smart journalism for ordinary New Yorkers has met with some success. The News's circulation has rebounded from drastic losses during a five-month strike two years ago, and advertisers have been attracted by a new television-listings magazine in the Sunday paper and other supplements and features.
Beginning his tenure by dismissing 170 news and advertising employees, Mr. Zuckerman vowed to cut losses estimated to be about $7 million a year. Some analysts say he may yet succeed in his goal of breaking even the first year.
 
Major Hurdles
 But he faces major long-term hurdles, including the huge expense of buying or building a new printing plant with color presses, newspaper executives said. Moreover, Mr. Zuckerman, who had every reason to believe that The Post, his main competitor, would vanish in 1993, now faces a long competition with Mr. Murdoch.
New York Newsday is now in its eighth year as a stepchild of Newsday, the highly successful Long Island paper. It is owned by the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles, one of the nation's most prosperous newspaper companies, which has made a long-term commitment despite New York Newsday's annual losses ranging from $8 million to $14 million.
Robert M. Johnson, the publisher of Newsday, recently told the staff of New York Newsday that he was personally committed to cutting those losses to $5 million a year in the next few years and to breaking even by 1998. At the same time, however, he said that the company did not expect circulation to rise as much.
New York Newsday's circulation in the five boroughs is about 275,000 daily and 269,000 on Sundays, according to a spokeswoman, Chiara Coletti. She said circulation increases of 30,000 or 40,000 a year were common in the paper's start-up years, but that growth in the next few years was expected to be 5,000 to 6,000 a year.
The prosperity of the Times Mirror Company and Long Island Newsday seems to guarantee New York Newsday's future. But while Mr. Johnson and other executives insist that the commitment to New York Newsday is open-ended, some analysts believe Newsday and its parent may eventually become frustrated if the New York circulation does not grow much beyond 300,000 and cumulative losses -- now said to be about $100 million -- are unchecked.
New York Newsday has acquired large segments of The Daily News's circulation in Brooklyn and Queens, and it has aimed at the more educated and affluent readers of The Times for much of its continued growth.
But some analysts say New York Newsday has always had an identity problem: whether to be a street-smart city tabloid or a more respectable, well-written suburban paper, with a balance of city, national and foreign affairs that is more typical of The Times and other broadsheets.
The Times has a daily circulation of more than 1.2 million and 1.8 million on Sundays, much of it outside New York City. It views itself as competing for news, readers and advertising in many markets, including the city, where it has worked lately to expand local and regional coverage and to reach a younger audience.
Financial analysts say The Times is more concerned about competition from New York Newsday than from The Daily News, but still has a majority of the local advertising market, with the rest split among the other newspapers.
Moreover, The Times, with its heavy emphasis on international, national and economic news, reaches an older, more established and more affluent readership, while New York Newsday has focused on the middle class, particularly younger, well-educated readers.

HEADLINE: California Questioning Clinton's Promise of Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2

 BODY:
When President Clinton arrives in California on Sunday evening for his second visit in a month, he will find growing impatience and political rancor over his Administration's response to the battered local economy.
Increasingly, even strong backers of the President among business and political leaders here are saying he must act quickly to reverse California's deepening slide into recession or risk losing the most populous state's 54 electoral votes in 1996. 
 The White House has responded by assigning several staff members to work on a California plan to supplement the efforts of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, assigned last May by Mr. Clinton to oversee recovery efforts here. A number of leaders here have complained to the White House that Mr. Brown, while saying the right things, has produced little.
While the Administration has taken steps to bolster the state's economy, the effort has taken on new urgency as California's recession deepens and as complaints from Clinton backers in the state rise.
 
Call for 'Real Initiatives'
 "It's hard for me to understand the delay," Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat who faces re-election next year, said in a telephone interview from Washington. "We need some real initiatives to put a focus on California."
Senator Feinstein has been urging the Administration to use Federal money to aid military conversion in California and to build a high-speed rail corridor down the middle of the state.
And last Tuesday about 15 top Southern California corporate executives met privately with David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in Los Angeles. According to a person present, the executives were blunt in describing the consequences of failing to act soon.
Their comments echoed those of Bill Press, chairman of the California Democratic Party, who said: "I've been saying to them California is Iowa without the floods -- it's that critical. The only way to turn it around is focused attention from the top."
 
Huge Layoffs
 While the Administration has made no explicit commitments to aid California, it is taken as a given by the White House that there can be no full national recovery without California and possibly no re-election in 1996 without a major reversal of fortunes in this state, where the end of the cold war has brought huge layoffs at bases and in military industries, contributing to unemployment on a scale not known since the Depression.
The main purpose of the President's three-day visit is to promote his health plan. But while he is in San Francisco to address the national A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention on Monday, Mr. Clinton is expected to take the opportunity to announce concrete action on the California economy.
A broader strategy of aid has been under discussion at the National Economic Council in Washington, White House officials say. But there is debate over whether to begin implementing them gradually or to have the President make a full-blown announcement that might raise undue expectations about what the strapped Federal Government can do to cure problems caused by global economic changes.
 
'Unrealistic Expectations'
 The political risks have not escaped the White House. Mr. Clinton won California last year with 44 percent of the vote in the three-way Presidential vote in which President George Bush's perceived insensitivity to California's declining fortunes was a major issue.
"People are impatient, but there are unrealistic expectations of what one person can accomplish," said Tom Epstein, who as a special assistant to the President for political affairs is in charge of dealing with the California issue at the White House.
"We know the economy won this campaign," Mr. Epstein said. "The President is deeply committed to getting the California economy back on track. But California was in a tailspin when he was elected. Nothing this Administration can do will turn it around quickly. It will take several years."
On a hopeful note, he added, "People will see some immediate benefits before the end of the year."
 
Loss of Jobs, and People
 Since Mr. Clinton's election, the California unemployment rate has hovered near 10 percent, two or three percentage points above the national average. More than 22,000 jobs have been lost in the last month alone, and 1.4 million people are unemployed. Nearly 300,000 jobs have disappeared because of Federal cuts in military spending. In the computer industry there has been a net loss of 50,000 high-tech jobs and a halving of new business formations over the last five years.
Military base closings have hit Northern California hard, but the part of the state that has been hit hardest is Southern California, long a center of aircraft, weapons and missile production. After decades of torrid growth, the population of Los Angeles is now declining.
 
Winning Applause
 The President's options are limited, given the tight budget. He won applause here on Wednesday when he eased cold-war-era export controls on computers and other high-tech products, a measure expected to help the computer industry. But California is clamoring for policies specifically tailored to its problems.
The Administration says it has already taken substantial steps to help the economy here. Mr. Epstein said the President had directed about a quarter of Defense Department money for conversion of military industries to California and acted to speed up transfer of closed bases to the local authorities.
Both Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have made numerous visits to California. Mr. Gore has been particularly interested in efforts to tie the thousands of high-tech companies in Silicon Valley, south of San Francisco, into a new fiber-optics communication system.
 
'California Project'
 And Mr. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, has created a "California Project" in his department, with offices in Washington, Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Melinda C. Yee, a special assistant to Mr. Brown who heads the San Francisco office, said the project had drawn officials from several Federal agencies to make recommendations on issues like speeding the transfer of unneeded military bases to local governments for conversion to other uses.
She said her office had also been working on helping cut red tape to speed Federal aid to dredging San Francisco Bay, considered essential to keep the port of Oakland competitive. And the Commerce Department has 10 people helping the Silicon Valley Global Trading Center, an office sponsored by the computer industry to help small companies market their products abroad.
 
'A Lot of Photo Ops'
 While welcome, such gestures are widely viewed as inadequate. "There are a lot of photo ops, but we have not yet seen a Federal response," said Tom Hayes, chairman of Joint Venture: Silicon Valley, an organization of companies and local governments formed to stimulate the local economy.
Jack A. Kyser, chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County, a private business group trying to help retool the area's battered economy, said it appeared to him that the Administration "doesn't know quite what to do."
Mr. Kyser, who described himself as a Clinton Republican, added: "Last year I said the Bush people did not seem to know what was going on. But now the bloom is off the rose for Clinton. Clinton Republicans are asking who the Republicans will run in 1996. Bill Clinton will have a tough time to carry California again."

HEADLINE: Led by Private Sector, Free Trade Unites Colombia and Venezuela

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Colombia's ties with Venezuela have been hailed as one of the most successful examples of economic integration between two developing countries.
While most free-trade pacts have been made possible through government initiative, Colombian and Venezuelan integration has been preempted by the private sector. 
 "We reversed the order," said the Colombian Foreign Minister, Juan Manuel Santos. "We lowered tariffs and let things happen. The private sector showed us how."
Integration between Colombia and Venezuela is formally derived from the Andean Pact, an agreement that also includes Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru. Early last year, the pact's five members vowed to liberalize trade and create joint external tariffs.
The fact that Colombia and Venezuela followed a continentwide tendency toward open-market economies has eased free trade. "If we had not gone this far, both countries would have felt the brunt of the worldwide recession," Mr. Santos said.
But economic troubles in Peru, elections in Ecuador and stalling in Bolivia prevented decisive action. So Colombia and Venezuela forged ahead, eliminating trade barriers, harmonizing customs laws and setting common external tariffs of 5 to 20 percent.
Venezuelan investors were focusing their attention on the Colombian financial sector, which had recently been deregulated. Banco Mercantil, one of Venezuela's largest financial corporations, bought a Colombian bank two years ago and opened a branch office here. Banco Latino, which has become Venezuela's largest financial group, is now in business in Colombia. Venezuelan investors own over 20 percent of Colombian Banco Ganadero, a recently privatized conglomerate.
Oswaldo Cisneros, a Venezuelan businessman who controls a large part of cellular phone communications in Venezuela, recently signed up with a group of Colombian investors to make his debut in communications here. And the Colombian Petrochemical Group obtained a stake in one of Venezuela's biggest industries when it bought two plants in Venezuela.
Governments are rapidly following suit. Beginning this year, Venezuela issued $150 million worth of government debt bonds in Colombian money markets. Venezuela is taking steps to deregulate its financial sector. Once this is done, Colombian investment in this area is expected to rise sharply.
Trade between the two countries has increased from about $340 million in 1987 to over $1 billion in 1992. They now represent each other's second largest markets after the United States.
Where there is a potential for competition, agreements in the private and public sectors have established quotas to insure a fair share in the market for each side. Overlapping exports in the metal industry led business leaders in both nations to sign a one-year pact establishing export quotas. Similarly, both agricultural ministries agreed on quotas for competing rice and potato production.
Venezuela and Colombia account for about 70 percent of the trade within the Andean Pact. Negotiations are under way to set common external tariffs with Ecuador, a move that will involve slight changes in the numbers already bargained on by Colombia and Venezuela.
"It's a difficult process," a Colombian diplomat said. "The more countries, the more difficult integration will become."

HEADLINE: Rebuilt Pittsburgh Economy Braces for New Blow Under a U.S. Health Plan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL DeCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
This city may always be known as Steel Town, but Medicine City would more accurately describe its economy today.
Health care became the dominant industry here after global competition wiped out most of the area's steel mills in the early 1980's. The health industry's steady growth, adding about 4,000 jobs a year in the last decade, helped revive the economy. The local hospitals have a worldwide reputation for transplant surgery and high-technology medicine. 
 Now, the prospect of a new national health care system is seen as a threat to the economic foundation of a region that has nearly as many magnetic resonance imaging X-ray devices as all of Canada. The new system will challenge an industry that economists say has too many hospitals, too many administrators and too many staff members.
The health care industry buoys the local economy by providing nearly 1 of every 8 jobs and by generating $3.8 billion a year, or about 9 percent of the region's total spending.
 
11.8% in Health Care Force
 Though Pittsburgh's economy is far from alone in its dependence on the medical industry, it is vulnerable because the region has 108,000 health workers, or 11.8 percent of its total work force in July, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. No other metropolitan area has such a high proportion of health workers.
If the Clinton health plan is approved and if it works as advertised, Pittsburgh's growth will stall, economists say, as its health industry becomes more efficient. The question is what will happen over the long term.
"It's clear that the health care sector here will not be a major source of growth in the future, if the Clinton plan goes as it is," said Judith R. Lave, a professor of health economics at the University of Pittsburgh. "It will be hard for Pittsburgh to adjust, but I don't think it's all gloom and doom."
As hospitals shed beds, thousands of jobs go with them. But some health economists expect that the loss of hospital jobs will be largely offset by increasing employment in the growing health sectors like home care, nursing homes and suburban clinics.
Nearly 15 percent of the region's 2.1 million residents lack health insurance. As these people obtain coverage, they will increase demand for primary and preventive services, said Margaret A. Potter, associate director of the Health Policy Institute at the University of Pittsburgh.
 
5-Year Stall Predicted
 And because the Pittsburgh region has the nation's second-oldest population of any in the country, after Miami, economists predict that the elderly's need for health care here will continue to rise slowly through the year 2030, even as Pittsburgh's population declines.
"My gut feeling is that health care will stop adding jobs for a five-year transition period, when some job shrinkage will occur, and then jobs would start to grow again," said Paul R. Flora, regional economist for the PNC Bank Corporation here.
Many health care workers already face a revolving job market. Last December, for example, Denise Kovach lost her job as a registered nurse at Forbes Metropolitan Hospital in Pittsburgh. "You can't take a job and think it's going to last forever anymore," said Ms. Kovach, 43.
The hospital, concerned about its future in a crowded market, converted from a 175-bed general hospital to a 121-bed institution serving only convalescing patients, said Dawn M. Gideon, a senior vice president with the Forbes Health System, which runs the hospital. She said the hospital laid off 292 of its 668 employees, but in March rehired 60 of them, including Ms. Kovach, as well as 40 new employees, when the transition was completed.
 
Support for Clinton Plan
 Hospital officials here said in interviews that they generally supported the Clinton plan, despite the spending reductions it promises. Many said the plan would accelerate some industry trends already under way.
"We believe that the plan has been pretty much anticipated, and our overall view of it is quite positive," said Jack C. Robinette, president of the Hospital Council of Western Pennsylvania.
Hospitals here are converting wards to outpatient services from inpatient ones, opening up suburban clinics that provide primary and preventive care, and canceling purchases of experimental medical equipment.
The change, Ms. Gideon of the Forbes Health System said, reduced her hospital's operating costs to an estimated $33 million this year from $46 million last year.
 
Tougher Times Ahead
 As the pace of change quickens, however, some economists say that more workers may be out of jobs, and for longer periods. Some may have to take lower paying jobs and others may need to move out of the region to find work. The jobless rate was 6.9 percent in July, the same as the national rate. And almost none of the hospitals are unionized, so workers have few contractual protections to ease the transition.
The biggest shake-up in Pittsburgh's health industry will occur if hospitals start dealing aggressively with the oversupply of beds. Pittsburgh has more than three times as many beds per capita as the nation, on average. On any one night in the metropolitan area nearly 30 percent of the 10,600 beds are vacant.
Such high hospital vacancy rates are a national problem, and pressure to eliminate the oversupply of beds would increase under a system that emphasized preventive treatment and steered more people to outpatient care.
A half-dozen hospitals have closed or merged in the last three years and, this year, hospitals have laid off 1,000 workers, from administrators to housekeepers.
 
A $60,000 Job, Lost
 Gloria Blint moved here with her husband and two small children from Erie, Pa., last summer to take a $60,000-a-year job as director of communications at a local hospital. In April the hospital eliminated many administrative jobs, including Ms. Blint's.
"I've been out of college 13 years and I've never lost a job," she said. "This was a shock."
Ms. Blint has not been able to find a comparable job in the region and does not want to uproot her family by moving again. She is considering starting her own advertising agency. "I'm going to stay the heck out of health care," she said.
Since losing his job as a personnel director at an area hospital in February, Jim Anderson, 57, said he has sent out 900 resumes and had 17 interviews for jobs as far away as Wisconsin. "A lot of human resource people are out of work," he said. He finally got a job, starting this month, at a hospital in Rome, N.Y.
Even the region's prestigious academic medical center, the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, is laying off workers and shifting them in large numbers. The center, a pioneer in transplant surgery and cancer research, is the region's largest private employer, with a staff of 12,000.
In June, the center laid off 250 workers and eliminated another 250 empty positions, mostly in administrative areas. The center is also shifting about 400 employees from its hospitals to new suburban clinics that will provide primary care, said Jeffrey A. Romoff, the center's president.
The center, which has a $1.3 billion annual operating budget, and the region could be hurt financially if an overhaul of health care limits peoples' choice of hospitals, Mr. Romoff said. Three-quarters of the center's patients come from outside Pittsburgh. "The Clinton plan recognizes this problem, but how it will work out is uncertain," he said.
 
Cutback on Technology
 The prospect of change in health care is also putting a damper on purchases of new medical technology. Mercy Hospital, for example, has decided against spending $3.1 million on an experimental scanning device used for studying the brain and other organs.
"We are reviewing all new requests for technology, to make sure we can manage them within our cost structure and remain competitive," said Michele Rone Cooper, a vice president of Mercy Health System, which operates the nonprofit teaching hospital.
Such caution is hurting Pittsburgh's nascent medical technology industry, which includes about 75 companies and 5,000 employees.
"Quite frankly, I don't see any new medical device companies starting up, and there is going to be a tremendous struggle for the others, without mergers or something like that," said Irene R. Skolnick, president of Dymax Corporation, a manufacturer of medical probes and scanning devices. She said declining sales had forced her to lay off three of the company's 25 employees, put two others on part-time schedules and reduce health benefits and salaries for everyone else.
But Ms. Skolnick is optimistic about her company's prospects under a changed health system. "In the long run," she said, "it will play into our hands because we're improving the effectiveness of medicine and reducing its cost."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Policy on Jobs Holds Trade Pact's Fate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Every year for at least the rest of the decade, more than two million Americans, most of them solidly middle class, are likely to lose their jobs because of fundamental changes in the world economy.
It is one of the most vexing social and political problems facing President Clinton, and its immediate symbol has become the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Unless Mr. Clinton can persuade lawmakers this fall that he is coming to grips with the question of lost jobs, Congress will reject Nafta, as the accord is known. From the President's perspective, the trade measure will be the most crucial issue Congress will vote on this year.
"Many Democrats are waiting to see what the Administration does on jobs," said Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, who is coordinating the campaign in the House on behalf of the trade agreement. "It will have a big impact on how members vote on Nafta."
 
Support Is Slender
 So far, only about one-quarter of the Democrats in the House have promised to vote for the trade measure, far too few for it to pass.
Administration officials insist that the agreement will actually lead to a net increase in employment in the United States and cause relatively few jobs to be lost. But they concede that as a political matter, the trade accord and the President's response to the jobs problem are inextricable. Right or wrong, many workers fear that free trade would result in the moving of their plants and jobs to Mexico, where wages are lower.
In the minds of many Americans and the politicians who represent them, the agreement, which would gradually lift trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada, has come to represent the economic transformation that makes the future seem bleak to many middle-class factory workers.
Politicians cannot vote against competition from Europe and Japan, against American plants moving overseas in search of cheaper labor, against companies at home cutting their work force or against the lower military budgets that are costing so many industrial jobs. But they can vote against Nafta.
The President's effort on the jobs issue is important for other political reasons as well. His election last year resulted to a large extent from his winning the votes of blue-collar workers who had voted Republican in the 1980's, and he cannot afford to lose them. And he will be hard pressed to win re-election if he cannot carry swing states like California, Michigan and Pennsylvania, where the problem of dwindling factory jobs is most severe.
 
Failure of Retraining
 The jobs situation is especially daunting because the solutions tend to be very expensive and because the Government's efforts over the years to find unemployed workers jobs in fields different from the ones they left have rarely succeeded.
"The problem you run into," said Calvin Johnson, a lobbyist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., "is what to do with a 40-year-old auto worker who's used to making $45,000 or $50,000 a year. No one has ever figured out how do we retrain the middle class."
Anthony P. Carnivale, the chief economist of the American Society for Training and Development, said studies over the years had showed that roughly 60 percent of workers who are laid off find new jobs within a year. Generally, he said, their wages are lower at first -- by 10 percent on average for service workers, 20 percent for manufacturing workers and 30 percent for automobile and steel workers. But within five years, these workers are usually earning what they were in their old jobs.
On the other hand, Mr. Carnivale said, perhaps 35 percent of the workers who lose their jobs never again make the same wages.
Louis Jacobson, an economist at Westat, a consulting company in Rockville, Md., took a different cut at the figures. Based on the records of thousands of people who were laid off in Pennsylvania in the 1980's, he and his colleagues calculated that the average cost of a job loss for a worker with at least six years on the job was $80,000 over the rest of the worker's life.
Few people know these statistics better than Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and his Assistant Secretary for Employment and Training, Douglas Ross. Mr. Reich, who taught at Harvard University, spent his academic career writing about economic changes and their effects on workers. Mr. Ross was director of the Department of Commerce in Michigan for five years in the 1980's when that state's economy was on the ropes.
In the Clinton Administration, employment policy has been almost completely delegated to the Labor Department, unlike other big domestic initiatives like health care, welfare and education, in which officials in the White House have taken charge. Gene Sperling, a top economic adviser to the President, said the jobs policy was being handled differently because of Mr. Clinton's high regard for Mr. Reich, who has been a friend for more than 25 years.
In separate interviews, Mr. Reich and Mr. Ross said that Government programs now on the books had been intended to correct for short-term unemployment resulting from a general economic downturn and that times were different now.
Three of four workers who lost their jobs last year did not go back to the same type of job, the highest proportion since the statistic was first recorded in 1967, Mr. Ross said. And he noted that people today were unemployed longer. In the 1970's, 11 percent of those laid off were still unemployed after six months. In the 1980's, that figure had risen to 15 percent, and last year, it was up to 21 percent.
What the Administration plans, he said, is an ambitious program that would identify permanently displaced workers early, give them counseling, help match them with available jobs and, in some cases, place them in community colleges or other forms of long-term education and training.
Studies have shown that job training for a few weeks or months generally does no lasting good, while programs for 18 months or longer often lead to new credentials, skills and solid jobs.
The most innovative element of the proposal, scheduled to be announced late this month, involves stipends to workers to cover living expenses while they attend school or undertake training.
These programs would be available to all workers regardless of why they lost their jobs and would take years before they were fully in effect. Mr. Reich argued that it would be a mistake to have a special program to help workers who lost their jobs because of the trade agreement. He said time and money would be wasted while a bureaucratic determination was made about why particular jobs had been lost, and he said it would be unfair to offer different programs to people who worked at the same company but made slightly different products.
Still, Mr. Reich said he recognized that a special jobs program related to the trade pact might be a political necessity, and he said the Administration was considering such a program "as a bridge to" a comprehensive jobs retraining program.
 
'Trying to Find Money'
 The comprehensive program would eventually cost $3 billion a year, Mr. Ross said -- $2 billion for job services and training and $1 billion for the stipends -- and the Administration has not determined how to finance it.
Mr. Reich said, "I am scurrying around trying to find money."
Critics say the Administration's proposals, even at a cost of $3 billion a year, would not come close to fulfilling those aims. Mr. Jacobson, the economist at Westat, said that reasonable compensation to workers who lose jobs because of Government policies could cost as much as $20 billion a year.
Another official engaged in preparing the Administration's jobs proposal said that no Government program could realistically protect factory workers from the economic changes sweeping the world.
Somehow, he said, the Government needed to persuade workers to take their future into their own hands and begin preparing for economic change long before it occurred.
He compared workers who lose assembly line jobs because their plants close to those who for years disregard warnings about smoking and cholesterol and eventually have heart attacks. "You can't wait till you have an economic coronary," he said.
That is not the kind of message politicians like to give their constituents.
