HEADLINE: COMMERCE LEADER FACES MAJOR TEST

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Ronald H. Brown, who easily weathered questions about ties to wealthy and powerful interests when he was confirmed as Commerce Secretary, is facing the most withering scrutiny of his career.
Mr. Brown is confronting accusations by a Vietnamese businessman that he sought $700,000 in return for his help lifting the trade embargo against Vietnam, at a time when he was moving from his quasi-official role as a political party official to the Government. 
 For years Mr. Brown has been a powerful lobbyist in Washington, and his connections have at times led to accusations that he skirted the edges of propriety. In January, as he awaited confirmation to the Cabinet, he was forced to cancel an inauguration tribute in his honor financed by large corporations, including some companies that could have been affected by his actions as Commerce Secretary.
Nevertheless, Mr. Brown glided easily through his confirmation hearings, becoming the country's first black Commerce Secretary. He had come from Harlem, where his parents managed the Hotel Theresa, and worked his way into a lucrative legal practice, several successful business ventures, the top position in the Democratic Party and finally, the highest echelons of power in the Clinton Cabinet.
 
Meetings With Businessman
 Two months after his confirmation, the questions arose about Mr. Brown's involvement in the Vietnam deal. His aides suggested that Mr. Brown did not know the principal figures involved. But this week, Reid H. Weingarten, the Secretary's lawyer, acknowledged that Mr. Brown met three times with Nguyen Van Hao, a former Vietnamese Government official who wanted to hire Mr. Brown to help ease the trading restrictions against Vietnam.
The first meeting was in November 1992 in Florida at a time when Mr. Brown was widely speculated to be under consideration for a Cabinet post, but had not yet been nominated. The second meeting was held in Washington at the townhouse of Lillian Madsen, a friend of Mr. Brown and the sister-in-law of Marc Ashton, another friend who introduced Mr. Hao to Mr. Brown.
The third meeting occurred in February after Mr. Brown's confirmation, when he gave Mr. Hao a brief tour of the Commerce Department. Mr. Weingarten said that Mr. Hao sounded out Mr. Brown about a proposal to set up a company that would provide advice to American concerns hoping to operate in Vietnam, but never discussed any payment to Mr. Brown in return for services.
Mr. Brown has said that he never participated in the Clinton Administration's deliberations over easing trade restrictions against Vietnam. The Administration has taken steps toward improving trade ties, dropping longstanding opposition to lending from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and allowing American companies to bid on projects in Vietnam financed by the international lending institutions.
 
Evidence Uncovered
 By the end of last week, Federal investigators had uncovered evidence supporting the assertions of Mr. Brown's principal accuser, Ly Thanh Binh, who said Mr. Hao told him that he was preparing to funnel money from Vietnam to Singapore to open an account to pay Mr. Brown. But there was no indication that Mr. Brown had received money from any overseas bank account.
A Government official familiar with Vietnam, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Hao was the only top official of the South Vietnamese Government who was allowed to stay on after the country fell to the Communists in 1975.
Mr. Hao was appointed South Vietnam's deputy premier for economic development in November 1974, but held only lesser posts under the Communist government, the official said. The official said Mr. Hao entered the United States in 1982 after leaving Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, aboard an Air France Flight to Paris.
As a Federal grand jury in Florida investigates Mr. Binh's accusations, anxiety at the White House seems to be rising rapidly, with President Clinton forced into a protective mode, publicly defending his Commerce Secretary. Attorney General Janet Reno chose not to appoint an independent prosecutor, giving her own prosecutors 60 days to complete their inquiry, Administration officials said.
 
Successful Career
 As chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1989 to 1992, Mr. Brown was considered highly successful, a conciliatory and energetic figure who helped revive the Democrats after the defeat of Michael S. Dukakis in 1988. He never flinched from his role as a critic of the Bush Administration, even when George Bush looked unstoppable.
But although he was party chairman, he never gave up his partnership in Patton, Boggs & Blow, one of Washington's largest lobbying firms known for its Democratic clientele. Mr. Brown insisted that he spent all his time on Democratic Party matters.
Over the years, Mr. Brown's talents had brought in clients like the Haitian Government, American Express and Japanese electronics companies. Gradually he was compared to lawyer-lobbyists like Robert Strauss of Texas, who headed the Democratic Party when Jimmy Carter won the Presidency. Mr. Brown resigned his partnership when he joined the Cabinet.

HEADLINE: Proposing a Manhattan Stadium Is a Risky Play for Cuomo and His Team

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 2

 BODY:
In their single-minded crusade to keep the Yankees from moving to New Jersey, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his aides may have undercut their primary goal: persuading George Steinbrenner 3d not to abandon his team's home and history in the Bronx.
But if they overplayed their hand by publicly discussing plans for a new stadium in mid-Manhattan, it was because they believed the risk was too great to do otherwise. 
 Mr. Cuomo and his economic development czar, Vincent Tese, the director of the Urban Development Corporation, have no way of knowing whether Mr. Steinbrenner is bluffing about moving his team out of Yankee Stadium to a more inviting site, possibly the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. But they clearly have calculated that he is capable of doing so, and that the damage caused to New York City and State by the team's departure to a neighboring state would far exceed the damage to the Bronx by the team's departure to a neighboring borough.
 
The Re-election Factor
 Some city politicians and Yankees fans do not necessarily agree. But Mr. Cuomo may be viewing the situation through the unique prism of reelection politics. If he runs for a fourth four-year term next year, few events could be more devastating than a Steinbrenner news conference announcing the team's departure for New Jersey. The Yankees, for so long the ultimate symbol of New York's pride, would become just as powerful as a metaphor for its decline.
"Who lost the Yankees will be equivalent to who lost China," said Mitchell L. Moss, the director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Tese contest that point, arguing that the departure for New Jersey of the New York Giants in 1976 and of the New York Jets in 1984 bore little political cost for elected officials like former Mayor Edward I. Koch. But Mr. Cuomo would be running as a relatively unpopular incumbent whose poll ratings had been battered by the impact of 12 years in office and four dismal years of economic hardship.
"If they do leave, it's just one more business and thousands more employees that have abandoned the state of Mario Cuomo," said the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, perhaps envisioning an advertising campaign featuring a boarded-up ballpark.
Said Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine: "If you lose, you want people to know you did everything that could have been done. And then, I suppose, you beat up on Steinbrenner."
Whenever discussing the future of the Yankees, Mr. Cuomo has been careful to say that his preference is to keep the team in Yankee Stadium, where the former minor league player witnessed his first professional baseball game, with Joe DiMaggio in center field.
But intentionally or not, the state's recent actions created a different perception. Mr. Cuomo began talking publicly in June about the possibility of building a stadium on a concrete platform above the Long Island Rail Road storage yards in Manhattan. Then this week, spurred by an article in The Village Voice about New Jersey's efforts to lure the team, Mr. Tese hastily disclosed details about a $319 million, 50,000-seat stadium, with an optional $50 million retractable dome, and a $211 million, 7,000-space parking garage. The stadium would be built on a 13.2-acre site bounded by 11th and 12th Avenues and 30th and 33d Streets.
 
'You Have to Act Now'
 "What Vincent's saying is you've got to act as though Steinbrenner's leaving, and that makes sense," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview on Friday. "You have to act now. You probably won't hear about a deal with New Jersey until it's made. You have to let this guy know there are other possibilities."
But what confounds officials in City Hall and the Bronx is that the state has not seemed to dedicate similar effort to keeping the team in Yankee Stadium after its lease expires in 2002. Mr. Steinbrenner has complained that attendance remains below its potential because of fan concerns about traffic, parking and safety. No plans or scale models have been unveiled to illustrate a package of proposed inducements for staying in the Bronx -- which have been discussed for five years -- like more parking, a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train station near the ballpark, and luxury boxes inside the stadium.
To the Bronx loyalists in city government, Mr. Cuomo seemed to be offering a concession before it was needed. And they suggested that it was unseemly for the Governor to appear to grovel before Mr. Steinbrenner, who was described by Mr. Lundine on Friday as "more disliked in New York City than Larry Hogue."
The net impact, some said, would be to undermine efforts to keep the team in the Bronx by letting Mr. Steinbrenner know that New York was prepared to take Herculean steps to keep him in the state.
City officials also were peeved that the state had acted unilaterally, after little consultation with the city. "If anyone asked my opinion," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, "I wouldn't be playing into Steinbrenner's hands to participate in a bidding war because that means the taxpayers lose. But nobody asked me."
After listening to a few days of such criticism, Mr. Tese issued a statement late Friday to make clear that "any offers to the Yankees are the sole decision of New York City" and that "the West Side idea is just that, an idea."
Some city officials said that Mr. Cuomo seemed to be grasping at straws because, like Westway, any plan to build a stadium on the West Side could almost certainly be strangled in court by residents opposed to its impact on traffic and pollution.
"I just don't see how we do it," said Betsy Gotbaum, the city's Parks Commissioner, who is leading the effort to improve the Yankee Stadium area.
The Daily News, in an article on Friday, christened the West Side stadium "The House That Mario Built." But Mr. Cuomo, whose infrastructural tastes have run to repaved highways, shored-up bridges and upstate prisons, said he is not motivated by a newly emergent edifice complex.
What drives him, Mr. Cuomo said, is less the preservation of jobs than the preservation of tradition. "It is more than the Giants in New York or the Jets in New York or even the Brooklyn Dodgers in Ebbets Field. 'New York Yankees' is really one word."

HEADLINE: Whitman and Florio Issue Pair of Hard-Edged Ads

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR, N.J., Oct. 2

 BODY:
With a month of campaigning to go in the race for governor, Jim Florio and his Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman, have begun pounding away at each other with new ads.
The hard-edged advertisements are a familiar strategy for Mr. Florio and his campaign. But they are new ground for Mrs. Whitman, who had avoided so-called negative advertisements until recent polls showed her losing ground to Mr. Florio in what had been a dead heat as late as three weeks ago. 
 The ads are the start of what is likely to be a furious and nasty month of campaigning, and even the release of the commercials turned into a race today. Mrs. Whitman's campaign scheduled a midafternoon news conference at a hotel here, near Princeton, to announce her ad.
 
Tape Handout Near the Lobby
 But as reporters arrived, Mr. Florio's chief strategist, James Carville, was waiting off the lobby to distribute videotapes of Mr. Florio's new ad.
It opens with the taunt, "Where is Christie Whitman?" and attacks her budget plan as a fraud, citing a newspaper editorial; accuses her of being indecisive on the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons, while showing her firing a rifle at a range, and contends that she is against welfare reforms.
Mrs. Whitman's ad criticizes Mr. Florio for the $2.8 billion tax increase that he pushed through the Legislature after his election in 1990. The ad accuses Mr. Florio of lying to the public and contends that the increased taxes drove 8,000 businesses into failure and cost 280,000 jobs.
 
Big Lead in Polls
 "Now Florio refuses to rule out raising taxes again," an announcer says. "Jim Florio, he may be the worst governor New Jersey's ever had."
After a summer of promoting their views to a sometimes uninterested public, Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman now rest their hopes on four weeks crammed with nonstop broadcast advertisements, whistle-stop tours and three televised debates.
In the last week the complexion of the race changed because of public-opinion polls showing Mr. Florio in the lead, including The New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll released on Tuesday that showed Mr. Florio with a 21 percentage-point lead.
At midweek Mrs. Whitman demoted her manager, her brother Webster B. Todd, and placed the day-to-day operation of her campaign in the hands of Ed Rollins, her chief political strategist and a former political adviser to President Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Rollins has set about to change the focus of Mrs. Whitman's campaign from her widely criticized tax-cutting economic plan that she has promoted for two weeks to sharper and more personal criticisms of Mr. Florio. Broadcast ads released this weekend reflect that change.
 
Warm-Up for the Debates
 Up to now, Mr. Florio's campaign has been the clear aggressor, pounding Mrs. Whitman almost daily on some point and making personal attacks on her over her wealth.
"I expect us to be even more aggressive here in October," Mr. Carville said. "We are going to continue to draw distinctions between us and Mrs. Whitman. It's going to be a lot of talk about guns and the National Rifle Association, about welfare, about drunken driving and a lot of talk about her pie-in-the-sky promises."
The rancor is most likely a warm-up for the debates, the first of which will be here at 8 P.M. on Thursday and broadcast over WABC-TV in New York and WPVI-TV in Philadelphia. The other debates, also to be televised, are on Oct. 19 and 24.
 
Challenge to Become Known
 Despite Mr. Florio's standings in the polls, there is ample evidence of the volatility of voters in gubernatorial elections. Over half those polled, 54 percent, in The Times/WCBS-TV poll, said they were undecided or might change their minds before Nov. 2.
Mrs. Whitman shows some clear strengths like the issue of trust, but she also faces huge tasks, the most pressing of which is to make herself much better known to the electorate.
"The Whitman campaign has failed in the primary responsibility of letting people know who she is," Neil Upmeyer, president of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton, said. "She has been telling voters all along that the issues are jobs and the economy. If she suddenly now says the issue is Jim Florio and his ethics, then that is going to raise even more confusion about her."
 
Sheltering of Candidate
 But at this late date Mrs. Whitman's campaign aides apparently feel they have little choice, and she has steered her effort in a different direction. The campaign has also become more open to reporters, inviting reporters to preview television and radio ads and scheduling a news conference for Monday at the State House in Trenton.
Under Mr. Todd's direction the strategy had been to shelter Mrs. Whitman from reporters as much as possible. In the summer she held few news conferences, and her schedule was filled with friendly venues.
That allowed Mr. Florio, through a daily barrage of news releases from his staff and manipulation of the power of incumbency, to command headlines as he tried to paint Mrs. Whitman as out of touch with the common voter because of her wealth, soft on crime and an ally of the National Rifle Association and its effort to overturn the state ban on semiautomatic weapons.
The Times/WCBS-TV poll showed that much of the plan has worked. Thirty percent of the registered voters who were surveyed said Mrs. Whitman understood their needs and problems; 45 percent said she did not. For Mr. Florio, 59 percent said he was more in tune with them.
The sampling error is 4 percentage points.
Nearly one-third, 32 percent, said Mrs. Whitman was "too close to the N.R.A." an idea driven home in Mr. Florio's speeches and ads.

HEADLINE: Bosnia's Desperate Gamble: Winter in Time of War

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Oct. 2

 BODY:
When the Muslim-led Parliament of Bosnia walked away from a peace plan this week, some members said they had given up their last chance of salvaging a territory of their own from the wreckage of their country.
As the Parliament dispersed, one legislator after another spoke of the agonies of conscience involved in rejecting a chance for peace. Several said that the Parliament's decision could mean life or death for tens of thousands of people, mainly Muslims. 
 Lord Owen of Britain, one of the mediators who has spent months negotiating with the Serbian leaders, was among those who feared that there could be more than bluster in Serbian warnings that rejecting the peace plan would lead to the "flattening" of Sarajevo and the extinction of Muslims as a political force.
 
No Illusions Left
 Radovan Karadzic, the Serbian nationalist leader in Bosnia, has said for weeks that if Muslims reject a state of their own on the 30 percent of Bosnia offered to them in the peace plan, they will end up with no state at all.
Until recently, in virtually every move it made, the Bosnian Government was motivated by the hope of Western military intervention. But by the time the Parliament met there were no illusions left.
President Alija Izetbegovic, who met President Clinton in Washington last month, told the legislators that Mr. Clinton had closed the door on military intervention, telling him that the Bosnian Government should make the best deal it could in the Geneva talks.
"Have no doubt about this," Mr. Izetbegovic said. "There will be no American intervention. We are on our own."
Mr. Izetbegovic has often been accused of engaging in public agonizing over Bosnia's fate instead of offering decisive leadership, and his performance in Parliament did little to assuage his critics.
 
'A Personal Tragedy'
 Calling the choice before the Parliament "a personal tragedy for all of us," he said he was unable to recommend acceptance or rejection of the peace plan. Instead, he offered arguments -- nine for the plan, five against -- and urged the legislators to make their own choice.
In opting for a middle course -- accepting the principle of Bosnia's dismemberment into three ethnic states, for Croats, Muslims and Serbs, but demanding a share of the territory closer to the Muslim proportion in the population, 43.7 percent -- the legislators appeared to have been swayed by several considerations.
The most powerful of these may have been one that Mr. Izetbegovic did not mention, but that many legislators spoke of off the debating floor: the unwillingness to be associated in history with an agreement that would bring an end to Bosnia's existence, after 1,000 years, as a territory where people of different faiths and cultures have mixed freely.
"These people feel like people who have been asked to sign their own death sentence," a Bosnian Government minister said. "Their attitude is, 'If they're going to hang us, at least don't ask us to give our assent.' "
Along with this, there were many in Parliament who said that they were deeply skeptical of the willingness of the Serbian leaders to carry out the pact, which would require the Serbian forces to withdraw from territories amounting to 25 percent of Bosnia. The history of the war has been one of broken agreements, and the legislators said the peace accord was so loosely worded ed and so lacking in enforcement mechanisms that it seemed to invite defiance.
 
Doubts in the U.S.
 In this, they shared similar concerns with members of Congress who have cast doubt on President Clinton's pledge to commit 25,000 troops to a 50,000-member NATO peacekeeping force if the peace pact is concluded. Like the American politicians who question committing troops to a situation where they could be trapped by renewed fighting, many legislators said they feared the peace agreement could be as elusive as the pledges Serbian leaders signed in London a year ago, promising to end "ethnic cleansing," to halt the use of heavy artillery against civilians, and to allow free passage of relief convoys.
Just as many Muslims at an earlier stage of the war pinned their hopes on United States military intervention, there are many now who see the prospect of having American troops here to enforce the peace pact as the saving grace of an accord that is widely regarded among Muslims as an appeasement of Serbian and Croatian territorial aggression.
Amid the general gloom that pervaded the debate, some legislators said that by accepting the peace pact now, Muslims might be dooming Bosnia as a country just at the moment when the tide in the war was beginning to shift.
Recent successes scored by Bosnian forces against Croatian nationalist troops in central Bosnia, where a string of towns have fallen to Muslim units, has boosted morale. Although Serbian forces remain dominant wherever they meet the outgunned Bosnian troops, many in the Parliament said that they saw signs that backing for the Serbian nationalist cause in Serbia was beginning to crumble under the pressure of international economic sanctions.
 
An Enormous Gamble
 But when the vote was taken, the sense among those who rejected the peace pact was that they had taken an enormous gamble. Apart from the risk of renewed Serbian offensives, thoughts of the approaching winter weighed on many minds.
United Nations relief officials have warned of a disaster for the 2.7 million Bosnians dependent on United Nations food supplies if the war continues into the winter, when snow-clogged mountain passes will cause new delays to aid convoys and many families will have to survive without fuel for heating.
"Winter will be tough enough" for Serbian and Croatian troops in the field, Mr. Izetbegovic told the legislators. "For us, it will be unbearable."

HEADLINE: Mandela Looking for Free-Market Investors

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Having been viewed as a liberator and a martyr, Nelson Mandela has now cast himself in a new, seemingly unfamiliar role: salesman for his country.
But Mr. Mandela, the head of the African National Congress, has found himself somewhat frustrated by the hesitancy of some members of the anti-apartheid movement in the United States to back fully the lifting of sanctions on South Africa. 
 In the week since Mr. Mandela called for the end of economic and trade sanctions, he has journeyed back and forth between Washington and New York, meeting with business executives, portfolio managers, pension fund trustees, stock brokers and officials of the International Monetary Fund, all in an effort to attract investment in South Africa.
Seeking to reassure potential investors, he has shed the Marxist language that used to characterize African National Congress pronouncements on the economy and is now sounding the theme of free-market capitalism.
"We are aware that we live in a world in which there is intense competition for scarce capital," Mr. Mandela said Friday in a speech to portfolio managers, venture capitalists, stock brokers, pension fund trustees and others who have money to invest. "We are therefore determined to insure that our own country becomes an attractive destination for the enormous capital resources held by the institutions you represent."
In their addresses and in interviews with journalists, Mr. Mandela and others in the South African delegation have stressed such things as competitive tax policies, the continued independence of the central bank, a constitution that will guard against arbitrary seizure of property and the need to control the spiraling violence that has wracked several parts of the country, most notably Natal and the Transvaal.
Mr. Mandela acknowledged that violence in his country is a major impediment to investment, and vowed to bring it under control. He stressed the need for foreign investment so economic development could forestall future political extremism.
"It would be reasonable for investors to be extremely cautious in investing in our country because of political instability and a lack of predictability, and, secondly, because of the alarmingly high level of the violence that is ravaging the country," Mr. Mandela said. "Conditions which can attract investment do not fully exist in our country."
But he insisted that much of the violence was politically motivated and fomented by right-wing elements opposed to the rule of the country's black majority. Mr. Mandela said that once the Transitional Executive Council, which will oversee government activity until the election on April 27, and a new peacekeeping force begin functioning, the level of violence will decrease.
While Mr. Mandela, who emerged from 27 years in prison in 1990 and will probably be his country's next leader, may feel the necessity to turn salesman for South Africa, he is clearly uncomfortable doing it. Reflecting his unfamiliarity with economics as opposed to politics, his speeches on the need for economic development are read in a wooden manner, with little flourish and few ad libs. When he concludes his sales pitch, he immediately turns the podium over to his economic advisers to handle questions.
In contrast, at a dinner at the British Embassy in Washington on Thursday night, Mr. Mandela extemporized with gusto on the need to build political bridges to all of South Africa's political parties and described how that was causing him to lose support among his hard-core backers in the African National Congress.
Yet even while much of the talk was about future tax structures, possible trends in domestic spending and export controls, hanging over all Mr. Mandela's appearances were questions over the continued high levels of violence. Frederick Thorne, a director at Harbor Capital Management, a Boston investment concern, said that was the question most asked by his clients.
"They are concerned about the tremendous amount of civil strife," Mr. Thorne said. "It's terribly disruptive to a country that is trying to straighten itself out economically."

HEADLINE: Yale Inaugurates Dean and Economist as Its 22d President

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Richard C. Levin was inaugurated today as the 22d president of Yale University in a traditional bell-ringing ceremony. He capped the installation with a lyrical effort to heal the wounds from the faculty revolt last year that led to the resignation of his predecessor.
The new president, who is 46 and the former dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, specializes in technological change, and he sought to reassure those engaged in university-based research that he is their champion. 
 Some critics, most of them outside the universities, have contended that the major educational institutions have promoted research, much of it inconsequential, at the expense of teaching.
"Today," Mr. Levin said, "the scientific capability of American universities is the envy of the world. We neglect its support at our peril."
After reciting lines from Sophocles's "Antigone," Mr. Levin said in his inaugural address that the purity of spirit of the Greek heroine, who chose self-sacrifice over yielding on principle, should be a model for "the social order we create within the university."
 
List of Prominent Alumni
 Then, like an old-time preacher whipping up enthusiasm by calling the roll of saints, Mr. Levin, who remains the Frederick William Beinecke Professor of Economics, recited a list of notable Yale alumni. The list included 14 members of the Continental Congress, 4 signers of the Declaration of Independence, 3 of the last 5 Presidents of the United States, 10 of the 100 Senators in office and, for good measure, Eli Whitney, Samuel F. B. Morse, Walter Camp and Cole Porter.
Despite a colorful procession, heraldic banners snapping in the wind, blue academic gowns and other trappings that date from the Middle Ages, Mr. Levin broke with one tradition. He dispensed with the formal dinner and held a reception for the entire community.
"That's more in the spirit of my administration than a black-tie dinner," he said.
Although his speech concentrated on uplift and unity, Mr. Levin spoke frankly on sensitive issues in an interview on Friday night.
Trouble developed last year when the president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., whose dealings with some faculty members had created enemies, announced a plan to close a huge budget gap by eliminating nearly 11 percent of the faculty of arts and sciences and by cutting programs and departments.
The faculty and students rebelled, voicing their anger at meetings and at one point sending an anti-Schmidt pamphlet to many alumni. In short order two of Mr. Schmidt's highest appointees resigned, followed by Mr. Schmidt himself. He left in June 1992 to head the Edison Project, a venture to create a national private-school system.
A history professor, Howard R. Lamar, was interim president until Mr. Levin took office on July 1.
In his interview Mr. Levin said he did not expect to be forced to make the deep cuts in the faculty and academic programs that Mr. Schmidt and his aides had proposed.
"Large savings have already been made by cuts in administrative and support services," he said.
"For example, for the fiscal year that ended in July, we cut the deficit, from a projected $22 million to $14.5 million. "That may sound like a lot. But that $14.5 million is less than the interest we pay on the loans taken out for renovation of the physical plant. Meanwhile our endowment has grown, from $2.8 billion to $3.2 billion, an increase of $400 million. So I don't anticipate having to make substantial programmatic cuts."
 
 'Centers of Excellence'
 But Mr. Levin acknowledged that he had been considering making the university smaller in some respects.
"You can't be good at everything," he said. "We don't have to deal with every subspecialty in every field. Instead we can create centers of excellence within departments and within professional schools."
On productivity, a term that academic circles use to focus on the cost of education per student, Mr. Levin, an industrial economist, said:
"When you talk about renovating the plant, most of our buildings were constructed in the 1920's and 1930's,and they need new heating and electrical systems. There, productivity is important. But if you think of students as our output, the only way you can produce more students per faculty member is to change the nature of education. I'm not for that. I don't want to substitute machines for teachers.
"At Harvard and Stanford new presidents have proclaimed that their No. 1 problem is to get their faculties to focus on teaching. But that's not a problem at Yale, where we pay close attention to it. Sure, we're not a four-year liberal-arts college, where teaching is given greater emphasis than research. We're committed to increasing human knowledge. But we have very few courses taught by graduate students."
 
Doctorate in 1974
 Mr. Levin was born in San Francisco. He received a bachelor's in history from Stanford and studied politics and philosophy at Oxford, where he received a graduate degree in political science in 1971. He received a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1974 and joined the economics faculty that year.
In addition to serving on policy committees, Mr. Levin was the chairman of the economics department from 1987 to last year, when he was appointed dean of the largest of the 11 graduate and professional schools at Yale.

HEADLINE: Seeking A Chance For a Home

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Lydia Watt stuffs pillows, blankets and sheets under the door to keep rats out of her bedroom at night in her small apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Some mornings, she wakes up to find her small kitchen ransacked by the rodents, with cereal, sugar and flour spilled everywhere.
"I just got fed up," she said, speaking through the window of a second-floor, two-bedroom apartment that she invaded with friends on Friday in a nearly completed public housing project at South 10th and Berry Streets in Williamsburg. "What we've done here should put everyone on notice that we're not going to tolerate these living conditions. It's not by choice that some of us live like this. The system forces it on us." 
 Ms. Watt was among 200 Hispanic protesters who took over the 150 units of the boxy brick project about 6 P.M. on Friday, fearing that Hasidic Jews in the neighborhood might receive preferential treatment in gaining apartments when they become available. They were organized by the Southside Fair Housing Committee, which works to counter discrimination in housing.
Yesterday, after a standoff of about 18 hours, the occupants left the project, declaring a small victory. The Housing Authority, which has about 600,000 tenants citywide, essentially agreed that when the project opens in November, it will rent the apartments to a fair mix of Hispanic and Hasidic tenants, as housing officials said had been their intent all along.
 
Dreams of Stability
 Many of the invaders, single mothers and unemployed people who have been on the New York City Housing Authority waiting list of 300,000 families for years, had similar stories. They fantasized about what they would do if they lived in the apartments and how, finally, they would be able to make ends meet.
While most of them slept in the project Friday night huddled on cold concrete floors without lights, electricity or plumbing, they said the conditions were far better than where they lived, mostly doubled up with family and friends in cramped apartments with rats and roaches. Those who live in Housing Authority apartments say they are in crime-plagued neighborhoods where they live in fear.
Before they left the apartments, with views of the graceful peaks of the Williamsburg Bridge and the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan, the protesters, although tired, were upbeat. They consumed a steady flow of milk and doughnuts as they spoke through windows. Peering through black burglar bars, they looked as if they were in prison.
 
Affordable, and No Rats
 Many said they had heard about the invasion by word of mouth and had not hesitated to join in.
"I was cold last night," said Mildred Montero, 21, a single mother of two children, "but I knew I had to stay. I was just praying to God that what we were doing would somehow end in something good. Even though I had no plumbing or electricity in this apartment, it is much better than where I live."
Ms. Montero, a data processer, has lived in a one-bedroom railroad flat in Williamsburg for five months, paying $550 a month. On Friday night she occupied the tallest building in the Housing Authority project, six stories. Because it has not been completed, there is no electricity or plumbing yet.
"I can't afford it, but I have no place else to go," she said of her apartment. "After I'm done paying rent, I barely have enough to buy food for me and my children. At least if I lived here, the city would set my rent according to what I can pay."
Ms. Watt, 40, who has two daughters, said she spends most of the $468 she receives monthly from public assistance on rent for her $317 apartment on Berry Street and Broadway, she said.
"The rent here would be affordable," she said. "I would be rid of the rats and for the first time in life, I would proud of where I lived." She said she had been on the waiting list for public housing for two years.
 
Looking for Choices
 Norma Alvarez, 24, lives in a two-bedroom apartment in Bushwick with her three children. Receiving public assistance, she pays $750 a month in rent.
"I did this because I've been on a waiting list for a public-housing apartment for four years," she said, speaking from the ground floor of one of the three-story apartment buildings that has electricity and plumbing. She has been trying to find work and would like to go to college, she said, but she feels trapped.
"I don't want to be on public assistance anymore," she said. "But as long as I'm in that apartment, I don't have any choice."

HEADLINE: China's Fix for Runaway Economy Is Falling Short

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Just a few weeks after China's economic czar, Zhu Rongji, opened his 16-point austerity program this summer, Asian and Western financiers were congratulating him on his early success in reining in China's runaway economy.
He had reimposed some central authority over China's bounding expansion by canceling scores of ill-conceived projects to pave over rice paddies with casinos and office towers and by calling in loans that were feeding a speculative frenzy in everything from condos to jetliners. 
 But more recently, the 65-year-old Mr. Zhu has admitted that the financial state of the nation is still "relatively grim" and that his progress has not been what he had hoped.
The United States Central Intelligence Agency, in a report to Congress that appears to be contested by other Government economists, is warning that economic growth and inflation in China are "threatening to spiral out of control," raising fears that social disorder could follow.
 
An Unpredictable Mess
 If there is any consensus about what is going on in China's economy today it is that it is a mess, perhaps an enviable mess to other countries that would like to see as many investors pouring into their airports as are pouring into China, but an unpredictable mess nonetheless.
Partly as a result of the new austerity measures combined with the effects of unabated inflation, some of China's state-owned factories are having trouble meeting their payrolls, and others have been forced to cut production drastically. A General Motors Corporation joint venture to build light trucks in northeastern China saw its output wither by half in the first two months of the austerity program as bank credits dried up.
Meanwhile, prices are still soaring. The cost of industrial raw materials is 40 percent higher than last year, as is the price of steel.
Inflation in big cities is at a four-year high of more than 20 percent, and China's money supply, which no central authority seems to be able to control, has been expanding at a rate of 30 percent a year since early 1992.
Still, with the steps that have been taken so far to stop wasteful investments, real estate speculation and an explosion of credit, Government economists like Fan Gang at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences assert that "the bubble" of speculation "has been stopped." But he acknowledged that "inflation is still not under control."
A World Bank economist here, who said he might have agreed with the C.I.A. analysis three months ago, added that "we were very concerned that if measures were not taken," the Chinese economy would have revved up so high that the country's transportation, energy and raw material bottlenecks would have brought on a catastrophic gridlock and crash.
 
'Too Early to Tell'
 But now, he added, "I would not say the Chinese economy is running out of control." The evidence for this assertion, he said, is that "the tremendous growth in investment has slowed down, but it is too early to tell whether that will be sufficient."
Since early summer, when China's leaders became so alarmed that they sacked the Central Bank chief and replaced him with Mr. Zhu, there has been an expectation that the acerbic former Mayor of Shanghai could somehow get the genie of money supply expansion and rampant speculation back in the bottle and China back on a footing for more rational growth.
He sent investigators to the provinces to gather information and to bully local officials who were circumventing Beijing's commands. He found some provinces building so many bridges, highways, ports and skyscrapers on concurrent schedules that they were driving material prices skyward and overloading the system.
Worse, the provincial authorities were paying their bills with a "triangular" pattern of debt passed among regional banks that was devaluing the national currency and sapping revenues needed to buy summer crops from farmers, meet factory payrolls and pay for high-priority transportation and energy projects.
 
Trying to Recover Loans
 One of Mr. Zhu's biggest gambles was that he could suck back into the banking system more than $38 billion that regional banks had lent to one another to cover credits extended out the back door to factories, developers and other investors trying to spend and get rich as fast as they could.
But in his report to the leadership on Aug. 30, Mr. Zhu admitted that he had recovered only a third of those loans, and he has now extended the deadline for regional bank officials to recover these funds to the end of the year.
Now that Mr. Zhu, by his own accounting, has failed to get inflation under control, many of China's economic reformers fear that their rivals, those old Communists who never met a free market they didn't want to bulldoze, might once again emerge.
"I think there were a lot of naive expectations outside of China that because Zhu Rongji is so competent, he would be able to engineer a soft landing for the Chinese economy," said a Western economist based here. "But there is no way for anyone to perform that kind of miracle."
 
Mostly Flying Blind
 The reason, many economists say, is that China's leaders, even when they agree on how to run their economy, are flying blind most of the time. In developed nations, central banks track money supply daily and impose discipline on credit through regulation and interest rates. In China, statistics are gathered monthly and controls are virtually nonexistent. Local officials often deceive Beijing about their lending.
In China under Communism, the People's Bank has been little more than a cash cow dispensing money to state-owned enterprises under a central plan. Taking responsibility for bad loans, maintaining capital reserves to cover loan losses and responding to money supply directives from a central authority are concepts that are still embryonic in China.
In the West, tax systems increase government revenues as the economy expands, but China's economic boomers, especially in the newly rich coastal provinces, have hoarded their money and left the Government with fewer funds to subsidize China's bottomless pit of state industries, which still soak up more than 70 percent of Government revenues each year.
 
Deng Spurred Investment
 In 1992, when China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, crusaded through the country's southern provinces exhorting factory managers and local officials to speed up their investment plans and thus China's economic miracle, he only added gasoline to the fire, though at the time his motive was to defeat hard-liners who were blocking progress toward a market economy.
"Right now the dangers of appearing to lose control of the economy are seen to be paramount political dangers," said David M. Lampton, president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations Inc., a nonprofit group that promotes American-Chinese ties.
"All of China's modern leaders have personal experience with what economic chaos brings in terms of mass suffering, not to mention its impact on political careers," Mr. Lampton said.
Mr. Zhu appears to be no exception. While one part of the Government was recently churning out anti-American propaganda over the search of the suspect Chinese freighter Yinhe in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Zhu was busy making soothing speeches to Western and Asian investors.
 
Commitment to Market
 His message is that this summer's austerity program and its reliance on the old levers of central Communist control have not dampened China's enthusiasm for "deepening" reform and building a market economy by the end of the decade. He pledged to press forward with plans to put state industries on a sink-or-swim financial footing, to build a central bank and a commercial banking system that will take responsibility for bad lending decisions and to revamp China's tax system so the Government can finance urgently needed projects.
"My guess is that he will use administrative measures that look serious to the Chen Yun and Li Peng forces," Mr. Lampton said, referring to the leaders of the conservative camp, "but I think Zhu can balance the factions and on the other hand still be seen as a pro-reform force."
One Chinese official suggested that Mr. Zhu may already be running into some resistance from the hard-liners and that his failure to control inflation has weakened his position.
"The conservatives have been saying Zhu Rongji is in charge of the economy and it is still going to the cows," the Chinese official said. "So the conservatives are a little stronger, but so far they have no alternative program."
 
Price Freezes Ordered
 This week, in a move that must have pleased the hard-liners, Mr. Zhu stomped harder on the brakes when the Government ordered price freezes on most commodities and services for the remainder of the year.
The C.I.A.'s warning aside, predictions for the outcome of the austerity program are hard to nail down.
An economist at one Western embassy said he thought that growth would decline to 6 or 7 percent next year and that China would take a one- or two-year breather to absorb the stupendous expansion of the last 18 months.
But Professor Fan predicted that China's growth rate would stay at 10 percent or more next year with continued high inflation, "but not out of control," because the leaders fear the social consequences of bringing down the boom too hard.
"So my prediction," he concluded, "is for relatively stable chaos."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
For Florio, Comfort From Other Governors' Distress?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey may have reason to be grateful for the fiscal problems in New York and Connecticut as he campaigns for re-election, based on research by two Princeton University economists.
In their study of the impact of tax increases on the re-election chances of incumbent governors in 48 states between 1960 and 1989, Timothy Besley and Anne Case said that a governor who has presided over an increase of at least $100 per year in the tax bills of households earning $40,000 or more in 1976 dollars is 15 percent less likely to win another term than governors in states with lower increases or none at all. 
 But if a neighboring state has undergone a similar tax increase, then the incumbent is only 2 percent less likely to be re-elected, they said.
Mr. Florio, who pushed a record $2.8 billion in tax increases through the Legislature a few months after taking office in 1990, has argued that his hand was forced by an unforeseen budget deficit and a State Supreme Court decision that ordered increased state school aid to poor urban districts. He also argued that 83 percent of New Jersey taxpayers, all except those in the higher brackets, were not affected by the tax changes, although all taxpayers were affected by a sales tax increase.
But an angry voter reaction dropped Mr. Florio's approval rating to about 20 percent, nearly unseated United States Senator Bill Bradley in 1990 and allowed the Republican Party to wrest control of both houses of the Legislature from Mr. Florio's Democratic Party the following year.
Republicans are eager to continue capitalizing on the tax-increase anger to defeat Mr. Florio in the Nov. 2 election, but recent public opinion polls have found that some voters are more willing to credit Mr. Florio with making a tough, but necessary, decision.
The polls by various organizations seem to indicate that the Governor may be pulling ahead of his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, who has made criticism of Mr. Florio's decision to raise taxes the cornerstone of her campaign.
If the Princeton economists are correct, Mr. Florio may have the budget problems in New York and Connecticut to thank for the softening of voter outrage.
"New York State has had several years of budget crises, and that alone should help Florio," Ms. Case said. "And Connecticut, whose struggles should be familiar to New Jerseyans since it shares the same New York-area media market as much of New Jersey, has enacted its first income tax."
Mr. Besley said voters are aware of what is happening in neighboring states and can apply it to Mr. Florio's situation. "Viewing the election in isolation might give a misleading conclusion about his prospects," he said.
 
Inquiry on an Aid Bonus
 How Lyndhurst received $1.5 million in state aid that it wasn't entitled to continues to fascinate the Republican majority in the State Senate, which hopes to capitalize on it in next month's legislative races.
According to a report by the State Attorney General's office in August, a Democratic Senator, Gabriel M. Ambrosio, persuaded John Ellis, then the Education Commissioner, to increase school aid to the town by $1.5 million in 1991, even though, the Attorney General's report said, Mr. Ambrosio intended that the money would not go to schools but to hold the line on local property taxes.
Mr. Ellis subsequently rescinded the award, and Mr. Ambrosio got the $1.5 million restored through the Legislature, according to the report. All of this happened before the 1991 elections, when Mr. Ambrosio and other Democrats were fighting unsuccessfully to keep control of the Senate.
The former Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, nullified the special aid award, and the office has said it will attempt to recover the money.
But the Senate Law and Public Safety Committee has been conducting its own hearings on the Lyndhurst aid, and Senator Louis F. Kosco, Republican of Paramus, said two Education Department officials testified that the Attorney General's office tried to pressure them into dropping their request for an investigation.
The Senate passed a bill that would create an independent counsel to conduct an investigation and sent it to the Assembly, which probably won't vote until after the election. It remains to be seen if the Republicans' interest will be as strong then.
 
A Hatch Act Opening
 Senator Dick LaRossa, Republican of Trenton, wants his opponent, former Senator Gerry Stockman and Mr. Stockman's Assembly running mates to drop out of the race, because, he says, they violated the Federal Hatch Act, which prohibits partisan election activities by Federal officials or state officials who handle Federal money.
Mr. LaRossa points to an invitation to a $200-per-person fund-raiser for Mr. Stockman's running mates, Shirley Turner and Joe Yuhas, that lists Dr. Bruce Siegal, the New Jersey Health Commissioner, and two other state officials as the hosts. Mr. La Rossa said the participation by the state officials violates the Hatch Act.
Rich McClellan, the campaign director for the Democratic candidates, said the propriety of the officials' sponsorship of the reception was checked and cleared. However, he said the event was canceled to avoid giving Mr. LaRossa anything to complain about. "The people involved are blameless, but as they say in the hot dog commercial, we'll answer to a higher authority."

HEADLINE: Walking Away, While He Still Can;
Troubled and Fearing Injury, Timm Rosenbach Quit Football

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PULLMAN, Wash.

 BODY:
Timm Rosenbach remembers clearly the beginning of the end because everything was pitch black.
He woke up in a dark room with his head strapped to a table, still wearing his Phoenix Cardinals uniform and shoulder pads and hip pads and cleats. He was frightened and alone, not sure if he was alive or dead. He couldn't move, didn't want to move. He knew he had been hurt, but didn't know how badly. He thought about his friend and former college teammate, Mike Utley of the Lions, who the year before had taken a tumble in a game and been left paralyzed for life from the chest down. 
 Then Rosenbach remembered the hit he had taken earlier that day. Was it minutes ago? Was it hours? Rosenbach, a 6-foot quarterback, was dropping back to pass in the third quarter of the season opener when he was blindsided by Santana Dodson, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' 6--5, 270-pound defensive end, in one of the brutal encounters that is commonplace in a National Football League game.
Rosenbach remembered only the resounding impact, as if being leveled by a tank, and then nothing. Until that moment in the room. And then, just as suddenly, he blacked out again.
This was Sunday, Sept. 6, 1992, in an X-ray room at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. Rosenbach was not aware that he had been taken, unmoving, from the field at Sun Devils Stadium on a stretcher and rushed to the emergency room. He was not aware that he had suffered only a severe concussion when his head slammed into the turf.
He would walk and talk normally again, even report back for work two days later, but the grim experience would not leave him. In the following game, he returned to the lineup only to be blindsided again, this time by Clyde Simmons, Philadelphia's 6-6, 280-pound defensive end, on the Cardinals' second series of the game.
"I made sure that the next time I get hit, I don't go head first," Rosenbach recalled, "and I didn't. I went shoulder first." And he suffered a separated shoulder. He was out of action for a month.
After the last game of the season, Dec. 27, 1992, Rosenbach, at age 26, did what some thought was unthinkable: He walked away from professional football and $1.05 million, the salary for the fifth and last year of his $5.3 million contract. He left the field and the money because he had developed fears that he might be crippled if he continued to play and because he began to "despise," as he said, the dehumanizing aspects of football that "can turn you into an animal."
It wasn't always that way. Two years earlier, in 1990, in his second year in the N.F.L., he took every snap for the Cardinals, all 1,001 of them, throwing for 3,098 yards to rank third in the National Football Conference. He ranked second in the N.F.L. in rushing yardage for a quarterback, behind Randall Cunningham. He threw 16 touchdown passes. He was admired, as one Phoenix sports reporter wrote, because "He was feisty. Gutsy. Combative. Ornery." His coach, Joe Bugel, called him "a throwback," a "gun-slingin', beer-drinkin' tough" in the mold of the late and colorful Bobby Layne.
Last summer, when it became apparent that Rosenbach had made his decision to quit football and return to Washington State University -- where he had starred in football and where he was 38 hours short of a bachelor's degree in general studies with an emphasis in psychology -- he didn't call the team. His agent, Gary Wichard, did. Rosenbach changed his unlisted phone number so that no one from the Cardinals organization could call to try to talk him out of retiring and no reporter could call and ask why.
Football generally had been fun for Rosenbach in school, and even into the pros -- he once relished the contact, proudly looking in the mirror at his bruises as an affirmation of manhood. But he was not prepared, as a 22-year-old right out of college for the hard-edged business of professional football, nor for the debilitating injuries that had sidelined him. And while his associations with a number of his teammates remained close, his view of this odd occupation became deeper, and darker.
There was speculation that Rosenbach had decided to become a professional rodeo rider, since he had participated as a team roper in a half-dozen events. When he married Carrie Serrano in June 1992, at his new 10-acre ranch in Gilbert, Ariz., the ceremony was held outdoors under a sagebrush arch with groom and groomsmen bedecked in black cowboy hats, tuxedo tops, black jeans and black cowboy boots.
"It's all a mystery to me," said Bugel. "I'd like for him to tell me right to my face what the problem is."
"I've seen young guys retire, un-retire, but certainly not a player of Timm's stature," said Larry Wilson, the Cardinals' general manager. "This is kind of strange."
But there was more to it than just the bruises of the business. "I thought I was turning into some kind of animal," Rosenbach said in a recent interview. "You go through a week getting yourself up for a game by hating the other team, the other players. You're so mean and hateful, you want to kill somebody. Football's so aggressive. Things get done by force. And then you come home, you're supposed to turn it off? 'Oh, here's your lovin' daddy.' It's not that easy. It was like I was an idiot. I felt programmed. I had become a machine. I became sick of it."
He remembered those "barbaric yawps," as he called them, when breaking from a huddle and the players began screaming like maniacs. "It lightened things up," said Rosenbach, "but it's still a part of the craziness of football. Like screaming at the other team at the top of your lungs all kinds of threats and obscenities."
He remembers his center, Bill Lewis, telling an opposing lineman, "You touch my quarterback and I'll end your career." He remembers players like Refrigerator Perry snarling with his huge face scrunched up inside his tight helmet. And then there was Reggie White: "He is very religious, and he'd hit you a murderous shot and then say, 'God bless you,' as he pulled you off the ground."
Rosenbach also felt the pressures that go with winning, or losing. "I began to despise the whole business of the N.F.L.," he said. When he was injured, he felt that the coaches, particularly head coaches, hardly recognized him. Since he was of no value to them, he was a virtual nonentity. When he was hurt, he wasn't even asked to travel with the team. "They asked, 'How're you feelin'?' But with no feeling," he said. "Their answer to injury is to give you painkiller pills. And the whole concept of medicine is to get you ready to perform -- what happens to you down the road is not of any interest to them.
"Team doctors often lose touch with humanity, too. They are working for the team, and love the association. So you hear players on the plane after a game and saying, 'Hey, Doc, give me some Percodin or Percoset or Codeine Tylenol or something else. When did players become pharmacists?
"And coaches are so absorbed in the X's and O's that they lose any feeling of being a human being. I guess the pressure is so great on them. I feel they viewed me -- us -- as robots. A mechanism. And if you don't fit the slot you're nothing to them."
 
Daredevil Turns Cautious
 One trick of being a professional athlete, he understood, was not to think too much. He had been a kind of daredevil quarterback, enjoying the contact, loving that glazed feeling when you hardly know where you are, even baiting some of the huge opponents like Perry during the heat of a game -- "It takes a long time to get all that into motion, doesn't it?" -- but when he returned to the lineup in the latter part of last season, things were different.
He couldn't move the way he used to because his knee was wrapped in a brace, and for the first time he felt fear on a football field, the fear of ending up a cripple. He had already missed the entire 1991 season because of a severed ligament incurred in a preseason practice a week before the opener. The injury required reconstructive surgery and rehabilitation and made him question his existence as a pro football player.
The challenge of going against ferocious linemen like Lawrence Taylor and White and Simmons and Perry, which had whetted his competitive appetite, had taken a different turn. "I got scared looking at the linemen before the snap," he said. "I remember I could feel the earth pounding when they chased me. When I went back to pass now, I was more concerned with where those guys were and less about where my receivers were going."
He said there was a lot of fear in the N.F.L. "Guys don't talk about it," he said, "but they feel it. And when you really know the game, you can spot them. But a lot aren't making the kind of money I did. And when a guy's making, say, $65,000 a year, and this is the only place he can make that kind of money, he's not about to get out."
After the injuries, his confidence, as well as his enthusiasm ebbed noticeably. He was booed. He remembers the discomfort of meeting people and feeling he had to apologize for his performance or the team's losses.
"Timm would come home in these moods," said his wife, Carrie, "and we were newlyweds. I didn't know what the problem was. He'd sit in a dark corner. I thought it was me. I thought, 'Why can't I make him happy?' But then I began to understand all the pressures he was under. And of course the pain. After some games, Timm was so bruised and battered it would take him a half-hour to get out of bed. And sometimes it would take him a half-hour to get off the couch and into bed."
The other side of life in the N.F.L. for Rosenbach was that of "royalty," as he describes it. In those earlier, more relaxed days, he felt pampered, and that it was his due.
"I had a lot of money -- more than I ever dreamed -- a great apartment, several cars, and wanted for nothing," he said. "I had become pretty arrogant. My neighbors hated me. I lived in an exclusive condominium in my first few years and played my music loud and didn't throw my garbage in the dumpster but left it on the porch."
"I almost never washed my clothes," he said. "When they got dirty, I threw them into the closet and went down to the mall and bought some more. I was young and rich and a professional athlete and I had no sense of reality. Just like most of the rest of the guys I played with."
 
Happy With a Lot Less
 Rosenbach's late father, Lynn, was a high school football coach and later the assistant athletic director at Washington State. His mother, Rosie, is an interior decorator. His brother, Todd, teaches special education, and his sister, Dana, is a high school teacher.
"When I went back and saw their lives," he said, "saw how they were all doing well on salaries that weren't a million dollars a year, and happy with their lives, I felt embarrassed for myself."
He spoke with Carrie about quitting and giving up that $1 million, as well as the millions that he might earn in football in the coming years.
"I didn't know how he could just give up all that money," said Carrie. "But after a while I understood. He said that if he had to pump gas, he'd do it rather than play football. And it was true."
In Phoenix, he was being called a "no-show," and a "mystery man."
But his agent, Gary Wichard, said: "Timm's an intelligent, sensitive guy, and he has made a decision that he's had it with football. He could have come in for a year and held for extra points and field goals, but that's just not Timm."
"I'm proud of Rosey," said Jim Wahler, a defensive lineman for the Redskins and a former Cardinal teammate of Rosenbach's. "I'm glad he did it. There are not many people in that position to do that. That's a standup thing to walk out on your own terms and not somebody else's. Most guys would like that opportunity."
He still has his ranch in Gilbert, but now lives with Carrie and seven dogs in a small house in an isolated area about eight miles outside of Pullman, Wash. She is a graduate of Arizona State and is in school at Washington State going for a master's degree in agricultural economy. Rosenbach has returned to general studies with a psychology emphasis.
Is he happier? "Yes," he said. "I was getting no enjoyment out of football anymore.
"It's funny, but when I was in school here before I sat in the back of the class and never said a word. Now I'm involved in the classes, and I'm always raising my hand. I'm sure some of the students are saying, 'Why doesn't that old guy just shut up?' "
Rosenbach hardly looks ancient in his sweatshirt and jeans. He still has that broad, boyish look and a cowlick in his short blond hair. And he also hasn't totally given up on football. He says a college game is still one of the exciting spectacles for him. And he still watches pro games on television, remembering the pleasure of the camaraderie of teammates, though he sees the action differently than he once did.
And he still has his memories of playing the game, every morning. His knees, his back, his shoulders still ache when he wakes up and slowly gets out of bed. When he drives for any distance in his truck, or walks distances when he is out hunting birds, his body hurts.
"And I'm still an alumnus of the N.F.L., it is still something I'm proud of," he said. "And I guess one day I'll be invited to some of those alumni golf tournaments, and wear an N.F.L. cap and play, if I can stand up."

HEADLINE: A Practical Woman With Dreams Intact

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Willye B. White's grandfather led her out to the rattlesnake-infested fields of Greenwood, Miss., and laid out the options; she could get pregnant, drop out of school and spend her life right here chopping cotton or she could go to college and create her own destiny. By the time she was 10 years old, Willye had plotted her escape. She would run to freedom.
That was 43 years ago, and Willye White is still running, slower now, through the South Side of Chicago, so she can talk to girls along the way, tell them to take control of their lives, to be free and independent people. A five-time Olympian who has never struck gold but who has always supported herself and spoken her mind, White has reached middle age a practical woman with dreams. 
 She was in a typically chatty mood this week. She is unemployed for the first time in 28 years, and has been using the time to hit the charity golf and banquet circuit and pitch her plan for a sports and education center. She's in town for the annual conference and award dinner Monday of the Women's Sports Foundation.
"This is such a society of the now," she said, "and we athletes think we will always be loved. We aren't taught, we don't want to hear, that once the lights go out, it's over.
"You would not believe how many athletes are struggling. Big names. Legends that are destitute. And they're hiding, they're so ashamed. They don't know how to take care of themselves. If I had won a gold medal in 1956, when I was 16, I might have stopped growing, too.
"We are taught to believe that the object in life is to win the gold, and that will open all the doors. Well, they don't tell us that it will open the door only a crack, and that you need lots more to open it all the way. You need presence and personality and marketability."
She added: "I came out of a challenging situation. My father left my mother after I was born because I was so much lighter than he was. And my eyes were green. He said I wasn't his. Ignorance. My mother gave me away to her parents. Turned out, I was his spit image. On his deathbed, he said, 'You are my child.'
"By the time I was 10, I knew there was something I could do. I was running on the high school varsity. By 12, I was starting on the high school basketball team. All I had to do was keep running and not get pregnant and I'd get out of Mississippi."
As a high school student, Willye spent summers at Tennessee State's track and field camp. Ed Temple was the coach, Wilma Rudolph her most illustrious teammate. White went to her first Olympics, in Melbourne, Australia, as a Tigerbelle and won a silver medal in the long jump.
"It was almost an embarrassment, coming in second," White remembered. "Worth one line in the paper. Second best in the world is treated like a shame. In the long run, I think athletes who win silvers and bronzes may do better than athletes who win the gold because we're still out there trying to get better."
She won another silver in 1960, in Rome, on the 400-meter relay team. She transferred out of Tennessee State after six months.
"Coach Temple wanted to control every aspect of your life, training, classes, who you dated, and I was too much of a free spirit for that."
She moved to Chicago State. When she couldn't crack the black quotas in nursing schools, she became a practical nurse. She began running for Mayor Daley's Youth Foundation and by 1965 got the first of a string of patronage city jobs, usually in the Board of Education or the Health Department. Along the way, she got a degree in public administration. A month ago, her job was phased out.
While White is well-known in national sports circles as a lively, generous resource, her public voice is less well-known; her energies have been spent in her community promoting programs for children rather than deals for herself. A visionary, White has never lost the athlete's compulsion to find a lesson in every loss.
"When Pennell died," she said, referring to the death last Sunday of a fellow Olympian, pole-vaulter John Pennell, "I decided I'm going to divorce from my life all unkind, unhappy people with attitudes. Even on a date with a man, from here on in, if you don't make me laugh right away, you are gone."
At 53 years old, like Pennell, Willye White has a plan.
"The hook would be a 200-meter indoor track that kids could reach by public transportation. And once I had them, I would teach them everything," she said."
White is not the only person who wants to shake the corporate money trees to give poor kids a running start. But hers is a voice worth listening to. She remained on the South Side of Chicago when she could have afforded the lake because she felt it was her responsibility to be "hands-on" rather than another flashy ex-jock showing up only for the photo-op.
"Now, Billie Jean King is a person who went out and helped people hands-on. But all these years in Chicago, I've never seen Bo Jackson on the street. I like Michael Jordan because he's got personality and he cares about family, but I've only met him at functions. I think William Perry was a disgrace, that tooth out, so fat. Charles Barkley is disgusting.
"I still live in the inner city because I don't want kids to think I deserted them. You know, there's a movement of middle-class blacks coming back. If we don't, we'll lose our schools and our neighborhoods to the gangsters.
"Kids will listen to me because they see me around. And I'll listen to them. What do they want to do, let's ask them. All we seem to do is tell them 'Just say no.'
"How can you tell that to a kid who saw her father get shot, who got shot herself in a drive-by, who has to walk an extra mile to get to school to circle around gang turf? Go ask that girl why she got pregnant at 15 and she might tell you the truth, she wanted someone to love her, and then you ask her how can you get someone to love you if you don't love yourself?"
Although her last city job was phased out, White is looking at the loss as a gain to find a corporation interested in the future.
"How about the Willye White Developmental Center? I'd bring in friends who are great hands-on, Nancy Lieberman, Pat Connolly, Ralph Boston, and I'd staff the place with senior citizens, they'll work for the minimum wage.
"I'm not interested in developing athletes, sports is just my hook to get that grass-roots kid. Athletes are prostituted in this society and the coaches aren't helping, they're not teaching kids that sports is just for a short time, you need other skills."
White's strength, she feels, came from the grandparents who raised her and also from that pre-integration, separate-but-equal world in which black teachers and coaches and ministers lived in the same community with the children who most needed their helping hands. She would like to find a way to recreate some of that sense of community.
"What do you think of Willye White World?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: A visionary, Willye B. White has never lost the athlete's compulsion to find a lesson in every loss and has always spoken her mind. (Barry Jarvinen for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 307 words

HEADLINE: Playing Favorites: The Pros and Cons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Hey Boomers: Share the Wealth, Dudes" (Viewpoints, Sept. 26), it's about time for the geniuses in corporate America to wake up and recognize the danger of destroying their customer base as demonstrated by their unwillingness to provide real jobs for the twentysomething generation. The brain trust of business once again illustrates their wonderful capacity to think solely in terms of short-run profits. Just who do these companies expect to buy their goods and services in the future? 
 The notion of failing to provide real, well-paying jobs goes against all common sense. First of all, if twentysomethings are not given an opportunity to earn a decent paycheck, where are they supposed to get the money to purchase the goods and services provided by these companies? Secondly, paying people obscenely low wages is a guaranteed way to lower employee morale and increase turnover. It does not take a rocket scientist to recognize how stupid it is to continue such a policy, yet business owners and executives show no signs of reversing this trend. Obviously, these people are not as smart as they hold themselves out to be.
To all you Boomers hoarding the wealth and arrogantly overstating your self-importance, remember what goes around comes around. The twentysomethings will not soon forget your selfishness. When they somehow manage to put themselves in a position to purchase goods and services, do not count on them making your company their first choice. The double whammy of consumer backlash and a sizable segment of the customer base lacking sufficient purchasing power will put a significant dent in your profits. Instead of thinking in terms of the bottom line, try using some vision. Inevitably the future will arrive, but will you be prepared?
 
PETER GERSTEL
Setauket, L.I., Sept. 26

HEADLINE: Playing Favorites: The Pros and Cons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The suggestion that employers hire more of the members of the generation born after 1961, not as temps but in real jobs with real opportunities, should prompt any fair-minded employer to make the following reply: 
 Sure, I'll hire a young person who happens to be the best candidate for the job, just as I'll hire a middle-aged or old person who happens to be the best candidate. But giving priority to people born after 1961 is age discrimination in favor of the young, a form of bias the job market has plenty of already.
 
FELICIA ACKERMAN
Providence, R.I., Sept. 26

HEADLINE: A Sounder Pesticide Law

 BODY:
Lost in the hullabaloo surrounding President Clinton's health care speech last month was another important Administration proposal: a comprehensive overhaul of pesticide laws. The proposal was promptly denounced by environmentalists as too permissive and by industry groups as too restrictive. But it looks like a reasonable compromise that should make the food supply safer.
The core of the compromise is a swap that makes both sides angry. The Administration proposes to do away with the 35-year-old Delaney Clause, a law that absolutely prohibits adding cancer-causing substances to processed foods but does not apply to fresh foods, which are allowed to contain cancer-causing residues. 
 In its place, the Administration would impose a tough uniform health standard on all foods that allows almost no room to consider the economic benefits of using pesticides. This new standard would be weaker in screening carcinogens from processed foods but stronger in screening them from fresh foods and stronger in curbing pesticides that cause illnesses other than cancer. The net result should be a gain in safety.
Even so, many environmentalists are vehemently opposed to scrapping the Delaney Clause, with its stipulation that no substance shown to cause cancer in humans or animals can be added to processed foods. With respect to pesticides, that provision means no cancer-causing residues can concentrate in processed foods at levels above those allowed on fresh foods.
Delaney's absolutist approach is undeniably appealing. Cancer is a scary disease, and no one is eager to deliberately add carcinogens to the diet. But the Delaney Clause does not really keep all carcinogens out of processed foods. If a carcinogenic residue is allowed on tomatoes, for example, the same level of residue can remain in tomato paste or tomato soup. Only if the residue concentrates at a higher level is the pesticide likely to be banned or curtailed.
That can lead to absurd situations in which a new, safer pesticide is rejected simply because it concentrates somewhat during processing, while an old, more dangerous pesticide, apt to cause more cancer deaths, is retained.
In practice, the Delaney Clause has only intermittently been invoked against pesticides. But a pivotal court decision now requires the Government to enforce it more vigorously, or change the law. The Administration's proposed compromise -- replacement of Delaney with a tough uniform health standard -- mirrors the approach suggested by the National Academy of Sciences and Democratic health leaders in Congress. Both Senator Edward Kennedy and Representative Henry Waxman, leaders of key health committees and known as advocates for public health, have sought a similar compromise for years.
The new Administration proposal would allow carcinogenic residues that pose no more than a negligible risk, defined as a one-in-a-million chance of causing cancer over a lifetime of use. That is not zero, but it is a very tough standard -- far tougher than could be met by some existing pesticides, which can pose risks as high as one in 10,000 of developing cancer.
The Administration also proposes other strong measures: extra protections for children and infants; strict deadlines to comply with the new standards; stronger Government powers to remove suspect pesticides from the market, and a new Federal campaign to reduce pesticide use and switch to other forms of pest control.
Critics in the food and agricultural industries, though delighted to see Delaney go, oppose expansion of the Government's enforcement powers and elimination of any consideration of pesticide benefits. But if the zero-risk approach of the Delaney Clause is to be abandoned, it is only right to stiffen pesticide regulation across the board.
