HEADLINE: Foreign Policy, Left Unclear

 BODY:
What is the Clinton Administration really trying to tell the American people about its foreign policy intentions?
First, a series of high-profile speeches dutifully affirms the importance of continued U.S. leadership and international engagement. Then a series of real-world policy decisions signals an unmistakable scaling back of Washington's commitments to participate in actual international peacekeeping operations, starting with Somalia and Bosnia. 
 Is there any relation between theory and practice? Probably. But to tease it out, the ideas in the speeches need to be decoded from the maddeningly abstract and elliptical language favored by foreign policy specialists. Only then can they be brought into the realm of democratic political debate.
Bill Clinton is no isolationist. But he wants his Presidency to be known for domestic achievements like health care reform and economic revival. So he has tried to avoid distracting foreign policy arguments by leaving the talking to key aides, stressing the rhetoric of continuity and, where possible, quickly changing the subject.
Trouble is, events haven't cooperated. Mr. Clinton has had to deal with real international crises, and has performed reasonably well. But mumbling the old verities of international engagement just sounds silly in a world radically transformed by the end of superpower confrontation.
The Administration now proclaims that America's global responsibilities are as compelling as ever even though the goal has shifted from containing Communism to enlarging the domain of democracy and markets. But that glides past today's most interesting challenges. At last, America's role in the world can be driven by choices instead of threats -- choices about where and where not to intervene, and by what means.
When should America resort to military force, and when should it limit itself to diplomatic and economic pressures? To what extent should it accept the constraints of U.N. or NATO joint decision-making and under what conditions should it act unilaterally? And how can foreign aid programs and trade liberalization strategies be made more compatible with foreign policy?
The Administration's speechmakers stabbed at sorting out these choices, but then seemed to give up, leaving too many agenda items on its crowded plate. And where they most needed to invite public debate, they called for reining it in.
"All of us who support engagement," proclaimed Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, "should be careful to debate tactics in a way that does not prevent us from coming together in common cause around that fundamental importance of the goal of American engagement and American leadership in the world."
Yet Americans are entitled to clear explanations whenever they are called upon to risk their lives and spend their treasure far from home -- especially at a time when foreign crises are less obviously threatening to America's security. The Administration's best hope of maintaining a consensus for engagement lies in demonstrating to Americans that the specific elements of its foreign policy bear directly on their lives and livelihoods. Failure to do so produced the public backlash against overambitious military goals in Somalia and Bosnia that Mr. Clinton was reacting to last week. In a different way, the same failure is reflected in exaggerated public fears over the pending North American Free Trade Agreement.
Mr. Clinton may yet discover that he can build a stronger mandate for domestic change not by dissembling on foreign policy but by facing up to the challenges of a new era and making clear his own choices.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trade Agreement Means Fat Cats Get Fatter

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Caterpillar Sees Free-Trade Boon" (Business Day, Sept. 21) shows a disturbing class conflict arising in the United States over the North American Free Trade Agreement. It is between the organized money class and the disorganized masses. Working class, middle class, manufacturing and clerical workers, even white-collar professionals like schoolteachers, lower management people and engineers, all have a nagging fear that the treaty will further redistribute income and jobs from them to the executives of large corporations, Wall Street bankers and brokers, corporate lawyers and politicians. 
 Caterpillar's executives are hoping the treaty will eventually add $45 million a year to the company's export sales to Mexico. But even this optimistic estimate amounts to a mere 4 percent increase in Caterpillar's sales and production. This is hardly enough for it to add new jobs, but large enough to add about $20 million to annual profits. Caterpillar's increased profits will most likely be attained by an immediate migration of at least 1,000 apparel-making and electronics assembly jobs from the United States to Mexico.
Like those 300 economists who endorsed the trade agreement and chief executives of large corporations and their lobbyists, the loudest endorsers are touting a brighter future prospect for the United States macroeconomy. But real people are saying that they cannot live on a fattened macroeconomic pie eaten by the organized money class. Long gone are the days when improved macroeconomic indexes like gross domestic product, the balance of payments and the Dow Jones stock price index also meant improved job and earning prospects for the working classes to middle classes of the United States.
Ironically, President Bill Clinton is asking Lee Iaccoca, a retired chairman of Chrysler, to sell the trade treaty to ordinary Americans. To ordinary Americans, Mr. Iaccoca has epitomized the cynical and self-serving executives who would heartlessly discharge their rank-and-file employees and help themselves to obscenely large salaries and bonuses.
President George Bush took Mr. Iaccoca on his politically disastrous trip to Japan in January 1992. Japanese and Americans both found it repugnant for the President to let Mr. Iaccoca demand that the Japanese give "jobs, jobs and more jobs" to the United States. Particularly to the bemused Japanese, Mr. Iaccoca and his traveling executives represented what was wrong with the United States economy.
Instead of spending his meager political capital on the trade agreement, President Clinton had best salvage the Uruguay Round Agreement to revive the multilateral and freer trading system of the world, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States, Canada and Mexico would benefit more from the revived and expanded GATT than from the trade agreement, which will divert a limited amount of trade from the United States and Asia to Mexico, at the expense of American jobs.
Japan's new Hosokawa Administration is even ready to open the rice market and work with the United States to persuade France to back reviving GATT before it expires Dec. 15. For the United States and the world, trading the treaty for GATT is a bad deal indeed.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Professor of International Business
Baruch College, CUNY
New York, Sept. 22, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Agreement Means Fat Cats Get Fatter;
The March of the Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One problem with the analysis of the North American Free Trade Agreement by the academic community is summed up in a revealing phrase by Prof. Paul Krugman, "on the average" (front page, Sept. 17). Like the river whose average depth is one foot, there are some very deep areas that cannot be easily crossed. 
 Thus, economists speak of tariffs "averaging 4 percent." But some tariffs, like those on apparel, are much higher. They have been kept high because of the product's high labor intensity and resulting sensitivity to competition from low-wage imports.
While there will be winner and loser industries in a deal like this, that does not mean employment will average out. A victory in machine tools helps an industry whose employment is reported by the Commerce Department as less than 40,000. But a loss in apparel jeopardizes the jobs of nearly 1 million.
Even economists seem to agree that the industries at greatest risk are those with the highest labor intensity. They, and the President, talk about new hi-tech jobs, but there are fewer of these than of more basic jobs, which we must assume will persist for years. Even our high-tech industries are shrinking -- computers, aerospace and defense. The idea that Mexico will be the market to create "better" jobs for Americans is ludicrous. When and with what will Mexico's struggling campesinos begin buying computers and jet planes?
Just as textiles and other manufacturing moved out of the Northeast to the South for cheaper labor, the trade agreement will force the same march on other manufacturing industries wherever they are in the United States.
 
SETH M. BODNER
Executive Director
Natl. Knitwear & Sportswear Assn.
New York, Sept. 27, 1993

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Protection Plans Are Eroding

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
THERE is a shrinking safety net under travelers who make payments to companies that later collapse. Two major organizations in the travel industry are cutting back on consumer protection plans and a third is looking for alternatives.
Here are the recent developments: 
 * Because of hefty claims, the Chubb insurance company would not renew the $5 million consumer protection plan it underwrote for three years for the United States Tour Operators Association, whose 30-odd member operators handle more than half of the tours sold in the United States. The plan, which could cover $5 million in losses in a year among the group's members, ceased Sept. 1. A modified plan protects $1 million in deposits for each company. However, that amount may not be enough: When Olsen Travelworld failed last year, the association had to make good on $1.7 million in payments for tours. Under the modified plan, those customers would have received only 60 cents on the dollar.
* The American Society of Travel Agents' leadership decided late last year that its $250,000 fund was not big enough to insure deposits paid by customers and agents to participating tour operator members. Unable to get support for premiums to provide a $1 million or $2 million fund, this group agreed early this year to terminate its plan in December.
* The National Tour Association, a large group of operators of mainly bus tours, will raise dues in 1994 to $600 a year from $400, to cover its $100,000 consumer protection program. The leadership is consideringalternative plans for 1995 lest insurance costs limit the organization's ability to serve its members.
These changes do not mean that the insurance plans were badly set up; they were battered by a deteriorating economy and tight profit margins in the travel industry. The changes also result from a decision by some big, solid companies to discontinue paying premiums into a pool fund that might permit weaker members to close their doors, or possibly take the money and run, leaving the pool to cover refunds.
 
Stranded Passengers
 Such anxieties are not unfounded. Travel industry experts estimate that 30 major tour operators have failed in the last five or six years, some, like Hemphill-Harris of California, which abruptly stopped operating in 1989, stranding passengers in exotic places. Other failures in the period include Asti, Flyfaire, Lindblad and Caribbean Holidays.
The plan maintained by the National Tour Association, which has a core membership of 575 bus-tour companies that operate in the United States, Canada and Mexico, has paid out $700,000 in the bankruptcies of 18 members since it began in 1988. At the most recent quarterly meeting, 68 percent of the membership wanted to continue the program, which is financed out of dues.
"Our plan is not going to go away," said the association's president, Dottie Maitland of Maitland Travel Service in Kalispell, Mont. "We are not going to bag it; it separates us from the hobbyists in travel, and we want the public to be protected. But we don't know how much more of a hit we can go on taking. We need to find a more cost-effective method."
The biggest fund, the United States Tour Operators', which was raised to the $5 million level in 1990, has paid out more than $7.5 million since then, including the $1.7 million on Olsen; the other failures among U.S.T.O.A. members were First Family of Travel-Hawaii, Four Winds and K.L.R. Members of this organization, now a total of 33, are estimated to serve 55 to 60 percent of people buying package tours in the United States.
Sadly, the net effect is that the pat advice, "be sure your operator belongs to an established national association," is not going to be a talisman against all evils. A logo on a brochure is not insurance.
The new plan of the United States Tour Operators Association requires members to give the association a $1 million bond, letter of credit or certificate of deposit. Robert Whitley, the president, said that this security would be used to refund payments for tours in the event of bankruptcy, cessation of operations or nonpayment of refunds within 120 days.
 
3 Operators Resign
 Three of this organization's members resigned at the changeover: Allied Tours, which arranges travel for overseas visitors to the United States; Domenico Tours of Bayonne, N.J., and Maupintour of Lawrence, Kan.
Three other members no longer qualify under the bylaws, according to Mr. Whitley. Supercities of Minneapolis, and General Tours, formerly linked to Olsen and Cartan in the First Family group, have new owners and new management, and the bylaws require three years' continuous ownership or management, or both. The third, Travellers International, changed the name of its tour program and is also disqualified.
Mr. Whitley cautioned that since brochures were usually printed once a year, the six operators' material might still show coverage by the protection plan. U.S.T.O.A., which was founded in 1972, will answer questions about membership at (212) 944-5727.
Thomas Di Domenico, executive vice president of Domenico Tours, a 30-year-old organization, said his company left because it had assets in the tens of millions, including 70 buses, that would protect customers. "We can stand on our own," he said. "It is not within our thinking that an association can police the standards of the industry. We hoped that the $5 million plan would work. We were committed to the U.S.T.O.A. plan as a wonderful vehicle for consumer confidence. But no insurer would cover."
Now, with protection for $1 million per company, he said, "the integrity of the program is gone if someone goes out holding more than $1 million."
Don Johnston, president of Maupintour, which was founded in 1951 and was a pioneer member, said that U.S.T.O.A. "is supposed to be a marketing organization, but it's spent all its time with the consumer protection program. We've been looking out for our customers for 42 years and we are weary of putting up more and more money. It's driving up the costs."
The American Society of Travel Agents' program for tour operator members, designed to protect its primary members, travel agents, and their clients, began to lose participants as the cost climbed. It had only 23 members by early 1993. When the group's executives concluded that the coverage would pay only pennies on the dollar in the event of a big failure, the members would not support a larger fund. The group then set up a voluntary escrow plan through the First of America Bank in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which holds tour payments until the trip takes place. So far, five operators have joined: Future Tours of Boca Raton, Fla.; Bahamas Vacations of Allentown, Pa.; Cartours-Prima Holidays of Los Angeles; Goway Travel of Toronto, and Places to Go of Coral Springs, Fla.
There is little comfort in all this for consumers, who must check the stability and track record of the companies from which they are buying tours. Any assertion that deposits are being held in an escrow account should be checked with the bank. Note that if you buy travel insurance that covers for operator failure, you should not buy it from the operator. The insurance will be invalid if the operator fails.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 17, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 3, about protection for consumers against tour operators who go out of business, referred incompletely to a company that failed last year, and misspelled its name. The company was Olson-Travelworld; its name was purchased in January by John M. Noel, president and chief executive of the Travel Guard Internationale insurance company. The new Olson-Travelworld is functioning as a tour operator.

HEADLINE: Stamp Collection Sold for Record $9.5 Million

BYLINE: By BARTH HEALEY

 BODY:
What was widely regarded as the premier collection of classic 19th-century American stamps has been broken up and sold for $9.5 million by a Japanese businessman. Christie's, the New York auction house that conducted the sale, said it was the highest single sale for such a collection.
Before the sale, which took place on Tuesday and Wednesday, Christie's had valued the collection at $9 million to $12 million. 
 The highlight of the 746 lots was an envelope that was mailed in May 1851 from Montreal to England by way of New York, and that has one Canadian stamp, to pay postage to New York, and five United States stamps, to pay postage to England. The price was $717,500, which Christie's said was a record for any such piece of United States postal history. It was bought by an Italian collector whom the auction house would not identify.
The collection, which covered all postage stamps issued in the United States from 1847 to 1869, had been built up over the last two decades by Ryohei Ishikawa. He is chairman of the Chubu Bank and of the Teisan Group, which has interests in transportation, finance and real estate.
Despite the prices, Mr. Ishikawa probably lost money on the sale because when he was building the collection, he was paying 150 yen or more for every dollar he invested. But the dollar has weakened over the past decade, and each dollar he earned from the sale is now worth about 105 yen.
Ben Schafer of Denver, who described himself as Mr. Ishikawa's North American lawyer, accepted this arithmetic. But in an interview in the auction room on Wednesday, he said that Mr. Ishikawa was not really an investor, adding, "He also got a lot of real pleasure from his stamps."
The banker had shown parts of his collection at stamp conventions over the years and had won several gold medals.
The most notable trend during the sale was a renewed interest in stamps rather than artifacts of postal history, like envelopes that bear markings showing how the mail was carried. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, a speculative boom in stamp prices drove many stamp collectors to postal history, where making a smart purchase depends far more on research than on the mere appearance of an item.
Colin Fraser, head of Christie's stamp department, said he was impressed by the large number of bidders.
Michael Laurence, editor of Linn's Stamp News, a weekly, said, "This sale shows that the hobby is basically healthy, and that people will pay for nice-looking stamps."
The big prices went to a few famous pieces of postal history and a few error stamps, two-color issues from 1869 whose centers had been printed upside down. But more modest items, typically sound, fresh-looking single stamps, sold in some cases for many times more than their pre-sale estimates. An 1869 3-cent stamp, for example, with an interesting cancellation reading "O-K," was estimated at $30 to $50; it sold for $241.50.
Most fancy stuff still brought fancy prices: a 24-cent error stamp of 1869, whose center is inverted, was estimated at $80,000 to $100,000; it sold for $228,000, the second-highest price ever paid for a United States stamp. In 1986, at the peak of a speculative surge, a 1-cent stamp printed in 1867 on special paper brought $418,000.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I was interested in your article on automobiles. As a disabled New Yorker, I am "automobile dependent."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Story of My Life? Glad You Asked.

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
EVERY FALL THEY TURN UP: new television characters with new families, workplaces or both, hoping viewers will learn to love them. But when networks may only give a show six episodes to live or die, viewers had better get acquainted fast. Maybe that's why, when it comes to exposition, some stars are saying it all in one speech. Here's how six new sitcoms handled things. ANITA GATES "The Boys" (CBS)
 Setting: A book signing. A customer asks a writer, Doug Kirkfield (Chris Meloni), when his next book is coming out. 
Speech: "Soon. We just bought this big old house in Washington State, and we're going to get away from the hustle and bustle and crime and pollution of New York and settle down in a sleepy little town where there's nothing for me to do but write."
 Reaction: The customer says, "I just asked you when it's coming out."
 
"Cafe Americain" (NBC)
 Setting: The first-class cabin of a trans-Atlantic flight. Holly Aldridge (Valerie Bertinelli) is seated next to a French model in a micro-mini, who asks, "And you are?"
 Speech: "Moving to Paris. Which is what I wish I'd done when I was 20, instead of marrying that jerk of an ex-husband who my sister tried to warn me about. She said, 'He is not right for you.' But I just had to prove her wrong."
 Reaction: "Is fantastic to know this," the model says. "I was asking your name."
 
"Family Album" (CBS)
 Setting: A contentious, multi-generational family dinner at the Lerners' new home. Jonathan Lerner (Peter Scolari) suddenly stands and angrily addresses his parents and his wife's mother.
 Speech: "Enough! Now look, we moved back here because we love you. We love your company, and we love your brisket, which you will never bring again. Until we ask you to. Now you have every right to make us as crazy as you want to. That's your job. But when it comes to our kids, just back off!"
 Reaction: From his mother-in-law: "Screw 'em up any way you want to."
 
"Frasier" (NBC)
 Setting: A call-in radio show. Dr. Frasier Crane (Kelsey Grammer) is on the air.
 Speech: "Hello, Russell. . . . Let me see if I can cut to the chase by using myself as an example. Six months ago I was living in Boston. My wife had left me, which was very painful. Then she came back to me, which was excruciating.
 "You see, I thought I could forgive her indiscretion, but I was only kidding myself. On top of that, my practice had grown stagnant. And my social life consisted of hanging around a bar night after night. You see, I was clinging to a life that wasn't working anymore. And I knew I had to do something, anything. So I ended the marriage once and for all, packed up my things and moved back here to my hometown of Seattle. Go, Seahawks!
 "I took action, Russell. And you can, too!" Reaction: A colleague informs Dr. Crane, "We cut to the news 30 seconds ago."
 
"Grace Under Fire" (ABC)
 Setting: A highway. Grace Kelly's (Brett Butler's) car has been pulled over by a highway patrolman (John Goodman).
 Speech: "I can't afford a ticket. I can barely afford this balloon. Do you have any idea what my life is like? . . . I'm going to tell you. You see those kids in there? I'm raising them by myself. No child support. No alimony. And you know what? It's hard. It's damn hard. Nobody gives you a medal at the end of a day. . . . Nobody comes up and pats you on the back and says, 'Way to go, Mom.' . . ."
 Reaction: The policeman speaks into his radio: "21 bravo. I may need backup here."
 
"The John Larroquette Show" (NBC)
 Setting: An Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. John Hemingway (John Larroquette) is at the podium.
 Speech: "I'm standing here tonight with good news. If I can still trust my ability to count, I have been sober well over five and a half days. You know what? And I've discovered some things that I didn't know when I was drunk. For instance, I'm in St. Louis. How the hell did I get here? I've discovered a few other things too. I was astounded to find out that a majority of people are offended by nudity in church. I discovered that wives get very upset when they're lied to for over a decade. And trying to kiss a dog on the lips can also have legal ramifications.
 "But seriously, folks, tonight I start a new job. As station manager of the Crossroads Bus Terminal. And I really, really, really have to make it work this time. I got the job because I have a master's degree in English literature, which is essential for working in a bus station. Did I mention I was the only one who applied?
 "Tonight may be the most important night of my life. And all I have to do is get through it without taking a drink."
 Reaction: The scene changes to the bus station, where a bum asks Mr. Hemingway, "Want a drink?"

HEADLINE: Debunking the Myths About Public Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As a public-school teacher and a parent of two children attending public school -- all of us in District 2 in Manhattan -- I wholeheartedly support the main idea of Eric Rothenberg's article on his daughter's switch from private to public school: "I can't help but wonder what might be accomplished citywide if those of us who have been running away from the public schools stopped running" ("When a Product of the Private Schools Goes Public," Sept. 19). 
If today's parents would research the public-school choices, many of the negative myths and horror stories would quickly dissipate. District 2, for example, has a diversity of wonderful programs run by talented and innovative administrators and teachers and supported by involved parents.
 My oldest child will be graduating from P.S. 6 in June. When I was recently asked by another New York City parent which junior high school we were considering for next year, I was both amused and appalled by this parent's contemptuous attitude when I said, "Probably Wagner," meaning Junior High School 167. I wish I had asked this parent if she had ever set foot in this school, let alone spoken with one of its teachers or students.
 We all need to replace our fear and ignorance with responsibility and knowledge.
BETH HERMELIN Manhattan

HEADLINE: Luxury-Tax Repeal Encourages Sellers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
LAST month, Thomas G. Caruso, owner of Total Marine Ltd. in Mamaroneck, sold a 37-foot Phoenix convertible sports fishing boat for $400,000. "It's a beauty," he said. "Sleeps six. Has everything, including air-conditioning, a microwave and two big diesel engines."
Mr. Caruso added that negotiations for the sale had begun earlier in anticipation of the repeal of the 10 percent excise or luxury tax on boats costing more than $110,000 and on other expensive items like jewelry and furs, but not on automobiles. "The customer told me he would have never bought the boat if he had had to pay the luxury tax, which would have added $30,000 more to the purchase price," Mr. Caruso said. 
 The 10 percent excise tax on expensive boats was imposed three years ago as a way to generate new revenue from the rich. The tax, say those in the boating industry, began having an immediate impact on sales as buyers adopted a wait-and-see attitude.
After waging a two-year battle that eventually led to the Congressional repeal of the tax in August, the boating industry now expects the repeal to have an immediate impact on sales, production and work-force levels, said Jeff W. Napier, president of the National Marine Manufacturer's Association, the principal trade group of the recreational marine industry.
 
Recouping Losses; Not a Victory
 Mr. Caruso said: "It will certainly help our industry, where activity doesn't start in the factory but on the showroom floor. Sales of boats at the retail level give manufacturers the incentive to produce. Our sales are starting to pick up a bit. And despite the recession we were not hurt too badly overall this year. Luckily, we are in an affluent area so the revenues we didn't generate in sales we were able to pretty much make up in service. And our marina was 100 percent occupied, so this season turned out to be a pretty good one for us."
But, Mr. Napier said, manufacturers don't view repeal so much as a victory as a chance to return to where they were before enactment of the tax.
"It's hard to be elated when our own government activity created a loss of 30,000 American jobs and destroyed dozens of companies in the process," Mr. Napier said. "And the revenues weren't there. For every dollar that was collected on the luxury tax, we estimated the Federal Government paid out $5 for each dollar collected in unemployment benefits and other costs caused by layoffs. Then, too, a contracting economy brought sales that were subject to the tax to a virtual standstill, causing unemployment, plant closings and foreclosures in the marine industry."
In addition, he said, big-boat sales were down from peak levels in 1988 to a historic low.
Edward Tomanek, manager of the Nichols Yacht Yard in Mamaroneck, said: "The tax certainly hurt the industry, no doubt about it. But we phased out our sales department sometime before the tax was enacted so it didn't affect us directly. Our revenues come from our marina. We have 170 slips and our service department."
 
Major Recovery Expected
 At Shongut Marine in Rye, the manager, Thomas Consolazio, said that although he knew the tax had had a severe impact on the marine industry, causing unemployment and hardship, his company was not adversely affected.
"One major reason is that we don't carry those very expensive boats," Mr. Consolazio said. "Our top price is $70,000, with the average boat we sell costing about $26,000. In fact, we had a good year. Our sales of new and used boats were up 12 to 13 percent, the highest it has been since the early 80's, and the service department was extremely busy."
Mr. Napier said the industry's feeling is that boat sales and jobs will now make a significant recovery.
"We think the pent-up demand from customers who refused to pay the tax will help the boat builders re-employ 5,000 workers within six months," Mr. Napier said. He also observed that renewed boat sales would help American manufacturers regain their competitive position in world markets.
 
Middle Class Also Affected
 People who earn their living in the jewelry and fur industries are also encouraged by the repeal of the luxury tax, which hurts their businesses, too. Barbara Greenberg, manager of H. L. Gross and Brothers, a jewelry store in the Galleria in White Plains, is also the immediate past president of the New York State Jewelry Association, a trade group.
"The association and I worked hard for two years to get that ill-conceived tax repealed," Mrs. Greenberg said. "It was extremely detrimental to us. Even before the tax was enacted, the jewelry industry was hit hard by the recession. Business has not been good across the board, and the tax certainly hurt us when we needed help the most."
The tax, aimed at the wealthy, actually hurt the middle class, Mrs. Greenberg said.
"We had to collect 10 percent luxury tax on all items that carried a price tag of more than $10,000," she said. "This actually affected middle-class customers, those who had saved up, for instance, to buy an engagement ring or an expensive watch for a once-in-a-lifetime occasion. They were the ones who hesitated and did not buy because the 10 percent tax on top of the sales tax just put them too far over the edge."
Although Mrs. Greenberg said that she was delighted to see the tax repealed and that she hoped sales during the coming holiday season will show an improvement, she said the paperwork required for refunds of the tax, retroactive to Jan. 1 this year, is formidable.
 
Impact Hard to Trace
 "We will have to contact every customer who paid the tax over the past two years and refund the money to them. Only then will we be reimbursed in turn, by the Government, and you can imagine how long that will take."
Danny Fusco, a furrier who has a business in Mamaroneck, said that the impact of the tax on his business could not be accurately defined.
"I really didn't directly feel the effect, but on the other hand I don't know how much it hurt me," Mr. Fusco said, adding that he will never know how much the tax cost him in lost sales and potential business.
"The tax was mainly applicable to sable coats, Russian lynx and Russian broad-tail coats that are in the $18,000 to $44,000 range," Mr. Fusco said. "We don't normally sell quantities of those coats. Minks are a staple, and most of those were priced so they weren't affected by the luxury tax."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luxury boats at Total Marine Ltd. in Mamaroneck. After waging a two-year battle that led to Congressional repeal of the luxury tax in August, the boating industry expects an immediate impact on sales and work-force levels. (Photographs by Susan Harris for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 10; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2024 words

HEADLINE: Their 15 Minutes

BYLINE: By RICHARD B. WOODWARD

 BODY:
RUDOLPH GREY has the wary, unshaven face of a New Yorker who finds sunlight irritating. Even in the dimness of his apartment, a second-floor walk-up in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood in New York, he squints. His hipster threads -- olive jacket with thin collar turned up, white shirt with big cufflinks, black jeans -- are nicely wrinkled. He chain-smokes thin brown Sherman MCD cigarettes, the ashes from which have, over time, formed a kind of fossil layer on his thousands of LP's and 45's.
Most of his adult life ("just say I'm in my late 30's," he insists) Mr. Grey has existed on the tattered fringe of New York's art and music scene. Since 1972, he has been known professionally and to his friends as Rudolph Grey, a persona chosen because "Rudolph is colorful and Grey is sort of neutral," he says. He won't give his real name. 
 Born in Brooklyn and trained as a painter at the School of Art and Design and the Institute of Technology in Manhattan, he has played guitar in small clubs, often with just a drummer, for about 15 years. His remarkably loud style, made from abstract slabs of noise laced with squealing feedback, can be heard on independent labels like New Alliance and Ecstatic Peace. But his following has never been large or devoted. "I don't want to talk about my music career," he snaps. "It confuses people."
The confusion rests, if only in his mind, on the fact that now Mr. Grey is better-known as an author. "Nightmare of Ecstasy," his oral biography of Edward Wood Jr., B-movie director and renowned transvestite, was published last year to outstanding reviews. ("Delirious and horrifying -- and All True!" Richard Corliss wrote in Time magazine.)
The production company for the director Tim Burton, who made "Batman Returns" and the new, animated "Nightmare Before Christmas," paid a reported $250,000 for the film rights. Now shooting in Los Angeles, it has become an $18 million black-and-white feature for Walt Disney's Touchstone Pictures, starring Johnny Depp, Patricia Arquette, Martin Landau, Sarah Jessica Parker, Lisa Marie Smith and Bill Murray.
Mr. Wood, for those who missed this summer's retrospective at the Film Forum, an alternative theater in SoHo, wrote and directed several of the most peculiar films to come out of Hollywood. Produced on trifling budgets that wouldn't pay the Perrier bill for a feature film today, Mr. Wood's efforts veer between bold, cut-rate experimentation and pure lunacy. Some, like "Plan 9 from Outer Space" and "Bride of the Monster," have become kitsch classics for their gimcrack props and plots.
Fascination with Mr. Wood has burgeoned as researchers like Mr. Grey have fleshed out the sad absurdities of his life. According to Mr. Grey's book, Mr. Wood was a none-too-secret cross-dresser. A decorated Marine in World War II, he is known to have worn a pink bra and panties beneath his fatigues during the invasion of Tarawa. As a director, he borrowed or stole wardrobe items from his actresses, especially anything soft and fuzzy, like angora socks or sweaters. And he often pounded out scripts or novels on a typewriter at the kitchen table while costumed in a wig, makeup, a skirt and high heels.
In Mr. Grey's book, the director John Waters sums up Mr. Wood as "brave, eccentric and sometimes insane."
"I knew from the very beginning," Mr. Grey says, "that this was an incredible story, the kind that a writer would invent -- if he could. Someone who was out there, all alone, writing these novels that nobody read or reviewed -- I mean nobody -- and making movies that no one ever saw. I knew they would be making million-dollar movies about him some day. I knew it."
Mr. Burton clearly shares an affection for Mr. Wood's work and an empathy for his travails. "There is something beautiful about somebody doing what they love to do, no matter how misguided, and remaining optimistic and upbeat against all odds," he says by fax from Los Angeles.
Mr. Grey, who has been hired as a consultant for Mr. Wood's film, grouses that his services have not yet been enlisted. "Ask Tim Burton why he hasn't called me," he says. Mr. Grey's recent, happy spin of the wheel of fortune seems only to have increased his apprehensions.
"Don't blow it for me," he warns as I sit down on the fake-fur sofa in his living room. It's two days before he is supposed to receive his money (he won't say how much) and he fears a last-minute snag. "These studios, you never know what they'll do," he says.
Mr. Grey has had no previous relationship with large sums of money. Getting by as a paste-up artist for publishers because his music jobs never covered the rent, he hasn't earned enough to pay taxes in 10 years, he says. His book proposal was turned down by 12 houses.
The book might not have found a home at all had a friend, the writer Jimmy McDonough, not told him to contact Adam Parfrey, editor and publisher of Feral House in Los Angeles. The renegade purveyor of underground classics like "Apocalypse Culture," an anthology of articles on various cults and conspiracies, Mr. Parfrey quickly signed the project.
"Adam was an Ed Wood fan," Mr. Grey says. "And he was hip enough to know this was important." Enthusiasm seems to have compensated for advance money. Mr. Grey received $1,000 to embark on the book.
As a teen-ager, Mr. Grey watched Mr. Wood's low-budget shockers with amazement on Channel 11's "Chiller Theater." After dozens of viewings, he still finds "Plan 9 from Outer Space" to be "perfectly charming, like a pulp supernatural fairy tale."
But not until December 1978 ("the fateful month," as he puts it in the introduction to his book), during a midnight screening at the old Thalia theater on the Upper West Side, did Mr. Grey experience the "revelation" that led to more than a decade of obsessive labor. The epiphany was "Glen or Glenda," Mr. Wood's most notorious and personal film. Violating most of the rules of cinema, this thinly disguised autobiography includes, among many jarring elements, clinical accounts of transvestism, Bela Lugosi reciting demented nursery rhymes and a confused young man who must tell his fiancee a dark secret -- and it isn't that he's been seeing another woman.
A MONG the many B-movie directors whose work ran on the bottom halves of twin bills during the 1950's and 60's, Mr. Wood has been singled out by some critics for special scorn. He was once voted the Worst Director of All Time by Harry and Michael Medved, creators of the Golden Turkey Awards. Videos of his films are marketed with campy warning labels that read: "Do not watch this film. It is so bad you may not be able to stand it."
The topic of Mr. Wood's supposed incompetence taps a hot gusher of emotion in Mr. Grey. "It's continually 'Ed Wood, Worst Film Maker,' " he said. "I don't see how these so-called critics can justify it. If he was such a bad film maker, why would anyone put his films out on video, right? The worst directors make some TV movie that no one ever thinks about. Movies that are insipid, bland, stupid, boring. That's the worst director."
"Anyone who does something really different in this country, the Bozo element of the press will attack him," he continues. "It's easy to make fun of low-budget movies. But Ed Wood grew up on the pulp movies of the 30's and the 40's. The Monogram films like 'The Apeman,' 'The Corpse Vanishes,' 'Bowery at Midnight,' which the French picked up on. And radio shows like 'I Love a Mystery' or 'Chandu the Magician.' His movies evolve perfectly out of that."
Mr. Grey spent more than 10 years researching and writing his book. To finance his many trips to Los Angeles, he sold off his huge collection of horror- and science-fiction-movie posters. Of the more than 600 he once owned, 40 are left. Prime examples, from "Attack of the 50-Ft. Woman," "Jail Bait" and "Bride of the Monster," still adorn his walls.
"In the early 70's, you could get them for about 50 cents," he says. "By the early 80's, they were worth $300 or $400 each. That paid for a lot of my research. And I borrowed money, of course."
He economized every way he knew. Unless he could find a ride from friends in Los Angeles, Mr. Grey took public transportation to interviews.
Mr. Grey managed to round up an enormous cast of Mr. Wood's cronies, including his mother and his widow. With help from actors and distributors, he has reconstructed the making of and atmosphere around each of the films, many shot in three or four days for $5,000. He has also read every Wood novel he could find. There may have been as many as 75 paperbacks, written under various pseudonyms for the pornography market, with titles like "The Sexecutives," "Side-Show Siren," "To Make a Homo" and "Death of a Transvestite Hooker."
Mr. Wood died in 1978 at 54, before anyone thought he might one day be infamous. "There was never an interview with Ed Wood on Ed Wood," Mr. Grey says, shaking his head. "No one took him seriously. Every time anyone interviewed him it was about Bela Lugosi. Ed Wood was the rotten mushroom at the bottom of the hill, as far as most people were concerned."
As described in the book, Mr. Wood's last years were wretched. Destitute and a drunk, he fought often and loudly with his wife. The police made regular calls to his apartment in a crime-ridden complex in Hollywood. The couple and their few possessions were finally tossed out on the street. Mr. Wood died of a heart attack three days later.
From Mr. Grey's apartment, one can look out on a theater complex where Mr. Burton's film could open next year; Mr. Wood's movies would have been lucky to play for a week in a few grind houses. The disparity troubles Mr. Grey.
"Here you have this director whom no one respected at all when he was alive, and now he's a legend in death," he says with agitation. "Don't think I'm not aware of the ironies in that. I'm not about to let that slip by. They're making an $18 million movie about him, which may be low-budget these days. But for $18 million, Ed Wood could have made about 300 movies."
Like Mr. Grey, Mr. Burton grew up watching Mr. Wood's movies on television. "Like everyone else, I remember thinking, 'Wow, what is this," he says. "But then I began to realize that even though they are bad, they are good. He didn't let technicalities like visible wires and bad sets distract him from his storytelling. There's a twisted form of integrity in that."
Mr. Grey's years of poorly paid research show a similar integrity, with a happy ending. But as self-righteous as his crusade may sound, it hasn't made him smug. Enchanted by anything Woodian, he has adapted one of the novels, "Killer in Drag," for a 10-minute film, using actors from Charles Ludlam's Ridiculous Theatrical Company. It has never had a public showing; nor has his 55-minute video "Whip Me Daddy." Sensing a publicity opportunity, Mr. Grey plugs an original screenplay, co-written with the critic Cole Gagne, "Dracula vs. Hitler."
"It's definitely a first-rate script," he says, outlining a plot wherein the Nazis take a supernatural book from the library in Dracula's castle to learn the secrets of ultimate power. The script concludes with an epic battle between the two evil protagonists of the title. "Dracula does actually fight Hitler," Grey promises. "We do deliver."
Mr. Grey will no doubt have to pay taxes this year on his windfall, although he seems not yet to comprehend his new financial standing. At lunch at a local Chinese restaurant, he asks for investment advice. "People tell me I should buy real estate," he says. "What do you think?" He would like to put some money away and use the rest to make movies.
As he sweats out the last days before his money arrives, he allows himself a few moments to relax and forget his fears of a snafu. The bill arrives and he looks on with puzzled admiration. "I've got to get one of those American Express green cards now," he says, nodding. "That's what my tax accountant told me."
He leans over the table, exhales some brown smoke toward the ceiling, and letting slip a rare smile, says, "I'm moving up in the world."

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
A Free-Spirited Survivor Lands on Her Feet

BYLINE: By JAMES GAVIN; James Gavin is the author of "Intimate Nights: The Golden Age of New York Cabaret."

 BODY:
For Annie Ross, living on the edge has become a fine art. In 1958, this cool-yet-sultry redhead earned a place in jazz vocal history when she became the female third of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, the trio famous for setting bullet-fire lyrics to jazz instrumentals. Ms. Ross's octave-leaping, sweet-and-sour voice intrigued Miles Davis, Dizzy Gillespie and other musicians who had little time for female singers. So did her capacity for partying -- until drugs nearly ended the fun permanently.
But her instinct for self-destruction was exceeded by a knack for survival. After beating heroin addiction, bankruptcy and chronic unemployment, the 63-year-old singer and actress has landed on her feet again. In Robert Altman's new film "Short Cuts," she plays a ravaged jazz singer named Tess Trainer who tries to block out reality with booze, pot, cynical love songs and bittersweet memories of a rocky past. 
 While almost every other character in the movie is drawn from the short stories of Raymond Carver, Mr. Altman created this one especially for her. "I heard her sing at my house a lot after dinner," he says, "and I became infatuated with her passion for her music. She hears a whole band inside her head. Every time she was bored or things weren't going well, she'd sing. And that's just what this character does."
The newly released soundtrack album for the film, which opened the New York Film Festival last week and is being released commercially starting today, is her biggest recording project since the 1960's. In it she gives a jazz spin to tunes by the likes of Dr. John, Elvis Costello and U2, whose "Conversation on a Bar Stool" -- a dark dramatic monologue that is heard throughout the film -- shows how Ms. Ross has made the transition from singer to singing actress. She has just kicked off a string of national singing appearances, performing songs from the album along with a repertory that salutes the masters of pop and modern jazz.
Years of overindulgence may have roughened her once-silky voice, but her impeccable rhythm and sense of swing remain -- not to mention a combination of worldliness and wry humor. As Jon Hendricks, her former partner, has said, "Annie Ross has that feeling you can't learn in no school, that feeling that the men in the old Basie band had from birth."
Recently, in her living room on the East Side of New York, Ms. Ross lit a cigarette and recalled a life story laced with mythology -- some of it her own invention. Her measured speech reminds one of England, where she was born Annabelle Short in 1930. Rumor has always had it that she is the daughter of Ella Logan, who starred in the 1947 Broadway musical "Finian's Rainbow." Ms. Ross, however, claims that Logan was her aunt -- and that her parents, a touring Scottish vaudeville duo, sent her to live with the singer in Hollywood at age 4.
As Annabelle Logan, she landed a singing role in the M-G-M short "Our Gang Follies of 1938," then played Judy Garland's kid sister in the 1943 film "Presenting Lily Mars." But she resented Logan's frequent absences and burned to make her way in jazz like her idols Duke Ellington, Lena Horne and Erroll Garner. After the 10th grade, she quit school, took the name Annie Ross and fled to Europe, where she quickly found work as a revue performer and band singer.
Things grew complicated in 1949, when she had a brief affair with the black jazz drummer Kenny Clarke and gave birth to a son, Kenny Clarke Jr. She left the child in the care of Mr. Clarke's family, then moved to New York in 1950. After two lean years, a producer at the jazz record label Prestige asked her to try her hand at "vocalese," the technique later immortalized by Lambert, Hendricks and Ross. She returned the next day with "Twisted," a witty tale of split personalities set to a solo by the tenor saxophonist Wardell Gray. She recorded it, then flew to Scotland to join her family's vaudeville act.
While she was gone, the song became an underground hit. "Someone sent me a clipping saying that I'd won the Down Beat New Star Award," she says. "So I came back. It got me a few more gigs." She spent the next five years working in jazz clubs and theater, recording occasionally, and hanging out with musicians, happy as long as she was having fun. "I only wanted to sing and be free," she says.
Stardom came unexpectedly in 1958. Mr. Hendricks had written lyrics to a set of instrumentals by Count Basie, and he and Dave Lambert, a be-bop singer and arranger, asked Ms. Ross to join a chorus assembled to record them. Except for her, the group "couldn't swing if you hung 'em," in Mr. Hendricks's words.
The three singers recorded their voices four times each to simulate the whole Basie band. The album, "Sing a Song of Basie," officially launched them as Lambert, Hendricks and Ross. Thereafter, they wrote dozens of other vocalese story-songs that kept them on top of the jazz polls for four years. Ms. Ross stood in the middle wearing couture dresses and a tiara, her high-flying voice winning a few awards of its own. Life, she says, was "like a party."
But in the jazz world, partying often meant drugs -- and her try-anything attitude turned her into an addict in short order. Ms. Ross stiffens at the mention of it. "Yeah, I had a hangup," she says, expressionless. "A little bit here, a little bit there, and that was it. It was the culture of the time -- the long hours, having to produce every night, needing stimulation. I guess you're young and fearless and think you're going to live forever."
In the late 50's, Ms. Ross fell in love with the comic Lenny Bruce, whose own drug problems were reaching their height. In the book, "Ladies and Gentlemen, Lenny Bruce!!," the writer Albert Goldman paints a grisly picture of their affair, recounting how Bruce and a friend once managed to revive her after a near-fatal heroin fix. By 1960, the singer Carol Sloane was subbing regularly for Ms. Ross. After the group finished a date in London in May 1962, Ms. Ross stayed there to try and go straight. "I kind of knew that if I came back to America I might die," she says.
She kicked her habit, but other trials lay in store. In 1963, she married the actor Sean Lynch, who helped her run a London cabaret called Annie's Room. Eighteen months later the investors replaced music with gambling, and Ms. Ross was out of a job. By that time, the British rock scene had made singers like her seem antique.
What's more, colleagues say that Lynch had a violent streak. The revue and record producer Ben Bagley recalls running into Ms. Ross at Ronnie Scott's, a London jazz club. "She had a black eye and was quite unsteady," he says. "She embraced me and cried as if we were old friends. We sat and talked for quite a while. Her self-esteem was down to nothing."
By 1975, she had declared bankruptcy, lost her home and divorced Lynch, who died soon after in a car crash. "They say that each of these is a traumatic thing -- well, boy, I had 'em all," she says. "Work? Meager. You know, if you can't do what you really want to do, you tell yourself you don't care, when in your heart you care a lot. People say, 'Oh, there, there -- you were a great singer.' You say thank you, but you think, damn it, I'm still a great singer."
Her luck took a turn in 1979, when she won a small acting role in the film "Yanks." Thereafter, parts in films like "Superman III" and "Pump Up the Volume," occasional theater and nightclub work, and the generosity of friends helped keep her afloat. Then in the mid-80's, she met Mr. Altman's wife, Kathryn, who introduced her to the director. He became a fan and gave her a cameo in his 1992 film "The Player." When the deal for "Short Cuts" came through last year, he signed her immediately.
Through the prodding of Mrs. Altman, she has now started an autobiography. Her 43-year-old son lives in Los Angeles, apparently without much of a career. "He's kind of in music," she says. "Sometimes he plays drums." As for Ms. Ross, the future is full of hope but not illusion. " 'As Bob said, 'If nothing else, at least you'll get to sing in better places.' Whatever happens, I could never give up music. That's my heart."
She leans forward on the sofa, and for a moment her hazel eyes come vividly to life. "What a gift Robert Altman gave me, to have this opportunity at my age," she says. "By rights I should be dead. But I'm just happy I survived."
And is the Annie Ross of today any different from the young woman who won Down Beat's New Star Award of 1952? Her brow furrows. "I've come down to earth," she says. Her eyes twinkling, she adds, "but only a little bit."

HEADLINE: FILM;
About the Baby, The Bathwater And Beyond

BYLINE: By ELLEN PALL; Ellen Pall teaches arts journalism at Fordham/The College at Lincoln Center.

 BODY:
Long before parent became a verb, mothers and fathers were driving themselves crazy over how best to care for their babies. That's one lesson of "Total Baby," one of 62 works in the 17th annual Margaret Mead Film and Video Festival. The six-day event opens tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, then travels to half a dozen cities.
"Total Baby," which was written and directed by two New Yorkers, Kate Davis and Alyson Denny, trains an anthropologist's cool eye on the staggering array of new products and programs (womb-simulating pillows, video mobiles, exercise workouts for newborns, cooking classes for toddlers) aimed at perfecting the American middle-class child from birth to 3 years of age. 
 "Would you like to see Rembrandt? I can show you some Rembrandt," chirps a carefully-groomed young mother, displaying a reproduction to her squirming baby. "This is Aristotle contemplating the bust of Homer."
In classic anthropological style, the film makers stand a bit outside the culture they scrutinized. Neither Ms. Denny nor Ms. Davis has children (though both were inspired by making the film to speed up plans to do so).
Ms. Denny, 30, became interested in modern child rearing when a friend mentioned how well she was doing with her investment in La Petite Academy, a chain of child-care and early education centers that accepts children from the age of six weeks. Intrigued, Ms. Denny mentioned the phenomenon to Ms. Davis, whom she had met when both studied film at Harvard. When the two began to look into the child-rearing business, they found a roiling world of high-energy entrepreneurship. "Once we jumped into the pool," said Ms. Davis, 33, "we learned: Forget the toddlers; the hottest stuff going was newborns."
Cutting back and forth from present to past, the film makers place current infant-rearing trends in historical context, telescoping 2,300 years of Western notions about babies into just under an hour. The emphasis on Western thought appealed to the festival's programmer, Elaine S. Charnov.
"We rarely look at our own child-rearing habits," she said, adding that the subject was of particular interest as a contrast to Margaret Mead's own film study of child rearing in non-Western cultures. Though the festival presents many studies by outsiders of so-called exotic cultures, it strives for diversity by including films on Western subjects as well as works by non-Western film makers about their own societies.
Ms. Davis and Ms. Denny believe that theories about infants are shaped by contemporary social forces. Thus the Victorians, surrounded by the Dickensian nightmare of the Industrial Revolution, made sheltered gardens of their nurseries, celebrating a cult of innocent babies nurtured by doting mothers. Around 1900, the assembly line inspired a model of baby-as-machine (aluminum mittens to prevent thumb sucking, for example). Today's elaborate attempts to sharpen skills in infancy, said Ms. Davis, reflect "a kind of mass generational anxiety" brought on by a daunting environmental and economic future.
Does she fear that the barrage of attention may actually damage the children?
Not in the least. "Eventually, everybody gets toilet-trained," she said. "I'm not at all worried about the babies."

LENGTH: 1837 words

HEADLINE: Disappointed Black Voters Could Damage Dinkins's Bid

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
In a mayoral contest that most experts say is now too close to call, one sure bet is that most black votes will go to David N. Dinkins. But many black ministers, politicians and neighborhood leaders contend that the Mayor's support among black voters is neither as monolithic nor as enthusiastic as it once was, suggesting that more black people than usual might decide not to vote at all.
To be sure, recent opinion polls show the Mayor drawing support from about 90 percent of black people. It is not considered likely that black Democrats would switch to vote for Rudolph W. Giuliani. But some who have informally canvassed black voters suggest there is nonetheless disappointment with Mr. Dinkins and his nearly four years in office. 
 Any softening of support for Mr. Dinkins could cause him significant problems in November. In his 1989 race against Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins won 91 percent of the black vote, which accounted for 28 percent of the ballots cast. A shift in just 22,000 voters in the total electorate of 1.8 million voters would have swung the election to Mr. Giuliani.
"I have no doubt that the Mayor will enjoy the down-to-the-wire support of the vast majority of African-Americans and Caribbean-Americans," said Esmeralda Simmons, director of the Center for Law and Social Justice at Medgar Evers College, who is campaigning for the Mayor.
"But there is still continuing disappointment that many of the dreams, hopes and aspirations that came with the election of a black Mayor have not been realized," she said.
Although that disappointment may prompt some black Democrats to cross over to vote for Mr. Giuliani, it is considered unlikely that the Mayor would face a large defection. But if the disappointment causes any reduction in black turnout, the Mayor will likely suffer.
 
Enlisting Some Help
 Seeking to prevent that, the Dinkins camp has asked Representative Charles B. Rangel, to join the campaign as an adviser. Also, the Mayor has in recent weeks made black churches a staple of his campaign activity, sometimes visiting several in one Sunday.
In addition, the Mayor's strategists have set up four campaign offices in predominantly black neighborhoods, one each in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. They have also worked with unions, black clergy and political clubs on a drive to get voters to the polls.
The Board of Elections does not compile information on voter turnout by race. But in 14 predominantly black Assembly districts -- including Central Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant -- 65.9 percent of the registered voters came to the polls in 1989, said John H. Mollenkopf, a professor of political science at the City University of New York Graduate Center. That compares with overall voter turnout of 63.6 percent citywide.
Black neighborhood leaders say that an erosion in enthusiasm toward the Mayor is the result of the high expectations that his election produced. Many hoped for a boom in jobs, a refurbishing of the city's tattered infrastructure and the stimulation of economic development in the city's predominantly black neighborhoods.
In interviews with several dozen black Democrats, most said they approved of the Mayor's handling of the city overall, but many had reservations about aspects of his leadership. Some, like Robert Gregg, a manager in a financial services company, say the Mayor has not been attentive enough to black neighborhoods. "He's trying to please one group in the city at the expense of his core constituency: the African-Americans," he said.
Mr. Gregg, who lives in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, said he will vote for the Mayor, "but with declined enthusiasm."
 
Ambivalence About Voting
 But some black New Yorkers seem ambivalent about going to the polls. "I may vote and I may not," said David C. McKay, a dentist in the Bronx. "In my mind, his four years have been unremarkable, and I haven't seen things improve." Mr. McKay, who voted for Mr. Dinkins four years ago, is likely to do so again, "but that's if I vote." Privately, some senior aides suggest that Mr. Dinkins has been hurt by other factors. They say the Mayor has relied too heavily on subordinates who do not share his commitment to meeting the expectations of many black people. Also, they suggest that the Mayor has done a poor job of informing black voters about those initiatives that have benefited them.
And as Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani have battled for what they consider the crucial Hispanic vote, many black Democrats say they have felt ignored.
To be sure, the Mayor won high praise from many of the black Democrats interviewed. They suggested that their support was driven by a number of factors, including a longstanding history of support for Democratic candidates, racial pride and a strong antipathy toward Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Dinkins's aides say that the Mayor must maintain a delicate balance, satisfying his black constituency while not alienating others. And with a brutal recession and a municipal budget that has had to cope with ever-growing social service needs, the Mayor has little flexibility to develop new programs and spend on business development, intensifying the frustration of many black residents, his aides say.
 
Helped by Controversy
 Several black politicians and other leaders say the Mayor's standing among black New Yorkers has been helped somewhat in the last two months by the perception that he has been under siege unduly.
The succession of crises -- from the state's report on the disturbances in Crown Heights to the furor over the Parking Violations Bureau contract -- might cause some black voters to rally to the Mayor, the officials say.
Certainly the racial issue gained visibility last week. President Clinton's suggestion that the Mayor's race might have subjected Mr. Dinkins to undue criticism have heartened some black supporters of the Mayor. And the Rev. William A. Jones's suggestion that "fascist" elements have gravitated toward Mr. Giuliani, while potentially embarrassing to Mr. Dinkins, was perhaps an indicator of a closing of ranks.
"To some extent these things work to the Mayor's advantage because people are beginning to feel he's been dumped on and persecuted by his critics," said Archie Spigner, a Democratic Councilman from Queens. "And they inevitably attribute it to the fact that the Mayor is an African-American. And that will help energize African-American voters."
Nonetheless, many who are active in black neighborhoods question whether that feeling will be sustained through Election Day.
Standing near a baseball diamond in the Crotona section of the Bronx, Austin L. Jacobo, the coach of a neighborhood baseball team, lamented the failure of the Dinkins administration to meet his expectations.
Mr. Jacobo, who is also president of the Crotona Community Coalition, said former Mayor Edward I. Koch had come to the area of neat, two-story homes more than a dozen times. "So whenever we needed something from City Hall, people at least listened to us when Koch was mayor," said the 64-year-old Mr. Jacobo.
"As black people we were glad when Dinkins was elected because we thought he would make more of a difference in our neighborhood," he said. "But that hasn't happened. In fact, he has never visited us."
When asked if he would vote for the Mayor, Mr. Jacobo said: "I don't know. It's something I have to think about."
Karl Stone, a 30-year-old analyst who lives in Flushing, Queens, also is disappointed with the Mayor. "It's become clear that he has not produced dramatic changes and probably won't," he said. "For people I know, there just isn't any sort of feeling like being part of a crusade like the last time. I think a lot of black people feel he has taken his base for granted."
Mr. Stone said he intended to vote for the Mayor but added that "I don't know how many of my friends will be motivated to go out and vote."
Alphonse C. Valbrune, a law student at Columbia University, said he expected to vote for the Mayor "even though my enthusiasm has waned." He also noted that many of his friends in his old Brooklyn neighborhood of East Flatbush will not likely vote. "The presence of a black Mayor hasn't made a difference to them. I don't think they feel motivated," Mr. Valbrune said.
There also is a perception among some black voters that in his effort to be seen as an impartial steward of the city's resources Mr. Dinkins has catered more to white constituents.
James Steele, a political consultant from Brooklyn, said, "When black people see the Mayor traveling to Israel during the Gulf War, but not visiting their community in New York City, it fuels the perception that he cares more about other communities in the city."
Top aides say Mr. Dinkins is virtually consumed by the notion of treating all groups fairly and is especially hurt by perceptions he has done otherwise.
Joyce F. Brown, deputy mayor for public and community affairs, said many of the Mayor's initiatives -- hiring more police and increasing the number of hours libraries are open, for example -- affect all communities. And she said that some programs have been particularly helpful for black and Hispanic citizens, like the city's Communicare centers, which offer preventive health care in neighborhoods where people had typically visited emergency rooms for treatment.
Furthermore, Mr. Dinkins's aides say he has repeatedly visited black neighborhoods -- just as he has a wide array of neighborhoods in the city.
If Mr. Dinkins chose to show favoritism toward black New Yorkers, it would not be unprecedented in city politics. Irish-American mayors, such as William O'Dwyer in the 1940's, were accused of favoring Irish constituents, and Italian-American mayors, such as Fiorello H. LaGuardia, were criticized for favoring New Yorkers of Italian descent.
But black advocates and clergy contend that many black New Yorkers expected Mr. Dinkins to be more successful at curbing joblessness and enhancing services in black areas of the city. In addition, they fault him for not offering what they consider at least more symbolic actions -- visits with local black community groups, for example.
Although Mr. Giuliani has done some campaigning in black churches and among black Republicans, his campaign officials indicate that there are no specific plans to capitalize on any discontent with the Mayor on the part of black voters. "People have the same concerns throughout the city," said Richard Bryers, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani.
Clarence A. Norman Jr., a state Assemblyman from Brooklyn and chairman of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, said disappointment with the Mayor among black voters might well fade once there is greater realization that a mayor cannot change everything.
"There was a sense of rising expectations for many black people because he was the first," Mr. Norman said. "But we have to realize that the Mayor cannot change things overnight. We have to have more realistic expectations."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Destroying Confidence

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last week, as a U.S.-sponsored "donors conference" pledged billions to develop Gaza and the West Bank, Arab states and the P.L.O. rejected the Clinton plea to end the boycott designed to stunt the growth of Israel.
The Arab economic war not only denies Arab markets to Israelis, but -- in its secondary boycott -- has effectively frightened all but a tiny percentage of the world's thousand largest companies from investing or locating in Israel. And not just in oil-dependent Japan: Ask your favorite global bank if it has a branch in Tel Aviv -- you'll be directed to Cairo or Beirut. 
 Two years ago, Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, expressed his confidence, echoed by the Baker State Department, that a cessation of new Israeli settlements would lead to the boycott's end. When Yitzhak Rabin was elected, he stopped the settlements; the boycott goes on.
At the White House ceremony where Rabin shook hands with Yasir Arafat, President Clinton pointedly called for "ending boycotts." Sixteen days later, Warren Christopher met with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, in New York's Waldorf Astoria to say that "now is the time for a concrete response. . . . The President wants demonstrable progress now."
The Saudi protested that "elements of secondary and tertiary aspects have been fixed at your urging" and that before "premature removal . . . more needs to be seen on the ground." When Christopher pressed, the Saudi promised only that the primary boycott would be "on the table for the Arab League."
Next day -- Thursday, Sept. 30 -- the Secretary met in Washington with the Saudi and other Arab foreign ministers to pass the hat for the P.L.O. When Christopher brought up the boycott, the gulf state leaders insisted that "Syria must take the first step," which gave Hafez al-Assad a veto on an Arab response to Israel's concession; his Damascus newspaper last week called for Arabs to "tighten rather than abolish the boycott."
"No, now," Christopher persisted vainly. "Arab states cannot continue to raise the ante." All he got back was that the league would "assess future steps." The P.L.O.'s man here, Yasir Abed Rabbo, promptly told reporters that the boycott should remain until Israel settled claims on Jerusalem.
Why didn't the U.S. link its half-billion dollar pledge to an end to the boycott? One reason is that Shimon Peres did not condition Israel's own $75 million donation on Arab reciprocation during Christopher's card-calling. Our Congress should link U.S. aid to an end to the boycott.
I asked Mr. Peres for his reaction to this thumb-in-the-eye to his strategy of sustained unilateral concession.
"We view peace as a process of give and take," he replied Friday. "Israel has given. It decided to stop settlements. The Arabs said they would put an end to the boycott in return. Israel lived up to its commitment; the Arabs did not.
"The Arabs then argued that -- should Israel recognize the P.L.O. -- they would 'stop turning their backs' on Israel. No such thing has happened."
"Peace is a matter of both mutuality and public conduct," states Peres. "It is impossible for one party to take its positions publicly with the other party applauding it in private. If this continues to be the case, Israel will view the Arab side as responsible for slowing and even endangering the continuation of the peace process."
Tough words. He then went on television to eagerly shake the hand of Jordan's smiling Prince Hassan, who said sternly afterward: "To those who have said the boycott is economic warfare, I would say removing the boycott is economic suicide."
Where are the denunciations of intransigence from doves now? Does anyone see the paradox in Israel and America helping make the P.L.O. financially strong enough to encourage Arab dictators to wage economic war on Israel?
"I am confident that in the course of time," Bill Clinton said after this latest confidence-destroying measure, "we will get the boycott lifted." After the West Bank withdrawal. After the Golan giveback. After the division of Jerusalem. After the dismantling of Israel's nuclear deterrent. And after that? Such is "the course of time."

HEADLINE: ALPINE JOURNAL;
Where House Numbers Are Secret, and at Issue

DATELINE: ALPINE, N.J.

 BODY:
SHHHHHH. There's a secret in Alpine. It's so closely guarded that even residents of this affluent Bergen County borough cannot get access to the information: their real house numbers.
The numbers are written on a tax map, which is rolled up in the desk of the Chief of Police, who is under orders from the Borough Council to keep it under wraps. 
 "We don't need house numbers," said Arthur Lair, a Republican councilman. "We have other ways of identifying our houses. I know of people who have put butterflies on their rocks. I have a brass placard on my driveway gate that says, Twin Oaks."
But some residents, mostly newcomers, disagree and say it is about time this tiny hamlet, a haven for executives and celebrities, steps in line with the rest of suburbia and adopts ordinary addresses.
"It's silly and dangerous not to have house numbers," said Karakian Bedrosian, a Democratic councilman. "It puts the borough in the position of a lawsuit if someone is ill and an ambulance can't find their house. The way it is now, people have to say things like, 'It's the sixth house on the right next to the blue house without the shutters.' If people want a house number, they should have it. I believe people are entitled to this information."
Whether to have house numbers is an issue, like whether to have sidewalks or door-to-door mail delivery (they don't have that either), that bubbles to the surface of the local political caldron here every few years. It has been raised again because the borough, anticipating becoming part of the 911 emergency network, hired an engineer who devised a numbering system to aid rescue vehicles.
Whereas residents of other towns take their house numbers in stride, in Alpine the proposal has been called both a threat to a rural, secluded way of life and the first step down the road to becoming just like hoi polloi in the rest of Bergen County.
"Not having numbers makes a house harder to find, and something less reachable takes on an aura of exclusivity," said Helen Feher, a real-estate broker who has lived in Alpine for seven years.
Instead of official numbers, some Alpine residents select numbers that appeal to them or, in other cases, name their houses and display the names on plaques. Most people simply post their own surnames, carved on wood plaques or painted on ceramic tile.
Mrs. Feher said her clients sometimes ask her for help in naming homes that are being put on the market. "A name gives it a sense of individuality, and some people relate individuality to importance and importance to dollar value," she said.
Some house names have a European ring, like "Mon Reve" ("My Dream" in French) or an Edwardian flavor, like Tatrawood. Then there are those homeowners who prefer landmarks. One resident had an arm with a hatchet carved from a tree stump on his front lawn. Another mounted a miniature gazebo on a post at the driveway. There is a white wood seagull on a brown plaque under a spotlight on Robin Lane, and a rearing white stallion at the corner of Hillside and Church Streets.
"It's a quirky town where people have all these weird little things to mark their houses," said a resident, Kathleen Sharma. "Everyone is very individualistic, and we were all perfectly content with this. We've always depended on there being the same people working in the Police Department, in the post office and on the U.P.S. delivery route, and they know where to find us."
Alpine, which is nine miles from Manhattan, is a borough of 1,716 residents whose median family income in 1989 was $115,426, according to the county Department of Planning and Economic Development. The average home sale in 1990, during the peak of the real-estate slump, was $852,000. Most houses are worth more than $1 million.
The house numbers issue has erupted into a partisan battle pitting the Republicans on the Borough Council, who oppose numbers, against the Democrats, who favor them. Republicans outnumber Democrats 4 to 2 on the Council.
"There's a difference between accessing the numbers and mandating their use," said Paul Tomasko, a Democratic councilman. "We thought the public would have a right to know this information. All we were trying to do is give residents the access to their numbers in the event they wish to use them."
After much debate over the last few months, the Council killed plans to mail residents the house numbers or to make them available at Borough Hall. The Council then voted to put the matter to a referendum in November, but that measure too, died.
"No one got back to me before the Aug. 20 deadline for adding it to the ballot, and it just slipped by," said Mayor Walter Duke, a Democrat, with a shrug. "It's just as well. The whole thing was getting out of hand. We're going to have house numbers one day, and that's that."
Not everyone agrees.
"People are attracted to Alpine because of its uniqueness, and one small part of its uniqueness is it doesn't have house numbers," said Mr. Lair, the councilman. "This comes up every once in a while because we have nothing else to make an issue of. The way it is now, if you want to put a number on your house, you can. You just do it. But to give out numbers, that might open up a Pandora's Box. I say things are nice the way they are."
And out of the box might come door-to-door mail delivery, which Mr. Lair said could result in having service coordinated from the neighboring town of Closter, and that could lead to a Closter mailing address.
Alpine residents must pick up their mail at the small post office in their municipal building.
For now, the numbers will stay in Chief William H. Grayson's desk. The chief, who has been on the Alpine police force for 26 years, said it was one responsibility he would just as soon not have. "I just wish this would be resolved," he said.
