HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN MOSCOW: Washington;
Clinton, Reaffirming Support for Yeltsin, Blames Rutskoi's Faction for the Violence

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton today blamed opponents of Boris N. Yeltsin for the violence in Moscow and vowed that the United States would not waver in its backing for the Russian President as he sought to restore order.
A senior American official described events in Moscow as "a very, very serious crisis." But as the 13-day-old standoff lurched into the streets, Mr. Clinton made clear he had no intention of lessening his support for Mr. Yeltsin. 
 Mr. Clinton said he believed that the Russian President had "bent over backwards" to avoid resorting to force. President Clinton said he remained convinced that the United States "must support" Mr. Yeltsin in his struggle with defiant leaders of Parliament.
"We cannot afford to be in the position of wavering at this moment or backing off or giving any encouragement to people who clearly want to derail the election process and are not committed to reform," he said before leaving for California.
 
Faith In Yeltsin
 With the violent turn today leaving Moscow more dangerous and unpredictable, American backing for Mr. Yeltsin carries some risk. But just as they blessed Mr. Yeltsin's dissolution of the Parliament, Administration officials said, they still regarded the course the Russian President had set as the best guarantee of democracy.
"We want to see this end as quickly and as peacefully as possible, and we want to see Boris Yeltsin prevail," a senior American official said.
The official said the Russian soldiers dispatched tonight had orders from Mr. Yeltsin "not to initiate fire, and only to return fire if fired upon." But he said it was apparent that the troops had been instructed "to do what's necessary" to reclaim strategic sites.
[Early Monday, Mr. Yeltsin ordered Russian troops and armored personnel carriers to move in on the Parliament building.]
 
Yeltsin 'Calling the Shots'
 Strobe Talbott, the State Department's Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet republics, said Mr. Yeltsin was at the center of the "inner circle and still is calling the shots."
On Wednesday, when Mr. Clinton met here with Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, American officials expressed confidence that Mr. Yeltsin had no intention of using the military to resolve the crisis. Today, they said Mr. Yeltsin's hand had been forced by a "cynical provocation."
They identified the instigators as Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, Mr. Yeltsin's rival, who was named acting president by the legislators, and Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the Parliament leader.
 
Embassy as Liaison
 Mr. Talbott attributed "this serious situation today" to supporters of Mr. Rutskoi and Mr. Khasbulatov, saying they had "sent mobs out into the streets to attack people" to thwart efforts to resolve the dispute.
With Mr. Yeltsin and his top advisers huddled in the Kremlin, there was no direct contact today between Washington and Moscow over the crisis. Mr. Clinton said the Russian President "has more important things to do right now than to talk to me."
Instead, the Embassy was serving as the liaison to the Russian Government, with Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering maintaining contact with Mr. Yeltsin's forces and passing on messages to Washington, where officials were in contact with the Russian Embassy.
And despite their avowals of support, American officials remained clearly determined to avoid steps that could be portrayed by Mr. Yeltsin's opponents as a sign that he was in Washington's thrall. The officials said the United States had not been asked to provide intelligence information or other assistance to Mr. Yeltsin and did not expect such a request.
"We're not trying to micromanage their crisis management," a senior American official said this afternoon.
 
Bipartisan Support
 Congressional leaders from both parties expressed support today for the Administration's posture. Representative Richard Gephardt, the House Majority Leader, speaking on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," described the crisis as "probably the moment of great danger" for democratic change in Russia and said the United States had no option but "to stick with the person who up until now has been the reformer."
But while voicing the same sentiment, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, speaking on the CNN program "Late Edition," said the United States might do well to consider whether it was wise to urge countries like Russia to impose economic shock therapies that carry the danger of political backlash.
A senior American official said Americans in Moscow were being advised to remain indoors. [Early Monday, non-essential personnel and families were evacuated from the Embassy compound.]
 
Uncertainty of Violence
 Tonight, Clinton Administration officials said it remained unclear to them how much violence might lie ahead, but they expressed scant doubt that the Russian President would survive the confrontation.
"I wouldn't overreact to this," Mr. Clinton said this afternoon. He said he believed that the Russian people remained "clearly still far more supportive" of Mr. Yeltsin than of his opponents.
"So we'll just have to wait for events to unfold. But I have no reason to believe that he'll be deposed.
"I think the United States should support Yeltsin as long as he is the person who embodies a commitment to democracy and to letting the Russian people chart their own course," Mr. Clinton. "And he does."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
EUROPEANS BACK YELTSIN
 LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- Britain, France and Germany expressed support today for President Yeltsin after thousands of opponents him clashed with police forces in Moscow.
Prime Minister John Major of Britain expressed support and said Mr. Yeltsin "has received a democratic mandate from the Russian people at the ballot box in this year's referendum and last year's presidential election. He deserves the support of all democrats inside and outside Russia."
In Bonn, the German Government declared its support for Mr. Yeltsin and urged the street combatants not to jeopardize democratic reforms.
"Every use of violence must be condemned," Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said, urging both sides to start negotiations.
France said it held anti-Yeltsin forces responsible for the casualties -- more than 20 people have been killed -- and it called for the free parliamentary elections that Mr. Yeltsin has promised. France "deplores the loss of human life for which forces opposed to President Yeltsin hold a heavy responsibility," the Foreign Ministry said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Domestic Cures To Californians

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton took his entire domestic agenda on the road today, using a rally and televised question-and-answer session to peddle his health care plan, urge the passage of gun-control legislation and promote a trade agreement that he promised would create, not cost, jobs.
Along the way, Mr. Clinton also pledged that he would appoint to the Federal bench only judges who would uphold the law allowing abortions, even if they are on record as being personally opposed to it. 
 Stating that his record as a supporter of abortion rights "is clear and unblemished," Mr. Clinton said he was considering at least two judicial nominees who are opposed to abortion.
"Some senators recommended judges to me who have been appointed who have questionable positions on that issue, but they're lower court judges," he said. "They have to uphold the law. If they won't do that, I won't appoint them."
Mr. Clinton's day had the random manner of a campaign whistle-stop tour. As he began the first of three days at work in California, Mr. Clinton found himself fielding questions as diverse as gay rights and job retraining.
At the raucous airport rally that began his visit here today, Mr. Clinton outlined his plan to ease some of the political discontent arising from the region's failing economy.
"We have got to focus on the economy of California, the state which has 12 percent of our nation's people, but 25 percent of our nation's unemployed," he said.
 
Expanding Issues
 The pressure to make a pitch to California, which remains a vital state, also changed the nature of Mr. Clinton's television appearance tonight, which was initially planned as part of the Administration's plan to educate the public about the universal health coverage it has proposed.
Instead, the 90-minute program broadcast from a Sacramento television station, was a grab-bag of issues and concerns, leaving Mr. Clinton little room to lobby for his health care plan.
"We are in a time of great change," Mr. Clinton said at the start of the program. "You know that out here. You've benefited from some of these changes in the last 10 years. Now you've suffered for the last three years from a lot of these economic changes."
Mr. Clinton suggested that one of the answers to the questions posed by this change was expanding security, a theme that he is using to tie the health care changes he proposes to issues like crime control and public education.
On health care, the questions were mostly the ones White House officials expected. Members of the studio audiences asked Mr. Clinton about whether they would be able to choose their doctors, afford experimental treatment and receive treatment from specialists.
 
Support for Brady Bill
 It was on other issues that Mr. Clinton forced to be more specific. He called once again for passage of the Brady Bill, the measure that would impose a five-day waiting period on the purchase of handguns.
"Congress should not drag its feet," Mr. Clinton said. "They have been debating this for two years. It is time to pass a crime bill. It is time to pass the Brady Bill. It is time to ban assault weapons, get them out of the hands of kids so the police can do their jobs and put more police on the street."
The President also offered a strong endorsement for the North American Free Trade Agreement that he supports despite complaints from opponents who have maintained it will drain the United States of critical jobs.
Mr. Clinton said that those who oppose the trade agreement "have some very good arguments, but they're arguing against things that happened for the last 12 years. They're arguing against the insecurity of the times our people have faced and the fact that our Government has not responded to them."
Mr. Clinton also said he supported efforts to stiffen controls on illegal immigration at the Mexican-American border. "If we permit our laws to be regularly violated and flagrantly violated, and impose those costs on a state that has the biggest economic problems, I think we run the risk of undermining support for immigration, which I think is a very important American value," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton speaking last night about his health care proposals at a town meeting in Sacramento, Calif. Photographs taken by a cancer patient to depict health care were projected in the background. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Businessman Details Case Involving Commerce Chief

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Suddenly, Ly Thanh Binh has found an audience.
For seven months, the small-time businessman has been spinning a wild tale of international intrigue, telling reporters and the Federal Bureau of Investigation that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown sought a bribe from the Vietnamese Government in return for his help in lifting the trade embargo against Vietnam. 
 Mr. Brown has dismissed the story as the stuff of pure fantasy, and there is no evidence that he has received any money or done anything wrong. But the emergence of new details last week has helped bolster Mr. Binh's credibility and prompted criminal investigators to treat his story with a new respect, even though his accusations of misconduct remain unproven.
In five hours of interviews over the weekend, Mr. Binh, a 37-year-old American citizen who was born in Vietnam, recounted the unlikely adventure that he says plucked him from a series of unsuccessful business dealings here and landed him in a Hanoi guest house for a meeting with the Vietnamese Prime Minister.
It began, Mr. Binh said, in the summer of 1992, when Nguyen Van Hao, a former Vietnamese official then running a convenience store in Broward County, Fla., recruited him into a sketchy plan to pursue investment opportunities in Vietnam. It ended, he said, last winter, when he learned that Mr. Hao was arranging to bribe Mr. Brown.
Since then, he said, he has been so determined to get out the story that he even pawned a family ring to get gasoline money to drive to Washington to talk to Congressional staff members.
His detractors say he is being manipulated by conservative veterans groups opposed to normalizing relations with Vietnam. Mr. Binh angrily denies it, saying he supports normalization. "My motive purely is that I do not believe in unethical government conduct," he said.
Mr. Binh acknowledges that he has never met Mr. Brown. He said his entire understanding of Mr. Brown's role comes from information relayed to him by Mr. Hao.
His story got a flood of new publicity last week when Mr. Brown seemed to contradict statements put out earlier by his aides. Asked about Mr. Hao, a Commerce Department spokesman had previously said that Mr. Brown "didn't recall meeting with this man."
But speaking through his lawyer, Reid H. Weingarten, Mr. Brown acknowledged last week that he had met three times with Mr. Hao, once before his selection as Commerce Secretary and twice there after.
 
Binh's Story Got Boost
 Mr. Weingarten said Mr. Hao had sought advice on trade issues involving Vietnam. But he said that his client and Mr. Hao had never discussed any payment, and that once Mr. Brown had been nominated to the Cabinet he had told Mr. Hao that he could not help him.
Mr. Binh's story got another modest boost last week when the authorities said they had found evidence that suggested the Vietnamese were preparing to establish a bank account in Singapore. Mr. Binh has said Mr. Hao told him that $700,000 was supposed to be deposited there for Mr. Brown. But it is unclear whether the authorities were drawing any connection between the money and Mr. Brown.
Law-enforcement officials say Mr. Hao has testified before a grand jury in Miami that is investigating the accusations against Mr. Brown. Efforts to reach Mr. Hao have been unsuccessful.
In the interviews this weekend, Mr. Binh said he came to the United States in December 1973 as a 17-year-old high school graduate to pursue his education and was stranded in the United States when the Government of South Vietnam fell two years later.
He moved to New Orleans, he said, enrolled at Tulane University, and graduated in 1978 with an economics degree. Over the next dozen years, he pursued a variety livelihoods, most of which encountered financial difficulties -- working as a financial consultant in Louisiana, a restaurant owner in Mississippi and founder of E.S.P. Inc., a company in Broward County that sold electronic devices to remove barnacles from boats. He had closed that business and was looking for a new niche in 1992, he said, when met Mr. Hao.
At that point, Mr. Hao was running the convenience store. But he later told Mr. Binh something that Federal officials have confirmed: that Mr. Hao was the only top official in South Vietnam allowed to remain in power after the country fell to the Communists.
Government officials have said that Mr. Hao was South Vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Development, but that he held lesser posts under the Communists. Mr. Binh said this weekend that the Communists appreciated Mr. Hao because he had preserved for them some of the country's gold reserves. He said Mr. Hao stayed in Vietnam for about seven years after the Communist victory, then left for Paris, Haiti, and then the United States. He said Mr. Hao is 57 years old and holds a French passport.
 
Asked for Business Help
 He said Mr. Hao had showed him a disorganized set of charts and that he had sought his help in converting them into a business plan. The idea was to help recruit businesses interested in investing in Vietnam in the event the trade embargo against Vietnam was lifted.
Mr. Binh said he threw himself into the enterprise with the understanding that he would be a partner and move back to Vietnam if normalization occurred. But he received no salary, he said, and borrowed money from his sister to support himself and his wife.
Though Mr. Hao rented a mailbox with a Manhattan address, Mr. Binh said, the enterprise was being run out of Mr. Hao's home in Coral Springs, Fla., and consisted mainly of sending their plan to potential investors. They called their endeavor the Vietnam Development Corporation.
But the focus began to change in November, Mr. Binh said, after Mr. Hao told him to send a copy of the plan to Mr. Brown. Mr. Binh said Mr. Hao and Mr. Brown had a mutual friend, a Haitian named Marc Ashton. Shortly thereafter, he said, Mr. Brown flew to South Florida on a private jet, met with Mr. Hao and told him he wanted to be "the exclusive lobbyist" for South Vietnam.
 
Plane Trip to Hanoi
 Mr. Binh was not at the meeting and says his understanding of it comes from Mr. Hao. Mr. Brown has now acknowledged meeting with Mr. Hao at a restaurant in South Florida in November.
Soon after, Mr. Binh said, he and Mr. Hao were on a plane heading for Hanoi, seeking to persuade the Vietnamese Government to give the lobbying contract to Mr. Brown.
Mr. Binh said they were treated as dignitaries in Vietnam, where they met with the Prime Minister, Vo Van Kiet. Mr. Binh said that the meeting concluded with a private discussion between Mr. Kiet and Mr. Hao and that afterward Mr. Hao had said the Prime Minister had agreed to hire Mr. Brown. They returned with a letter from Mr. Kiet to Mr. Brown, urging Mr. Brown to continue discussions with Mr. Hao.
By the time they arrived home in December, Mr. Brown had been nominated to the Cabinet.
Mr. Binh said Mr. Hao had then traveled without him to Washington, to meet with Mr. Brown, and returned saying Mr. Brown wanted $700,000 and other economic concessions. Mr. Binh said the money was to be placed in a Singapore bank account controlled by Mr. Ashton.
Mr. Brown has acknowledged a December meeting with Mr. Hao and Mr. Ashton. But Mr. Brown's lawyer said his client told Mr. Hao at that meeting that he could not help the enterprise since he was going into the Government. Mr. Ashton, who has also testified before the grand jury, has been unavailable for comment.
Upon learning of the plan, Mr. Binh said "my guts turned upside down." He said he told Mr. Hao that he could not support it. He said Mr. Hao tried to persuade him to stay with the group.
He said he last saw Mr. Hao on Feb. 15, when Mr. Hao offered "to pay me money to keep my mouth shut." Instead, Mr. Binh said, he began his campaign to publicize the plan.

HEADLINE: South Raises Stakes in Fight for Jobs

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Last week it was Mercedes-Benz going to Alabama. Last year it was BMW in South Carolina. Before that it was Saturn in Tennessee and Toyota in Kentucky.
Increasingly, in large ways and small, manufacturing in the United States has a Southern accent. 
 How much of that is the result of the region's strengths and how much reflects the fierce competition for jobs that allows companies to demand, and receive, major economic incentives is a question that is increasingly being debated by politicians and development officials.
In long-suffering Alabama, seldom thought of an industrial Mecca, there was widespread exultation over last week's announcement that Mercedes-Benz had chosen the state over 30 others bidding for a $300 million, 1,500-employee plant that will produce the German automaker's new four-wheel-drive sports utility vehicle.
 
Intense Competition
 "This kind of opportunity comes once in a lifetime," said Prof. Mac R. Holmes of Troy State University, who prepared an economic analysis that said the plant and businesses it attracted could lead to 15,000 to 17,000 new jobs over 10 years and additional wages of $5.9 billion over 20 years. "Not only are there the returns in terms of money, but the symbolism may be as important as the direct economic impact."
But outside the state there are widespread questions about an incentive package estimated as high as $300 million put together by a financially strapped Alabama. Some experts say the Mercedes bidding became so extravagant that it raised questions about the value of the prize.
"This is really what I'd call a quantum leap in incentive bidding wars," said Douglas P. Woodward, an economist at the University of South Carolina. "I think it's gotten to the point where you really have to seriously question the cost and benefits of doing this kind of thing."
For the nation, the questions go to what sort of guidelines, if any, should rule the increasingly cutthroat competition for a declining number of manufacturing jobs. For the South, they complicate the costs and benefits of what is largely a positive picture of economic growth.
"I couldn't begin to tell you how many speeches I've read by Southern governors saying: 'We're no longer going to get into that. We only want industry that can pay their way,' " said Prof. James C. Cobb, a University of Tennessee historian and author of "The Selling of the South" (University of Illinois Pressf, 1993), a history of economic development in the South. "It never means anything. And the sad fact is the situation is probably getting worse rather than better."
 
Not a New Trend
 The Mercedes decision comes at a time the Southern economy, particularly in manufacturing, is outperforming the national one. First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C., recently reported that the Northeast and West Coast had lost more than 450,000 manufacturing jobs in the last two years while the Southeast had gained 23,000.
The trend is hardly new. Since the 1930's, the South has used the promise of low costs, non-union labor and economic incentives to lure manufacturing plants. In recent years, the region's newer roads and utilities, its growing network of suppliers and its lower living costs and more relaxed way of life have also been substantial inducements. And the South, particularly the Interstate 85 corridor from the Carolinas to Georgia, was well ahead of the rest of the nation in seeking out foreign manufacturing investment.
Whatever the cause, from 1990 to 1992, 9 of the top 12 states for new manufacturing plants and major expansions were in the South.
What apparently made the difference for Mercedes in Alabama was an extraordinary package of incentives. They include $77.5 million to improve water, sewer, gas and electrical services; $92.2 million to improve and develop the factory site, and $60 million to train Mercedes employees, suppliers and workers in related industries. The plant will be built on 1,000 acres of pine forest east of Tuscaloosa.
Professor Holmes said his economic analysis was conservative and indicated that over 20 years the plant would mean at least $320 million in increased state tax receipts, and $115 million in benefits to local governments.
But the sheer size of the incentive package led to widespread concerns that the bidding had become destructively competitive. Such concerns have been rising in recent years and were debated in August at the National Governors' Association convention. The governors approved a resolution saying competition for jobs "should not be characterized by how much direct assistance a state can provide to individual companies." They urged states to use incentives that could benefit an entire community, like worker training.
"The whole issue of economic development today is in many ways out of control," said David Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. "It's like the customer going into an automotive dealership with a high rebate and once he gets a taste, it becomes the price of entry. They keep going higher and higher and where does it stop?"
Some skeptics say the game is particularly perilous for a state like Alabama, which has crushing needs including an educational system so deficient the state's Supreme Court ruled that it failed to provide student with a minimally adequate education guaranteed by the state Constitution.
But for such states the lure can also be the greatest.
Kentucky raised eyebrows in 1985 when it lured Toyota with what was then a record $147 million incentive package.
But Charles Haywood, director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Kentucky, said it has become clear the money was worth it. He said the plant, which was expected to bring 3,000 jobs, would bring a total of 6,000 by 1995. He said the plant would cost the state $305.2 million by 2005 but will produce $993.4 million in additional state revenues.
"It's been a heck of an investment," he said.
Still, Alabama will be investing twice as much money for only 1,500 direct jobs. Mr. Woodward of South Carolina said that in Europe there were controls on the kind of incentives bidders could offer. It is unlikely such controls can be adopted here, particularly at a time of growing international competition.
 
States Desperate
 No one suggests incentives account for the bulk of the South's economic success. Most relocation or expansion decisions are relatively routine and depend more on specific location, low wages, lack of unions and other considerations.
And even Professor Cobb says it is hard to that say the policy has been wrong headed. All the Southern states have seen significant income increases relative to national figures in recent decades. In 1960, per capita income in North Carolina was 71 percent of the national average, South Carolina was 62 percent and Georgia was 74 percent. In 1992, the figures were 89 percent, 81 percent and 91 percent.
Still, Professor Cobb said, it is a reflection of just how desperate states are for jobs that a practice that was supposed to be transitional has now become an entrenched and increasingly important part of economic development. That is true both for businesses choosing between New York and New Jersey or Alabama and South Carolina.
Few expect it to change.
"People have complained, not only citizens but elected officials, but it's sort of like talking about the weather," said Charlie Gatlin, of the Georgia Department of Industry, Trade and Tourism, one of the unsuccessful Mercedes bidders. "Everybody talks about it, but is anybody really going to do something about it? I don't know. I don't think so."

HEADLINE: With Strike Ended at Post, Job Applications Readied

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
After months of turmoil, The New York Post begins a new lease on life under the stern golden hand of Rupert Murdoch today, starting with the assembling of a new editorial and business staff to replace members of the Newspaper Guild of New York, whose strike fell apart last week.
At the request of the defeated guild's leadership, John Cardinal O'Connor appealed to Mr. Murdoch yesterday to be fair to 287 guild members -- reporters, editors and advertising and circulation staff -- who lost their jobs in the climactic confrontation, and may or may not be rehired. 
 Because he bought only The Post's assets, and not the corporation that owned them, Mr. Murdoch, according to his aides, is under no legal obligation to honor old union contracts or keep workers employed by the previous owner. But he said through a spokesman yesterday that he would let all guild members apply for their old jobs and would treat them as fairly as the needs of the money-losing newspaper allowed.
"Rupert Murdoch has great respect and affection for the Cardinal," Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman, said. "He will treat the workers fairly based on talent, experience and the needs of The New York Post. The process is expected to take weeks, perhaps months. The goals will be to stop its terrible economic hemorrhaging and provide a quality publication for the public."
Mr. Rubenstein said Mr. Murdoch had made no promises about the number of guild workers who would be rehired or the number of new employees or the wages to be offered. He noted only that each person offered a job would be asked to sign an agreement specifying employment terms and conditions. He declined to say what these would be.
Peter Faris, executive vice president of The Post, said in an interview that management was not planning to reduce the size of the newspaper's 700-member staff, would seek "the best and most aggressive" personnel for its news and business departments and would pay "competitive" salaries. The Post's most experienced guild editorial and business employees were paid about $900 a week.
"The entire staff will be approximately the same size, maybe a little less to begin with, but as we grow and become successful it will be back up," Mr. Faris said. While hiring continues, he said, executives and others, including some new workers hired last week, will produce the paper.
 
Other Agreements
 After repeated brushes with bankruptcy and flirtations with would-be owners, The Post has been rescued by Mr. Murdoch, whose global media interests had a profit of $605 million last year. Vowing to cut The Post's $14 million-a-year losses, he signed agreements in recent months with nine craft unions; they took effect when he bought the paper in Federal Bankruptcy Court on Friday. It had been owned by Peter S. Kalikow.
But no agreement was reached with the guild, and after Mr. Murdoch insisted upon a period of freedom to dismiss any worker, regardless of seniority, the guild struck last Monday. When craft unions refused to cross guild picket lines and The Post was unable to publish for three days, Mr. Murdoch threatened to walk away from his deal to buy the paper.
In the face of a threat that might have killed The Post and all its jobs, the craft unions crossed the lines and The Post resumed publication. While the strike technically continued, a guild unit that had represented Post workers for 50 years had been broken, its ties with production unions were cut and its own future was cast into doubt.
Barry F. Lipton, the guild president, said yesterday that the union, under Federal law, would continue to represent Post workers if Mr. Murdoch rehired a majority of the former guild staff; if he hired less than half, the guild would have to organize a new shop, which Mr. Lipton pledged to do if necessary.
Mr. Lipton said that Cardinal O'Connor, after meeting with guild leaders, sent a letter to Mr. Murdoch "basically asking for fairness in the way he treats guild people." That, Mr. Lipton said, meant restoring the jobs of as many as possible and providing severance and other benefits to those not rehired.
While guild members held a candlelight vigil and pickets continued to march outside The Post at 210 South Street last night, the symbolic end of the strike and the beginning of a new era for the paper was set for noon today, when the picket line is to come down and employment applications are to be handed out.
In January, when Mortimer B. Zuckerman bought The Daily News, his managers on the first night handed each guild employee an envelope -- thick ones with job offers, thin ones with dismissal notices. About 170 received thin ones. At The Post, the procedure is to be somewhat different.
When the picket line comes down, Mr. Faris plans to meet Mr. Lipton in the lobby and hand him application forms for all his members, sparing them, but not Mr. Lipton, from the first step in what many saw as a humiliating process of seeking their own jobs. Mr. Lipton said he had not decided whether to go into the lobby for the forms.

HEADLINE: Largest Publicly Held Hospital Chain Is Planned

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Richard L. Scott, a 40-year-old Texas lawyer who started a small Sun Belt hospital group five years ago by buying a pair of down-at-the-heels hospitals in El Paso, emerged yesterday as the head of the world's largest investor-owned hospital group.
Mr. Scott's Columbia Healthcare Corporation and the HCA-Hospital Corporation of America announced on Saturday that they had agreed to merge in a tax-free exchange of shares. It would be the seventh-largest merger in any American industry since 1981. 
 Columbia Healthcare had about 150 million shares outstanding as of Friday. HCA had about 180 million shares, which would be exchanged for about 188 million new Columbia shares. The two companies said the 338 million shares would be valued at $10.22 billion, based on Friday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange of $30.25 a share for Columbia's stock. HCA shares closed Friday at $22.75 on the Big Board.
 
Would Create 190-Hospital Chain
 If the merger is approved by shareholders of both companies and Federal antitrust regulators, the new chain would have 190 hospitals with 42,000 beds. The new company would have hospitals in 26 states, concentrated mostly in the South.
Analysts said they were surprised by the speed with which the companies acted, although consolidation of hospitals seemed inevitable. "We did not expect it to be this big and this fast," said John F. Hindelong at Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette Securities.
Columbia's chairman, Rick Scott, celebrated last night at a restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan with Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr., chairman of HCA, and Richard E. Rainwater, the financier from Fort Worth, who is a shareholder in both companies, and their wives.
Dr. Frist, whose father founded HCA, would be chairman of the new company, to be called Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, and Mr. Scott would be president and chief executive. The new board would include Columbia's 11 current directors and 4 HCA directors.
The executives said that by merging they would get a jump on changes that have been gathering momentum in the health care system. They said the new company would dominate local markets in Miami, Houston and El Paso, and would squeeze costs to be low bidders in a string of Southern cities, including Louisville, Ky., and Nashville, where it will have executive offices.
"This will make us the low-cost provider of health care in the markets wherever we are," Mr. Frist said.
Mr. Scott said that although there were no plans to close any of the existing hospitals, the group would probably buy "10 or 20 hospitals in the next two to five years, which we would shut down."
Health economists say that hundreds of hospitals will close across the country as Government and private payers increasingly give their business to low bidders. Mr. Scott said health maintenance organizations in Miami were already reducing payments to hospitals by 10 percent compared with a year ago.
Some hospital experts were skeptical. "The for-profit hospitals are having a great deal of financial difficulty, primarily because of low rates of bed occupancy," said Gerard F. Anderson, director of the Center for Hospital Finance and Management at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Indeed, both Columbia and HCA have bed occupancy rates of less than 50 percent.
The companies said they expected to save $130 million a year by combining marketing, data processing and purchasing; trimming overhead, and borrowing working capital at lower rates. Columbia has a higher credit rating than HCA, which is still reducing debt it assumed in a 1988 leveraged buyout.
 
High Personal Stakes
 The principals in the merger have large personal stakes in the deal. The 18 million shares owned by the Frist family would be worth $545 million at Columbia's Friday price.
Mr. Scott and Mr. Rainwater, who each put up $125,000 in working capital in 1988 and borrowed to buy the El Paso hospitals, will also do well. Mr. Scott's six million shares were worth $181.5 million. Mr. Rainwater's stake would be $272 million; he has 5.3 million HCA shares and more than 3 million Columbia shares.
Columbia operates 94 general and specialty hospitals and HCA operates 96 general and specialty hospitals, including 20 psychiatric hospitals. Both companies also operate diagnostic, outpatient and other treatment centers.
Merrill Lynch & Company is advising Columbia and Goldman, Sachs & Company is advising HCA on the merger project.

HEADLINE: A Season When Quick Trips Aren't;
Autumn in New York: Trying to Get There With No Detour

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
When horn-honking, engine-revving, cut-'em-off-at-every-opportunity New York drivers look back on September 1993, what comes to mind almost sounds like a tin-eared rewrite of a song from the musical "The Fantasticks": Try to remember the kind of September when traffic flowed smoothly and roads were not under construction.
Mark Kulewicz tried to remember that far back, but could not. 
 "This September was worse than last September, which was worse than the September before, notwithstanding the recession, which has reduced traffic volume," said Mr. Kulewicz, the chief engineer for the Automobile Club of New York.
 
Some Sort of Detour
 As someone who makes his living studying traffic-artery-clogging phenomena like middle-of-the-day expressway bottlenecks and middle-of-the-road rubberneckers, Mr. Kulewicz has a lot he can study. To many motorists, the blocked-off lanes and under-construction streets have become a symbol of how the city doesn't work because getting there from here inevitably seems to involve some sort of detour.
A quick trip from the Upper East Side to the Upper West Side? The 79th Street transverse through Central Park has been closed for more than a year. A midday cab ride from the Upper West Side to Grand Central Terminal? The fastest way may be through -- yes -- the garment district, because two lanes of the Avenue of the Americas are torn up, creating long backups on eastbound side streets.
The conventional wisdom used to be that the three weeks at the end of the year, when holiday crowds jammed New York to see the tree in Rockefeller Center and maybe "The Nutcracker" at Lincoln Center, brought the worst traffic of the year.
Now, after a week with a Presidential visit that led to a huge traffic jam in Queens -- on a Sunday, no less -- as well as the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, which froze traffic on much of Manhattan's East Side, many motorists insist that autumn is worse. And on weekends it's street fair time.
"There's no second-guessing New York City traffic," said Barry A. P. Paduani, who was a taxi driver in the 1980's and now pilots an 18-wheel behemoth of a cement mixer. "It makes a fool out of you. In a cab, a passenger gets in and says, 'Take me the fastest way.' I don't know the fastest way. Every time you think you know a fast way, it's fouled up. I got to where I'd put it on the passenger and say, 'You tell me.' And usually, their way is about as good as anything."
Carrying cement instead of people has not moved Mr. Paduani into the fast lane. "Twice last week the inbound lanes on the Manhattan Bridge were closed," he said, "and you can't take a truck on the Williamsburg Bridge and it costs $26 to go on the Verrazano. The only free choice is the Manhattan Bridge, but last week it was just horrendous. It took two hours to get from College Point to Jersey City, just because they closed one lane."
Regular drivers like Mr. Paduani can recite a litany of lane and road closings. Last year, Mr. Kulewicz said, the Queens-Midtown Tunnel viaduct and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway were under construction. Now the Long Island Expressway, and some lanes have been closed on the East River bridges.
"The light at the end of the tunnel, so to speak, is hard to see because it seems like as soon as one project ends, two more start," Mr. Kulewicz said. "Next September we will be talking about the Gowanus Expressway, and that one threatens to last 12 years."
 
Other Street Closings
 Work on the Cross Bronx Expressway was completed in the last year, he said, but that kind of welcome news is lost in other street closings.
In addition to the Avenue of the Americas project, Columbus Circle has been constricted for the last several weeks while work crews dig and repave. On weekends, traffic was funneled through the buses-only circle in front of the New York Coliseum. On Saturday, the part of the circle leading to Central Park South was blocked off.
A couple of weeks ago, when traffic was allowed onto on Central Park South, the block between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue was particularly slow because of lanes that had been closed for construction work.
 
A Two-Year Project
 Farther uptown, Columbus Avenue is scheduled for a two-year, $62 million water, sewer and utility project from 59th to 110th Streets. In a recent newsletter to constituents in that area, City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge claimed credit for getting Con Edison to limit its preliminary work to below 62d Street and above 88th Street.
Compounding all that is the fact that it is once again autumn. "In August, traffic's way down," said Lisa Daglian, a spokeswoman for the city's Transportation Department. "In September, it's back to normal. The comparison makes it seem worse. At Christmas, it's not concentrated in one area, except maybe Rockefeller Center. The General Assembly doesn't come close to bringing the same number of people over such a broad area."
She said that before the General Assembly session began last week, her agency considered declaring "delegate-lock" or "U.N.-lock," but officials feared that the first term was erroneous -- the delegates are generally not the ones stuck in traffic -- and the second would be pronounced "unlock." Also, the Transportation Department is trying to go easy on warnings. It stopped issuing gridlock alerts for the holiday season, she said, "because nobody was paying attention."
"People just say, 'Yeah, yeah, another gridlock day,' " Ms. Daglian said. "That's why we didn't issue one for last weekend, although in retrospect maybe we could have."
But it might not have mattered. "New York is accustomed to slow intracity traffic," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center. Drivers know, he said, the fastest way from Brooklyn Heights to the Upper East Side is often the West Side Highway.
Last week, as the General Assembly gathered, diplomats' security personnel pleaded with ordinary motorists who stumbled across limousine-length parking spaces, and small motorcades tore through town, oblivious to red lights.
Dave Saunders, who works in a Mail Boxes Etc. store at 847A Second Avenue, near East 45th Street, said he was almost hit by a truck that was swerving out of the way of what appeared to be a diplomatic caravan.
"There were all these police" on the sidewalk, he said, "but it wasn't like anybody was doing anything to help pedestrians."
But Mr. Kulewicz of the Automobile Club said things could have been worse. Fortunately for drivers, he said, neither the Yankees nor the Mets made it to the playoffs this year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traffic frozen last Monday along Third Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets because of a visit from President Clinton. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Trying to Guess Economy's Pace

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The wide range of estimates for how much nonfarm payroll jobs increased last month signal that the bond market could be surprised by the report due on Friday from the Labor Department.
But even the high-side estimates of 200,000 new jobs do not represent a significant jump in the pace of economic growth. And the low-end estimates of about 75,000 would seem to assure that growth is still sluggish. 
 If 200,000 jobs were created last month, the average monthly increase for the third quarter would still be just 124,000, below the average of 179,000 for the second quarter, and the average of 162,000 for the first three months of 1993.
So the question going into Friday's report is unlikely to be: Is the rally that has pushed long-term yields down to 25-year lows over? The more likely question is this: Is the economy still growing slowly enough to open the way for a new drop in interest rates that would bring the yield on the 30-year bond to 5.75 percent, just below the 25-year low of 5.86 percent reached on Sept. 8?
 
Gauging Market Response
 It may still be difficult to gauge how the market will respond. One reason is that traders and investors will be waiting for the two important inflation reports -- the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index -- to be released the following week. The consensus on the C.P.I. is that it will show an increase of about a tenth of a percent, which should be reassuring for the market after a disturbing rise of three-tenths of a percent in August.
But what still makes the guessing tough is figuring out how much growth -- even if it is still moderate -- it will take to worry the bond market. Given the near standstill pace of 1.3 percent for the first half of the year that has helped fuel the 1993 rally, it may take only a little pickup in growth to get traders and investors to sell.
"The market is going to be feeling skittish," said William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. The data will show that the economy is stronger than in the first half of the year, but it will be ambiguous about how much stronger, he said.
 
A Bet on Lower Rates
 Will it be stronger at a 2.5 percent growth rate, or stronger at a 3 percent growth rate? The answer, he said, would be unclear for a while. Goldman, Sachs is forecasting stronger, at 2.5 percent, with estimates of growth in the current quarter at 2.1 percent, and 2.7 percent in the last three months of the year. On this outlook, the firm is still betting that long-term interest rates will fall to new lows.
The Goldman, Sachs nonfarm payroll projection shows an increase of 100,000, Mr. Dudley said, a pace that should "reassure the bond market that while the economy is doing a little better, growth is not picking up to the point where they have to worry about the Fed" and inflation.
But he said growth over 3 percent would worry the market, because at that point there was a chance the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates because the central bank would begin to worry that inflationary pressures were building.
Susan M. Phillips, a governor of the Federal Reserve, did not directly address this interpretive problem in a speech in New York City last week. But she seemed to indicate that growth would continue to be contained -- that is, continue at a pace that should not worry the bond market. And she expressed confidence about inflation, even admonishing the traders and analysts at the dinner to look beyond the C.P.I. to see the restraint on prices in the economy.
In a speech to the Money Marketeers of New York University, Ms. Phillips said, "This is indeed a slow recovery." In running through a description of the sectors of the economy, she noted that "spending is likely to remain fairly moderate" and housing is "surprisingly weak." She also said the Clinton plan to reduce the Federal budget deficit would not be the only drag on the economy. Tax increases and spending cuts at the state level will also slow growth.
 
'Look Beyond the C.P.I.'
 She was more upbeat on inflation. She said producer prices were "showing a disinflationary trend," industrial material prices "have been soft," and corn, soybean and precious metal prices had moved down again. "In trying to assess inflation, it is wise to look beyond the C.P.I.," she said.
The report on Friday that the price index of the National Association of Purchasing Managers plunged to 46.8 in September, from 54.6 in August, added to the data that indicate that the coming inflation reports should show minimal increases for September.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, who is predicting a 200,000 increase in nonfarm jobs for September, said that if the C.P.I. for September increased only one-tenth of a percent, the yield on the 30-year bond, which closed on Friday at 5.99 percent, should stay near the bottom of its present trading range, which has taken the yield as low as 5.94 percent.
If the nonfarm employment number is lower -- in the 75,000 range -- and the C.P.I. is still up only one-tenth of a percent, "the rally would continue," he said. "You would be on the way to 5.75 percent."
 
An Impact of Tax Increases
 Mr. Fine argued, however, that even if the yield on the 30-year bond rose in the near term because the economic data were a little stronger than the market could take, interest rates would still remain low or even fall as the economy moved into next year.
He said he believed, as do other economists, that even if the growth rate of the economy jumped to 3.5 or 4 percent in the fourth quarter, the pace of growth would slow to the 2 percent level in the beginning of 1994. Why? Among the reasons, he said, are the impact of the tax increases to reduce the Federal budget deficit; the uncertainty surrounding the fate of the Clinton Administration's health care plan; continued cutbacks in military contracting and the recessions in Europe and Japan that are curtailing purchases of American exports.
"In light of that, it is hard to argue why interest rates should rise any time soon," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Focus on Home, Hearth and Profit

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
As the magazine industry grimly continues to struggle through a recession that refuses to recede, Jack D. Rehm, the chairman, president and chief executive of the Meredith Corporation, is thinking positively.
His demeanor is in keeping with the typically cheerful spirit of the Des Moines-based company, best known for publishing two magazine industry giants: Better Homes and Gardens, with a circulation of 7.6 million, and The Ladies' Home Journal, with 5.1 million. In addition, Meredith publishes more than a dozen home-and-hearth magazines like Country Home, Country America, Midwest Living, Traditional Home and American Patchwork and Quilting. 
 The company also has a book publishing division and owns seven television stations. It is also involved in cable television systems and residential real estate.
About five years ago, in a prescient move, Meredith decided to refocus its magazine operations. It sold its printing operation and made plans to cut jobs, invest in new technology, build a data base of subscribers and start spinning off new magazines from existing publications.
 
Emphasis on Circulation
 Then, when advertising proved a fickle friend in hard times, the company turned circulation into its chief source of revenue.
"The reason we have succeeded with so many magazine titles in the last several years is that we are able to get readers to really pay for the magazines," Mr. Rehm said. "We must count much more on the reader to generate the revenue stream than the advertiser. Historically, that has not been true, and magazines who were overly dependent on advertising were the ones who really suffered."
"We will charge readers a lot of money on the theory that if they really like the magazine they will pay for it," he said.
They might also pay for new magazines on the same subject, Meredith has found. For instance, the company started Wood magazine in 1984 for people whose hobby is woodworking. Its circulation, initially 150,000, is now 650,000. Within the last few years, Wood has spawned a magazine called Weekend Woodworking Projects, then another called Decorative Wood Crafts, which is aimed at forlorn-feeling spouses of the mostly male readers of Wood. This was followed by Super Scrollsaw Patterns, for those woodworkers who like to use a scroll saw.
 
Profit for the Year
 Meredith's moves are paying off, Mr. Rehm said. Net earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30 were $18.6 million, in contrast to a net loss of $6.3 million the previous year. Magazine advertising revenues were $234.4 million, compared with $227.5 the previous year, according to the company.
Circulation is also up for most of the Meredith magazines tracked by the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The exceptions are Country Home and Better Homes and Gardens, which intentionally cut back its circulation last year to make the magazine more efficient.
New titles in 1993 have included American Patchwork and Quilting, with a circulation of 200,000; Craft and Wear, with 200,000, and a group of occasional publications called the Ladies' Home Journal Celebrity Spinoffs, each with circulation of 400,000. The first of these was devoted to Katharine Hepburn, who was interviewed by Myrna Blyth, editor in chief and publishing director of Ladies' Home Journal.
 
Data on Subscribers
 Another big step has been the investment of several million dollars in a central data base containing the names of 60 million subscribers to the company's books and magazines. Many publishing companies, including Time Inc. and Conde Nast, have been creating data bases with various kinds of information about their readers' interests. The giant is Reader's Digest, which has a worldwide data base of more than 100 million households, slightly more than half of which are in the United States.
"I don't think you can be in our business and not have a data base that is not state of the art," Mr. Rehm said. "It allows editors to know in detail about the people who read their products. If you subscribe to one or more of our magazines, we know that. If you are a member of a book club or have purchased a cookbook, we have it in the data base."
Meredith can use the data base to focus on specific groups of readers, thus reducing its mailing costs.
"We can also use it for advertising," he said. "For instance, if you are a Ford owner, Chevrolet might be interested in you."
Meredith is still testing the potential of its data base. By April, the company hopes it will be useful in a process called selective binding, which allows a magazine to place a special section into some copies. For instance, eight pages about gardening will be included next spring in issues going to readers identified in the data base as gardening enthusiasts.
So far, about 200 employees have left Meredith in connection with its refocusing of operations, including 119 who volunteered for an early retirement program offered last year.
 
Coping With the Flood
 One event that was unplanned, of course, was the flooding that devastated parts of the Midwest last summer. For two weeks, Des Moines was without a water supply, but Mr. Rehm said no deadlines were missed and every magazine went out on schedule.
The flood even brought about some efficiencies. A plan to convert from a mainframe computer system to desktop publishing was pushed forward by about eight months when the mainframe system broke down during the flooding. The company quickly invested $400,000 in new personal computers, rented a large space in a suburban area that had less damage from the flood, and gave about 150 of its editorial employees a crash course on desktop technology.
For the longer term, Meredith's plans include continued development of its newer magazines and maybe some new titles.
"I don't think we'll branch out in new directions," said Mr. Rehm, who will turn 61 this week and faces mandatory retirement at 65. "Our expertise is home and family; that's what we know best. We are going to concentrate on magazine and book products that fall under that umbrella.
"We are going to stick to our knitting," he added with a smile.

(Jeffrey Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Stocks Proved Wise Choice in Quarter

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Foreign stock prices posted impressive gains in the third quarter, aided by falling European interest rates and dynamic growth in a number of the Pacific Rim's smaller economies.
The improvement on foreign equity markets stood in contrast to what took place at home, where market averages, sloshing around at record highs, managed only a marginal increase. 
 Outside the United States, in dollar terms, stock prices rose by nearly 6 percent in the third quarter, according to The Financial Times world index. By comparison, the index showed that prices rose by just under 2 percent in the United States.
 
 
'Great Quarter'
 "It was a great quarter," said Richard R. Foulkes, whose $1.6 billion Vanguard International Growth Fund was up more than 11 percent for the quarter.
It also furthered a trend that has been in place since the start of the year, one in which Americans who have invested in international mutual funds have done much better than those who have invested their money at home.
"Historically, people invest outside their home market when the home market doesn't look all that attractive," A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, said. "And on a year-to-date basis, the 350 world funds we track have outperformed the more than 1,200 general equity domestic funds we follow by roughly three times."
Despite that stellar performance, most managers of international portfolios have failed to outpace global market indexes.
Through the first nine months, The Financial Times' global stock index that excludes the United States was up by just under 30 percent in dollar terms. During the same period, prices in the United States rose by just under 6 percent.
 In the third quarter, Malaysia was the world's best-performing market, as stocks rose by 28 percent. That showing lifted it past Japan, the six-month leader, as the best performer for the first nine months. So far this year, Malaysian equity prices are up more than 60 percent.
"Malaysia was a classic situation," said Marcus Grubb, an international equity strategist at Salomon Brothers in London. "The economy was strong, interest rates were low and falling, and price-earnings ratios on Malaysian stocks were low."
After the third-quarter surge, Malaysian shares "are no longer cheap," Mr. Grubb added, "but people think it has a long way to go."
For much of the year, money has been flowing into European stock markets on the expectation that dismal economic conditions in a number of countries would force central bankers to ease interest rates.
Some countries did cut rates, but it took a major crisis in Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism to do it.
Rates were not lowered much in Germany, but unexpectedly good economic news made Frankfurt the Continent's most successful exchange in the third quarter, with German stock prices rising 16.8 percent in dollar terms.
"In the third quarter we basically got paid for our view that interest rates in Europe were going to come down, and when they did that would be very supportive of stock and bond markets," said John R. Hickling, who manages more than $2 billion in international mutual fund money for Fidelity Investments. So far this year, the two funds Mr. Hickling manages are both up around 30 percent.
Portfolio managers said Britain, Japan and Hong Kong were the most disappointing markets in the third quarter.
Share prices in Britain were up just over 5 percent in the quarter, despite falling interest rates. Equities in Japan, the world's best-performing market for the first half of the year, advanced just under 4 percent. And Hong Kong stocks rose 6.24 percent.
 
 
'Better Value'
 Despite big price moves so far this year, the analysts said they expected share prices in Asia and in selected European countries to advance further.
"Right now Asian markets afford better value than in Europe or North America," Mr. Grubb from Salomon Brothers said. "We like Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. And European markets outside the E.R.M. look cheap, like Britain and Switzerland."
Mr. Hickling said stocks in Europe that were sensitive to interest rates should continue to do well.

HEADLINE: Unions Gird for War Over Trade Pact

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Leaders of American labor unions, who are here to set goals for the next two years, say that nothing -- not health care, not the long erosion of blue-collar wages, not even the Reagan and Bush Presidencies -- has stirred worker passions as has the proposed North American Free Trade Agreement.
The prospect of deregulated trade with Mexico so angers some unions that they are vowing to take the unusual step of making the vote of a member of Congress on the agreement a single-issue test of loyalty to labor. The unions say they will use their money and skills to drive from office those who support the agreement. 
 "We see this as a life-and-death issue," said Jay Mazur, president of the ladies garment workers' union. "We won't support people who vote for Nafta."
William H. Bywater, president of the electrical workers and organized labor's most outspoken foe of the agreement, said, "We're going to go out and defeat every congressman who votes for Nafta."
In strong union states like California, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio and Pennsylvania, such threats carry real weight.
 
'They're Steamed Up'
 Leaders of the big teamsters and machinists unions are saying much the same. George J. Kourpias, president of the machinists union, said he had not yet issued ultimatums against lawmakers who vote for Nafta. "But," he added, "I can tell you, we will get no requests from our members back home to support them. They're steamed up about this." George Poulin, a machinists vice president for the Northeast who is also here, said: "Knock them off. That's our position."
Posturing over something that the Government or business is doing is routine among unions. It helps build cohesion among their diverse members whose numbers are sinking. But there is more to labor's opposition to the trade agreement. It presents the liveliest red-meat issue unions have faced in years. The jobs at greatest risk are in factories, where unions are strongest and where more lost jobs spells further erosion of labor's political influence. Today, less than 12 percent of the workers in private industry are unionized.
The trade issue is different, too, because for the first time in decades unions stand a chance of reversing a trend in international economic policy that they blame for many lost jobs. Most trade agreements are reached through negotiations with foreign governments. But because Congress must approve the agreement with Mexico, and Canada as well, labor has a chance to influence the vote.
Partly in response to labor's lobbying, several leading Democrats in Congress have broken with President Clinton to join labor in opposing the agreement, most recently Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader.
"No doubt about it," said Robert N. McGlotten, chief lobbyist for the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, "it's a lightning rod."
 
Little Dissent, No Change
 The union officials are in San Francisco preparing 200 policy resolutions that will be presented at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s weeklong biannual convention here, beginning Monday.
Among other things, the resolutions will salute Mr. Clinton's universal health care proposal, a union goal for decades, condemn sexual harassment at work, call for overhauls of the labor laws and health and safety regulations in the workplace and urge legislation to prohibit employers from dismissing workers who strike. The delegates, some of whom are elected by the rank and file while others are selected by the union leaders, will vote on the resolutions with little dissent expected.
They will also elect their leaders, the 32 men and three women who make up the federation's policy-making executive council. It includes the federation's president, Lane Kirkland, 71, the secretary-treasurer, Thomas Donahue, 66, both first elected 14 years ago, and the leaders of 33 unions.
Whatever their respect for democratic traditions and the processes they would use to banish members of Congress, the delegates always elect and re-elect the council members by acclamation, without ballots or opposition.
Dissent, instead, is aimed at Washington and a President who, with the exception of his stance on the trade agreement, they tend to like.
 
Weighing Trade and Jobs
 Since his election, Mr. Clinton has answered one union prayer after another. He signed the Family and Medical Leave Act, lifted the hiring ban on the air traffic controllers dismissed by President Ronald Reagan, proposed an overhaul of the health care system that is close to what many unions wanted and has loaded his Administration with former union officers. Mr. Clinton will speak here on Monday.
But unions do not buy his endorsement of a trade agreement that the Bush Administration negotiated, fearing it will lead to lost jobs.
Many unions are also alarmed because for the first time ever, they have witnessed an economy climbing out of a recession for more than two years without restoring jobs lost in the recession or creating well-paid new jobs. Laid-off workers have enrolled in an immense variety of Government-sponsored courses and programs to learn new skills, only to find insecure jobs that pay half as much as the old jobs.
Union officials have begun to mock Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich's assurances that better training and education will lead to better jobs. A guest economist here, Thea Lee of the union-funded Economic Policy Institute in Washington, calls this the "field-of-dreams" theory of job creation.
"Raise people's skills, and new industries to hire people will come along," Ms. Lee said, citing the views of Mr. Reich, who will address the convention on Tuesday. "Then when corporations go shopping for workers, they will come to the United States." That's unlikely, she said. "Those workers will be cheaper somewhere else."
Not a single union here backs the trade agreement, but some unions, like the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees and the American Federation of Teachers, are less alarmed than others.
Two officials of the teachers union said that they thought that the potential threat to American jobs had been overstated and that American industries would keep moving to Mexico even if the agreement is not approved.
Some other officials said they feared that vituperative opposition to the agreement would provoke an anti-union backlash in the Administration or among legislators who support labor on many other issues. John N. Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, said he would not ask his members to banish members of Congress who support Nafta. "I'm not going to touch that one with a 10-foot pole," he said. "We might end up driving them against us."
Still, even among unions whose members face little direct threat from jobs moving to Mexico, there is fear of chain-reaction effects on their members' jobs.
Richard L. Trumka, president of the mine workers union, said that when factories shut down they stop using the fuel that runs many of them -- the coal his 75,000 members mine. "There will have to be extremely, extremely, extremely special circumstances," he said, "for us to support any congressman who votes for Nafta."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
JACKSON LEADS RALLY IN CANADA
 NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Jesse Jackson came to Canada this weekend to join Canadian protesters in condemning the trade agreement.
Mr. Jackson led about 150 protesters across the international border on Saturday and was met by about 500 Canadians, including labor leaders. He had told an audience in Sudbury, Ontario, on Friday that corporations had pushed for the pact as a way of getting cheap labor.
But Mr. Jackson said Saturday that he did not blame Mexican laborers for problems the deal could pose for American and Canadian workers. "Our mission is to raise Mexican standards, not lower our own," he told the crowd.

HEADLINE: Salinas Offers Plan to Aid Mexican Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today announced a complex plan to raise Mexican wages and bolster the nation's economy. His proposals address United States concerns about American jobs displaced by cheap Mexican labor and lay the groundwork for the 1994 presidential election campaign.
At a ceremony in Los Pinos, the Mexican White House, Mr. Salinas said the complex package of economic measures would allow Mexico to "harvest and use the advantages" it earned in five years of fiscal discipline. In that time, inflation has been trimmed to a single-digit annual pace and Mexico's foreign debt has been substantially reduced. 
 The stimulus package includes individual and corporate tax cuts, lower prices for industrial electricity and diesel fuel, lower cargo rates at airports and on railroads, and accelerated corporate depreciation for investments like environmental controls and motor vehicles.
 
Productivity a Factor
 Those measures are being taken in addition to wage increases, which for the first time will take into account Mexican workers' increasing productivity. The higher wages were a promise Mr. Salinas made to President Clinton as side agreements on the North American Free Trade Agreement were being negotiated.
But today Mr. Salinas made a point of saying his actions were directed at the internal market "independently of external business circumstances or accords."
The package's cost is thought to be roughly $6 billion, an amount equal to the federal budget surplus, which Mr. Salinas has said he plans to use.
He has been criticized for waiting until now, just before the start of the election campaign, to start spending the money. Although he is prohibited from running for re-election, his party, which has governed Mexico for more than 60 years, has a lot at stake.
"It's an attempt at a fiscal act with obvious political overtones," said Jorge G. Castaneda, a professor at the Autonomous University of Mexico and a critic of the Salinas Government.
Government officials said they thought the package would bolster Mexico's economy enough to make up for the lower tax rates without creating a budget deficit.
Minimum wages are set each year by a national commission. For the coming year, minimum wages will be increased by the anticipated 1994 rate of inflation in Mexico -- 5 percent -- and the rate of increase in productivity for manual labor as a whole throughout the country. The formula for determining productivity has not been set, officials said, but will conform with international standards.
The Mexican Government has been taken to task for leaving vague its promise to link wages to productivity. Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, was among those who criticized the pledge because only 16 percent of workers in Mexico earn the minimum wage.
 
Negotiating for Bonuses
 Mexico's Secretary of Labor, Arsenio Farell Cubillas, said today that the raise next year would be no less than 7 percent but no more than 10.8 percent. Mr. Farell also said that workers who earn more than the minimum wage would be able to negotiate for productivity bonuses with their employers.
Besides the wage increase, Mexican workers, especially those with the lowest incomes, would benefit from proposed adjustments to Mexico's income tax code. One big change would create what in effect would be a negative income tax. Workers at the lowest levels could use legal deductions resulting in their receiving an extra payment from the Government.
Tax rates for those earning up to four times the minimum wage would also be reduced so that 2.6 million workers, twice as many as before, would pay no taxes.
The income provisions are part of the Government's yearly program of wage and price controls, called El Pacto, which was renewed today for the eighth time. At the signing in Los Pinos, Mexico's labor unions, farm workers and business executives strongly supported the renewed agreement, saying it would usher in "a new culture of competitiveness and productivity."
The plan has something for everyone, though there are concerns that by spreading it so widely, the impact has been diluted. For farmers, Mr. Salinas pledged a new program of direct assistance. For businesses, corporate tax rates would drop to 34 percent from 35, depreciation would accelerate for environmental investments and motor vehicles, and prices on a range of government products and services would be lowered.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Oct. 4 about Mexico's plans to raise minimum wages misstated the range of the increases planned for next year. The minimum wage should rise at least 5 percent, not 7 percent, to match the expected rate of inflation in 1994. There is no Government-imposed ceiling on increases in the minimum wage; they are not limited to 10.8 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Sharp Increase In Drug-Caused Emergencies

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Federal health officials in Washington yesterday reported sharp increases in the number of medical emergencies resulting from drug use. They said the numbers underscored the need for more rehabilitation programs and more effective prevention efforts.
While casual drug use has continued to decline, heavy users of cocaine, heroin and marijuana have been streaming into hospital emergency rooms in unprecedented numbers, the officials said. 
 The number of those seeking help for adverse reactions to cocaine in 1992 increased 18 percent over the previous year, to 119,800. At the same time, heroin overdoses and other reactions to the drug rose 34 percent, to 48,000, and adverse reactions to marijuana, like respiratory problems and paranoia, jumped 48 percent, to 24,000.
"These are the highest levels ever," said Daniel Melnick, a senior official in the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which released the data yesterday.
Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, the president of Phoenix House, the largest residential treatment organization in the country, said: "These kinds of big rises suggest a desperation of use and a kind of hopelessness among users. They think they are trapped and can see no alternative but to keep using."
The emergency-room cases resulting from heroin and marijuana use included people of all ages, from adolescence up. But cases among cocaine users 12 to 17 years old declined, the data showed.
The unrelenting rise in drug cases in hospital emergency rooms from the mid-1980's, most of which reflects chronic, as opposed to casual, use, goes to the heart of the national health crisis, many drug experts said.
Emergency-room treatment is among the most expensive kind of care, the experts pointed out, and it has little affect in reversing chronic drug use.
 
Cry for More Treatment
 Both Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the parent organization of the substance abuse agency, and Lee P. Brown, President Clinton's chief anti-drug aide, said the soaring drug casualties cried out for more spending on treatment and anti-drug education.
But President Clinton's proposed $13 billion anti-drug budget for the coming year sticks with the pattern established by Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, in which the biggest share of the money goes to trying to stop the flow of drugs rather than to programs aimed at rehabilitation and discouraging drug use. With the President's consent, Congress trimmed from his proposal $100 million that had been earmarked for treatment and $143 million designated for anti-drug education.
White House officials had promised that the Administration's overhaul of the national health system would include substantial increases in money for drug treatment. But the proposals include no provisions for the kind of long-term residential treatment that most experts say is needed to deal with the kind of chronic drug users now flooding emergency rooms.
Instead, Mr. Clinton's health insurance proposal would cover two periods of 30 days of hospital or clinic treatment in any year, along with 30 days of outpatient care.
"We're not talking about people who can use 30 days of inpatient treatment," Dr. Rosenthal said. "We're talking about people here who, if they are not in the emergency room, they are likely to be getting into all kinds of anti-social behavior that can lead to prisons, courts and everything else."
Many experts say that curtailing heavy drug use would sharply cut national health costs. The Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, for example, recently found that 20 percent of all Medicaid costs were related to drug abuse. Medicaid is the Federal-state program for the poor.
"Trying to cut health care costs without solving the drug crisis is like trying to sail a sinking ship without fixing the hole on the bottom," said Paul Samuels, the president of the Legal Action Center, a national drug policy organization based in New York.
Many experts said Mr. Clinton appeared to be avoiding the drug issue. He has seldom addressed the issue in public and has not presented a comprehensive national strategy.
 
'Feeling of Being Left Out'
 Herbert D. Kleber, the executive vice president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, said, "the President is so concerned about health care reform that he is not paying enough attention to drug abuse."
Dr. Kleber added: "And it is going to be hard to reform health care in a cost-effective way if he doesn't pay adequate attention to this group of heavy users that we're hearing about today. It's also going to be hard to stop violence."
A number of studies have shown that heavy drug users consume most of the illegal drugs sold in this country, and that they are often involved in property crimes and violence.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat who heads the House Caucus on Narcotics Abuse, said there was clearly a relationship between the steep increases in emergency-room cases due to drugs and "the feeling of being left out economically."
"If you plot the hospitals where the highest amounts of casualties are coming from," Mr. Rangel said, "you will also find the highest concentrations of AIDS, of unemployment, of people going off to jail, of teen-age pregnancies and of violent crime."

Graph also tracks number of all emergency room patients, patients admitted for cocaine, and patients admitted for heroin from 1978 through 1992. (Source: Drug Abuse Warning Network)
