HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
In Finagling on Trade Pact, Legislators' Barter Is Votes

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
It's a ritual as old as Congress itself.
The Louisiana delegation wants to change a provision in the North American Free Trade Agreement that could put local sugar farmers out of business. Florida lawmakers want safeguards to protect orange growers who fear a surge of Mexican citrus. And Iowa and Ohio legislators are urging a slower phase-out of tariffs on stoves and refrigerators to protect local producers. 
 The wheeling and dealing over Nafta is just beginning, and with the trade agreement expected to be approved or rejected by a handful of votes, President Clinton would be wise to watch his wallet. The trick for the Administration is to do a favor here and make a concession there without opening a floodgate of requests that would force it to go back to Mexico for last-minute rewrites of the Nafta text. And by satisfying one group of lawmakers, the Administration risks upsetting another.
"We've got teams of shoppers prowling the halls of Congress," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat who is an ardent foe of the pact. "They're saying, 'What can we leverage?' or 'What can we do for you?' "
The deals lawmakers are seeking fit into two general categories: garden-variety personal favors and more specialized requests that deal with a particular tariff or environmental concern. In the first category, Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, has warned that he may not be able to vote for the agreement if the Administration cannot persuade Mexico to extradite a Mexican accused of kidnapping and raping the 4-year-old niece of the Congressman's secretary.
In the second category is Representative Esteban E. Torres, a California Democrat who has urged the Administration to help organize a North American Development Bank to finance roads, bridges and environmental cleanups along the border.
While many lawmakers are looking for nothing more than an invitation to dine at the White House before they promise to vote for the accord, negotiations have revolved mostly around sugar and wheat.
Mexico produces a lot of sugar, but because so many Mexicans have a sweet tooth, the country is a net importer, to the delight of American producers. But those producers are afraid the trade pact will foster a torrent of sugar imports from Mexico. They argue that when American corn flows south of the border, the Mexicans will replace the sugar in their sodas with corn syrup, freeing the cane for export.
Such fears have made a big impression on lawmakers from Louisiana, Texas, Florida and Hawaii. Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who helped engineer a compromise energy tax in order to pass Mr. Clinton's budget, has again taken center stage by urging the Administration and Mexico to negotiate a letter of understanding to limit a possible sudden surge of sugar imports.
Many Midwestern lawmakers have voiced concerns that the pact will permit Canada to subsidize wheat shipped south, a situation that they say is already occurring despite a separate trade agreement that was supposed to prohibit such practices. The lawmakers argue that Canadians are dumping subsidized wheat and barley onto the American and Mexican markets and that the Administration must take action.
At a meeting with lawmakers last Tuesday, Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, and other senior officials promised that the Administration was pressing Canada on the issue. Mr. Dorgan, the Nafta opponent, said he interpreted the pledge as a quid pro quo, and then stormed out of the meeting.
"The message is, 'If we're willing to help you, are you willing to help us?' " the North Dakota Democrat said. "It's not a subtle message." Mr. Kantor said Mr. Dorgan's interpretation was "unfair," and denied that a deal was offered, or even implied.
Some supporters of the agreement, like Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, view the surge in deal-making as a positive sign. Mr. Kolbe said it shows lawmakers are looking for ways to shake their fears that big labor or Ross Perot's legions will punish them at the polls if they vote for the agreement.
But other boosters are losing patience, calling on the President to shake fewer hands and flex more muscle. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said of Mr. Clinton, "He's got to use a little more of the L.B.J. technique."

HEADLINE: Clinton Defends Trade Pact To Skeptical A.F.L.-C.I.O.

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Taking his effort on behalf of a North American Free Trade Agreement to perhaps the unfriendliest audience he could find, President Clinton assured labor leaders today that the pact would not cost American jobs.
Mr. Clinton told 915 delegates at convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations that he was arguing on behalf of the trade agreement, "not so you'll agree with me, but so you will know what I want you to know, which is that I would never knowingly do anything to cost an American a job." 
 Arriving on the opening day of the convention, which the A.F.L.-C.I.O holds every other year, the President made his declaration as part of a speech devoted largely to his Administration's efforts on behalf of working people. It was met with lukewarm applause. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has already declared itself solidly against the plan to eliminate trade barriers among the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Minutes before the President spoke, Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents 13.3 million members of 95 unions, said the federation would not budge in its opposition to the trade agreement. He added that it was a mistake for Mr. Clinton to continue to support it.
 
Pact as a 'Poison Pill'
 "By and large, his agenda is our agenda," Mr. Kirkland said of Mr. Clinton in a speech just before the President spoke. "But we do have one major difference of opinion. Among the poison pills left behind by George Bush is a lethal one called Nafta."
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton insisted that the trade agreement would make the economy stronger. He contended that trade deficits with Asian nations posed a greater threat to American jobs than the prospect of lowering trade barriers with Mexico, a nation with which the United States enjoys a trade surplus.
"Is it a perfect agreement?" Mr. Clinton asked the mostly silent unionists. "No. But I don't want to make the perfect the enemy of the better."
Opposition to Nafta, as the trade agreement is known, has been led by labor unions and heavily promoted by Ross Perot, the former Presidential candidate.
This opposition, Mr. Clinton told the labor leaders, "has become the symbol of the legitimate grievances of the American working people about the way they've been worked over the last 12 years."
"I have got to lay a foundation of personal security for the working people of this country and their families in order to succeed as your President, and you have to help me do it," the President continued.
Later, speaking to a group of California business leaders and politicians, Mr. Clinton described the reception he received from the labor convention as "an interesting encounter" and launched into another defense of the plan.
He received a considerably warmer reception from the delegates when he turned to other items on his domestic agenda, including his opposition to a proposition on the California ballot that would allow the state to finance private school tuition.
Mr. Clinton said he objected to the proposal, Proposition 174, because he said it would divert government funds to parents of private school students who already had the money to pay for their children's education. Proponents have argued that the measure would improve public schools by enhancing private competition and making the education system more flexible.
"I can tell you this is not the way to get it done, and the people will regret this if we pass it," he said.
And the President tried to mend political fences in California by offering up a package of new economic incentives that would free Federal money to repair interstate highways damaged in the 1989 earthquake in the San Francisco area. The plan would send $36 million to Stanford University for the development of a high-energy physics center and provide $109 million in housing grants for the state.
 
Opposition in California
 These announcements were intended, in part, to slow the growing opposition to the trade agreement in California. The accord is widely perceived by politicians here as a job loser for the nation's most populous state.
But Mr. Clinton presented his support for the accord as a necessary ingredient in a formula to resolve entrenched national problems.
"We have to struggle to redefine a new balance between security and change in this country, because if we're not secure we won't change," he said. "And if we don't change, we'll get more insecure, because the circumstances of the world will continue to grind us down."
"And that's what makes this such a difficult time," he added, "because we have to rethink so many things at once."

HEADLINE: Poverty in U.S. Grew Faster Than Population Last Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Despite the end of the recession, the number of poor people in the United States increased last year by 1.2 million, to 36.9 million, increasing three times as fast as the overall population, the Census Bureau reported today.
The number of poor people was higher than in any year since 1962, when John F. Kennedy was President. In that year, of course, the nation's population was much smaller, and the poor accounted for a larger proportion of the total population: 21 percent in 1962, as against 14.5 percent last year. 
 Census Bureau officials and economists said the rise in poverty last year reflected lingering unemployment and a slow recovery from the last recession, which ran from July 1990 to March 1991.
The poverty rate last year was three-tenths of a percentage point higher than in 1991, and it was the highest since the 15.2 percent level recorded in 1983.
 
Many Parallel Data
 At the same time, the Census Bureau reported that the number of Americans without health insurance rose 2 million last year, to 37.4 million. President Clinton has repeatedly cited such statistics in asserting that the Federal Government should guarantee health insurance coverage for all Americans.
The new poverty data reflect trends already evident in other statistics. Unemployment last year averaged 7.4 percent, up from 6.7 percent in 1991, the year the recession ended. The number of people receiving food stamps climbed steadily, to 26.6 million in December 1992, from 24.9 million in December 1991. And the number of people on welfare, in the program known as Aid to Families with Dependent Children, rose to 14 million in December 1992, from 13.4 million in December 1991.
Daniel H. Weinberg, chief of income and poverty statistics at the Census Bureau, said many analysts had predicted a drop in poverty last year after the recession ended.
Household income, after adjusting for inflation, declined last year in the Northeast, but was virtually unchanged in other regions and in the nation as a whole. But nationwide, a series of small declines from 1989 to 1992, cut the real purchasing power of the typical household's income by $2,000, to $30,786 in 1992.
 
Black Couples Not Immune
 Overall, the number of poor Americans rose 3.3 percent last year, while the total population rose just 1.1 percent.
For years, the Census Bureau has been saying that the high poverty rates for blacks resulted, in part, from the breakup of many black families. But last year the bureau also found a significant increase in the poverty rate for black married couples, to 13 percent from 11 percent.
A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income less than $14,335 last year. A family of three was poor if its income was less than $11,186. The official poverty levels are updated each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. Though living costs vary widely across the country, the poverty level is the same nationwide.
As defined by the Government, income includes wages and salaries, Social Security and welfare payments, but does not include the value of food stamps, Medicare, Medicaid or health insurance provided by employers. Counting these noncash benefits would make the poverty rate seem lower but would not change the trends in poverty observed in recent years, Census Bureau officials said.
Household income declined last year in 14 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The poverty rate rose in 33 states, including Connecticut and New Jersey; in New York it was unchanged at 15.3 percent.
 
More Poor Children
 Mississippi, Louisiana, West Virginia and New Mexico had the highest poverty rates. Delaware, New Hampshire, Utah, Connecticut and Virginia had the lowest.
The Census Bureau found a slight increase in poverty among young children. Twenty-five percent of those under 6, and 21.9 percent of those under 18, were poor last year. Nearly half of black children under 18 were poor.
Clifford M. Johnson, policy director at the Children's Defense Fund, said the new data showed that "poor children are more likely to suffer extreme poverty than ever before."
Last year, 47 percent of all poor children -- 6.8 million of the 14.6 million poor people under 18 -- lived in households where incomes were less than half of the official poverty level.
"The rich clearly did get richer" from 1967 to 1992, Mr. Weinberg said. But he found some preliminary evidence to suggest that the trend toward greater inequality in the distribution of income, after accelerating in the early 1980's, had begun to slow.
Offering historical perspective, the Census Bureau said that the poverty rate fluctuated between 11.1 percent and 14.2 percent from 1967 to 1981. It peaked at 15.2 percent in 1983 -- the highest since the 17.3 percent recorded in 1965 -- and then declined to 12.8 percent in 1989. It has risen each year since then, to 13.5 percent in 1990, 14.2 percent in 1991 and 14.5 percent in 1992.
 
'Safety Net' Is Credited
 Wendell E. Primus, a deputy assistant secretary of health and human services, said the new data "show that Government programs are helping reduce poverty."
Poverty rates, excluding the value of Government assistance, increased significantly from 1991 to 1992, Mr. Primus said. "But after taking into account Government programs like Social Security and Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the poverty rate was not significantly higher in 1992 than 1991," he said.
"The rate did not go up nearly as much in the latest recession as in the 1980-82 recession, partly because safety-net programs were better used, and we didn't cut benefits as much under President Bush as under President Reagan," Mr. Primus said.
The data in the report are drawn from interviews with 60,000 households chosen to be representative of the entire population.
In its report, the Census Bureau also made these points:
*The poverty rate for children under 18, listed at 21.9 percent last year, was the highest since 1983 and was nearly as high as in 1964, when it stood at 23 percent. It was in 1964 that President Lyndon B. Johnson declared his War on Poverty.
*In 1992, only 47.2 percent of poor people were covered by Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people. In many states, the income limit for those seeking Medicaid is substantially below the official poverty level. In some states, it is difficult for poor people to get Medicaid if they have no children.
*Among poor people 16 years old and over, 40 percent worked in 1992, and 9.2 percent had full-time jobs throughout the year.
 
And the Rich Got Richer
 Using a new measure of economic well-being, the Census Bureau reported that the condition of the most affluent families improved substantially in the last 25 years, while the condition of the least affluent families appeared to stagnate.
The most affluent one-fifth of all families had incomes averaging 8.4 times the poverty level in 1992, as against six times the poverty level in 1967. By contrast, the least affluent one-fifth of all families had incomes averaging 91 percent of the poverty level in 1992, down from 97 percent in 1967.
The 33.3 percent poverty rate for blacks last year was nearly three times the 11.6 percent rate for whites, the Census Bureau said. The rate for Hispanic people, who may be of any race, was 29.3 percent last year. For Asian Americans, it was 12.5 percent.
Whites account for two-thirds of the poor, even though their poverty rate was lower than the rates for Hispanic people and blacks.
The South, which has for years had a higher poverty rate than other parts of the nation, was the only region in which the rate increased significantly last year. The poverty rate was 16.9 percent in the South, 14.4 percent in the West, 13.1 percent in the Middle West and 12.3 percent in the Northeast. Forty percent of all poor people live in the South.

HEADLINE: Dinkins or Giuliani? Voters Equally Unimpressed

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Four weeks before Election Day, the race between Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani remains a tossup. Fewer than half of voters trust either candidate to deal with New York City's problems and nearly half are concerned that each might make serious mistakes, according to the latest New York Times / WCBS-TV News poll.
In a bitter rematch between two well-known contenders, the electorate is strikingly unenthusiastic about both. Just 38 percent of voters expressed a favorable opinion of the Democratic Mayor, while a scant 31 percent had a favorable view of his Republican-Liberal challenger. About as many voters viewed each candidate unfavorably as viewed him favorably. 
 Mr. Dinkins held a slight edge, drawing the support of 44 percent of voters polled to 41 percent for Mr. Giuliani, and 2 percent for George J. Marlin, the Conservative and Right-to-Life Party candidate. But the Mayor's lead is within the poll's margin of error and thus statistically insignificant. Moreover, a national study of the vagaries of polling in racially mixed contests has shown that when black candidates led white ones by fewer than 8 percentage points in pre-election polls, chances are they had no lead at all.
At the same time, there were new danger signs for the Mayor: his support among Jewish voters has slipped to 23 percent, from one-third in May, and to 21 percent among white voters overall, down from 27 percent. Many such voters have apparently shifted to the undecided column, which now stands at 12 percent, compared with 7 percent last spring.
Mr. Dinkins won the last election by 2 percentage points with 35 percent of the Jewish vote and 27 percent of the overall white vote, and his aides have long held that he needs at least one-quarter of the white vote to win. No previous Times poll has found his support among Jewish voters so close to his support among whites as a whole. Coming at the end of three weeks of largely favorable publicity for Mr. Dinkins, beginning with his victory in the Democratic primary and including a visit from President Clinton, that is not encouraging.
"In the end, what's amazing about this race is it was close, it is close and it's going to be close," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. "The number Dinkins now has for whites is below a winning number for him. But it's a plague on both their houses. It's clear people do not find as many reasons to vote for the candidate of their choice as to vote against the other guy."
Despite the voters' entrenched views, the race remains volatile. One-third of Giuliani voters said they might change their minds, compared with just one-quarter of Dinkins supporters, and only 38 percent of Mr. Giuliani's voters strongly favor him, compared with 55 percent of Mr. Dinkins's backers.
The findings suggest risks and opportunities for each candidate, and make voter turnout, field organization, debates or last-minute events more important than ever in determining the outcome.
The telephone poll was conducted Sept. 29 to Oct. 3 -- the same period in which the Mayor began broadcasting his first television commercials attacking Mr. Giuliani's record. The poll included 1,223 adult city residents, of whom 804 said they were registered to vote. The margin of sampling error for voters was plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Hevesi and Green Ahead
 In the other citywide contests, Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens led former Representative Herman Badillo, 48 percent to 31 percent, for city comptroller, while Mark Green led Councilwoman Susan D. Alter, 58 percent to 19 percent, for public advocate.
The poll contained some glimmers of good news for Mr. Dinkins. It suggested that his support among Hispanic voters has crept back up a bit, with 48 percent now backing him compared with 36 percent for Mr. Giuliani, although the margin of sampling error for this subgroup is plus or minus 9 percentage points, which means they could be roughly tied, as some other polls have suggested. In 1989, Mr. Dinkins won two-thirds of the Hispanic vote, compared with one-third for Mr. Giuliani.
The Mayor also appeared to have reopened the gap between male and female voters, and now has the support of 46 percent of women, compared with 36 percent for Mr. Giuliani, who held a slight edge among women last spring. And the Mayor's overall job rating has crept up slightly in the last six months, with 46 percent of registered voters approving of his performance in office and 44 percent disapproving, compared with 40 percent approval and 47 percent disapproval in May. That suggests the Mayor's advertising and campaign speeches around town stressing his record may have had some effect.
"To me, what this shows is that this thing is going to go down to the wire," said the Mayor's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, who said he was still optimistic that the Mayor could regain some of the white voters who have drifted away. "Turnout is obviously going to be key, and we've got to have a big vote-pulling operation out there. What we need to do for the next month is just keep working hard to get our message out there of the Mayor's accomplishments the last four years and of his vision for the future, versus Mr. Giuliani's non-record."
 
An Improvement for Giuliani
 Four years ago at this point in the race, most polls showed Mr. Giuliani trailing by double-digit margins. His chief strategist, David Garth, said: "My feeling is, considering the boom the Mayor's had the last couple of weeks, I think it puts us in a very good position, frankly. When you're within the margin of error, it's a very strong spot."
Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani had a clear edge among the voters on only one issue each. Three-fourths said Mr. Dinkins cared about the needs and problems of average New Yorkers, compared with 58 percent for Mr. Giuliani; while 68 percent said Mr. Giuliani was tough enough to deal with crime, compared with just 40 percent for the Mayor -- who has presided over the largest police hiring program in the city's history.
On almost every other personal attribute or issue facing the city, the poll found the electorate more evenly divided or with each candidate holding just the barest edge. Nearly half said each had strong qualities of leadership. Nearly 7 in 10 voters rated the local economy as bad, and one-quarter of voters polled said that if Mr. Dinkins was re-elected it would get worse, compared with 14 percent for Mr. Giuliani. But 21 percent said the economy would improve if Mr. Dinkins won, compared with 28 percent for Mr. Giuliani, and more than 4 in 10 said it would stay the same no matter who won.
Asked whether they were concerned that Mr. Dinkins, if re-elected, might make serious mistakes in office, 46 percent said yes. The figure was the same for Mr. Giuliani.
Sixty percent of voters said past Republican administrations were most to blame for lost jobs in the city, compared with just 16 percent who blamed Mr. Dinkins -- an argument the Mayor makes often. But 61 percent also said it makes no difference whether the President and the Mayor are of the same party -- negating an argument that Mr. Dinkins has tried to make into a cornerstone of his campaign.
Just over 20 percent said race relations would get better if Mr. Dinkins was re-elected, while just under 20 percent said they would get better if Mr. Giuliani won. One-quarter said race relations would get worse under Mr. Giuliani, while 18 percent said they would get worse under Mr. Dinkins. Most voters -- 55 percent for Mr. Dinkins and 44 percent for Mr. Giuliani -- said relations would stay the same whoever won.
Yet the poll showed that questions of race permeate the contest, and views of the candidates remain starkly polarized along racial lines. Mr. Dinkins had the support of 91 percent of black voters, compared with 2 percent for Mr. Giuliani, while Mr. Giuliani had the support of 61 percent of whites, to 21 percent for the Mayor.
Mr. Dinkins's favorable rating among whites is now just 16 percent, half what it was in June 1989, when he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination, while 54 percent of whites now view him unfavorably, three times the number of four years ago.
Voters were evenly divided -- and strictly along party lines -- over President Clinton's assertion that people are "still too unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are." Fifty-three percent of Dinkins backers said that was accurate, while 54 percent of Giuliani supporters said it was not.
 
Impact of Crown Heights
 The official state report issued in late July on Mr. Dinkins's handling of the black-Jewish violence in Crown Heights in 1991 appeared to have taken its toll. In May, when voters were asked to name the worst thing Mr. Dinkins had done in office, no answer stood out. In the current poll, 20 percent cited Crown Heights. Yet two-thirds of voters, the same as in May, continue to say that in conflicts between blacks and Jews, Mr. Dinkins had treated both sides fairly.
Crime remains the problem New Yorkers most want the next mayor to focus on, though nearly twice as many voters -- 46 percent -- cited this as a major problem as did so four years ago. None of the next most-cited issues -- not education, homelessness, unemployment, the economy or drugs -- was mentioned by even 10 percent of voters. Sixty-one percent of voters said the city was less safe than it was four years ago, yet 44 percent said they see more police in their own neighborhoods and 13 percent cited hiring more police officers as the best thing the Mayor had done.
Polls are merely a snapshot, and none can predict turnout or last-minute shifts in voter sentiment.
One obvious question is how Mr. Dinkins can have lost substantial support among every major voting group except blacks between now and the last election and still remain roughly within his previous margin of victory. The answer is that in the latest Times poll, some voter groups on balance favorable to the Mayor -- like Hispanic voters and women -- were represented in the electorate in slightly greater proportion than they were four years ago, while others -- like Jews -- were slightly less represented.
That may or may not accurately reflect the current electorate. The Times's sample was chosen randomly, weighted to reflect current census data, and respondents were then asked if they were registered voters, but there is no way to say with certainty who will vote on Nov. 2.
Allocating undecided voters further underscored the closeness of the mayoral contest. When those who initially expressed no preference in the trial heat were asked if they leaned toward either candidate, and were then added to the supporters of the candidate they mentioned, the trial heat became 47 percent for Mr. Dinkins and 44 percent for Mr. Giuliani.
When, following recommendations by analysts at the Gallup Organization, the remaining undecided voters were allocated to the candidate of their same racial group, the trial heat then tightened into an exact tie -- 48 percent for Mr. Dinkins and 48 percent for Mr. Giuliani.
One of the biggest uncertainties for Mr. Dinkins is whether white voters are unwilling to state their true preferences in a contest in which a black candidate is running, or whether pollsters are somehow otherwise unable to obtain an adequately representative sample because of some voters' refusal to answer questions.
In recent years, polls have frequently overstated black candidates' standing, compared with the actual results, and in 1989, Mr. Dinkins was leading substantially in late polls, only to win by just two points.
 
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-Tv News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 29 to Oct. 3 in all parts of New York City with 1,223 adults, 804 of whome said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in English or Spanish.
 The telephone exchanges called were selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each area in the city was represented inproportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus including both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated at random to respond to the survey.
 The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age and education.
 In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on suchsamples would differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from a poll of al adult New Yorkers.
 For smaller subroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is 4 percentagepoints for all registered voters, 5 for white registered voters, 7 for black registered voters, and 9 for Hispanic registerd voters.
 Besides sampling error, the practical difficulties of ocnducting any opinion survey may introduce other errors. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can cause results to vary somewhat.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS: BASEBALL;
In WPIX vs. MSG, Benches Have Cleared

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Once upon a time, the MSG Network and WPIX-TV/Channel 11 got along quite nicely. Their executives claimed to be friends. They even had a three-year deal that made non-cable homes happy: MSG, which controls the rights to all 150 locally televised Yankees games, bought the time to put 50 of them on WPIX.
But that amity expired on Sept. 24. Now, as hopes flicker that MSG and WPIX will make a new deal to keep Yankees games on free TV, war has broken out.
"They're making it impossible to make a deal," said Michael Eigner, general manager of WPIX. Yesterday, he released a 31-page analysis of MSG's deal with the Yankees that WPIX says is irrefutable evidence of MSG's reluctance to make a deal with the station. MSG called it all nonsense. 
 "We're disturbed that WPIX, in the midst of negotiations, would distribute erroneous and misleading information about the MSG Network's financial picture," said Bob Gutkowski, president of Madison Square Garden, parent of the network. "It is unreasonable that WPIX would attempt to do a profit-and-loss statement on the MSG Network with no accurate knowledge of our numbers."
The WPIX treatise says that when MSG claims to have lost oodles on this deal, the network is not telling the full truth. Eigner did not offer to release the profits of WPIX, which is owned by Tribune Broadcasting. He said WPIX is making money.
Said Gutkowski: "MSG would be willing to submit to an independent audit of our profits if WPIX would submit to the same audit to show its profits."
Negotiations ended in late August, yielding little except mutual rejection of each side's suggestions, including one that WPIX buy 50 games a year from $15.3 million in 1994 to $18 million in 2000. MSG says those charges are not a penny more or a penny less than what they pay the Yankees in their nearly $500 million deal with the team through 2000.
WPIX says that's not fair, and hence their unseemly battling.
MSG does not want to repeat its misbegotten WPIX deal, which it wanted in 1991 but now regrets. The network says it has lost $22 million on the deal, including $7.5 million in 1993. By paying WPIX an average $93,000 a game to put 50 games annually on WPIX, MSG retained control over game advertising on its own network and on WPIX, a situation it found preferable to selling games to WPIX and letting the station compete for Yankees ad time.
WPIX claims to have lost on the deal, too, because it sold its time to MSG for one-third it would get for selling advertising on movies. "If you came off the street, those three hours would cost you $300,000," Eigner said.
In the WPIX world, MSG really made money but omitted from their calculation one large source of revenues: subscriber fees. MSG leveraged Yankees baseball to doubling its subscribers to 5 million since 1989, and for increasing the fees cable subscribers pay to get the service. WPIX calculates that 5 million subscribers pay $1 a month for six months of Yankees baseball, or $30 million.
The Yankees' acquisition has been so potent, WPIX's Eigner said, that by increasing subscriber rolls and fees, MSG's total subscriber revenues have increased by $46 million a year since 1988.
Because one-third of the 150-game package appears on free, over-the-air WPIX -- a channel that is a staple of local cable systems, which brings substantial and valuable exposure to the less available MSG -- Eigner reckons that one-third of the fees, $10 million, would offset the $7.5 million loss and produce a $2.5 million profit.
But MSG's Gutkowski said: "If we don't have games on the MSG Network, we don't charge subscribers fees for it. It's like saying, 'WPIX, you lose a little on the Yankees, but what do you make on those other shows?' "
WPIX's tortuous calculations also conclude that MSG made $8 million on its 150-game package this year.
MSG isn't hiding the fact that it wants to recoup from WPIX some of the money it paid to Boss George. By unsuccessfully demanding of WPIX a six-year rights fee that escalates to $18 million in 2000, it is seeking an (over)payment at precisely the per-game rate MSG now (over)pays Steinbrenner.
An offer by Douglas Moss, the president of the MSG Network, cited per-game fees that rise from $305,640 in 1994 to $368,300 in 2000. Those figures are within a few dollars of what WPIX alleges are the per-game charges MSG pays to Steinbrenner.
"They know we won't pay that," said Eigner. He said the fallacy with MSG's arithmetic is that games airing on MSG generate twice the revenue (because of the subscriber money) than those on WPIX, and should be valued at a lower rate than games on MSG in any offer to WPIX.
In 1989 and 1990, when WPIX paid the Yankees between $10 million and $11 million for rights to 75 games a season, its per-game fee was more like $133,000 than $300,000. "That was economically feasible," he said.
Eigner took his case yesterday to a city official, Bill Squadron, commissioner of the Department of Telecommunications and Energy.
And Gutkowski is saying: Let's go to the independent audit.
Can't anybody here make a deal?

HEADLINE: Too Rich a Soil: Scientists Find the Flaw That Undid the Biosphere

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
THE major flaw in the $150 million Biosphere 2 project has been discovered by a leading geochemist and his student, raising questions of whether the venture in the Arizona desert will be corrected in the interest of serious science or will be doomed to repeated cycles of failure in the years ahead. In theory, the experiment is to last 100 years.
A mysterious decline in oxygen during the two-year trial run of the project endangered the lives of crew members and forced its leaders to inject huge amounts of oxygen, spoiling the idea of a self-contained ecosystem that was supposedly a way to learn about living in space. 
 The cause of the life-threatening deficit, scientists now say, was a glut of organic material like peat and compost in the structure's soils. The organic matter set off an explosive growth of oxygen-eating bacteria, which in turn produced a rush of carbon dioxide in the course of bacterial respiration.
The main mystery was where this carbon dioxide was going, since so little of its calculated mass was found in the dome air.
The scientists who solved the riddle were Dr. Wallace S. Broecker, a geochemist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University in Palisades, N.Y., and one of his graduate students, Jeff Severing haus. Late this summer the two found that the missing carbon dioxide had been absorbed by the concrete that forms and lines the structure's interior. The 110,000 square feet of exposed concrete has a surface area greater than two football fields.
"The oxygen is disappearing because they were arrogant and put five to 10 times more organic matter in the soil than you'd get outside," Dr. Broecker said in an interview. "They made a fundamental day one mistake.
"Our assessment is that this decline will continue for decades," he said, unless major steps are taken to correct the mistake, like replacing all or most of the soils in the domes. All told, the soil weighs 30,000 tons.
Dr. Broecker advises the Arizona group but gets no fee, he said, in order to avoid the perception that his opinion is shaded in any way.
 
Search for Solutions
 Dr. John Corliss, the recently appointed scientific director of Biosphere 2, which is outside Tucson, said in an interview that the group was still considering options for dealing with the soil trouble, ranging from replacing the overly rich loam to doing nothing but continuing to pump tons of oxygen into the domes. Most of the possible actions would involve minor changes, he said, at least for the immediate future.
"My assumption is that we'll go ahead with the second mission the way it is," he said. "We're searching for ideas that might be alternatives to taking the soil out."
The next experiment in human habitation is scheduled to begin Feb. 26 and to last one year. The shorter period of occupation -- one year versus two -- in itself will lessen the severity of the problem since the decline in oxygen becomes more severe and dangerous over time. The crew of men and women for the new mission has yet to be selected, although a group of candidates is now training at the Arizona site.
During the two-year trial run, which ended Sept. 26 amid celebratory fanfare, four men and four women gasped increasingly thin air inside the 3.15 acres of glass domes. Beginning in January, then again in August and September, project officials injected 23 tons of pure oxygen into the sprawling glass bubble to avoid a medical emergency, raising levels from a low of 14 percent oxygen to the normal 21 percent.
Work on Biosphere 2 (project officials refer to Earth as Biosphere 1) began in earnest around 1984, financed by Edward P. Bass, the Texas billionaire and oil heir. The plan was that human inhabitants would thrive in a miniature world whose environmental cycles were powered by an ocean, rain forest, marshland, desert and farm. Everything would be recycled. Most importantly, the project sought to show that humans could for the first time create a life-support system that was totally self-sufficient and esthetically pleasing -- sort of a new Eden.
Despite its New Age overtones, the project was promoted as highly scientific. Its officials were quick to note the prestigious talent hired to get things under way, including the Smithsonian Institution's Marine Systems Laboratory, the New York Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany and the University of Arizona's Environmental Research Laboratory.
 
Delicate Atmospheric Balance
 The university laboratory used powerful computers to predict how various combinations of plants, animals and soils would affect the structure's atmosphere. Dr. Robert J. Frye, a senior researcher there, said in an interview that all his mathematical models assumed that the agricultural soils would contain 4 or 5 percent organic matter -- what he called "representative figures" for standard enrichment.
Dr. Frye said that some project officials "wanted to use much higher amounts" and that an important issue in discussions was whether bacterial respiration would upset the atmospheric balance. Those questions, he said, "came up frequently in meetings." Limited to giving advice, the university laboratory apparently had little idea that the enrichment of some soils would turn out to be quite high.
As Dr. Frye remarked: "I don't think anybody here ever said, 'This is going to explode on you,' in a formal way, simply because our involvement was very small."
But other experts say the red flags were plentiful. "A lot of people warned them," said Dr. Mary W. Olsen, a plant pathologist at the laboratory who advised the project.
John Allen, the leader of the ecology project, has previously noted the importance of rich compost and soil microbes to decomposition. In a 1991 book, "Biosphere 2: The Human Experiment," published by Penguin, he wrote: "Bacteria help recycle nutrients. Without them, dead animals and plants would simply pile up until Biosphere 2 became a large heap."
 
High Level of Organic Matter
 The actual soil of the newly built structure, Mr. Allen wrote, was "rich in microbes." The all-important agricultural soil, he noted, was 70 percent dirt, 15 percent peat and 15 percent compost -- that is, about 30 percent organic matter, far higher than the university laboratory assumed in its calculations.
The first crew was sealed inside the structure in September 1991, along with 3,800 species of plants and animals. Things went downhill fast. Most distressing was the declining oxygen, which, after the repair of a faulty sensor, was measured as steadily going down throughout 1992.
Abigail Alling and Mark Nelson, two crew members, wrote in "Life Under Glass: The Inside Story of Biosphere 2," published last month by the Biosphere Press: "This drop in oxygen was particularly startling because during all the Test Module experiments we had never experienced a fall in oxygen levels. Nor had it been reported by other life-support facilities, so it had not been an area anyone in the field considered critical."
The outside experts were put on the problem in May 1992. The rich soils were immediately suspect. Dr. Broecker of Lamont-Doherty gave the riddle to his graduate student, Mr. Severinghaus, who for months struggled to find the missing oxygen or its metabolic byproduct, carbon dioxide. One suspect was urine. The original dirt, from a nearby pond, contained dung and urine from cattle, and the experts thought that perhaps urea in the urine was somehow responsible for the drop. It was not.
Many other theories were later tested and rejected, including one that the carbon dioxide was reacting directly throughout the soil to form calcium carbonate, the material found in limestone and caves.
Finally, Mr. Severinghaus's father, Dr. John W. Severinghaus, a high-altitude physiologist at the University of California at San Francisco, suggested in a telephone call to his son that the structure's concrete might be soaking up carbon dioxide from bacterial respiration. And so it was.
 
Tests Support Theory
 Careful tests of the hypothesis were done by the son this spring and summer. Concrete samples from inside and outside the structure showed strikingly different levels of calcium carbonate, which was rapidly being formed inside the domes as huge amounts of carbon dioxide reacted with calcium hydroxide in the concrete.
"Their concrete is dripping with it," Mr. Severinghaus said of the calcium carbonate. "It's 10 times more than outside."
Dr. Broecker and Mr. Severinghaus say the reaction increases the concrete's acidity, weakening it and creating a danger that reinforcing bars will eventually start to erode as the carbon dioxide works its way deeper.
The obvious cures, the scientific team says, are to paint the interior concrete with a nonporous coating and replace the offending soils, steps that would bring the project to a halt for months or perhaps years as fauna and flora are removed and then painstakingly reintroduced.
"Biosphere 2 management should take a very deep breath, start over, clean out all the topsoils, replace them with soils that are more representative of natural soils, and make a serious attempt to balance the carbon budget," Mr. Severinghaus wrote the group Sept. 22. "Although starting over seems like a lot of work now," he added, "in the long run, 10 years from now, it will more than pay for itself in a system that truly works instead of a lame one we are dealing with now."
Dr. Corliss, the project's scientific director, who joined the group this year, said many possible solutions were being considered, including painting the concrete and replacing some soils, although perhaps just those in the farming area.
Other possible solutions are to find new plant species that might soak up carbon dioxide faster, or perhaps to add a layer of dense soil that would block the flow of gases in and out of soil. "The question is whether we can slow down the rate," Dr. Corliss said.
The decision of the moment, he added, is simply to keep pumping in more oxygen and to do detailed studies of the concrete to see how fast it is being transformed.
Dr. Broecker said the original error occurred because the group was led by environmental zealots who chose the intuitive wisdom of organic gardening over scientific advice. Even so, he said, he still felt sympathy for the members of the project. He said they had done fairly well, considering the challenging goals they had set.
"It's not easy to think of all the possible things that could go wrong," he said. "Anybody else would have made equally bad blunders, but different ones. Over all, I'd give them an A-minus."

HEADLINE: In Real-Estate Slump, Some Owners Are Donating Buildings

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
It sounds like a bad one-liner: The market for commercial real estate in New York City is so bad, they're giving it away. But in isolated cases, it's true.
The latest example came last week, when a pair of Minnesota investors donated a 15-story office building at 30 West Broadway, in Manhattan's financial district, to the City University of New York. In June, General Electric donated the 50-story Art Deco masterpiece at 570 Lexington Avenue, at 51st Street, to Columbia University. 
 A close look at the situation at 30 Broadway demonstrates that the current market is so anemic that the owners of some buildings, particularly those more than 30 years old, are better off giving away real estate than trying to coax out a profit. "I won't be surprised if more owners decide to do this," said Bruce Surry, managing director of the Edward S. Gordon Company.
Just how many more is uncertain. Like the planets, the factors that make a donation economically sensible align themselves only rarely. The building must be empty or nearly so, and need modernization, and there must be a willing recipient who can use such a gift. It helps if the owner lacks either the resources or the patience to lose money for a while.
 
A Grim Situation
 Facing the departure of their sole tenant, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, a heavy tax burden, the need for millions of dollars in renovations, and stiff competition in a renter's market, the owners of 30 West Broadway faced grim financial prospects. By some estimates, the landlords, Miles and Shirley Fiterman of Minneapolis, could expect to lose $40 million or more over the next year or two if they kept the building, and somewhat less if they tried to sell it.
"The charitable option may just have been the best for them, economically," said Peter R. Hauspurg, president of Eastern Consolidate Properties, a real-estate investment firm.
Experts were quick to add that they did not question the philanthropic instincts of the Fitermans, who have made previous charitable contributions worth millions of dollars. Miles Fiterman made a fortune in the 1960's selling do-it-yourself home building kits.
Among landlords in similar straits, some are overhauling their buildings to remain competitive, analysts noted, others are mothballing their properties, both betting that the slump will end and commercial real estate will become profitable again.
For the City University, the gift of the 375,000-square-foot structure is an unqualified windfall that will, at a single stroke, solve both an acute space shortage at the Borough of Manhattan Community College and worries about how to pay for more room. The building will become a secondary campus for the two-year community college, relieving the strain on the school's primary home four blocks away, at 199 Chambers Street, where nearly 17,000 students crowd a building designed for 10,000.
 
Paying Off the Mortgage
 Mr. Fiterman said he would pay off the $8 million mortgage on the property, giving it to the university free and clear, even though he could simply abandon the building and not be responsible for the mortgage.
University officials said the offices were easily converted to classrooms, so the cost of adapting the building will be relatively small. To build a new home of similar size would cost the university, at a conservative guess, about $112 million, said Robert I. Shapiro, president of City Center Real Estate. Analysts said that to rent the building, without any improvements, would have cost at least $5.5 million a year.
"This is a New York City miracle," Borough President Ruth W. Messinger said at a ceremony Thursday marking the transfer of the building, which has been renamed Miles and Shirley Fiterman Hall.
The deal came together remarkably quickly, following a late July overture by the university, which was interested in leasing the building, but concerned about the cost. In mid-August, after meeting with the University Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, the Fitermans agreed to the donation. Some of its office space was turned into classrooms in just three weeks, in time for the start of classes on Sept. 10.
The building, built in 1959 and bounded by West Broadway, Park Place, Barclay Street and Greenwich Street, sits on the original site of King's College, the precursor to today's Columbia University.
 
A Question of Value
 The actual value of the building depends on who is doing the counting. University officials said it is worth $30 million, based on an independent appraisal done this summer, making it the most valuable gift in the institution's history. The city assesses it for property taxes at $24,225,000. But real- estate professionals said its value to the Fitermans is far less, as is the price it would fetch on the open market.
"The values of a lot of these buildings if you try to sell them is perilously close to zero," Mr. Hauspurg said.
Another analyst, who asked that his name not be used, said the building, which the Fitermans bought in 1979 for $10 million, might sell for as much as $2 million if they were fortunate.
Even at that price, experts said, they would lose money on the sale, because the Internal Revenue Service would demand that the Fitermans pay income taxes on the depreciation allowances -- a form of tax deferral -- the owners have taken on the building. The I.R.S. also demands taxes on depreciation when a building is given away, but a donation could have another tax advantage, as a deduction for a charitable contribution.
Analysts agreed that with 20 million square feet of vacant office space in downtown Manhattan, the Fitermans would have had to undertake major renovation of the building to attract a tenant. Their estimates of the cost ranged from $12 million to $35 million. An overhaul could take a year or more, and in that time, the Fitermans would collect no rents and would continue to pay off the mortgage and nearly $2.6 million in property taxes.
Timing is also crucial.
"A lot of leases are going to expire in the next two years," Mr. Hauspurg said. "If the market doesn't pick up, you'll see a lot more owners looking at this option."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Picks Investment Banker For Municipal Assistance Post

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today appointed Eugene J. Keilin, a Manhattan investment banker and longtime associate of Felix G. Rohatyn, to succeed Mr. Rohatyn as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Mr. Rohatyn announced his resignation last month from the agency he helped form 18 years ago to pull New York City from the brink of bankruptcy. When bankers closed the credit markets to the city in 1975, the state formed the corporation as a vehicle to borrow on the city's behalf. It continues to manage a large investment portfolio on the city's behalf, and its nine-member board oversees the city's finances in an advisory role. 
 Since the corporation's founding, it has served as a sturdy soapbox for Mr. Rohatyn, whose opinions on city finances shaped budgets and spending priorities over two decades. Whether the 51-year-old Mr. Keilin will carry similar influence remains to be seen.
 
'A Seamless Transition'
 For much of Mr. Rohatyn's tenure at the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mr. Keilin served at his right hand. "He will provide a seamless transition from the superb leadership of Felix Rohatyn," Mr. Cuomo said in a statement. Mr. Keilin was traveling today and could not be reached for comment.
In 1976, Mr. Rohatyn plucked Mr. Keilin from the New York City Office of Management and Budget, where he was general counsel, to become executive director of the corporation. He worked there until 1979, when he left to join Lazard Freres & Company, where Mr. Rohatyn is a partner. He also was named a member of the corporation's board, which is appointed by the Governor with the consent of the Senate.
At Lazard Mr. Keilin developed a specialty in advising unions on buyout bids. He represented the Air Line Pilots Association in deals involving Frontier, United, Eastern and Trans World Airlines. He left the concern in 1990 to form his own company, Keilin and Bloom. Last year, he represented unions at The New York Daily News that were seeking buyers for the bankrupt paper.
A native of Houston, Mr. Keilin graduated from Rice University and Harvard Law School.
 
Director of Housing Is Named
 Also today, Mr. Cuomo appointed State Senator Donald M. Halperin of Brooklyn as state director of housing and Commissioner of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
Mr. Halperin, a Democrat who has served in the Senate since 1971, recently lost a race for his party's nomination for Public Advocate in New York City. He finished fifth out of six candidates with 8 percent of the vote. The race was won by Mark Green.
The 48-year-old Mr. Halperin will succeed Angelo J. Aponte, who resigned to join the investment banking firm of M. R. Beal. He will receive a salary of $100,528 a year, a raise from the $72,500 he received for his service in the Senate.
First elected at the age of 24, the youngest person ever elected to the Senate, Mr. Halperin will leave as the third most senior Democrat.

HEADLINE: Japan Doubt On Car Goal

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Japanese car makers may not meet their pledge to buy $19 billion worth of American auto parts in 1994-95 because of the economic climate, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.
"I cannot say we can achieve that figure," the association's chairman, Yutaka Kume, said at a news conference. He said that with the domestic economy in recession and the high yen inhibiting exports, times were hard for Japanese car makers. 
 In January 1992, the Japanese industry said it would buy $19 billion worth of parts in the fiscal year that begins in April 1994, including those for use in Japanese-owned plants in the United States.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: A Mill for High-Grade Pulp;
Giving Recycled Paper A New Chance to Shine

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Not many mills can turn the waste paper pouring out of the nation's offices into high-quality pulp for recycling. That weak link in the recycling chain gets a little stronger today with the opening of Superior Recycled Fiber Industries' $76 million mill in Duluth, Minn.
"There are some larger plants that turn office waste into low- grade papers like tissue and some big higher-quality de-inking facilities attached to paper mills, but this will be the largest high-quality pulp producer for the open market," said Gerald Ostroski, president of Synertec Inc., which is Superior's majority owner. Synertec is a subsidiary of the Minnesota Power and Light Company. 
 Superior expects to take in 120,000 tons of waste annually, about 6 percent of the roughly two million tons of office waste collected for recycling nationwide. The waste will go through eight wash cycles to convert it to pulp for blending into coated paper used in annual reports, as paper stock by magazines like Time and for advertising inserts of mass merchants like Target stores.
Demand from such users has encouraged five nearby paper companies to sign up for nearly three-quarters of Superior's output. At current prices, they will pay up to 20 percent more than for virgin pulp, Mr. Ostroski said. But because virgin pulp will still account for as much as 90 percent of the finished products, the premium for the recycled portion will not add much to the users' costs.
Synertec will buy waste from as far away as Dallas, at least until more is collected closer to home. Most office waste -- about 90 percent, according to some estimates -- still goes directly into landfills or incinerators.
The company also said it had held preliminary discussions on building a second plant for high-quality recycled pulp. But don't look for it anywhere near cities like New York that generate most of the waste. "The economics favor making the pulp near the papermakers," Mr. Ostroski said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Little Changed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices and yields were little changed yesterday with light volume and cautious trading ahead of the release of September employment data on Friday.
The end to the fighting in Moscow seemed to have little impact in the bond market or other financial markets because, some analysts said, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia seemed to be in control despite the bloodshed. 
 In fact, bond markets in Europe ended a little higher. In Frankfurt, after a selloff early in the trading day, the market recovered after reports of people leaving the Russian Parliament building. The 10-year Treasury note ended at a yield of 6.08 percent in Frankfurt, down from 6.10 percent Friday. In London, the 10-year note yield fell to 6.88 percent, from 6.90 percent Friday. The yields on short-term notes also declined
In trading at 5 P.M. yesterday in New York, the price of the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was off 4/32 point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6 percent, from 5.99 percent Friday.
 
 
10-Year Note
 The yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.32 percent from 5.33 percent. The yields on short-term Treasury notes were a little lower as some investors may have bought them because they were a less risky investment than long-term maturities. The price of the two-year note was up 1/32 as the yield fell to 3.81 percent from 3.83 percent.
But at the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the discount rates were up sharply. The average discount rate on three-month bills was 2.96 percent, up from 2.90 percent last week, and the average rate on six-month bills was 3.08 percent, up from 3.02 percent.
Beyond Russia, the focus was on the wait for the September employment data. In this report, investors and traders hope to find clues to the near-term outlook for the economy. If economic expansion is still sluggish, and the Consumer Price Index report for September due a week later shows moderate inflation, there could be enough buying to push prices higher and yields lower again.
 
 
Chrysler Rating
 The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised the Chrysler Corporation's senior debt rating yesterday to investment grade.
Chrysler is now rated investment grade by all the major credit rating agencies for the first time in more than three years.
But traders and investors in the corporate bond market have been trading Chrysler at investment-grade prices and yields since around June, according to Geoffrey Kurinsky, a senior vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston.
He said that since then the spread between the yield on Chrysler bonds and comparable Treasury securities had been in a range that is equivalent to other investment-grade bonds.
The rating agencies often tend to lag behind the market "rating" of a company, in part because the rating agencies are taking longer views of financial developments in a company.
S.& P. cited the timely introduction of well-designed new products, improved operating efficiency enhancing competitiveness and financial results that have far exceeded expectations in raising its rating to triple B from double B+. Triple B is the bottom of the investment-grade category.
The upgrading will lower borrowing costs for Chrysler because there is less risk in owning the company's debt securities. With less risk, investors will accept lower interest rates.
The rating change by S.& P. affects about $12.8 billion in outstanding debt. Moody's Investors Service Inc. raised its rating to the investment-grade level of Baa3 from Ba2 on Sept. 7. Both S.& P. and Moody's had downgraded Chrysler to junk bond, or sub-investment-grade, level in June 1990.
 
 
Chrysler Financial
 In addition to this rating change on Chrysler's senior debt, S.& P. raised the subordinated debt rating of Chrysler Financial and the preferred stock rating of Chrysler to BBB- from BB-.
Scott Sprinzen, an S.& P. analyst, said in a report that he had upgraded the company because "well-designed and fortuitously timed new products, coupled with steps to improve operating efficiency, have enhanced Chrysler's competitive position."
For example, he said, Chrysler pushed ahead plans to begin second-shift production of its new Neon subcompact to Nov. 28 from May of next year.
Chrysler, which reported a loss of $795 million for 1991, earned $723 million last year; for the first six months of 1993 it earned $1.2 billion.

HEADLINE: Mexico Will Phase Out Price Supports for Corn

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Mexico said today that it would phase out its politically sensitive system of price supports for corn and other crops and replace it with direct payments to farmers based on the amount of land they cultivate.
Mexican officials called the new system a "transitory scheme" that would last for 15 years and was intended to lead to the development of more economically competitive farms. The program is meant to complement an economic stimulus package of tax cuts and wage increases that Mr. Salinas announced on Sunday. 
 The 15-year period coincides with schedules for eliminating protection on corn and other sensitive products listed in the North American Free Trade Agreement. If the trade accord is approved, the last tariff on American-grown corn coming into Mexico would be lifted in 15 years, the longest period for any product covered by the pact.
Mexican officials said the subsidy program, announced today by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, complied with all terms of the trade pact, as well as with the free-trade requirements of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Mexico's Basic Bread
 Mexico, more than most Latin American countries, has developed extensive agricultural subsidies. They cost the Government more than $3 billion a year and cover several basic commodities. The primary one is corn, which is consumed daily in the form of tortillas or other food by nearly every Mexican. About three million farmers throughout the country plant corn, even though much Mexican land is poorly suited for its production.
The subsidies hold down the price of tortillas and are thus as much a political matter as an economic one. While the current system is intended to help consumers and poor farmers, it allows well-to-do farmers with well-irrigated land to switch to corn and take advantage of the price supports. Poor farmers who grow corn only for their own use and do not sell it do not benefit.
About four million farmers who have grown corn or any of eight other grains over the last three years will be part of the new program, though there will be limits on the biggest farmers. Payments will be made on the basis of the number of acres under cultivation.
For example, a farmer with 20 acres of corn now sells his crop to a government buyer for more than $200 a ton, about twice the international price, and the total amount he receives would depend on how much corn he succeeds in producing on his land.
 
Influencing Choice of Crops
 Under the first year of the new system, that same farmer would receive about $50 an acre a year for each of his 20 acres regardless of the size of his harvest. In the future, the payment will increase and the farmer would not even have to continue growing corn to receive the money.
Mexican agricultural officials say this will allow farmers to grow crops that are best suited for their land or for the market.
But Steven E. Sanderson, an agricultural expert at the Center for Latin American Studies at the University of Florida in Gainesville, said there was little chance that the program would work that way.
"The poorest people with the crummiest land don't have much flexibility, regardless of the incentives," he said.
Basing the new program on the ownership of about 28 million acres of land is expected to cause political problems, even social unrest, because land claims have been a flash point since the Mexican Revolution of 1910.
"There will be conflicts, we cannot deny that," said a Government agriculture official who asked not to be identified by name. He said a program to verify land claims would be established, and in cases where poor owners could not produce title to their land, claims will be determined by local councils.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower As Some Global Jitters Ease

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar dropped against most major currencies yesterday as Boris N. Yeltsin triumphed over Russian hard-liners, easing investors' fears of an interruption in Russia's transition to a market economy.
Currency dealers said the dollar rose in early trading in Asia on reports of armed troops and gun battles in Moscow. But as Mr. Yeltsin's forces gained the upper hand, investors felt they no longer needed to hold dollars, traditionally considered a haven during political turmoil. 
 "It's very much a headline-driven market," said Matt Porio, a vice president at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Once Yeltsin's foes surrendered, he said, "we saw a selloff of the dollar."
Margaret Kudarauskas, a foreign exchange analyst for the Technical Data analysis firm, said many traders had stocked up on dollars on Friday amid uncertainty about what would happen over the weekend in Russia.
The dollar lost nearly a pfennig yesterday against the German mark, which investors had earlier avoided because of that country's economic ties and proximity to Russia.
With the Russian turmoil apparently quieted, traders said their attention would turn to economic fundamentals, notably the United States jobs data due out on Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 106.00 yen, down 0.38 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, it fell to 105.75 yen, compared with 106.05 on Friday. In New York, the dollar finished at 105.65 yen, down from 105.90 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5165, from $1.5050 late Friday. In New York, the pound was trading at $1.5140, up from $1.5050 on Friday.
Other dollar rates in New York late yesterday, compared with late Friday, were: 1.6235 German marks, down from 1.6315; 1.4190 Swiss francs, down from 1.4240; 5.6645 French francs, down from 5.6930; 1,588.00 Italian lire, down from 1,593.00, and 1.3413 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3379.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, were: 1.6230 German marks, down from 1.6308; 1.4165 Swiss francs, down from 1.4240; 5.6560 French francs, down from 5.6875; 1.8222 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8211; 1,587.00 Italian lire, down from 1,591.00, and 1.3395 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3388.

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN MOSCOW;
'Dear Compatriots': Yeltsin's Appeal to the People

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of yesterday's televised speech to the nation by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, as translated by The Associated Press.
 Dear compatriots: 
I am turning to you at this difficult moment.
 Shots are thundering in Russia's capital and blood has been spilled. Fighters who have been brought from the whole country and have been incited by the White House leaders are sowing death and destruction.
 I know that it was a sleepless night for many of you. I know that you have understood everything.
 This troubled and tragic night has taught us a lot. We did not prepare for a war. We hoped that we could reach an agreement and preserve peace in the capital.
Those who moved against the peaceful city and unleashed the bloody massacre are criminals.
 But it was not just a crime committed by individual bandits and vandals. Everything that happened and is happening in Moscow -- it was an armed revolt planned in advance. It was organized by Communists seeking revenge, by fascist leaders and some of the former deputies -- representatives of the Soviets.
 
'Cynical Lies'
 Under the cover of negotiations, they have been building up their forces, gathering groups of mercenary bandits used to murders and violence. A tiny group of political conspirators has tried to impose its will on the entire country.
 The means they intended to use to control Russia have been revealed to the whole world. These are cynical lies and bribes. These are rocks, sharpened iron bars, automatic rifles and machine guns.
 Those waving red flags have once again covered Russia with blood.
 They hoped to use surprise, to sow fear and confusion with their impudence and unprecedented ruthlessness.
 They hoped that the military would stay away calmly and watch defenseless Muscovites be persecuted and a bloody dictatorship be established in our country.
 They hoped that the citizens of Russia would believe their lies. They hoped for a fast victory.
 For them and for those who gave them orders, there can be no forgiveness, because they lifted their hand against peaceful people, against Moscow, against Russia, against women, children and old people.
 The armed revolt is doomed. Troops are entering Moscow to restore order, peace and quiet.
 Their task is to liberate facilities seized by the criminals, to lift the blockade around them, and to disarm illegal armed groups.
 I am asking you, dear Muscovites, to give your moral support to boost the spirits of the Russian soldiers and officers. They belong to our national army and police. They have one task today: to defend our children, to defend our mothers and fathers, to stop and neutralize the rioters and murderers.
 Moscow and Russia are awaiting your courage and decisive action.
 
'The Decree Was Signed'
 The public organizations that took part in mass disorders and other unlawful actions are banned on the entire territory of Russia. The Central Bank has been instructed to immediately stop all operations involving their bank accounts. The Prosecutor General's office has been told to open a criminal investigation into the facts of mass disorders.
 The decree that calls for these measures and others was signed overnight and is already being implemented.
 I appeal to all political forces in Russia. For the sake of those whose lives have already ended, for the sake of those whose innocent blood has already been spilled, I appeal to you to forget your internal disputes that seemed important yesterday.
 All those who value peace and quiet, the honor and dignity of our country, and all those who are against war must stay together.
 I am appealing to the citizens of Russia. The armed fascist-Communist revolt in Moscow will be suppressed in the shortest possible time.
 The Russian state has all the forces necessary for it.
 
'I Consider It My Duty'
 I consider it my duty to turn to Muscovites. In the past day and night, our numbers have grown smaller. Let us bow to those who perished.
 Many of you followed the call of your hearts and spent last night in the center of Moscow, [guarding] the far and near approaches to the Kremlin. Tens of thousands of people risked their lives.
 Your will, your civic courage, your moral strength have proved to be the most effective weapon.
 I bow to you from my heart.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Which companies will suffer if tourists steer clear of Florida?

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson

 BODY:
INVESTORS reacted to a spate of recent attacks on tourists in Florida by temporarily punishing the shares of the Walt Disney Company, on the assumption that some vacationers would stay away from Disney's theme parks in Florida. In the weeks since, other companies with ties to the state's $30 billion-a-year tourist business have braced for a similar backlash.
Because the fall is generally a slack period for Florida attractions, there is little evidence yet that the number of annual visitors, about 40 million, will decline. Even so, tourism officials and some amusement park operators expect the blizzard of negative publicity over the 10 visitors who have been killed in Florida since last October will curtail visits by 15 to 30 percent this winter and possibly hurt bookings thereafter. 
 Some leisure companies with ties to Florida may be large enough, or so geographically diverse, that they have little to fear. Even a 10 percent drop in car rentals will not depress General Motors' earnings, said one broker who advised against short selling any rental companies. G.M. has stakes in the Avis and National car rental agencies.
"They are spread out like ants," agreed Chase Burritt, a partner with Kenneth Leventhal & Company, real estate consultants in Tallahassee. "None will see earnings impact."
Other companies may be more vulnerable if tourism falls. Hotel consultants and tourism experts say other companies that could be hurt are American Airlines, which has a hub in Miami; USAir, which has the most service between Florida cities, and midpriced hotel chains like Holiday Inn and Choice Hotels' Quality and Comfort Inns, which cater to international tour groups. Nine of the 10 victims were foreigners.
A more speculative suggestion comes from Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service, a newsletter in Half Moon Bay, Calif., that ferrets out stocks that he expects to decline.
"In general, when you're trying to play a geographic area, play the bank," Mr. Murphy said. "The health of a bank is totally intertwined with the economy."
Since he expects Florida tourism to decline, Mr. Murphy predicts that Barnett Banks, the state's largest bank company, will see a decline in its share price to the low $30's by late December. Barnett closed yesterday at $45.125, up 25 cents. "That's the only one we've shorted," he said.
Like many bank stocks, Barnett's share price has climbed over the last year. Industrywide, earnings have been buoyed by low interest rates and investors have been anticipating even greater profits because of the cost savings that resulted from a wave of consolidations.
Barnett, with $38 billion in assets, earned $104 million in the first half, up 66 percent from a year earlier. The company, based in Jacksonville, saw a 14-year streak of consecutive earnings gains end with Florida's real estate collapse in 1989. The bank has since trimmed its portfolio of bad loans, cut costs and merged with First Florida Banks.
Violence aimed at tourists could hurt Barnett by further depressing Florida real estate values and cutting the cash flow of the bank's business customers, Mr. Murphy said.
John Godfrey, Barnett's chief economist, dismissed the bearish prediction as premature, since tourism has not yet fallen off. "There's not any evidence of it happening yet," he said.
During most of September, when three fatal attacks on Florida visitors occurred, Barnett's stock lagged behind a regional bank index, but caught up in the final week, according to George Salem, a banking analyst for Prudential Securities.
The stock activity shows "the stock had been affected earlier, but in the most recent week shrugged it off," Mr. Salem said, adding, "Enough damage has been done that it's a nagging issue."
He expects American travelers, as well as foreigners, will avoid Florida. "It's fear and it's real and it's vivid," he said.
