HEADLINE: The Last Gasp Of Russia's Communists

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes, professor of history at Harvard, is author of "The Russian Revolution."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Now begins the arduous task of reconciling the Russian nation and building a democratic state on the rubble of Communism. The prospects for success look better than at any time since the abdication of Czar Nicholas II in March 1917.
Unless President Boris Yeltsin repeats previous mistakes and seeks compromises with his defeated enemies, who interpret readiness to compromise as weakness, we are unlikely ever again to see a resurgence of a militant antidemocratic opposition. The events of the past two days are probably the last outbreak of violent counterrevolution in Russia. 
 The weekend riots in Moscow were much bloodier than the unsuccessful putsch of August 1991, but no less desperate and futile. A small minority of diehard Communists, out of touch with reality, inspired by a vision of a revived Soviet empire and by the desire to regain their privileges, tried again and failed again to rally the masses behind them.
This time they were much better organized. Vice President Alexander V. Rutskoi, who fancies himself a modern-day Lenin, tried to re-enact October 1917. His tactics emulated those of Leon Trotsky in the original Bolshevik coup d'etat: disguise the anti-democratic offensive as a defense of democracy, negotiate while seizing power and strike at the nerve centers of the state (which today include television broadcasting stations).
But October 1993 is not October 1917, and we can only marvel at the ability of the self-styled parliamentarians to delude themselves.
One problem with Russia's political vocabulary -- such as "Parliament" and "Constitution" -- is that it parrots Western words that bear little relationship to reality.
The self-styled Parliament, actually the Supreme Soviet, is an offshoot of a body elected under President Mikhail Gorbachev, when there was a Soviet Union and a Communist Party to rule it. Neither exists today, and the membership of the Supreme Soviet, composed overwhelmingly of Communists, represents a state that has passed into history. The Constitution is a document from the 1970's. Amended more than 300 times, it has only historical significance.
It is absurd to talk of a coup d'etat by President Yeltsin, because the concept presumes an "etat," a state -- a generally accepted and functioning system of government. Russia has not had such a system since autumn 1991, when the party was outlawed and the Soviet Union disintegrated into its constituent republics.
The state has to be created anew, and this can be accomplished only by elections, which require the dissolution of the unrepresentative Supreme Soviet and its parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies.
The inhabitants of Moscow recognize this situation. An opinion poll conducted in Moscow two days after President Yeltsin dissolved the Parliament showed that 62 percent supported the measure while 12 percent opposed it; only 6 percent acknowledged Mr. Rutskoi's claim to the presidency. If we are to judge by referendums and opinion polls, at most one-tenth of Russia's population subscribes to the ideology of Mr. Yeltsin's opponents.
An exhaustive survey conducted in 1989 and updated in 1992 under the direction of the sociologist Yuri Levada showed that a mere 4.9 percent of the people yearned for their country's lost superpower status -- and only 4.1 percent believed that it was surrounded by external enemies. The majority want, above all, democracy, better living conditions and civil rights. Nearly 45 percent believe that Russia's misfortunes are caused not by external enemies but by its own faults.
These statistics indicate that a sea change has occurred in the Russian psyche. In 1917, the masses could be rallied behind utopian visionaries of various ideological persuasions because they thought it possible to attain a perfect society and believed that Russia would show humanity the way. Today, Russians no longer believe that politics, least of all violent politics, can solve human problems or that Russia leads the world in anything except crime and the consumption of alcohol.
They have become thoroughly depoliticized. For this reason, the slogans with which the parliamentary opposition tried to arouse the masses fell on deaf ears. In Moscow, the diehards succeeded in assembling mobs of a few thousand embittered Communists and anti-Semites. In other cities, including St. Petersburg, they met with no response.
The failure of the antidemocratic forces was a foregone conclusion -- except for two unpredictable factors: Mr. Yeltsin's personality and the armed forces' loyalty.
The President combines courage and pugnacity with a tendency to fall into apathy after winning a fight. Desperately anxious to avoid dividing Russia into warring camps, he retreats when he should be advancing to consummate his victory. This he did after the August 1991 putsch and again after the referendum of April 1993, in which his proposals for new presidential and parliamentary elections and for economic reforms were solidly supported. This time, fortunately, he decided to act resolutely by meeting force with force.
Although the armed forces declared loyalty to Mr. Yeltsin, there was no assurance that they would obey orders to fire at civilians. The sympathies of most generals, almost to a man ex-members of the party, lie with Mr. Yeltsin's opponents, who promise to restore Russia's empire and return to the army its privileged status.
Some fraternization between the internal security forces and the rioters on Sunday gave cause for concern. Nevertheless, in the end the officer corps proved true to Russia's military tradition of obeying legitimate authority, and routed the armed rebels.
This is not an unmitigated good, because while Mr. Yeltsin's dependence on the military might have saved him, it may compel him to conduct a more nationalistic foreign policy than he would if he were free of it.
Mr. Yeltsin, one hopes, will continue to act firmly and adhere to his program of two-tiered elections: in December for the new Parliament, in June for the presidency.
Judging by what we know of Russian opinion, the likelihood is that he will win a comfortable majority, perhaps as much as two-thirds of the deputies. Another 10 percent may be expected to consist of members of the uncompromising nationalist and Communist opposition. The remaining 25 percent will probably represent the floating constituency of those who think of the past with nostalgia and yet realize that it is gone beyond recall, and are willing to promote democracy and privatization.
Western statesmen have acquitted themselves splendidly in this crisis -- much better than in August 1991, when, uncertain how definitive the collapse of Communism was, some held back support from Mr. Yeltsin.
In coming months, Western governments should continue to extend unstinting support -- moral, diplomatic, economic -- to those who have just brought Russia back from the brink of disaster.

HEADLINE: Tremors in Cuba Bending Exiles' Hard Line

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 5

 BODY:
As Cuba's economic and political crisis deepens, exiles here are reaching out to their kin on the island as never before by sending aid, exchanging visits and seeking their advice on how to ease Fidel Castro from power.
The monolithic core that once dominated exile politics is splintering, and moderates are emerging as a vital new force among Cuban-Americans. Convinced that Mr. Castro's fall is imminent, exiles here have plunged into an impassioned debate over how to bring down his 34-year dictatorship without inflicting further hardship on Cuba's 11 million people. 
 "There is a change in the air," said Maria Elena Torano, a business consultant active in both exile and local politics. "Something is happening. We don't know how it is going to end, but there is a new sense of freedom to speak up."
In place of a single organization, one that claimed to speak for all 1.2 million Cuban-Americans and preached unrelenting hostility toward Cuba's Communist government, new groups now openly urge negotiations. Thousands of exiles, responding to the pleas of family members still in Cuba, have defied calls to starve the island into submission and are sending money and supplies through the scores of shipping agencies that have sprung up here.
Still others have responded to Mr. Castro's recent invitation to exiles, whom he once spurned as "worms" and "scum," and are visiting their families in Cuba. New flights making the Miami-Havana run are booked weeks in advance, and relatives of top Cuban officials have also come to seek out moderates here to discuss ways the two groups can cooperate.
This war of words and ideas is being monitored in Havana and Washington. American officials say more flexibility on the part of Miami exiles would make it easer to deal with the crisis in Cuba, and the Cuban Goverment increasingly regards the prosperous exile community here as a source of financial and material support for an economy near collapse.
Although both Governments deny anything has changed in a hostile relationship that is one of the last vestiges of the cold war, exile groups here of every ideological stripe say the momentum for a transformation is building. Last week, the United States Government announced that Cuba had agreed to accept the forced repatriation of up to 1,500 Cuban prisoners being held in Federal prisons, an action that came shortly after Havana handed over to the Drug Enforcement Administration a pair of cocaine traffickers who had eluded American helicopters and fled into Cuban waters.
Since the Soviet Union disintegrated, Mr. Castro has been forced to do without billions of dollars in subsidies. As a result, food and fuel are increasingly scarce, the population now spends much of its time foraging for supplies, and discontent with the Government has grown increasingly open.
With the prospect, if not the reality, of change, "the crisis of Cuba is a crisis here as well," said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University. "The discourse in Miami has always been one of hostility and isolation," he added, but now "you get alternate positions emerging."
He labeled the sides "those who say 'Let's try something different' " and "another side which says, 'No, just hold on, and things will happen.' "
 
Exile Leadership Is Splintering
 During the Reagan and Bush years, exile politics were monopolized by the Cuban American National Foundation and its leader, Jorge Mas Canosa, a multi-millionaire contractor with a penchant for questioning the patriotism of his opponents. With generous donations to Republican presidential candidates and key members of Congress from both parties, the foundation, founded in 1981, gained entree to the White House and came to exercise a virtual veto power over American policy toward Cuba.
With the advent of the Clinton Administration, the foundation's stock dropped sharply. Hoping to capitalize on the opening, a coalition of business executives, academics and other professionals who say they represent "the moderate or progressive sector of the Cuban-American population" in August formed the Cuban Committee for Democracy to provide an alternative to the foundation.
The new coalition brings together several groups that have emerged here in recent months, including Cambio Cubano, led by a former guerrilla commander and political prisoner, Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo. The coalition also has ties to exile leaders in Spain and with dissidents still in Cuba.
"There are a whole bunch of people disturbed by the fact that a small group of Cubans here have been able to convince Washington that their views represent the totality of Cuban-American opinion," said Alfredo Duran, a Miami lawyer who is a founder of the coalition and a former state chairman of the Democratic Party.
A year ago, Mr. Duran said, it would have been pointless to form such a group. "But now there is a willingness to listen to new views" in Washington, he said, while at the same time "Cuba is in a position to be easily influenced to bring about change."
For years, the foundation and its allies have pushed the United States to tighten the screws on Mr. Castro, mainly through the economic embargo in effect since the Kennedy Administration. The apparent objective is to provoke a popular uprising or military revolt that would enable exile leaders like Mr. Mas to return to Cuba and perhaps even succeed Mr. Castro.
But the newly invigorated moderate groups oppose punitive economic steps, arguing in the Cuban Committee for Democracy manifesto that "such measures harm the living conditions of Cubans without affecting the present Communist leadership." In addition, the manifesto expresses a "willingness to meet with representatives of the present Cuban Government" as a step toward negotiating Mr. Castro's departure from power.
The foundation camp, which remains dominant and continues to regard itself as a sort of government-in-exile, has responded to those suggestions with a mixture of alarm and contempt. Mr. Mas has a policy of not responding to inquiries by The New York Times, saying through a spokesman that he regards the newspaper's reports of Cuban affairs since the mid-1950's as sympathetic to Mr. Castro. He did not return phone calls asking for comment on the changing political situation here.
But his allies, including most Spanish-language radio stations here, have fulminated against suggestions of a new approach. Arguing that any call for dialogue only prolongs the agony of the Cuban people, they have questioned the motives of the moderates and threatened to punish them in a post-Castro Cuba.
"Many of them serve Fidel Castro, while others are simply accomplices or collaborationists," said Armando Perez Roura, director of Radio Mambi, a Spanish-language radio station. "No honest person with any level of political development can believe the promises of third-rate Cuban bureaucrats.
 
Families Come First For Many From Cuba
 For many ordinary Cuban exiles, though, worries about the living conditions of relatives on the island now seem to carry more weight than demands for ideological purity.
"I feel disoriented," said Jesus Menendez, a retired factory worker who left Cuba for Miami three decades ago but who has never given up his dream of returning. "I no longer believe either the politicians or the people in exile."
Dozens of freight companies now dot the Miami area and, for $10 a pound or more, ship packages of food and medicine to Cuba. Under American law, exiles are permitted to send up to $300 worth of such items to close relatives in Cuba every three months, a loophole in the embargo that exiles exploit with a combination of relief and guilt.
"You don't want to help Fidel, but you feel sorry for your family, and you don't want them to have to suffer," Maria Pinera Suttles explained as she left one such company recently. "It's like you are torn between two desires."
Mrs. Suttles, 46, and her mother, Zoila Pinera, 86, said that as often as they were able, they sent packages containing sugar, cereal, coffee, vitamins, aspirin, toothpaste, powdered milk, peanut butter and beef jerky to Mrs. Pinera's two sisters in Cuba.
But other exiles argue that it is wrong to put personal concerns above the national interest.
"I won't send anything, not a single cent, to Cuba," said Aldo Schwerert, 65, a mechanic. "I have a 94-year-old father and two sisters still over there, and they've asked me, but I have sent them nothing because I am an anti-Communist. Those places are only playing Castro's game."
Nevertheless, Mr. Schwerert made his comments after coming out of one of the same freight companies he said he would like to see shut. He said that despite his own opposition, his wife, Estela Martinez, insists on sending packages to her relatives, and that he had come to inquire about one such shipment.
Hungry for hard currency, Mr. Castro this summer announced that Cubans could now own dollars and urged exiles to visit Cuba. Despite a campaign in Miami to discourage such trips, including bumper stickers that read "I'm Not Going to Cuba" and "No $ For Cuba," the first flights permitted under the new rules began leaving here in September, with every seat taken and a waiting list for future bookings.
 
New Arrivals Versus the Old
 The debate over humanitarian aid and travel has intensified political differences among exiles. The exile establishment, which for the most part arrived here in the early 1960's, has done well in business, and generally has fewer close relations on the island. The newer arrivals, who tend to be poor and less educated, include the 125,000 refugees who fled Cuba in the Mariel boat lift of 1980, as well as the growing number of "balseros," or "rafters," who have resorted to that even more dangerous form of escape in the past five years.
Many of the newer refugees say the first wave of exiles has a vision of Cuba that is, by turns, romantic, intransigent and hopelessly outdated.
"I was born into Communism, and lived through it in my own skin," said Jorge Luis Velazquez, a 31-year-old chauffeur who left Cuba in 1991, leaving behind his mother and daughter, who he helps support with occasional packages of food, medicine and clothing. "I know what it is like over there. These people do not."
For their part, some established exiles are suspicious of the new arrivals, questioning why they waited so long to break with Castro.
"There are dozens of people arriving here now who are really seeking exile from the next government of Cuba," said Tomas Garcia Fuste, a prominent radio commentator. "We know that there are people here who have done bad things over there and think that they are better off being here when the Castro regime falls."
Hard-liners admit they are worried that Washington may soften its stance on Mr. Castro now that a Democratic Administration is in office. Already, the Clinton Administration has liberalized guidelines on humanitarian aid and travel to Cuba by American citizens and offered Havana a new telecommunications agreement that would provide Cuba with tens of millions of badly needed dollars each year.
Though encouraged by what they see as subtle indications of a lessening of hostility in both capitals, the moderate exiles say they are fearful that events on the island are developing faster than Washington's ability to absorb them.
Mr. Duran of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, said, "There doesn't seem to be a plan for what to do to bring about democracy in Cuba." The Clinton Administration, he said, seems to be "in a position to react to something, but not in a position to bring about change in an orderly way."
Many moderates are forging their own network of contacts with Cuban officials they see as likely to play a role in a post-Castro era.
Several close relatives of senior members Cuban Communist Party officials recently visited Miami on tourist visas and sought out exile leaders who favor dialogue, according to people who have taken part in such conversations. In several instances, the relatives have returned to Cuba with letters or verbal messages from exile groups here.
"There are people in Cuba in the government who are very concerned" about the disintegration of Cuban society, said one prominent exile figure who has received emissaries from Havana, speaking on condition that he not be identified. "They are looking for changes too."

Others, like Alex Zaldivar, right, who attended a recent demonstration in Miami, urge a continuing boycott. (Photographs by Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times) (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: WORLD MORATORIUM ON NUCLEAR TESTS IS BROKEN BY CHINA

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Rejecting a plea from President Clinton, China exploded a nuclear weapon at a test site beneath its western desert today, breaking an informal testing moratorium. In response, the Administration ordered preparations for a resumption of American tests.
"The United States deeply regrets this action," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued this morning after receiving reports that the Chinese had set off a nuclear device in Xinjiang province. Mr. Clinton added that he had "directed the Department of Energy to take such actions as are needed to put the U.S. in a position to be able to conduct nuclear tests next year." 
 The action comes when relations between the United States and China were already in rough water over China's record on human rights, weapons sales and nuclear proliferation issues. Early this summer, the Administration reluctantly agreed to extend China's favored trading status, but only for one year.
 
Crucial Issue
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said today that nuclear non-proliferation "is one of the issues on which our relationship with China depends."
While Mr. Clinton today set in motion plans that could lead to the first nuclear test by the United States since September 1992, the Administration by law must win approval from Congress before exploding a nuclear bomb. And the President placed a number of stringent conditions to be met before the United States could resume its nuclear testing program.
Mr. Clinton's response reflects internal divisons in his Administration over the wisdom and the need for the United States to resume nuclear testing.
Officials from the Pentagon and the National Security Council, as well as some from the State Department, have argued that if other countries resume testing then so must United States, to make sure that its nuclear arsenal is being maintained safely. On the other side, officials from the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the Department of Energy say there is no need to resume detonations because the safety of the nuclear weapons can be determined without testing.
Administration officials also say there is intense concern that a resumption of nuclear testing by the United States would set off an international political chain reaction that could sink Mr. Clinton's efforts to secure an indefinite extension of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and to negotiate a comprehensive test ban treaty.
"With each additional test by any nation, whether it's France or Britain or China or the U.S., for that matter, the chances of getting a comprehensive test ban treaty are that much weaker," said a State Department official who asked not to be identified.
On July 3, after an intensive debate within the Administration, Mr. Clinton extended by 15 months a 9-month moratorium Congress had imposed on nuclear weapons testing. At the same time, he warned that the United States might resume testing if any other nation detonated a nuclear device.
Russia and Great Britain have said they would not resume testing unless the United States did. President Francois Mitterrand of France is awaiting a report from a panel of experts on whether French adherence to the moratorium would compromise France's nuclear weapons.
Early indications are that such a request would face rough going in Congress, where there is growing sentiment that the United States should apply economic pressure on China, rather than resume testing.
Officials say it is doubtful that the Administration would resume testing until sometime next summer, if at all.
A letter to the President being circulated on Capitol Hill by Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, asks that the Administration hold up granting an export license for a Cray supercomputer and other "sensitive sales of dual-use advanced technology" ordered by the Chinese until Beijing guarantees that it will not conduct more nuclear tests.
Another letter circulated by Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, and Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, was signed by 24 Senators. It said it would be "inappropriate and counterproductive" for the United States to conduct a nuclear test in response to the one by China.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Experts See Maneuvering
 HONG KONG, Oct. 5 (Special to The New York Times) -- A statement issued late today by the official New China News Agency confirmed the test, but provided no details. "It is entirely for the purpose of self-defense that China develops and possesses a small number of nuclear weapons," the statement said.
China asked the nuclear powers to conclude a comprehensive test ban treaty by 1996, but also called for the commencement of a "parallel negotiation" to conclude a treaty in which nuclear powers would pledge no first use of nuclear weapons and not to use or threaten to use "nuclear weapons against non-nuclear states and nuclear-free zones."
Western analysts said China's unwillingness to heed international pressure over the nuclear test fits a pattern of recent Chinese behavior that is assertive and unaccommodating in its international relations. A number of analysts attribute this behavior to the pending leadership succession in China, where the country's longtime senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, recently passed his 89th birthday and is reported to be increasingly frail.
These analysts say they believe that the Chinese leaders under Mr. Deng are taking tough and uncompromising positions to demonstrate their qualifications to succeed him.

HEADLINE: THE SOMALIA MISSION;
CLINTON REVIEWS POLICY IN SOMALIA AS UNEASE GROWS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton met with his top advisers tonight to review the American role in the international military operation in Somalia. He sought to balance the need to remain in Somalia to recover American hostages with mounting calls from Congress for a clear withdrawal strategy and the President's own goal of putting Somalia on the road to recovery.
After a 90-minute meeting, during which the President reviewed options ranging from a quick pullout to a large-scale buildup of American forces in Somalia, Mr. Clinton told his aides he wanted to think more about the alternatives and asked them to reconvene Wednesday morning. 
 Aides said the President seemed to be tilting toward an approach that still focused on putting Somalia on a road to political recovery so an indigenous government could sustain and feed the country on its own. But the aides said the President was insisting on accomplishing this much more quickly and with a clear exit strategy that he could hold up to Congress.
 
Complications of Hostages

The deaths on Sunday of 12 American soldiers, the wounding of 75 others and the capture by Somali gunmen of at least one American soldier has thrown the Administration off balance, adding a layer of complications and crystallizing Congressional opposition.
"If we had a vote today, we'd be out today," Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said. But, he added, "We can't get out with hostages there."
As hundreds of additional United States troops with special weapons and aircraft began heading to Somalia, a wave of hostility toward the widening operation swept Congress. The opposition led the White House to send Secretary of Defense Les Aspin and Secretary of State Warren Christopher to Capitol Hill to try to calm critics from the left and right of both parties and to beg lawmakers for additional time to draw up a new policy. [Page A16.]
 
Angry Legislators
 But Mr. Aspin and Mr. Christopher were besieged by skeptical lawmakers, who scorched them with demands for a clear road map for an exit from Somalia, coupled with bitter complaints that the policy goals were unclear or unrealistic.
It is not clear whether the critics can assemble sufficient votes to pass a law requiring Mr. Clinton to stop the operation. But Congressional anxiety, already high, has been fueled by a wave of constituents' telephone calls reflecting outrage over the prospect of a new hostage crisis, and television pictures of Somali crowds dragging a dead American servicemen through the streets.
Public sentiment appeared to be less in favor of exacting revenge and more in favor of simply leaving Somalia and letting the Somalis deal with their violent factions.
The leader of the most aggressive faction, Mohammed Farah Aidid, warned today that sending additional troops would solve nothing, and he urged Somalis to defend themselves against "colonialism."
After a meeting at the White House that included Mr. Aspin; Mr. Christopher; the United Nations representative, Madeleine K. Albright, and the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, aides said the President still seemed to be leaning away from the two extreme options, an immediate pullout or a major expansion of the American military presence.
 
What the President Wants
 His instinct, said one adviser, was to remain committed to building up a government in Somalia, but to do it in a way that American troops did not become the focus of local opposition.
At the same time, though, the United States has to find a way to negotiate the return of American prisoners without making a hero of General Aidid, whose limited popularity in Mogadishu could easily be enhanced if he appeared to be the strongman against the Americans.
The fact that General Aidid holds one or more American soldiers makes an immediate American withdrawal from Somalia impossible, officials said, while the mounting opposition in Congress makes any large-scale expansion much more complicated.
"I detect no inclination to pull out in a panicky reaction to this week's events," a senior Administration official said of the President's mood. "But we need to rethink it."
 
Resolve of Boutros-Ghali
 Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said the United Nations had to remain resolute in Somalia against those seeking to destabilize the nation. In a lunch toast to heads of state and governments at the General Assembly, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said:
"Those who were responsible for Somalia's collapse now seek to prevent Somalia's rescue and to destroy all that has so far been achieved. They must not succeed. We must show ourselves to be resolute and firm as we confront the challenges ahead."
But the call by Mr. Boutros-Ghali found little support on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Clinton was considering three basic options. One, now being urged by many in Congress, is to pull American forces off shore. The danger with that option, officials said, is that although the 4,700 American troops are just a fraction of the 28,000-member United Nations force in Somalia, they are its backbone, and it is highly likely that the whole peacekeeping force from 33 nations would collapse.
 
Possibility of Discredit
 Some 3,000 American troops perform logistics, providing water, food and transportation for all the other units. About 1,300 other Americans, bolstered recently by 400 Rangers, make up the Quick Reaction Force, which was intended to provide rapid support for other nations' peacekeeping units that found themselves under attack.
But the other argument against a quick pullout -- that the Administration would be discredited around the world and even at home -- is dismissed by some top Presidential advisers.
Their view is that the world understands very well the difference between vital American interests and ones like Somalia that are not vital. Therefore, even if the United States pulls out, no one would be misled into thinking that the United States is not ready to stand and fight when its vital interests are at stake.
When the Reagan Administration suddenly pulled out of the peacekeeping in Lebanon in 1982, many analysts argued that American credibility in the Middle East would never be the same. But as soon as Washington demonstrated its resolve in the Persian Gulf war, that perception vanished.
The second option, officials say, is to go to the other extreme and beef up the military presence in Somalia to a point where it can break the back of General Aidid's opposition movement.
The problem with that, a senior official said, is that it could effectively mean "going to war with Somalia in order to save Somalia."
"Clearly our goal has not changed -- that is, to restore order so that humanitarian relief can continue," the official said. "But given the active opposition of Aidid, what is involved in doing that is a much larger effort. We have to decide: do we raise the ante to meet him? And by raising the ante, do we increase the likelihood that we will be going to war against Somalia so that we can never really achieve our original goals?"
 
Examination of a Third Option
 Summing up the first two options, the official said, "In one case you kill Somalia by going to war to save it, and the other case you kill Somalia by not going to war to save it."
This leaves a third option, officials said, a new mix of political and military steps that would upgrade the American presence so that troops will be somewhat better able to protect themselves and provide a secure environment.
The head of the United States Central Command, Gen. Joseph Hoar, the overall commander of American forces in Somalia, met this afternoon for two hours with the Joint Chiefs of Staff to discuss Somalia. General Hoar counseled against dispatching many more troops, officials said.
One military option under consideration, though, is sending two additional Marine amphibious groups. That would involve 3,800 marines and several ships, but would certainly give American forces on the ground greater strength.
Judging from their public comments, the Clinton team is heading toward some variation of the third option. Mr. Christopher said today that with the attacks on United Nations forces over the weekend and American personnel missing, "it certainly is not the time for us to depart."
Mr. Christopher said the United States wanted to withdraw its forces when possible, "but not before our job is done of providing some security."
"At the same time," he added, "it is vital that a political solution be sought there."

 Established in May 1993 to take over from the U.S.-led humanitarian operation which began in December 1992.
 
MANDATE: Establish a secure environment throughout Somalia for humanitarian assistance, disarmament, reconciliation, restoration of peace, law and order, economic reconstruction, rebuilding social and political institutions, recreate a Somali state.
 
PERSONNEL: Involves about 28,000 troops, 4,400 of them Americans. Countries contributing include: Argentina, Australia, Bangladesh, Belgium, Botswana, Egypt, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Ireland, Italy, Jordan, Malaysia, Morocco, Namibia, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Pakistan, South Korea, Romania, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Tunisia, Turkey, Uganda, United Arab Emirates, the United States, Zambia, Zimbabwe.
 
CASUALTIES: 69 dead, more than 200 wounded.
 
BUDGET: $1.55 billion for 12 months.
 
COMMANDERS: Jonathan T. Howe, a retired American admiral and now a special representative of the United Nations Secretary General, is in overall charge of the operation. The force commander is Lieut. Gen. Cevik Bir of Turkey. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS HAIL YELTSIN FOES' ROUT

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
American officials expressed hope today that the defeat of President Boris N. Yeltsin's opponents in Moscow had swept aside the vestiges of the old Soviet system. But they said they remained unsure that the opening would make way for true democracy.
With their vision of a democratic Russia still embodied almost solely in Mr. Yeltsin, the officials said they recognized that the path toward democratization remained littered with obstacles within Russian society and perhaps presented by the Russian President himself. 
 In a telephone conversation with President Clinton today, their first since violence erupted in Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin renewed his pledge to hold free parliamentary elections on Dec. 12 and "to proceed resolutely on political and economic reform," a White House spokesman said.
 
A Sense of Relief
 Across the Administration, there was a powerful sense of relief today that Mr. Yeltsin had triumphed in his showdown, and that he had done so at a smaller human cost than was initially feared.
But an initial American headiness at Mr. Yeltsin's subduing of his foes was tinged with some apprehension about what lies ahead. Officials said they were concerned that in a country lacking a democratic tradition, the elections could be sidetracked, run into logistical problems or produce another parliament unfriendly to reform.
Clinton Administration officials said they would be watching particularly closely to see whether Mr. Yeltsin, who used Government television stations as an instrument in his standoff with Parliament, would prove willing to allow the press freedoms necessary for a fair ballot.
Today, Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island and the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, made clear that such conduct would also be a focus of concern in Congress, which holds the purse strings on Russian aid.
Thomas Pickering, the American Ambassador to Moscow, today described the elections promised by Mr. Yeltsin as "a significant factor in whether he can institutionalize the new democracy in Russia." But he also spoke of "the wide-ranging views" continuing to divide Russia even after the quelling of the parliamentary revolt.
 
Envoy Expresses Confidence
 In a television interview, Mr. Pickering hinted at what remains the unspoken worry of American policy, expressing confidence in Mr. Yeltsin's leadership "if he maintains his democratic credentials."
Without election law, electoral districts or a political party system, Mr. Yeltsin's pledge to hold free and fair parliamentary elections by Dec. 13 will not be simple to fulfill. And while Clinton Administration officials continued to express confidence in the Russian President's commitment to reform, the events of recent days have served as an uncomfortable reminder of a leader who has displayed an unpredictable streak.
In the most optimistic scenario, the December elections will establish in Russia a new cadre of legitimate, democratic leaders, making it possible for Washington to grow less reliant on Mr. Yeltsin even before he convenes presidential elections in June.
But that outcome relies not just on Russian sentiment, but on Mr. Yeltsin's health, which has been far from perfect. And American officials said today that it would also depend on how quickly he was willing to relax the controls he had imposed on the news media and his political opponents.
At the State Department's daily briefing, a spokesman said the United States had "every indication from the Yeltsin Government" that the restrictions would be no more than temporary. As a sign of Russian intentions, Mr. Pickering and others said they took heart in Mr. Yeltsin's apparent decision to free all but the leaders among the parliamentary rebels in Moscow.

HEADLINE: The Deepest Dive Yet For Gulf of Mexico Oil

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it would spend $1.2 billion to bring into production a giant oilfield in the Gulf of Mexico, a project intended to push offshore-recovery technology to the deepest levels yet and to create 2,200 jobs, most in Texas and Louisiana, and thousands more among subcontractors in 34 states.
The announcement, made in Houston, was welcome news to the domestic oil industry, which in the last year has seen its drilling activity at the lowest level in decades amid falling prices for crude oil and a slowdown in the rate of increased demand for gasoline and other petroleum products. 
 The company said that in the first phase of the project, it hoped to recover about 500 million barrels of oil. It intends to begin production in 1996 at a daily rate of about 100,000 barrels of oil and 110 million cubic feet of gas.
"It's a very significant project," said Fred Leuffer, an oil analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "It's also going to be very profitable."
Indeed, the domestic oil industry has not seen a project of such size and technological challenge in about a decade and in the gulf in the last 20 years.
Still, Jack E. Little, executive vice president for exploration and production at Shell, said that such quantities would have only a small effect on oil imports. These now total more than seven million barrels a day and account for about half of American consumption.
The recession, and the slump in oil prices -- which are now near a four-year low, settling late today at $18.39 for benchmark West Texas intermediate crude -- have led to a prolonged decline in exploration, drilling, refining and related activity, with the loss of about half a million jobs.
Although it was well known within the industry that Shell had been working for years to prepare to develop the field in the Gulf of Mexico, the industrywide slump created uncertainty whether the company would go ahead with such a major project.
Over the last decade, Shell has been a pioneer in offshore development and has taken steps leading toward yesterday's announcement. Shell struck the huge field, called Mars, in 1989 on a block in the Mississippi Canyon, which is about 130 miles southeast of New Orleans. The company estimates that about 700 million barrels of oil can be recovered from the field.
Mr. Little said that by gulf standards, a field that yielded 100 million barrels was considered a giant find.
 
Other Efforts by Shell
 Shell Oil is building another platfrom in the Auger field in the gulf, at a depth of 2,860 feet, and at about the same cost. It estimates it will recover 250 million barrels of oil from the project, which was announced in 1989.
Mr. Leuffer, the Bear, Stearns analyst, said the Mars project would bring twice the oil for about the same investment, making it a very attractive venture for Shell.
He added that it could encourage other companies, notably Amoco, which have found oil in deep water in the gulf, to begin to extract it. And Mr. Leuffer said that British Petroleum, which has a 28.5 percent interest in the Shell project, would benefit, too.
"While the potential is very great, the challenge is also very great," Philip J. Carroll, the president of Shell Oil, said at a news conference yesterday at Shell's headquarters in Houston.
The development will be watched by the oil industry because Shell will install a tension-leg platform in a depth of 2,933 feet, the deepest offshore recovery platform yet. That is 203 feet more than if the two World Trade Towers stood one atop the other, and greater, too, than most other American skyscrapers.
Tension-leg platforms, made of steel and concrete, are anchored to the ocean floor by vertical tendons that eliminate up and down motion. Twenty-four production wells are to be placed on the platform. Once the platform has been built, a staff of about 25 will be needed to run it.
 
Vicissitudes of Geology
 The technology has been 10 years in the making and could enable companies to begin to get oil out of fields that had been thought too expensive and risky to develop.
The idea of a tension-leg platform was first explored about 20 years ago, but was not proved until Conoco built one in the Hutton field in the North Sea in 1984.
In addition, improvements in seismic reading have enabled Shell to go ahead. The geology at such deep ocean levels is different from that of fields in shallower water.
Mr. Little said that because of the greater depth and geological considerations, Shell would approach the Mars project in phases, adding, "Mars represents a departure from the way we have traditionally developed fields in the gulf."
The wells are expected to be much more productive, yielding about 5,000 barrels a day each, five times that of the average well in the gulf, which yields about 1,000 barrels.
Shell has the largest operation in the gulf, with about 500 tracts under lease -- roughly 2.5 million acres. This represents about a third of areas leased by the entire industry.


GRAPHIC: Shell's plan to develop the Mars oilfield depends on building offshore rigs that can extract oil at depths below 2,933 feet in the Gulf of Mexico, the deepest attempted so far. One platform would handle the flow from 24 wells on the sea floor.

 A floating concrete and steel platform is tethered to the sea bottom by cables so taut that the platform does not move up or down with waves or tides.

HEADLINE: A.M.A. Says Compromise Is Possible on Budgets

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The American Medical Association soft-pedaled its unhappiness with parts of President Clinton's health plan in Senate testimony today, saying it could even agree to overall national health care budgets if doctors were involved in setting them.
Meanwhile, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, faced a flurry of questions today when she appeared in two House hearings. She said the Administration would deliver its bill in two weeks, in answer to Republicans who repeatedly complained that it was hard to focus on an unfinished proposal. 
 The A.M.A. has called on its members to lobby patients against financial restrictions on health care, including cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid and limits on the cost of insurance premiums. So Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, asked Dr. James S. Todd, the A.M.A.'s executive vice president, whether the group was so dissatisfied that it could not work on developing the plan.
Dr. Todd replied: "Absolutely not. The need for reform is now. The President has provided a good foundation from which to start. We have found him to be responsive to some of the concerns which we have raised; we need to go forward with the President, with this committee and with the Congress and get it done."
 
Praises and Worries
 He was one of five spokesmen for major organizations of doctors, hospitals and nurses who testified and praised the Clinton plan in general terms, while raising particular concerns over whether it would provide enough money for nurses' training, whether its overall timetable was impracticably rapid and whether Medicare should be integrated into the proposed new system.
Of the groups testifying today, those representing hospitals and doctors have fought recent national health care efforts. But today Dr. Robert Graham, executive vice president of the American Academy of Family Practice, rebuffed Republican senators who tried to get him to say that the President's plan involved limiting choices.
He said the plan "maintains pluralism." In any event, he said, patients have less and less room in the current system to choose their doctors.
 
The Abortion Factor
 Sister Maryanna Coyle, head of the board of the Catholic Health Association of the United States, said that while the organization was firmly against including abortion coverage in a plan, it was not saying it would oppose the bill solely for that reason.
In the House, Ms. Shalala's businesslike reception by the Energy and Commerce Committee and the Ways and Means Committee provided a clear contrast with the amiable way Hillary Rodham Clinton was greeted on Capitol Hill last week.
Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, began, "Let me say, first, Dr. Shalala, I would have strongly preferred that your testimony be based on an introduced bill so that all members could work off actual legislative language and not just the unofficial Sept. 7 draft document."
Mr. Bliley added that he was particularly intent on getting more details from the Administration on its financing. "I am not aware of one independent health care expert or economist who has found your financing and cost containment proposals credible," he said.
Ms. Shalala said a bill would be submitted in about two weeks. She also indicated that some of the financing details were not settled, including planned subsidy levels for small business. At one point, under questioning from Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Energy and Commerce Committee, she said, "We're not actually locking ourselves into any of the subsidy numbers at this moment."
Ms. Shalala also played down the size of the bureaucracy that would be created under the proposal. The National Health Board, she said, would be "a relatively minor oversight group" with a staff of about 100. She also said she hoped the regional health alliances that would negotiate insurance purchases for its members would be "lean and mean."
 
Complaints of Vagueness
 This afternoon, at the House Ways and Means Committee, she encountered the same complaints about vagueness from Democrats.
Representative Pete Stark of California, chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said, "I have my doubts about the advisability of enacting a comprehensive benefit package for the under-65 population which is substantially more generous than the benefit package guaranteed under Medicare to my mother."
Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, said, "Until we get legislation, we're just going to be talking generalities."

She spoke with Representative Pete Stark before a Ways and Means Committee appearance. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On the Plains, a Huge Rail Yard Starts to Hum

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH PLATTE, Neb.

 BODY:
Day and night, freight trains up to one and a half miles long rumble past Buffalo Bill Cody's ranch on the outskirts of town and into the world's biggest railroad yard in a rhythm that seems to gauge the nation's economic pulse more plausibly than any Government statistic.
More than half of Union Pacific's traffic moves through the Bailey Yard, a web of 250 miles of track and 800 switches on which cars from all directions pause briefly in cross-country treks carrying plywood, tires, sugar, bicycles, grain and a myriad of other raw materials and manufactures. 
 From the air, Bailey seems part of a silent but impossibly intricate model railroad, the east classification yard alone being 64 tracks wide. The view from the ground, though, is both gritty and high-tech as nearly 3,000 cars a day are uncoupled and -- at exactly 4 miles an hour -- recoupled to the sound of thunks and squeals.
And what's happening in the Bailey Yard as autumn begins is quickened activity, a pace associated with economic expansion and, if product patterns hold, probably further pickup in the months ahead.
 
Economics Are Promising
 "The volumes have grown so much we've gotten to the point where we're hiring new people," said Cathy Andrews, the 2,000-employee yard's manager for quality and reliability. "The business is definitely there."
The Union Pacific is more diversified in its freight than many carriers, with routes stretching from New Orleans to Canada and to all the major West Coast ports. The Bailey Yard thus provides a useful window through which to view the United States economy, a microcosm of what, and how much, is being produced, sold and shipped.
After making allowances for the likes of summer flooding and the installation of concrete ties in the 125-mile corridor between here and Gibbon, Neb., the busiest freight corridor on earth, the Union Pacific is rolling well.
"Right now, we're running flat out," James A. Shattuck, the railroad's executive vice president for marketing, said in an interview at railroad headquarters in Omaha, the city through which President Lincoln himself decided the transcontinental railroad would move west. "We look for a strong fourth quarter."
[On Sept. 30, the Union Pacific set a system record of 97,787 cars loaded in a seven-day period, 3 percent more than in the comparable 1992 week. On Oct. 4 the railroad broke its seven-day carloading record again -- 98,221 cars, 5 percent above the 1992 period.]
For the Bailey Yard, where trains are disassembled one or two cars at a time and sent rolling over a hump and down an incline to be reconfigured into new trains, the year-to-year comparisons are striking.
 
Increases Each Month
 Trains built here rose each month from May through August, by an average 11 percent from 1992 periods, after posting declines in three of the first four months of the year.
At the same time, however, the figures as well as anecdotal and other information gleaned in a two-day visit to Nebraska in late September and some follow-up phone calls, are subject to various interpretation. This includes the possibility that livelier train activity here may reflect a business pickup already on the wane.
For decades, economists paid close attention to rail carloadings as a barometer of business activity, but truck tonnage, reflecting a growing share of the market, gradually supplanted it during the 1970's. Carloadings still tell a tale, particularly now that trucks themselves are increasingly likely to make part of their journeys aboard trains.
And the widespread adoption of just-in-time inventory practices by corporations has also helped improve carloadings as an indicator of economic health. In this strategy, components are shipped to factories only as they are needed, causing orders to fluctuate more directly with demand.
Still, officials caution that the various figures are just erratic enough to make trends hard to discern. For example, truck trailers and ship containers making part of their journey by rail had been falling short of the targets set, suggesting to some a 1993 holiday shopping season less robust than last year's. September-October is a peak period for carrying imported goods from the Far East like electronics.
Lately, however, shipments have accelerated. According to Tim J. Rhein, president of APL Land Transport Services, a shipping line affiliate that is the Union Pacific's biggest customer, imports are "pretty strong" and about equal to the 1992 pace. What Mr. Rhein wonders about is what happens after these goods arrive to replenish generally low stocks on merchants' shelves.
"I still don't see where people are getting the money to buy," he said.
Richard K. Davidson, the Union Pacific's chairman, frets about drag from weak overseas economies and what he sees as lackluster demand for such basics as lumber, paper and building products. "The economy is just not that vibrant," he said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Davidson projects a 4 percent to 5 percent traffic gain in 1994, partly reflecting a larger share of the market. This year, with floods costing it 47,000 carloads -- less than half of which is likely to be recovered -- the Union Pacific expects to post a 3.5 percent gain, shy of its 5 percent goal.
In the aggregate, carloadings are generally regarded by economists as coincident indicators, those that move about the same time as the economy at large. But Union Pacific officials, who estimate that two-thirds of what the railroad carries is sensitive to the business cycle (grain and coal for utilities are relatively unaffected), find that the goods showing the most variation do not provide much help to forecasters. And much rail data tend to look backward, rather than forward, in economic time.
 
Autos and Forecasting
 "In looking at past recessionary periods, we found that the automobile business actually lags because what typically happens is that the manufacturers make one last push to get inventory out into the field," said J. J. (Jack) Koraleski, executive vice president for finance and information technologies. "So even after things have cooled down, we can see our automobile business keep up."
During the first 24 weeks of this year, until flooding began, the Union Pacific carried 7.7 percent more carloads of motor vehicles and other equipment like tractors than it did in the comparable 1992 period.
Other products seem to lag less or perhaps not at all. "When you see chemicals heating up, it's usually that the economy's starting to turn around," Mr. Shattuck said. This spring, chemicals matched their best quarter in nearly three years.
But those more optimistic than Mr. Davidson, who associates say is typically cautious, point to iron, copper, lead and other metals -- demand for which the economics fraternity widely accepts as leading, or predictive, indicators.
Shipments of metallic ores on the Union Pacific spurted 6.6 percent during the first half of 1993, while coke, used for making steel, jumped 9.9 percent. Crushed stone and other construction materials are also perking up, causing some congestion in Texas, where much of this material is both produced and consumed.
"We can really see when they have a good highway program or something going," Mr. Shattuck said. "It reflects itself pretty considerably in our numbers."

HEADLINE: Arts World: Many Tiny Economic Stars

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
For all the acknowledged importance of Broadway theater, Woody Allen's movies or a blockbuster show at the Museum of Modern Art, a new study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has found that the arts in New York exert their greatest economic impact through a myriad of far smaller and more obscure enterprises and organizations.
According to the comprehensive, yearlong research project, the arts and other cultural activities have grown substantially in importance over the last decade. They now pump at least $9.8 billion a year into the New York metropolitan area and, directly and indirectly, support more than 107,000 jobs. The arts directly employ some 41,000, appreciably more than the 36,000 employed in advertising. 
 "This sector of the regional economy has grown even as the region itself has suffered through difficult times," the study found.
Within the New York-New Jersey region that the Port Authority serves, the arts remain largely concentrated in the city. It accounted for 91 percent of the direct jobs and 93 percent of total expenditures by cultural institutions.
 
A Broad Reach
 The authors argue that the very diversity of New York's extensive cultural complex has helped it thrive: "stimulating it to grow some 14 percent in real terms over the 10 years. In many ways it was the creativity of the institutions themselves that allowed them to prosper, increasing their revenues from operations and concessions sales to fuel their growth."
While giant institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Lincoln Center are highly visible, the authors concluded that the strength of the cultural community rests on thousands of individuals and organizations who make toe shoes for ballet dancers, build stage sets for dramatic productions, devise lighting for television commercials and produce buffets for movie crews.
"Today the cultural world extends far beyond Madison Avenue and SoHo art galleries and is not just those museums and institutions within a mile of Central Park," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University and an adviser to the study group.
The sponsors of the report -- which include the business-supported New York City Partnership and the Partnership for New Jersey -- intend to use the findings to lobby for additional backing for the arts from public agencies. While the City of New York, after a round of cuts in 1991, has largely maintained its arts budget, state and Federal support for cultural activities has fallen sharply since the late 1980's as the recession has carved a deep hole out of government tax revenues.
 
Theater-in-Meadowlands
 But louder voices are also clamoring for Albany's attention. Local leaders of the arts complain that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo largely ignores the contribution of cultural activities, but bends over backward to respond to the threat by George M. Steinbrenner 3d, principal owner of the New York Yankees, to move his baseball team out of the Bronx. The Governor has suggested building a $500 million stadium in Manhattan if that is necessary to prevent the Yankees from leaving for the Meadowlands in New Jersey.
"Twice as many people go to theater, dance, museums and concerts as all the sports combined in New York," declared Martin E. Segal, chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts. "The Governor is charming, intelligent, a marvelous orator, but he doesn't go to the cultural attractions of the city." Gerald Schoenfeld, president of the Shubert Organization, which owns 16 Broadway theaters, said: "Unfortunately, we can't exactly pick up and move, but what you do see is that nobody has built a new theater in New York for a very long time."
Vincent Tese, director of the state's Urban Development Corporation, replied: "I don't think that keeping the Yankees is counterproductive to the state's involvement in the arts. I understand there is frustration that the arts got cut back in the recession, like everything else. That should improve as the economy recovers. But the important thing to remember is that we need to maintain a critical mass of all types of entertainment and culture."
Another state official joked, "When Lincoln Center says they are going to move to New Jersey, we'll pay attention."
The study found that visitors to New York for the City's cultural offerings generated an estimated $2.3 billion a year in economic activity, up by 13 percent in real terms from 1982.
The report was supported by foundations, business groups and arts organizations and it is the first installment of a larger $650,000 study of the impact of tourism and the arts.
To some extent, the rosy health of the arts in New York today may serve to undermine its advocates' case for greater government support. Since most cultural institutions have managed to survive and even expand on their own despite recent public austerity, state officials argue that other recipients have greater needs.
But supporters of the arts contend that that is a short-sighted view. Investment in cultural activities pays big dividends, they say.
Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, is leading the effort to build a large $200 million to $250 million cultural complex, similar in scale to Lincoln Center, in downtown Newark. At least 625 new construction jobs will be created directly in the initial phase, and Mr. Goldman said he hoped to attract as many as 650,000 visitors a year once the center is completed, providing permanent employment at the center for more than 470 people. The ripple effect would help support 6,700 jobs in Newark, according to an economic analysis of the project.
"An arts center is not something that is in the exclusive province of the culturally elite," Mr. Goldman said. "People in Newark and other central cities also need things to be proud of."
 
'Part of the Infrastructure'
 While most of the money to expand such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Guggenheim Museum was raised privately during the Wall Street boom of the 1980's, government funds also helped fuel what Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts, a nonprofit organization that represents a wide range of local cultural institutions, called "the greatest period of building cultural institutions in this region since the 19th century." He said that the decadelong investment of $1.5 billion, which followed years of public and private neglect, "is now an unequaled part of the infrastructure of the city, just like bridges, roads and mass transit."
As in the broader society, though, New York's 80's business boom and subsequent bust helped widen the gap between the cultural haves and have-nots.
Private art collecting soared, helping boost the economic impact of roughly 500 major art galleries and auction houses by 48 percent from 1982 to 1992, to a total of $840 million in payrolls and purchases. That measure excludes the value of art bought and sold.
With the nonprofit sector, which includes nearly 1,400 institutions -- museums, dance companies, orchestras and numerous other arts organizations -- growth was concentrated in prominent large institutions. In recent years some smaller nonprofit groups have been forced to close and others have shrunk.
"An across-the-board cut may look equitable on the surface, but when you recognize that smaller institutions are more dependent on public dollars, they suffer more," said Kinshasha Holman Conwill, director of the Studio Museum of Harlem.

HEADLINE: Bellwether Area Cool to Whitman

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Sept. 30

 BODY:
If Middlesex County is any indication, and Middlesex County usually is, Christine Todd Whitman has run smack into a wall of voter skepticism in her bid to defeat Gov. Jim Florio.
Here in the heart of New Jersey, in the blue-collar neighborhoods of Carteret and along the cheek-to-jowl strip malls of Route 1, Mrs. Whitman's anti-Florio message and promises of economic reform seem to have fallen largely on disbelieving ears. 
 "Her program is not realistic," said Hunter Ward, a carpenter who stood last week outside a department store under construction in New Brunswick, protesting what he said was the use of nonunion workers inside. "How can she cut taxes by 30 percent? No way can you do it without cutting services."
Traditionally hardcore Democratic, but with a Reagan Democrat streak, the county has a history of going with the winner in nearly every important race: Ronald Reagan in 1980, George Bush in 1988 and Bill Clinton last year. In one notable exception, the county picked Mr. Florio over Thomas Kean in the 1981 race for governor.
Middlesex County's political importance lies in its size -- its block of 339,448 registered voters is surpassed only by the huge population centers of Bergen County and Essex County -- and its eclectic mix of residents who have become a bellwether for New Jersey politics.
The county is home to factories, oil refineries, farms, sprawling office parks, Rutgers University and some of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies.
Unemployment in the county stood at 6.9 percent in August, just below the statewide rate of 7.1 percent. The rate has risen steadily from 3.3 percent in 1989.
It would unfair to say that campaign fever has hit Middlesex County. Many residents stopped at random last week said they were not that interested in the governor's race.
"I haven't been paying that much attention, to be honest," said one young woman quizzed at a beauty parlor in Edison Township. "Maybe you should try the bank next door. The people there are older."
 
Questions of Qualification
 But the voters who are paying attention expressed a common theme. Although disappointed with Mr. Florio or still angry with him for ushering through a record $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990, they do not see Mrs. Whitman as a viable alternative.
"I really don't think she's going to be too qualified," said Ann Cunningham of Edison, who was shopping at a supermarket on Route 1. "I think the state's going to be in worse shape than it is if she wins. I guess he's the better of two evils."
Mrs. Whitman, the Republican candidate who almost upset Senator Bill Bradley in 1990, entered the race for governor hoping to capitalize on lingering voter anger against Mr. Florio over the tax increase, and, to be sure, plenty of that anger remains.
"I probably wouldn't vote for the Governor now," said Robert Kay, who manages a video store in Edison. "I just don't like the way things are now. I don't like the taxes."
Mrs. Whitman has tried to rekindle that anger by accusing Mr. Florio of misrepresenting the state's fiscal situation in 1990. At a news conference this week, Mrs. Whitman said Mr. Florio exaggerated the size of the deficit he faced upon taking office to justify his decision to raise taxes.
"He wanted to raise taxes in order to increase spending," she said.
 
Elections and Lies
 But a surprising number of voters seem to have forgiven Mr. Florio. They say they believe him when he says he had no choice.
"When he raised taxes everybody was up in arms," said Lillian Handerhand, who oversees senior citizen programs for the city of Perth Amboy. "But with the good that it has done, I think everybody now says, 'Well, we needed it.' I think they understand more than they thought they would."
Phil Milazzo, who operates two small convenience stores in Edison, said he disliked Mr. Florio's raising taxes after promising not to do so. He even believes the governor intended to raise taxes all along. Still, he will not hold any of that against Mr. Florio on Election Day.
"He's a politician," Mr. Milazzo said. "He's not going to get in if he doesn't lie to people. People don't want to hear the truth."
Mr. Milazzo said he did not know much about Mrs. Whitman except that she was wealthy and that she had proposed cutting the state income tax by 30 percent over three years.
"I don't see how she's going to do that," he said. "It's a nice thought," he said. "But my first impression is that she is lying."
 
Commercials Have Effect
 What little else he knows about the candidate has come largely from a string of negative commercials run by the Florio campaign. Although Mr. Milazzo said he realized that the commercials may distort Mrs. Whitman's views, he acknowledged they had affected his thinking.
He said Mrs. Whitman seemed wealthy, stiff and out-of-touch with the way most people live.
"I didn't like the idea that her husband made about $4 million last year," he said. "It's hard for her to say, 'Yeah, I'm a down-to-earth person.' "
Mrs. Whitman has also staked her candidacy on her tax cut proposals, which she says will stimulate the economy and create jobs in New Jersey. But Mrs. Handerhan of Perth Amboy is skeptical.
"That's not easy to do," she said. "You can say anything you want before an election. The question is are you going to come through after the election."
John Craig, a photographer in Edison, said many of his friends who were considering voting for Mrs. Whitman before she announced her tax cut plan were now questioning her thinking, and her honesty.
"She stretched the bounds of credibility when she came out with that tax cut," Mr. Craig said.
 
Local Parties Reinvigorated
 Still, Republican Party officials say they believe Mrs. Whitman will carry the county in November. Although registered Democrats still outnumber Republicans three-to-one, the Republicans have managed to break the stranglehold Democrats held on Middlesex for six decades.
In the backlash of public anger over the state tax increase, voters in 1991 gave Republicans control of the County Board of Chosen Freeholders for the first time this century. Republicans claim either the mayor or a majority of council members in 12 of the counties' 25 towns.
On the state level, the county, which includes parts of five legislative districts, is represented by four senators and eight assembly members who are Republican and one senator and two assembly members who are Democratic.
"We have built a base there for Republicans," said the county Republican chairman, Sam Thompson. "It's a very different picture than you might have seen five years ago when you could just take it and stick it in the Democrat column."
But Democratic officials are much more optimistic about their candidate's chances in Middlesex County than they were two years ago.
The Democratic Party organization has been reinvigorated by a 1992 reform movement that gave more decision-making power to the 1,200 committee people, said Democratic county chairman Harry Pozycki.
Mr. Pozycki said he believed the reenergize party bodes well for Mr. Florio in Middlesex County.
"Because of this new enthusiasm, people are willing to engage in one-on-one conversations with their neighbors," he said. "All the candidates report being much more warmly received that in the past two years."

HEADLINE: LOAN GUARANTEES FOR ISRAEL ARE CUT

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has slashed the loan guarantees that it will give Israel next year because of Israel's continued settlement in the occupied territories and its disputed construction in East Jerusalem, officials here said today.
Instead of receiving guarantees on $2 billion, Israel will have to settle for assurances on less than $1.6 billion. In all, the officials said, the Administration has recommended to Congress that $437 million be sliced from the program, a dollar-for-dollar penalty because of Israeli spending on settlements in the territories. 
 Israeli officials had expected a reduction, but not such a large one, and the action raises a question of whether Israel might challenge it either in Congress or by asking Mr. Clinton to reconsider the issue. Some Israelis see the cut as a political blow to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, even though the economic consequences may not be severe.
No issue has created greater tensions between Israel and the United States in recent years than the $10 billion worth of guarantees, spread over five years in annual installments of $2 billion. Some Israeli economists question whether the assistance is even needed, but the Government insists that it is and it used the guarantees to borrow the full $2 billion in 1993, the first year of the program.
 
Request to Bush
 Originally the idea was to help Israel absorb a huge wave of arrivals from the former Soviet Union. But with immigration down, the assistance has evolved into a more general development program, including an opportunity to reduce borrowing costs. What the United States provides are not actual loans, but rather assurances that it will cover the debts should Israel default -- something that officials here say has never happened and never will.
In 1991, Yitzhak Shamir, who was then Prime Minister, asked President George Bush for the guarantees. In no time the guarantees turned from an economic issue into a political battle, largely over Mr. Bush's strong displeasure with Mr. Shamir's aggressive policy of building settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Mr. Bush withheld the assistance until Mr. Rabin's Labor Party was elected in June 1992 on a promise to change spending priorities.
Against that background, the big chunk taken out of the total for the 1994 United States fiscal year, which began on Friday, was seen by some officials here as a political blow. The fact that it was delivered by an Administration regarded as one of the friendliest that this country has seen in many years only intensified the sting.
 
'Timing of the Slap Is Crazy'
 "Technically it's a fine on paper that may not even hurt the Israelis," an official of an American Jewish group said. "But it's a slap, and the timing of the slap is crazy." By that he meant that it occurs at a moment that many Israelis feel they are taking considerable risks by agreeing to Palestinian self-rule in the territories.
But Israeli Government spokesmen insisted that they were not caught off-guard by the Administration action. It was based on spending figures that they had provided, as required under the guarantee agreement, they said. They knew that they faced penalties, they added, and there was no way for Mr. Rabin to reverse Mr. Shamir's settlements policy fully.
