HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
1968, Soaked in Student Blood, Refuses to Fade

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Francisco Buendia was not born when angry students shook this city with demonstrations as it prepared to be host to the 1968 Olympic Games. Although he looks something like a throwback in shredded jeans and long hair, he conceded that he was not much of a counterculturalist, either.
"I agree with the economic modernization of this country," Mr. Buendia, 20, a student, said, lowering his voice lest other protesters overhear him. Referring to accords that Mexico has signed with Canada and the United States, he added, "I'm probably one of the only people here who supports the free-trade agreement." 
 But there was Mr. Buendia on Saturday, one of thousands of young people who tramped through the rain in demonstrations to commemorate the student movement that flowered here 25 years ago and the army massacre that crushed it on Oct. 2. "I owe the students from those days a lot," he said. "This struggle is not over."
For all the nostalgia that the year holds for reluctantly middle-age people from California to the Czech Republic, the power of 1968 is different in Mexico. Here the moment is inevitably represented as a wound or scar, one that will not or cannot heal.
 
Silence on Files and Death Toll
 Even after 25 years the Government has yet to account fully for what occurred on the evening when the army fired on the 5,000 or 10,000 protesters gathered in the square of a housing project called Tlatelolco. Dozens, perhaps hundreds, were killed, and more than 1,000 were wounded. But lists of the dead are only now being compiled by a group of intellectuals who have volunteered to investigate.
When thousands of people marched to the Tlatelolco square on the anniversary of the killings on Saturday chanting for the release of official files on the shooting, the Government answered with silence. Last year, when the shooting was so much as mentioned in new elementary-school history textbooks, military leaders became incensed. When the books were provisionally rewritten the chronology stopped before 1968.
Few officials question that the killings helped destroy myths that had until 1968 helped hold together Mexican society -- a legitimate Government and a sacrosanct President; a clear, bright future, and a broad national consensus. Yet as the generation that was studying in 1968 has taken political hold -- President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and many important aides were in college then -- the legacy of the movement has continued to divide Mexico deeply.
 
'Never Joined in the Questioning'
 "The men in power now learned a great deal from 1968," said Lorenzo Meyer, a leading historian who is campaigning for the release of the files. "But they never joined in the questioning of authority. Their question was, 'What do we have to change in order to remain in power?' "
The demands that fueled the movement, drawing as many as 350,000 people to the main square, the Zocalo, included greater autonomy for the universities and freedom for political prisoners. As it has been handed down to students today the goal takes a simpler form. Then as now, current and former students say, the struggle is for democracy.
"Of that great wave of '68, France and Czechoslovakia and the United States and Germany, they don't still do this anywhere else," a former student leader, Pedro Penalosa, 45, said. "In all of those other countries the basic problems of democracy have been resolved."
As he looked out at the demonstrators on the Zocalo again Mr. Penalosa recounted an odyssey that is in some ways typical. From radical groups, he moved through small leftist parties, serving as a member of congress in the 80's. After the 1988 presidential election, he joined the governing-party dissident who ran against Mr. Salinas, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, and he helped focus the left on issues like electoral fraud and the iniquities of political competition.
Standing nearby at the demonstration, a lawyer in a pin-striped suit, Manuel Reyes Retana, 50, said he could not disagree more with Mr. Penalosa. "What all of this achieved is that these people can be out here saying whatever they want," said Mr. Reyes, who joined the movement as a young law student. "All of this asking for democracy is just about trying to make the country look bad."
Nodding to a group of young long-haired men, he added: "These kids don't know what repression is. They have never been repressed like we were."
In 1968, Mr. Salinas was a 20-year-old economics student at the National Autonomous University of Mexico and the son of a former cabinet minister. But neither he nor any of the 40-ish men in his cabinet are known to have joined the marches.
Although a few former student leaders have joined the Administration in lesser roles, the man who is perhaps most associated with Tlatelolco in the Administration is Manuel Camacho Solis, a student friend and close adviser of the President. Now Mayor of Mexico City and an undeclared candidate to succeed Mr. Salinas, Mr. Camacho has insistently advocated talks rather than force to defuse opposition protests. That strategy has helped restore the governing party's strength in the capital.
 
Essayist on Problems
 Months after the massacre Mr. Camacho won a national student prize for an essay on political and economic problems. The work quoted Mao and spoke of an urgent need to organize the masses. But Mr. Camacho argued that only the Government had been able to win the support of "the great majorities." He dismissed the students' alternatives as "confusing in the extreme" and condemned to complete failure.
Later Mr. Camacho met President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, a move that would have been unthinkable for many other students.
Once each week now in a small cafe above a bookstore a group of intellectuals has been interviewing old students, formalizing requests for interviews with former officials and writing to request the declassifying of Government documents. By year's end, the group says, it hopes to have a preliminary report on what occurred 25 years ago.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pitch on Health Takes Zigs and Zags

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CULVER CITY, Calif., Oct. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton's appearance at a picturesque park here today was staged with utmost care to take advantage of all of the things the Administration wanted to emphasize this week. Most of the crowd was elderly and they all lived in California, a state that remains crucial to Mr. Clinton's political success. The topic was health care.
But after little more than half an hour of reassuring his audience that Medicare benefits would not be cut, the President apologized and ducked offstage to his waiting motorcade and rushed back to Washington to meet with his national security advisers on developments in Somalia, leaving a policy adviser, Ira C. Magaziner, behind. 
 The onlookers, many of whom had been bused into the site, streamed away anyway, forcing the event's organizer to plead with them to stay.
"Buses will not leave until Mr. Magaziner has had an opportunity to answer questions," said Judith Brown, a board member of the American Association of Retired Persons as she watched the elaborate health care forum disintegrate before her eyes.
 
Series of Obstacles
 It has been like that for three days for the Administration's great health care sales pitch to Californians. Mr. Clinton arrived in California on Sunday to take part in a 90-minute statewide question-and-answer broadcast that his aides had planned as a health care program. But the local stations broadcasting the session balked at limiting the questions to health care, and the President ended up spending most of his time answering questions about crime, immigration and education.
At the end, when Mr. Clinton suggested wistfully that he would not mind taking a few more questions, the local host intervened brusquely to insist that the NBC affiliates broadcasting the program really had to rush back to their regular programming, in this case "seaQuest DSV," a new underwater science fiction program.
The President tried again the next day in San Francisco, where he addressed the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention. But by the time Mr. Clinton finished talking about his commitment to working people, his dread of a California school voucher proposal and his support for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Lane Kirkland, the president of the labor federation had just denounced as a "poison pill," there was little time left to talk health.
When the other pressing domestic concerns were not enough to distract the President, events in Russia and Somalia sealed his fate.
"It's a good example of how difficult it is to fashion a message and stick to it," said a White House official who traveled with the President.
Mr. Clinton left Washington on Sunday afternoon with good intentions. He brought his health care advisers along and was also accompanied by political advisers with special expertise in California politics. Most of the time, the health care advisers had little to do.
But Mr. Clinton made the first efforts at what aides have predicted will be a new running theme of tying together many of the Administration's initiatives into a single package. By stressing the interrelatedness of personal and economic security, Mr. Clinton is trying to make every element of his domestic agenda dependent on each other.
 
A Glittering Audience
 Aides said he honed the pitch further at a fund-raising dinner held in Los Angeles on Monday night, which drew Hollywood luminaries like Barbra Streisand and Lew R. Wasserman, the chairman of MCA Inc., as well as political leaders who were contributing to a fund for Senate candidates.
Mr. Clinton, the aides said, spoke for more than an hour without notes, stressing the security theme to an audience that is arguably the most secure group he will ever speak to.
Then he walked upstairs to his hotel suite and watched the brutal footage of dead American soldiers being dragged through the streets of Mogadishu.
"The best-laid plans of mice and men," said Dee Dee Myers, the press secretary. "That just comes with the territory. We just keep trying."

HEADLINE: Tom Bristol Coughran, Banking Executive, 87

 BODY:
Tom Bristol Coughran, a banking executive who was an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury during the Eisenhower Administration, died on Saturday at Alexandria Hospital in Virginia. He was 87 and lived in Falls Church, Va.
The cause was heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Coughran was Assistant Secretary for International Affairs from 1957 to 1958, and also served as the United States executive director of the World Bank and the International Finance Corporation.
He began his career at the Bank of America in Exeter, Calif., after graduating from Stanford University in 1927. In the next 30 years, he rose from branch manager to vice president and manager of the bank's international banking department in San Francisco.
After his stint at the Treasury Department, he returned to the Bank of America in New York, becoming executive vice president, vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of America International in New York.
He retired from the bank in 1971 and was one of the founders of the Wobaco Holding Corporation of Luxembourg. He served as Wobaco's chairman before retiring in 1975.
He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Florence, and a daughter, Jane, of Alexandria.

HEADLINE: Office Towers in 42d St. Project May Be Getting Taller

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
While public attention has focused on an interim plan to rehabilitate 42d Street with honky-tonk flourishes, New York State officials have also been considering changes to the longer-term redevelopment plan that could lead to office towers far taller than previously envisioned.
For instance, the skyscraper planned on the site of Nathan's Famous restaurant, at Broadway and 43d Street, would grow to 895 feet from 750 feet. That would make it the eighth tallest building in New York City -- two and a half times taller than One Times Square Plaza, where the ball drops on New Year's Eve. 
 The discovery that tower heights are being renegotiated with the developers has set off protests from civic groups and local leaders. They said their attention had been diverted by the interim plan, which conveyed a future 42d Street where Damon Runyon might feel at home, full of neon, noise and razzmatazz.
 
'No Longer Blinding'
 "The glare of the neon is no longer blinding people," Nicholas Fish, chairman of Community Board 5 in mid-Manhattan, said yesterday.
Even though the skyscrapers would not be built until the next century, their future is tied into talks about the interim rehabilitation project because both would be undertaken by the same team, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, who praised the interim plan when it was unveiled last month, said she had been unaware until a few days ago that the planned tower heights were being reconsidered.
"It is my strong hope that reason will prevail," she said, "and that the incredible growing towers will become incredible shrinking towers. And soon."
The plan to construct four office towers at 42d Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue was approved by the city's Board of Estimate in 1984, revised in 1988 and postponed last year in the face of a devastated real-estate market. Until the market improves, existing buildings on those four sites are to be rehabilitated as stores and restaurants.
 
Shades of 'Guys and Dolls'
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presided over the unveiling of the interim plan on Sept. 15, at the Academy Theater on West 42d Street. On easels behind him were vivid, evocative renderings by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, which might have been backdrops for "Guys and Dolls." The images were well publicized and much discussed.
"The trouble is," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, "every aspect of that plan is slated for demolition as soon as the office market returns."
On the same day as the Governor's announcement, the enlargement of the future office towers appeared on the agenda of the State Urban Development Corporation, as an amendment to the 42d Street plan.
Under this amendment, floor-to-ceiling heights would grow to 13 feet -- an increase of from 3 to 6 inches a floor, depending on the tower. This added height is meant to accommodate extra computer and telecommunications lines overhead and underfoot. If the buildings are better suited for technological expansion, they would presumably be that much more attractive to prospective tenants.
"A 13-foot height is not an uncommon requirement for new buildings," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a subsidiary of the Urban Development Corporation.
 
Overall Floor Area
 State officials said there would be no increase in the overall floor area of the four office towers, which would amount to more than 4 million square feet. Two towers would gain a story, one would stay the same and the largest, on the Nathan's Famous site, would actually lose two floors even as it grew in height.
No decision has been reached by the corporation, which has scheduled a public hearing for Nov. 15 on this and other amendments to the 42d Street plan.
"Our feeling," Mr. Barwick said, "is that it's time to consider whether or not the original concept has outlived its usefulness."
"It was arresting or ironic," he added, "that at the very moment that all the focus was on the interim plan, the city and state were on the verge of agreeing to make the office buildings even larger. That's insult to injury."
Joseph B. Rose, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, said that "under the guise of the lights and signs of Robert Stern are a whole bunch of substantive changes that alarmed people who've been following the project closely."
 
To Urge Opposition
 Actors' Equity Association has not yet taken a position, but Jack L. Goldstein, the special assistant to its president, said he would urge opposition.
"I don't think those buildings should be taller than they are now for any reason," Mr. Goldstein said. "If they need greater floor-to-ceiling heights, they can have fewer floors."
Mr. Fish said the community board had not yet taken a position but that "once the attention shifted from the design elements of this so-called interim plan to the details, certain things became clear that were potentially a problem for our community board."

HEADLINE: Weicker's Lieutenant to Run for Governor

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, who joined Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s fledgling independent third party as his running mate in 1990, announced today that she would run for governor next year.
"Governor Weicker and I have worked hard to provide leadership, and we have established a record of getting things done," Mrs. Groark said at a news conference at the State Capitol. "I believe for Connecticut to succeed that that leadership must continue." 
 Mr. Weicker, who said last week that he would not seek a second term, was on hand to pledge his support for Mrs. Groark and promise victory. So he stood in the background applauding someone else, a rare place for a man who has so dominated the spotlight through most of his political career. When he stepped up to the microphones to address Mrs. Groark's supporters, he conceded the oddness of the moment.
"I have been so roused by the reception that you gave Eunice, it's sort of like that fellow who was on the bench that leaped off onto the field to tackle somebody," Mr. Weicker said. "I know that A Connecticut Party could not have a finer standard bearer."
 
Tie-Breaking Votes
 Mrs. Groark, a soft-spoken 55-year-old former Republican from Hartford, has been a pivotal figure in some of the key moments of the Weicker administration. As presiding officer in the State Senate, she cast the deciding, tie-breaking vote in 1991 that gave Connecticut a state income tax. She also broke a tie earlier this year in favor of a law that made Connecticut only the third state in the nation to ban the sale of some semiautomatic assault rifles.
But until today, she was very much in Mr. Weicker's large shadow. She admitted that many people around the state still do not know her, and that her starting place is far different from Mr. Weicker's, who had served for 18 years in the United States Senate before his third-party bid and whose name and face were known across Connecticut.
The saving grace, she said, is that the other candidates in the race so far -- State Senator John B. Larson of East Hartford, and State Senator Richard J. Balducci from Newington, both Democrats -- are not well known either.
"I don't think I'm any more unknown than any other possible candidate," she said.
 
Continuation of Policies
 Mrs. Groark, who served as corporation counsel for Hartford and who ran unsuccessfully for mayor of that city in 1985, promised to continue the policies of the Weicker administration, which she identified as economic development and job creation. She said she hoped to retain many of the administration's appointees, many of whom were in the room cheering.
But where else she might draw support was a matter of dispute. Edward L. Marcus, the Democratic state chairman, said that Mrs. Groark was simply another Republican who would draw Republican voters to the benefit of Democrats. The Republican state chairman, John A. Mastropietro, on the other hand, said that just as Mr. Weicker had "crucified" the Democrats in 1990 -- when the state's largest political party drew barely 20 percent of the popular vote -- so would Mrs. Groark draw Democratic votes.
There is little formal structure within A Connecticut Party for her to draw on. After three years, the Governor's party had only 1,783 members statewide in early March, according to the most recent figures from the Secretary of the State's office. By contrast, there were 736,336 registered Democrats, 501,022 Republicans and 706,320 unaffiliated voters.
Officials in the two major parties say that however much Mr. Weicker might help Mrs. Groark, his long shadow may also be a great liability.
"She is not Lowell Weicker," said Mr. Marcus, the Democrat. "A Connecticut Party is Lowell Weicker, and you're just not going to be able to transfer that."

NEW YORK CITY
 
MAYORAL RACE IS A TOSSUP
Four weeks before Election Day, the race between Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani remains a tossup. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Poles a Quick Study With Fast Food

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Poles love pizza. But Pizza Hut didn't know they loved pizza that much. Or that they would fall for corn on the cob, or burritos, or for that matter, Taco Bells.
After six weeks, Pepsico's first "three in one" restaurant outside the United States, with a Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Taco Bell under one roof, has proved an overwhelming success. 
 So much so, planned television advertisements were shelved for fear of swamping the restaurant with too many customers. For two days, corn on the cob ran out.
"We're doing much more business than in Moscow," gloated Nick Howle, business development manager in Eastern Europe for Pizza Hut, who was involved in the company's Moscow opening three years ago. "In Moscow we thought we had to be there if business was going to happen. We thought of it as a stepping stone. But Poland is a main focus for Pizza Hut. We're committed."
The American fast-food chains have discovered that Poland is a wide-open market. The only real questions are whether Polish corn is up to snuff with the Hungarian corn the restaurants have been importing and whether local potatoes will ever make a decent french fry. For now, Pepsico is importing those, too.
Four years along the road to a market economy, the Poles are showing many of the attributes of fast-food devotees. More Poles have more disposable income than before. Life styles are changing so that the traditional heavy hot meal at 4 P.M. at the end of the workday has given way to the Western convention of lunch, more work and then dinner.
And like fast-food eaters the world over, Poles like to be in American-style, squeaky clean surroundings. The interior of the "three in one" restaurant at Warsaw's Bank Square is decorated with murals of Chicago, which has the largest population of Poles outside Poland.
"We're doing about double the number of transactions we expected," said Paul Clark, the operations manager as he passed an eye over the crowded tables and checked how the sour cream was being prepared for the burritos in one of the three kitchens. "We'd predicted about 15,000 transactions a week. We're doing 25,000."
Usually, the novelty factor wears off after the first few weeks at a new fast-food location and sales dip before picking up into a solid business, Mr. Clark said. The novelty seems to have strong staying power at the Pizza Hut troika. Transactions -- one of the standard measurements in fast food -- are up 15 percent over the opening week, he said.
The restaurant's flying start seems to confirm Pepsico's faith in Poland. In August, the company announced it was investing $500 million over the next five years in Poland. About 40 percent of the Pepsi stake would go to soft drinks, 20 percent to the snack-food market and 20 percent to the restaurants, said D. Wayne Calloway, Pepsico's chairman and chief executive, when he opened the new restaurant.
So far, Pepsico has one other Pizza Hut restaurant in Warsaw, a gleaming shopping mall location in a well-to-do suburb. Four more openings are planned in the capital before the end of the year, including a Pizza Hut in the restored Old Town. Next year, the company will venture to some of Poland's other major cities, including the cultural and university center of Cracow.
The McDonald's Corporation has been in the Polish market longer and set records of its own here, too. In 1992, the Warsaw McDonald's had 31,000 transactions on its opening day and last month the new venue in Gdansk on the Baltic Sea outdid that number by 3,000 on opening day.
Tim Fenton, McDonald's manager in Poland, won't say how many transactions are being done at each of his six restaurants. But he defies New Yorkers to find a McDonald's in Manhattan that bustles like the main two-story Warsaw outlet with 18 cash registers. "We're doing very well," he said.
Burger King, the other entrant in the fast-food trade, has opened four restaurants in Warsaw and plans 50 across the country in the next five years, said Magdalena Grzelewska, the marketing director for the International Fast Food Corporation, the franchiser in Poland for Burger King and a wholly owned American subsidiary of Capital Acquisitions Inc.
"There's still lots and lots of room for all of us in Poland," Ms. Grzelewska said. "The market is far from saturated."
Doing business in Poland is still not easy, the fast-food executives said. Inflation at 35 percent and the recent 8 percent devaluation of the zloty complicate matters. But costs for Pizza Hut in Poland are substantially lower than in Moscow, where most of the food has to be imported, Mr. Howle said.
But even in Poland, Pizza Hut is still perfecting food ingredients from local suppliers.
As Mr. Clark toured the kitchens, three rich yellow chunky cobs of corn were being carefully placed on trays for a tasting. This was an important moment: would Jerzy Zajaczkowski, a food chemist and the restaurant's technical manager, find that Polish corn was as good as Hungarian corn? Until now, the restaurant's corn has come from Hungary, which proved a big problem when supplies ran short in the opening week and frantic Pizza Hut managers couldn't pry their Hungarian corn out of the Polish customs inspectors.
"We'll be testing for moisture, defects, and looking at the micro biology results," said Mr. Zajaczkowski of the samples slathered in melted butter. Three different corn varieties had been given to Polish growers in the north of the country in an effort to get them to match the Hungarian quality, he said.
Similarly, the company imports its french fries from the Netherlands because the local potatoes make inferior fries. In one year of trying to grow American and Canadian potatoes, the farmers have made strides but have yet to reach the quality required by Kentucky Fried Chicken, Mr. Zajaczkowski said.
And needless to say, all the ingredients for Taco Bell items -- except for the iceberg lettuce -- are imported. "It's so foreign, it's all flown in," Mr. Clark said.
The pizza by the slice is the big hit at the "three in one" restaurant. It seems to be priced just right, from 15,000 zlotys to 24,000 zlotys (63 cents to $1.20). The crust is chunkier than the feeble, pale efforts of most Polish pizza, and the Hawaiian recipe with ham and pineapple -- an almost unknown fruit in Poland -- is the best seller, said Jacek Bresckiewicz, the Pizza Hut manager.
"We've been to the United States three times," said Leszek Bubel, a businessman who brought his wife and two children to the Pizza Hut for a Sunday meal. "When I'm here I feel I'm back in the States. This is our second time. We're going to come and try everything on the menu."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await U.S. Report on Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed against other major currencies yesterday as traders awaited the latest employment data.
Gold prices were little changed after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for October delivery closed at $353 an ounce, up 30 cents. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $353 a troy ounce, unchanged from Monday. 
 Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said dollar trading was quiet ahead of Friday's report on September unemployment.
"There's still a lot of question about the underlying strength of the U.S. economy," Mr. Johnson said. He predicted the unemployment report would show an increase of around 150,000 nonfarm jobs last month.
 
Impact on Interest Rates
 An improved employment picture would help strengthen the dollar because it would mean that the economy is improving and interest rates are less likely to fall.
A drop in rates often depresses the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities less valuable.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.80 Japanese yen, up from 105.65 yen on Monday. The dollar also rose to 1.6260 German marks from 1.6235 marks.
The British pound rose to $1.5150 in New York from $1.5140.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, were: 1.4225 Swiss francs, up from 1.4190; 5.6780 French francs, up from 5.6645; 1,591 Italian lire, up from 1,588, and 1.3386 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3413.
Silver prices were mixed. On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.063 a troy ounce, up from $4.054 late Monday.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact to Give Latin America a Big Boost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"One Specious Argument for Nafta" (editorial, Sept. 23) misconstrues the Clinton Administration's argument that the North American Free Trade Agreement is in our fundamental foreign policy interest. You suggest that this Administration's support for the agreement is intended to bolster the Government in Mexico, which faces elections next year. 
 The United States does not take sides in Latin America's elections. But we do have a stake in reform, political and economic, in Mexico and throughout the hemisphere. The development of democratic institutions and emergence of free markets reflect our values and reinforce our national interests. We pursue these objectives daily in our diplomacy.
That is why the United States has a direct stake in Congressional approval of the trade agreement. It will create the world's largest free trade area, a common market of more than 370 million consumers. And as President Clinton has said, "Free trade and open markets not only enrich people; they empower them."
If we approve the trade agreement, we will strengthen the drive toward economic liberalization and political reform in Mexico. Approval will also increase Mexico's capacity to cooperate with the United States on a range of issues -- including narcotics, illegal immigration and environmental protection -- that affect Americans.
If we reject the trade agreement, protectionists and those opposing reform will almost certainly be emboldened by such a clear signal of American retrenchment. We hope you are correct in your assertion that Latin American countries would continue their reforms if the agreement were defeated. But we see no need to test that proposition.
The foreign policy arguments for the North American Free Trade Agreement make the strong case on its economic merits more compelling. We are confident the American people and Congress will recognize, and seize, this once-in-a-generation opportunity.
 
ALEXANDER F. WATSON
Assistant Secretary of State
Bureau of Inter-American Affairs
Washington, Sept. 27, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE PLAYOFFS;
National League Championship Matchup

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:

ON THE MOUND
 
Can They Get The Final Outs?
 
The rotation gave the revolution the club staged over the second half in the N.L. West its momentum. It's deep and often unmerciful, paid multi-millions to allow as close to nothing as possible. The team's collective e.r.a. of 3.14 wasted the rest of the competition in the N.L. Greg Maddux should win his second straight Cy Young Award, Tom Glavine won 20 games for the third straight season and Steve Avery has the most sinister stuff of all of them. John Smoltz, the man with all the pitches and all too often the habit of wasting a great part of his talent, is a post-season deity in Atlanta. He seems to find his zone when the October moonlight finds him on the mound. Avery split his season record against the Phillies, his e.r.a. a full half a point higher versus Philadelphia than it was for the season. He will also be facing the club's right-handed lineup, certainly its more lethal incarnation. Maddux simply is the best pitcher in baseball at the moment. He walks no one, gives up a hit every five innings or so and always takes his club deep into games. Glavine, who has a mixed post-season resume at best, may enter the scene with the most to personally prove. The bullpen, as almost virtually all in baseball are, is ordinary. Mark Wohlers throws hard, but straight, and so is turning around a lot on the mound. Kent Mercker never seems to throw strikes when he has to. Steve Bedrosian and Jay Howell have been effective surprises. But the Braves have not won the World Series the last two seasons because they never seemed able to get the final out. Greg McMichael, barely invited to spring training, gets the invitation to make history for the Braves as the club's closer. But the right-hander, whose out pitches are not strikes, has been awfully suspect after a summer-long run of fantasy finishes. The Phillies, who have faced McMichael six tmes in 1993, stuck him with an 8.53 e.r.a.
 
At Least They're Healthy
 
Conventional wisdom says the Phillies are at the wrong end of a mismatch in this department. As usual, there's considerable truth to standard thinking. The club's starters, a revelation over the first half, were often wounded and worked over across the team's uneven trek to October's promised land. Tommy Greene has been hurt, and Terry Mulholland was once feared done for the season. All are now available and certainly capable. They may have to be much more. Their track record, though, says the corps, one augmented Danny Jackson's left-handed presence, will give the Phillies innings, keep them close enough for there to be hope that the offensive engine will wear down the opposition. Certainly, turning the games over to the bullpen will be a mortifying option. The contingent of relievers, one the front office sought all season to improve and alter, was ranked 11th in the N.L. They together amassed 24 blown saves. The Phillies, not surprisingly, were a marginal 23-20 in one-run games. Mitch Williams, the theoretical closer, is the perfect top man for a below average bullpen. His final pitching line of the season about captured the perpetually potential downside to his dramatics: 1 IP, 1 hit, 2 runs, 2 walks, 2 wild pitches.
 
Advantage Braves
 
IN THE FIELD
 
Sometimes Vulnerable
 
You don't win three straight division titles without a line of defense, and the fielding fortifications for the Braves got more imposing when McGriff was added. His bat gets people's attention and headlines and it might have got him more than a handful of MVP votes (McGriff's arrival sparked the inflation of everyone's averageinfalted the averages of his cohorts at the chop shop, but his play aty first might get the Braves an extra out or two when it counts most this series. But Atlanta, whose overall fielding efforts ranked third in the N.L., isn't without its departments of defense that trouble Manager Bobby Cox. Terry Pendleton, garnerer of Gold Gloves, has been erratic this season at third. Ron Gant, for all his speed and hustle, still can seem unrefined three years after his conversion to an outfielder. David Justice can launch the odd throw that looks more like one of his home runs. And the defense's vulnerability was on full and painful display over the season's final stretch.
 
Freddy Krueger With a Glove
 
It can be Nightmare on Broad Street when the Phillies slip into their slapstick routine in the field. It can happen anytime with this club, and there won't be a worse time than if the Phillies don't make the routine and remarkable plays in October that win championships. Dave Hollins is the first baseman of the future, only he now plays third base in the present. He doesn't do it soundly. John Kruk, the man who does play first, hasn't of late played it nearly as efficiently and airtightly as he had earlier in the season. The club turned the fewest number of double plays of any club in the N.L. in 1993. It also made 141 errors, their defense finding its rightfully mediocre place in the second tier of the league (9th place.) Pete Incaviglia, the man with the World's Gym upper body and world's worst set of wheels, can be an adventure in left. Lenny Dykstra still runs into walls in cnter, but doesn't pick himself up with the ball in his glove quite as often.
 
Advantage Braves.
 
AT THE PLATE
 
Well-Balanced and Hot
 
"There are good lineups at the plate - Texas, San Francisco, Philadelphia," said Ron Gant, the left-fielder for the Braves. "None are hot like we are hot." The temperature turned out these numbers - Atlanta's 169 homers led the N.L. and Gant, David Justice and Fred McGriff all hit 30 or more homers and drove in 100 or more runs. It's a lineup blessed with fabulous balance - Otis Nixon's basehit bunts and afterburners (his 47 stolen bases were good enough for 3rd in N.L.), Jeff Blauser's hit parade out of the No. 2 hole (182 for a shortstop), Terry Pendleton's decision to go nuts with the bat the last week of the season (the third baseman drove in nine over the final weekend), and Mark Lemke's repeated flair for post-season mass production. The lineup had a perfectly healthy appetitite for the strong-arm offerings of the Phillies, as Justice, Pendleton and McGriff combined to hit .333, with Justice homering three times. Gant, though, could be the wild card. With right-handers Tommy Greene and Curt Schilling coming at the Braves in Game 1 and Game 2, Gant, who hit only .191 against the Phillies, will be under the microscope to see if the breakthrough in the clutch he made throughout the second half of 1993 extends to the second season.
 
They Score in Bunches
 
The club nearly scored 900 runs in 1993, a staggering total that wasn't hurt by the 5.3 runs a game the club scored on average in its 12 games with the Braves. Len Dykstra, who might have been the runaway choice for N.L. MVP in the absence of Barry Bonds, is a machine of offensive menace, on base always and across the plate more than any other player in baseball this season. He's a lifetime .312 hitter against Atlanta. The heart of the order is as patient and muscular as they come - John Kruk (.430 on-base percentage, .316 average), Darren Daulton (105 r.b.i., 117 walks) and Dave Hollins (.330 against left-handers.) And the attack - Philadelphia's club average of .274 trailed only the Giants - has been aided by assorted phenomena - Pete Incaviglia drove in an astonishing 89 runs in only 368 at-bats (the left-fielder hit four homers against Atlanta pitching) and and Kevin Stocker, a minor-league promotion halfway through the season, hit .324 in 70 games. Key questions would involve how fast Daulton's bat still is (the catcher played in 147 games), how a lack of team speed might hurt the club in a short series (the Phillies were next to last in the N.L. in stolen bases), and the ability of players with great numbers but inconclusive track records (Mariano Duncan, Jim Eisenreich) to produce in the passion of post-season.
 
Advantage Phillies.
 
OFF THE BENCH
 
Not Glamorous, But Solid
 
Sid Bream, Rafael Belliard, Bill Pecota. They aren't glamorous names, but they are the estimable backbone of the bench for the Braves. They'll provide professional defense and the occasional quality at bat in a big spot. And the dugout isn't devoid entirely of intriguing mercenaries. Deion Sanders can steal a base and make an impact if asked to start. And Francisco Cabrera, whose 15 minutes of fame might have been among the most intense in baseball history hit .357 with a homer and three r.b.i. against the Phillies this year.
 
Which Ones Are They?
 
It's hard to separate the bench from the regulars. Jim Eisenreich hit .318 as the right-fielder against right-handers and Milt Thompson drove in 44 runs as the left-fielder against right-handers. Pete Incaviglia wreaked havoc against lefties and Wes Chamberlain hit 12 homers and 20 doubles in under 300 at-bats. The bench is deep beyond the platoon, too. Todd Pratt 87 as the backup catcher and pinch-hitter. Rickey Jordan who can homer on half-swings, hit .289. And Kim Batiste can fill the role of home-run threat.
 
Advantage Phillies.

HEADLINE: THE SOMALIA MISSION;
Clinton Sending More Troops to Somalia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to order about 2,000 more United States troops to Somalia to try to stabilize the country and has set a deadline of roughly six months for the withdrawal of all American forces, White House officials said today.
By setting a specific withdrawal date, Mr. Clinton hoped to ease Congressional pressure to end the Somalia operation immediately. The President also planned to spell out more clearly the precise goals he is setting for the American troops, who have been in Somalia for nine months on a mission that has already been extended and redefined. 
 "It is essential that we conclude our mission in Somalia but that we do it with firmness and steadiness of purpose," Mr. Clinton said today after two days of policy discussions with his top advisers. "We are anxious to conclude our role there honorably, but we do not want to see a reversion to the absolute chaos and the terrible misery which existed before."
 
Risky Strategy
 The emerging strategy includes the sort of timetable and definable, limited goals that the Congress has been demanding. But it also comes with great risks. If Somalia is not able to run its own affairs and feed itself, and the United Nations is not able to put together an effective military and logistical force to replace the Americans, a United States pullout would almost certainly result in a reversion to chaos there, a failure for which Mr. Clinton could be blamed.
Summing up the mood in the Administration, one White House official said: "You do what you can reasonably do to give the Somalis and the United Nations a chance to get on the road to recovery. We know it won't happen tomorrow. But if in a reasonable period it does not happen, at least we will have done what we can do."
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, appealed today to the United States and other countries with troops in Somalia to keep them there despite recent losses. At the same time the Secretary General announced plans for a stepped-up drive to promote political reconciliation and start the process of economic recovery when he visits Somalia and countries of the region next week.
Mr. Clinton will brief Congressional leaders on Thursday on his new strategy and then will outline it for the nation in a public appearance.
 
Clinton to Define Objectives
 He is expected to define the American objective as fostering a more peaceful and more secure environment in Somalia than the one that existed before the United States arrived, and one that is stable enough that a United Nations peacekeeping force, without American troops, can maintain order and continue the relief operations and the process of political reconciliation.
To realize that objective, Mr. Clinton is ordering several policy moves.
First, he will set a timetable for the withdrawal of American troops. The deadline will be no later than roughly six months from now, so other countries in the peacekeeping force do not decide to pull out before the mission has any chance of completion.
Officials said they want to send the message to Somalis that the United States is definitely not staying forever, in hopes of easing any Somali fears that the United States has colonial ambitions. They also want to make clear to the Somali leaders that the United States armed forces are not leaving tomorrow, in the hope of enlisting greater cooperation from them.
The message to the American Congress, officials said, is that the United States is not in an open-ended mission with undefinable goals.
Officials said the President has a fixed date for withdrawal in mind but he does not want to disclose it before he has a chance to consult with Congressional leaders.
 
Bush Sent First Troops
 The Bush Administration, which sent the first troops to Somalia in December, initially projected that the mission would be over in a couple of months.
As the Clinton team took over, they set a timetable to remove American combat forces by early fall and the remaining logistical units supporting other United Nations troops by the end of 1994. But that timetable presumed a relatively peaceful environment.
The second element in the strategy calls for the United States to spur Mr. Boutros-Ghali to act much more vigorously to put more United Nations troops from other countries into Somalia, so that the force that remains after an American withdrawal will be credible and effective.
American officials say they are convinced that other countries will come in if more pressure is brought to bear from the United Nations and if they are convinced that the United States is staying long enough for an effective hand-off.
 
'Tough' Message to U.N.
 They said the American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, who took part in strategy sessions yesterday and today, was dispatched to deliver "a very tough" message in this vein to Mr. Boutros-Ghali. She was accompanied by Gen. Joseph P. Hoar, head of the United States Central Command with responsibility for Somalia, officials said.
Third, Mr. Boutros-Ghali is also being asked to use his influence to reinvigorate the process of political reconciliation among Somalis that had begun last year but was aborted in June, when the forces of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid first attacked the United Nations peacekeeping force, killing 24 Pakistani soldiers.
American officials believe that the United Nations should press leaders of neighboring African countries with a stake in stability on the Horn of Africa, particularly Eritrea and Ethiopia, to take the lead in fostering this political reconciliation process so that it does not appear that the United States, or even the United Nations, is trying to impose a solution from the outside.
 
Peace Talks Threatened Aidid
 Two peace conferences have already been held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to nurture reconciliation among the Somali factions. American officials believe that General Aidid felt threatened by this process, which was developing alternative power centers, and that was why he went after United Nations forces in June. American officials concede, though, that they played right into his hands by allowing the whole political reconciliation process to be sidetracked by the manhunt for General Aidid.
Fourth, Mr. Boutros-Ghali is being asked to intensify his efforts to shift responsibility for logistical support of the 28,000-strong United Nations peacekeeping force in Somalia from American troops to civilian contractors who would be hired by the United Nations, or to the armies of other nations.
Fifth, in addition to increasing American troop strength in Somalia from the current level of 4,700 soldiers to between 6,200 and 6,700 troops, covert and overt efforts will be made to free the missing Americans.
Some 50 more armored Bradley fighting vehicles are also likely to be dispatched, along with the 650 fresh troops with tanks and other armored vehicles Mr. Clinton ordered to Somalia after Sunday's shootout in which 12 Americans were killed.
Although 65 House Republicans sent Mr. Clinton a letter criticizing his "indecisive and naive approach to foreign policy," for the most part tempers appeared to cool on Capitol Hill today.
 
Clinton Conferred With Senators
 President Clinton spoke on the telephone with his fiercest critic on Somalia, Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, and promised to rush a report on his policy to Congress. Mr. Byrd expressed satisfaction with Mr. Clinton's concession and agreed to put off a vote by the Senate to cut off funding for the military mission until the middle of next week at the earliest.
Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, rose on the floor to say that Congress should give the President time to define his policy before it cuts off funding precipitiously.
"It is not a time for panic," Senator Dole said. "I think we need to come to a resolution over what is happening in Somalia, but we should not do it in any way that would either now or later impact on the integrity and the honor of American forces."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Clinton Administration has decided to conclude the mission to Somalia, but not before sending more troops to try to stabilize the country. At the office of Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, an aide kept a tally of calls, which were overwhelmingly in favor of withdrawing U.S. forces. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Tests Added for Women in Health Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Responding to complaints from women's advocates, the Clinton Administration announced today that its health plan would pay for more frequent mammograms than it had originally recommended.
Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, told the Senate Labor Committee that in addition to free mammograms every two years for women over the age of 50, the Administration had decided it wanted additional breast X-rays for women in high-risk categories, like those with a family history of breast cancer, to be fully paid by the program.
 
Worried About Bureaucracy
 When it gets the Administration's final proposal, Congress is expected to alter many details, and more liberal benefits for women's health concerns are politically inviting to many lawmakers. Last week, 36 women in the House urged Hillary Rodham Clinton to see that more generous standards were adopted. 
 Another complaint about the plan was answered today at the White House. The Administration trotted out its big economic guns at a news conference to rebuff charges that the health plan would hurt the economy and result in the layoffs of more than one million workers.
And at the House, Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, and 45 colleagues proposed an alternative health care plan that would require no employer contributions to insurance premiums. It would make insurance available to everyone by regulating premiums and prohibiting insurers from refusing people with health problems. Mr. Cooper said their program would avoid building a new Government bureaucracy.
When Dr. Shalala appeared before the Labor Committee, she promised several times that the final version of the Administration's proposal would be ready in two weeks.
She said that the plan already provided twice as much as most insurance plans offer in preventive care, and that "the preventive part is free" for patients. But she was chided by several senators who want more preventive measures, like more frequent physicals for children, or nutrition counseling, in the plan.
But none of those issues affect as many people as women's health questions.
The women in the House have urged the Administration to follow guidelines set by the American Cancer Society, which recommends annual mammograms for women over 50 and mammograms every one to two years for women 40 to 50.
Dr. Shalala insisted that the Administration was acting on the best scientific evidence. "We're making these decisions now," she said, "and we're still in conversations both with the groups, with members of Congress. They are not finalized on this whole prevention package, but will be in the next two weeks."
She told Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, that she shared a concern that not enough has traditionally been done on women's health concerns. "You can be assured that both Mrs. Clinton and I are going to personally look at the package of women's health services that go into this package," Dr. Shalala said.
And she insisted that Administration decisions were not being made on the basis of cost.
 
Alternative Plan
 Representative Cooper, along with 26 other generally conservative Democrats, mostly Southerners, and 19 usually moderate Republicans, listed their disagreements with the Administration's plan. Besides requiring employers to pay for workers' insurance, these areas included a national health budget, price controls and continued tax deductibility for generous insurance plans.
Mr. Cooper's insurance purchasing cooperatives would have less authority than their counterparts in the Clinton proposal. Mr. Cooper contended that even without budgets and controls the improved level of competition created by the cooperatives would save money.
He insisted that under his plan "we should help all the poor and near-poor buy coverage." Mr. Cooper suggested that the Government raise the money by ending what he called excessive tax deductions. Noting that many of those who are not insured are well above the poverty line, he said the Government's obligation was to make sure that such people could buy insurance, and he said a combination of competition and restrictions on the ability of insurance companies to deny coverage would insure that.
At the White House news conference on the economy, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the Clinton plan would make American industries more competitive by preventing their health costs from galloping upwards. She also said the Administration's economic studies showed that the health plan would have a small effect, perhaps positive, perhaps negative, on the total number of jobs. It was impossible to give a precise number, she said.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, said the President's plan would make it easier for workers to move to better jobs because they would no longer have to worry about losing their health insurance. He also said the plan would encourage many people on welfare to return to work because they would not lose their insurance when they took jobs.
In arranging the news conference, the Administration wanted to make sure it did not make the same mistakes on its health plan that it made on the budget package in March and April, when it hardly responded when Republicans argued that the plan would devastate the economy and cost hundreds of thousands of jobs.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. to Give Hanoi a $223 Million Loan

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund announced today that it would make a loan to Vietnam of about $223 million to help Hanoi rebuild the economy. The loan is another step in Vietnam's bid to become a fully integrated member of the world economy.
Last week Vietnam became eligible for new funds when it paid the I.M.F. about $140 million in arrears on previous loans, with the help of a group of donor countries, particularly France and Japan. That repayment was made possible when the United States dropped its opposition to the French-Japanese plan in July. 
 More funds for Vietnam are expected to come from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
In a statement, the I.M.F. said Vietnam has made "major progress" in moving toward a market-oriented system. The fund especially cited the move toward family-based farming, the liberalization of agricultural prices, reform of the tax system and the establishment of a two-tier banking system as positive factors.

HEADLINE: Gun in Home? Study Finds It a Deadly Mix

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Instead of increasing protection, a handgun in a home almost triples the chances that someone will be killed there, a study of homicides in three metropolitan areas has found.
The conclusions of the study contradict the popular notion that keeping a gun at home increases personal safety, the researchers said today. 
 "This study is the first to clearly link the risk of homicide to the immediate availability of a gun," said Dr. Arthur L. Kellermann of Emory University in Atlanta, the lead researcher.
"In light of these results, people who are considering buying a gun for protection should think again," he said in an interview, "and families who keep guns in their homes should strongly consider getting them out of the house."
 
Findings From 3 States
 In a report in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, the researchers said they looked at homicides from August 1987 to August 1992 in Shelby County, Tenn., which includes Memphis, and in King County, Wash., which includes Seattle. Another team looked at murders in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which includes Cleveland, from January 1990 to August 1992.
Studying 420 homicides that occurred in the homes of the victims, about a quarter of the total, the researchers found that a majority of victims, 76.7 percent, were killed by a spouse, family member or someone they knew, and that in 85 percent of cases there was no forced entry into the home.
Documented homicides by a stranger accounted for only 3.6 percent of the cases, although in 17.4 percent of the cases the identity of the killer was not known.
Gunshot wounds were by far the most common cause of death, killing half, or 49.8 percent, of the victims killed at home.
Even in the 14 percent of cases involving forced entry, which often involved a spouse or other family member, a gun in the home offered little protection, Dr. Kellermann said at a news briefing here.
 
Variety of Sources
 "Guns were not found to be associated with decreased risk of homicide in any subset, or subgroup, that we studied," Dr. Kellermann said, "even when we just looked at cases involving forced entry or cases in which the victim actively resisted the assailant."
To get a detailed picture of each household where a homicide occurred, the researchers said they not only examined reports by the police and medical examiners, but also interviewed surviving family members or others who knew the victim well. In addition, they developed a matching control group for comparison by interviewing an adult member of a randomly selected household in the neighborhood of the victim. Such a household included a person of the same age range, sex, race and economic circumstance as the victim.
Dr. Kellermann and colleagues at the University of Tennessee, the University of Washington and Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland found six risk factors for homicide in the home: living alone, having a household member who was ever arrested or who used illicit drugs, living in rental housing, having someone who was ever hit or hurt in a family fight, and keeping one or more guns.
Domestic violence and the use of illegal drugs were the strongest risk factors for domestic homicide. But even when these were factored out, the researchers said, they found that the risk of being killed was 2.7 times higher, or nearly triple, in homes with guns than in homes without them.
The National Rifle Association criticized the findings, saying that a study of homicides could not reflect the effectiveness of guns for personal protection. That is because "99.8 percent of the protective uses of guns do not involve homicides," said Paul H. Blackman, research coordinator for the group. Such uses, he said, would include brandishing a weapon to deter assault, holding an assailant at bay or firing a weapon to wound or frighten off an attacker.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Bradley Asks U.S. to Confront Middle-Class Economic Fears

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Hoping to prod the Clinton Administration into paying more attention to the economic anxieties of middle-class Americans, Senator Bill Bradley is arguing that the Government should guarantee all workers not just health care but also the opportunity for lifetime education and training and pension protection.
One of the most influential legislators on economic issues, Senator Bradley has been working for weeks on a speech addressing the insecurity that American workers feel in light of changing economic conditions. This anxiety underlies the strong opposition in Congress, particularly among Democrats, to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which the New Jersey Senator and the Clinton Administration strongly favor. 
 Senator Bradley plans to deliver the speech on Thursday to the Center for National Policy, a public affairs research institute here, and he discussed its elements in an interview today.
Four transformations, he said, are "running through the economy like a powerful river," promising long-term economic benefit to most Americans but threatening some workers' jobs.
 
Four Changes Listed
 He said the four changes are these:
*The end of the cold war, which has cost jobs in defense industries.
*International competition, which has opened markets for American exports but forced American workers to compete with those abroad who work for less.
*The increased demand in the workplace for knowledge and technology, which has left some low-skilled, poorly educated Americans behind.
*And the drive to lower the Federal budget deficit, which has meant that the Government is spending less on construction and other projects that would produce jobs.
"The one thing we can't do is hold on to the old ways, because if you simply hold on, you lose," the Senator said.
President Clinton, Mr. Bradley continued, is properly focusing on promising health care coverage for all workers. But he said the President had not paid enough attention to two other matters that contribute to workers' insecurity. They are "the inability to get access to the means by which you can get another job and a high-paying job, and the fear that you'll work 30 years and end up with no pension."
"The Administration could do more," the Senator said. "It's a matter of emphasis. It's not a matter of omission. It's a matter of raising people's consciousness of just how important this is in the overall scheme of things."
 
Influence With Clinton
 Senator Bradley has considerable influence with the Clinton Administration, not only because of his position as a senior Democrat on the Finance Committee but also because he is one of the President's most reliable supporters in the Senate and one of the few lawmakers who tackle sophisticated economic issues with the same relish as Mr. Clinton.
The Senator said he was not proposing specific new programs now but hoped his speech would start a debate within the Government about how to address the anxieties of the middle class. In the same vein, he said he planned to hold a series of Finance Committee hearings on pension issues.
Beyond guaranteeing health care, access to education and training and pension protection to all workers, Mr. Bradley said, the Government should generally stay out of business's hair and let the free market run its course.
With that in mind, he said, the Government should abolish the payroll taxes that workers and employers pay for Social Security, Medicare and unemployment insurance and replace them with some form of consumption tax. That, the Senator said, would make it less expensive for companies to create new jobs and hire new workers.

HEADLINE: Another Vote

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
While the Mayoral race captures the attention of most of New York City, another campaign is taking place this week. For the first time in the history of their migration to the continental United States, mainland residents of Puerto Rican ancestry will have a chance to voice their preference on the island's future -- whether it should remain a commonwealth, form an independent nation or become the 51st state.
The vote will begin today in polling places in schools, community centers and storefronts in New York, with other cities to follow over the next few weeks. It was organized by a group of mainland Puerto Rican politicians and advocacy groups who were angered by their exclusion from the island's Nov. 14 nonbinding plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political status. 
 So many organizers support commonwealth status, say supporters of statehood, that the statehood advocates are suspicious that the whole effort is intended to encourage support for a continued commonwealth.
The vote's organizers say members of the island's ruling, pro-statehood, party, have urged their followers on the mainland to boycott the vote. They say pro-commonwealth sentiment runs high on the mainland, especially among older voters who saw the island develop under its present status. Representatives of the statehood party deny urging a boycott.
 
Organization Criticized
 There have been persistent criticisms that the vote was poorly organized and rushed without reaching out to the scores of community groups that could help educate voters and turn out the vote.
The vote was organized this summer by the Coalition Pro-Puerto Rican Participation '93, a group of Puerto Rican elected officials and community advocates. In New York and other cities, they are being aided by local election boards, which will provide voting machines and tally the vote. Mainland Puerto Ricans who live where no formal vote is occurring can send in ballots that will be counted by the National Puerto Rican Coalition, a national advocacy group.
The results from different cities will be counted by the organizers, witnessed by representatives of the island's three political parties and its bar association. They have yet to set a date for releasing the final count.
In New York State, the vote will take place today through Saturday. Similar votes in Springfield, Mass., and Orlando, Fla., are slated for late October and early November. Balloting is also planned for New Jersey, in sites not yet announced, and Chicago.
 
Getting Out the Vote
 Although the turnout is not expected to be large, the organizers have run public service announcements on the vote, while some parties, most notably the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party, have sent operatives to get out the vote in New York and other cities.
On Monday, Ruth Fernandez displayed the zest of a campaigner skilled at pulling both heartstrings and votes as she reminded a crowd of elderly people in Brooklyn just how far they had come from their childhoods in Puerto Rico.
The five dozen elderly men and women murmured and nodded in sad recognition as the 74-year-old singer and former member of the Puerto Rican Senate recounted how in her youth children went barefoot and hungry, and dark-skinned Puerto Ricans like herself faced discrimination. But progress, she said, came to the island through the economic and social benefits of its commonwealth status, one which she urged the crowd to reaffirm this week.
"Go to any Latin American country," she said as volunteers pressed pro-Commonwealth fliers into eager hands. "Who is the most advanced in education, health? Puerto Rico. You don't change what's good."
 
Word Slow to Spread
 Elsewhere in the city, campaign workers handed out fliers at subway stops and busy intersections while supporters of various political parties arranged information meetings.
Still, word has been slow to spread.
"Here all they talk about is Dinkins and Giuliani," said Martha Cuello, bringing home an armful of groceries in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "I don't know about Puerto Rico; I just know about here."
But the organizers said that whatever the turnout, the vote would send a strong message that the mainland community is entitled to have their say on the island's dominant political issue. They argue that the Government of Puerto Rico has often courted mainland residents for their support on such important island issues as this year's fight to preserve tax breaks for American corporations doing business on the island.
They also say that the mainland community will play an important role in lobbying its Congressional representatives on the island's status, since any decision on Puerto Rico's future rests with Congress.
"We want to be involved and we have a right to be in on any decision that affects Puerto Rico on a permanent basis," said Manuel Mirabal, the coordinator of the Coalition Pro-Puerto Rican Participation '93. "By doing what we're doing now strengthens our position and right to be a part of that process."
Political analysts say they expect a modest turnout, not because of a lack of conviction on the issue but because of doubts about the referendum's usefulness. They say the mainland vote is seen by some as an effort by Puerto Rican politicians in New York to boost their own visibility and show the mayoral candidates that they can pull Puerto Rican votes.
"People want to participate in something that has concrete ramifications, not someone else's agenda," said Hector Cordero-Guzman, research director for political economy at the City University of New York's Center for Puerto Rican Studies. "People see it as cosmetic and they don't want to waste their time. I suspect there will be low participation, which is not a lack of interest as much as the process not having much credibility."
 
Little Debate, Ferrer Says
 The balloting will be open to registered voters who were born in Puerto Rico or have at least one Puerto Rican parent and can prove it with a birth certificate, passport or other official paper. Those lacking papers can sign an affadavit and vote, and those who are not registered to vote can register the day they vote.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President and a supporter of the mainland vote, acknowledged that there had been little time to educate voters on the implications. "I don't think there has been as much of a recent debate as I would like to see," he said. He would not say how he intends to vote.
While the clout of the city's Puerto Rican politicians allowed them to organize the local vote in time for October, advocates in other cities, like Hartford and Bridgeport, said they lacked the time and resources to hold a vote.
"If it is going to have any validity you have to have had enough time for discussion and consensus," said Edwin Vargas, Jr., education director for the Hartford Federation of Teachers and a member of the board of the National Puerto Rican Coalition.
Mr. Vargas, whose city is home to some 50,000 Puerto Ricans, said he supported the plebiscite in principle but warned that it would not be representative of the national picture.
Organizers said Chicago would be voting, but a number of community advocates there said they had yet to hear the details.
Mr. Ferrer countered that while other cities lacked the political resources to carry out the vote, voters could still send in their ballots. Further, he said, the lack of participation in other cities will not detract from the effort's impact, since New York is home to about 40 percent of the nation's mainland Puerto Ricans.
Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, has faulted such New York-centered comments as betraying an arrogance that diminishes any impact of the vote. He said the organizers, like Mr. Ferrer, seized on the emotional issue of the island's status to generate a higher profile for themselves.
"A group of these guys all sat down and figured out how they can get some mileage out of this thing, then found out they had to try to do something," Mr. Falcon said. "They were arrogant in not seeing the importance of this issue across the nation and that this goes beyond playing narrow political games."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The wisdom of managing trade is coming under scrutiny.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to trade, everybody knows that the Japanese are different, and that the only way to make economic peace with them is to dispense with the vague promises and insist on specific trade results.
Well not quite everybody. Last week an elite, mostly American group of economists (including four Nobel Prize winners) wrote to President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa in preface to the Japanese leader's official visit, deploring America's drift toward a "results oriented" trade policy and pleading for a return to what might be called internationalism by the rules. 
 Why the harsh message? There is serious disagreement among serious economists about whether Japan's economic system creates unique barriers to trade, said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan and an organizer of the letter campaign. It galls him, though, that the results-oriented faction captured the Clinton Administration virtually without a fight.
The now-conventional wisdom about Japan goes something like this:
Japan has lowered formal barriers to imports to the point where, with a few important exceptions, the restrictions have little effect. But in the words of C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, "a very pervasive pattern of exclusionary practices" still makes it exceptionally difficult for foreigners to crack the local market.
In some cases, this pattern is laughably transparent: Washington State apples pampered to Japanese specifications are not likely to carry disease to the locally grown crop. More typically, the pattern is explained away by foreigners' failure to unlock the secrets of Japanese marketing.
Either way, though, the solution of choice is not issue-by-issue head-butting, but negotiated import targets -- tangible goals with tangible measures of success or failure. That's apparently why even soft-liners in the Clinton Administration -- notably Lawrence H. Summers in the Treasury Department -- want to hold Japan to a timetable for reducing its overall export surplus. And it explains why the hawks in Congress and the Commerce Department want to go further, "managing trade" to guarantee a minimum fraction of the Japanese market to foreigners and limiting Japan's trade surplus with America to a specific dollar figure.
Mr. Saxonhouse said, however, that "it is by no means clear who wins on anecdotes." Well-documented horror stories about America's own exclusionary trade practices filled "Fair Trade Fraud," a recent book by James Bovard, a former researcher at the Cato Institute. And the statistics-based research on the question of whether Japan is different is inconclusive.
Work by Robert Lawrence of Harvard University suggests that Japan does indeed import fewer manufactured goods than can be accounted for by the island's endowments of natural resources, capital and labor. And evidence from 12 individual industries just published by Mr. Bergsten and his colleague, Marcus Noland, supports the view that Japan is under-importing by about 30 percent.
On the other hand, parallel research by Mr. Saxonhouse places Japan's import behavior squarely in the middle of industrial nations. And those who care to look will find another dozen studies that come out on the Saxonhouse end of the argument.
Moreover, even if the "results oriented" crowd is right about the problem, they may not be right about the solution. If the Japanese are breaking the rules, Mr. Lawrence suggested, we have to be tougher about calling them to task. But "I don't think the managed-trade game is the right answer," he says.
Why are reputable economists ranging from Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to Anne Kreuger, the former chief economist of the World Bank, so out of synch with a President who prides himself on his knowledge of the subject?
A simple explanation is that the Clinton Administration's trade agenda was hijacked early on by partisans: Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic adviser, made her reputation as a defender of managed trade. But the simple explanation isn't necessarily the right one.
An equally plausible view is that President Clinton is driven by the need to build coalitions to replace the crumbling New Deal amalgam. And managed trade neatly bridges the interests of diverse constituencies that Mr. Clinton courted during the campaign. After all, activist government appeals to the bedrock of the Democratic Party: trade unionists in steel, autos and other well-paid industries threatened by foreign competition. But it also intrigues Silicon Valley executives, whose support lent credibility to Mr. Clinton's claim to represent the New Democratic values of the suburbs.
Managed trade may thus prove a political winner. The unanswered question, though -- one Mr. Clinton is hardly the first occupant of the White House to face -- is whether good politics makes for good policy.

HEADLINE: A Disabled Child Is Seen More Likely to Be Abused

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Disabled children are abused and neglected far more frequently than other children, according to a Federal study.
The report, by the National Center on Child Abuse and Neglect, is the first nationwide look at the extent of maltreatment among children with a physical, mental or emotional disability. 
 Researchers found that disabled children are physically abused at twice the rate of other children, sexually abused at nearly twice the rate and emotionally neglected at almost three times the rate.
Overall, children with disabilities are maltreated at 1.7 times the rate of other children. And in nearly half of those abuse cases, the child's disability was at the root of the abuse or neglect, according to the report by the agency, a part of the Health and Human Services Department.
In all but 14 percent of the cases studied, the maltreatment was either committed or permitted by a child's primary caretaker, who is generally the mother, the study said.
The study was based on reports of maltreatment, substantiated by child welfare agencies, involving 1,834 children.
The report underscores both the "tremendous economic and social pressures that are crushing" many families with a disabled child as well as the need to help them, said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, who sponsored the 1988 legislation requiring the study.
"Children are vulnerable," Mr. Dodd said in an interview. "But children with disabilities are the most vulnerable. It's terribly disturbing to realize that children with disabilities are being maltreated to such a high degree."
The researchers' findings are based on data collected from 35 child protective services agencies. Each agency provided information on all cases of substantiated maltreatment over a period of four to six weeks in early 1991.
Dr. Edward Schor, associate professor of pediatrics at Tufts Medical School, and Dr. James M. Perrin, associate professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, noted that caring for a disabled child can be expensive, stressful and physically exhausting.
Parents may also become isolated from friends, family and their community. "It just makes their situation and their ability to parent a little bit more fragile, a little bit more likely to take a direction that is not good for the child or good for their relationship with the child," Dr. Schor said.
For the study, children were considered disabled if they had one or more of a variety of mental or physical ailments and, because of the ailments, they were limited in mobility, self-care or expression.
