HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Two Candidates Present Two New Yorks

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
In the New York City of Rudolph W. Giuliani's television ads, people live in fear. They worry about drug dealers, high taxes and bad schools. They are scrappy and strident, and their voice has a timbre that is straight out of Brooklyn.
They resent the implication that a vote for Mr. Giuliani has anything to do with race.
In the New York of David N. Dinkins's ads, people live in harmony. They favor conciliation and healing, and in times of trouble, they walk the streets together. They are optimistic and hopeful, yet, paradoxically, they see racial unrest as an ever-present possibility. 
 Their most pressing fear, it seems, is Mr. Giuliani.
Television advertising is, of course, only one of the means that the New York City mayoral candidates are using to try to get their message out to voters in this media-saturated city. But amid all of their appearances on the six o'clock news, at newspaper editorial board meetings, on radio talk shows and Sunday morning public affairs programs, their ads remain the candidates' clearest statement of their election strategies.
As such, they show that the two major candidates are waging campaigns that depend on very different senses of the city -- and its electorate. They also show how both candidates are trying -- sometimes subtly and sometimes not -- to capitalize on the city's racial antagonisms.
 
Two Views of City
 Mr. Giuliani's campaign is intended to appeal to a New York weary of crime, scared about job loss and eager for change. Polls show that this is a sizable portion of the city; a recent New York Times/WCBS-TV poll, for example, showed that 58 percent of all New Yorkers believe that the city is less safe today than it was four years ago.
Mr. Dinkins's campaign, in contrast, is intended to appeal to a New York that is proud of its liberal Democratic tradition, feels victimized by outside -- meaning Republican -- forces and believes that under Mr. Giuliani conditions can only get worse. This, polls suggest, is also a significant portion of the city; the same poll showed that 58 percent of New Yorkers blame Republican administrations in Washington for the loss of jobs in New York.
Many voters, particularly the undecided voters crucial to each side, may share both senses of the city; it is the goal of each candidate's commercials to make his vision somehow seem the more compelling one.
Both candidates began their advertising campaigns with positive commercials intended to give viewers some affirmative associations. But over the last few weeks both have moved firmly into the attack mode. And just in the last few days both Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Guiliani have introduced ads that criticize the other directly.
In his most recent ads the Mayor accuses Mr. Giuliani of waffling on the issue of abortion rights and, as a member of the Reagan Administration, working to undermine civil rights and environmental laws. In a separate ad, the Mayor stresses his own reputation as a conciliator, implicitly questioning his opponent's ability to keep the peace in troubled times. "Four years ago a great city chose the path of conciliation instead of confrontation," the narrator says in this ad, "and through both criticism and praise, David Dinkins has continued to work for peace, because in the end he knows that is the only way New York can live."
 
Surrogates on the Attack
 In his most recent ads, Mr. Giuliani -- through his surrogates -- tries to undermine Mr. Dinkins's image as a healer and accuses him of playing to what might be called reverse-racial fears. In one ad, Mr. Giuliani's running mate, Herman Badillo, running on the Republican and Liberal lines for city comptroller, says: "The Dinkins campaign is trying to make this an election about race because they want to avoid the issue of competence. One of his supporters attacked me for marrying a Jewish woman, and another stood right next to Dinkins and called Rudy Giuliani a fascist. And while people who support the Mayor are called proud, people who support Rudy and me are called racist."
Through what they say and what they do not say, each candidate's ads show what he -- or at least his campaign consultants -- believes to be his major strengths and weakness heading into November.
Mr. Giuliani's first ads, which were broadcast in early August, were clearly intended to "humanize" the candidate, who, in his last campaign, often seemed to come across as cold, even wooden. They showed the Republican-Liberal candidate playing with his children and reflecting on his family in gentle tones.
His next group of ads focused on the city's problems, fertile territory for the challenger. They featured ordinary New Yorkers, voicing their fears and frustrations, and, in the trademark style of Mr. Giuliani's media consultant, David Garth, they had a gritty, low-budget look that seemed to underscore the candidate's ties to financially strapped voters.
In a commercial focusing on crime, Paul Balsamo, a restaurant worker in Brooklyn, wearing an apron, said: "I remember when I was a kid Avenue N used to be lined with people sitting out in front of their houses or in front of their apartments at night to cool off. You don't see that any more because everyone's afraid to come out at night."
The Giuliani campaign in its ads has never laid out in any detail what the Republican-Liberal candidate would do to solve the city's problems, apparently believing that simply outlining the problems will suffice. "Giuliani's overall strategy is to present himself as calm, competent, in touch with ordinary people and to portray the city we live in as a disaster," said Phil Friedman, a consultant who worked on Andrew J. Stein's failed mayoral bid.
 
Listing Accomplishments
 Mayor Dinkins began his television ad campaign almost three weeks after Mr. Giuliani, at the end of August. He started out by trying to remind voters of the things that he has accomplished over the last four years -- and trying to blame others for what he has not. The ads, after the style of Mr. Dinkins's media consultants, David Doak and Bob Shrum, had a Madison Avenue feel, with inspirational background music, a soothing, baritone narrative and lots of children to personify hope.
"Along with the oath of office, they gave him a massive deficit, a hostile administration in Washington and a city at the boiling point," the narrator of one ad intoned. "He's balanced four budgets, cut waste, and in a recession, saved jobs by persuading companies like CBS and Prudential to stay in New York City." Another ad featured boys of many races playing ball on a lot the city has converted into a practice field, and a third showed a boy using a public library whose hours the Dinkins administration has extended. At the end of each one, a message of harmony -- "One City, One Future" -- flashed on the screen.
In his most recent commercials, Mr. Dinkins has shifted his attention to Mr. Giuliani. The shift seemed to represent an acknowledgement that the Mayor's record -- or at least the public's perception of it -- is not strong enough to win him re-election on its own and that to do that the Mayor will have to make his opponent seem an unpalatable choice. "If they're going to win this," one Democratic consultant said of the Dinkins campaign, "they have to turn this into an election about two bad choices."
Mr. Dinkins's negative ads -- which conclude with the tag line "Can we elect a man who's fought against everything we stand for?" -- portray Mr. Giuliani as the type of Republican that Democrats cannot in good conscience make Mayor. They show Mr. Giuliani looking awkwardly in the wrong direction, and are clearly aimed at the white, liberal voters who, polls indicate, may well decide the outcome of the election.
 
Accusation of Race-Baiting
 The latest campaign commercials to go on the air are the Giuliani ads accusing the Mayor of a minority candidate's version of race-baiting. These ads are aimed at the same white liberals, and intended to neutralize the notion -- voiced by President Clinton in his visit to New York -- that a vote for Mr. Giuliani is an implicitly racist vote. One ad features Mr. Badillo, another Mr. Giuliani's wife, Donna. "This election shouldn't be about race, it should be about competence," Ms. Giuliani says.
It is one of the rules of media politics that a negative campaign only becomes more so. As the candidates try to sway voters, viewers in both of their New Yorks, it seems, should be prepared for a television campaign that grows increasingly divisive as the election draws near.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Television ads for Mayor David N. Dinkins, left, and Rudolph W. Giuliani are the candidates' clearest statement of their election strategies. Mr. Dinkins's commercials appeal to a city proud of its liberal Democratic tradition; Mr. Giuliani's appeal is to a New York weary of crime, scared about job loss and eager for change.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Trade in Tight Range

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market was on hold again yesterday, with prices and yields bouncing around in a narrow range.
But the hold may be lifted tomorrow, when the Labor Department releases its September employment report. That data may give traders and investors an indication of whether interest rates should remain in their current trading range or break out in one direction or another. 
 A signal of slow economic growth, which could come with a report showing nonfarm payroll jobs rising just 75,000 last month, could get interest rates drifting lower again if inflation remains at a pace of just below 3 percent.
 
 
Biggest Worrry
 The biggest concern in the market right now seems to be that the employment data and the inflation data that follow the next week will be inconclusive. If this is the case, the bond market would stay in a narrow trading range, which is the kind of activity that not only bores traders but also makes it a lot harder to make money.
In late trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was down 2/32 point, with the yield remaining unchanged at 6.01 percent. The 10-year Treasury note was up 4/32 point as the yield slipped to 5.31 percent, from 5.33 percent Tuesday.
Short-term notes and Treasury bills recovered from the losses yesterday in response to the unexpected increase of $2 billion in the size of the weekly auction of Treasury bills. The increased reliance on short-term financing to cover the Government's budget deficit had been expected. But the $2 billion increase came sooner and was larger than anticipated.
The price of the two-year note rose 1/32 point, with the yield dipping to 3.83 percent from 3.84 percent. The discount rate on the three-month Treasury bill was down to 2.96 percent from 2.99 percent.
 
 
Corporate Bonds
 Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's No. 1 retailer, sold $1 billion of corporate bonds yesterday; the issues were bought up fairly quickly.
Jon Winkelried, the head of the fixed-income syndicate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead underwriter, said that the demand for the $250 million of 30-year bonds that Wal-Mart offered was another sign of the scramble for higher yields in a time of low or declining interest rates.
He also said that the overall interest in the sale signaled that some of the upward pressure on yields in the corporate bond market from recent issues may be easing a little.
He said that Wal-Mart chose a mix of 12-year and 30-year bonds because together they brought the maturity of the company's total debt to the average the firm is aiming for. Both maturities were new for the company, which is based in Bentonville, Ark.
The first portion of the issue was $750 million of 5 7/8 percent notes with a maturity date of Oct. 15, 2005. They were offered at a price of 99.617 to yield 5.92 percent, or 58 basis points more than yield on the current 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
 
Second Part
 In the second part, Wal-Mart sold $250 million in 6 3/4 percent notes with a maturity date of Oct. 15, 2023. The price was 99.693 to yield 6.774 percent, or 60 basis points more than the yield on the 7.125 percent 30-year Treasury bond that is due in February 2023.
The corporate bond market has used the older 30-year Treasury bond as a benchmark for pricing long-term debt because underwriters do not have confidence that the new 6.25 percent bond properly reflects the yields at 30 years out. One reason for this concern is that with the Treasury issue of the new 6.25 percent bond last month, the Government cut the annual sales of 30-year bonds by about 40 percent, making supply a factor that could distort the performance of the bond.
Both issues were rated aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trades a Bit Lower As Dealers Await Incentives

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly lower against other leading currencies yesterday as dealers awaited fresh incentives to step into the market. Trading was light.
Rumors that European central banks were selling dollars at 1.6300 marks to build German mark reserves kept the dollar from advancing beyond that level, while good buying interest at 1.6200 marks defined the United States currency's bottom. 
 "It's just the typical dollar malaise," Chuck Spence of Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles said. "With the dollar staying in the 1.6150-to-1.6500-mark range, customers really don't have any reason to hedge and all we get is interbank trading."
 
 
Thin Trading Band
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6225 marks, down from 1.6245 marks Tuesday. The dollar also slipped to 105.75 Japanese yen from 105.80 yen.
Dealers said they expect the dollar to trade in a thin band until important American employment data are released tomorrow.
There was little market reaction to news that an influential economist, C. Fred Bergsten, had urged the Clinton administration to fix the dollar at 100 to 110 yen.
Comments by Mr. Bergsten, whose views are thought to mirror President Clinton's, have roiled the currency market in the past.
Mr. Bergsten was speaking after releasing a report of the bipartisan Competitiveness Policy Council, of which he is a member. It suggested the White House reach an agreement with Japan or rich industrial nations to lock in the stronger yen to help United States competitiveness.
 
 
'Works for Everyone'
 But Mr. Bergsten said the report itself did not include a specific exchange rate target. Laura Tyson, the White House's chief economist and a representative on the council, did not contribute to the report.
"The Japanese won't tolerate the dollar below 100 and the Americans don't want it above 110, so 105 works for everyone," Frank Pusateri, vice president at Bank of Boston, said.
The British pound finished in New York at $1.5245, compared with $1.5145 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A new company's process excites investors in waste disposal.

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
INNOVATIVE technology combined with a careful reading of rules governing the handling and disposal of hazardous waste may turn into a winning combination for a start-up company named Molten Metal Technology Inc. of Waltham, Mass. Early buyers of its stock have done pretty well, even though the company is not expected to earn any money for at least another calendar year.
Molten Metal made an initial public offering in February at $14 a share. The price slipped briefly to $10 in April but has been rising, more or less steadily, since July. The shares passed $20 in early August and have stayed over that level, closing yesterday at $23.125, down 37.5 cents in Nasdaq trading. 
 Why has Molten Metal attracted favorable attention even as the hazardous waste business over all has been slumping? Because Molten Metal's approach, if it works on a commercial scale, will allow customers to dispose of problem substances much more economically than if they had to treat them as hazardous waste.
Molten Metal says it can treat nasty stuff like polychlorinated biphenyls, better known as PCB's, and break them down into their chemical elements -- carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and chlorine -- which can then be recovered for re-use.
The value of the recycled substances is minimal. The market's enthusiasm for the process comes more from its potential ability to help users of the technology avoid a costly liability.
Once classified as hazardous, waste must be carefully handled and disposed of under complex government regulations. Thus, the technology could not only save companies the enormous cost of having to dispose of their hazardous waste, it should also free them from having to deal with mountains of paperwork and permits.
"People want to avoid disposal to the maximum extent possible," said Douglas R. Augenthaler, an analyst who follows the company for Oppenheimer & Company. "If you recycle, the waste is never a waste, it's a product, and so it is not regulated."
As the name might suggest, the core of the company's technology is a bath of molten metal, usually iron. The materials to be destroyed are injected into the bottom of the bath, and the mixture is heated to 2,500 to 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit. At that temperature, even exceptionally stable compounds tend to break down into their basic components, which can then be drawn off as gases from the sealed system.
Molten Metal has built a commercial-scale demonstration unit in Fall River, Mass., and has begun testing the system on materials supplied by potential customers. But it has no intention of becoming a contract disposer of other people's wastes, as Chemical Waste Management is. Instead it plans to sell the devices to companies, like chemical producers, so that they can incorporate them into their own production processes.
One thing that has apparently impressed investors is the cmpany that Molten Metal keeps. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has invested in the Fall River plant and has closely followed the development of the technology. Molten Metal also has alliances with Fluor Daniel Inc., an engineering specialist unit of the Fluor Corporation; Am-Re Services, a big environmental insurer; L'Air Liquide, a French chemical company, and Rollins Environmental, which operates incinerators.
As with any new technology, the biggest risk is that it might not work as well in the real world as it appears to do in the laboratory. A crucial question is whether the process will cleanly break materials down into gases that can be separated or instead will generate large amounts of slag that have to be dumped in a landfill at a heavy cost.
"That's obviously the key question," Mr. Augenthaler said. "If it does not work, the stock is overpriced. If it does, it is a bargain."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Across the Globe, Expressions of Regret and Gratitude

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
From the "Say It Ain't So, Mike," headline in The Chicago Sun-Times to the special news report on Romanian television, Michael Jordan's abrupt retirement sent shock waves around the globe yesterday. And in a world where basketball has become a rare unifying force, the world reacted as one, with surprise, admiration, understanding and dismay.
The dismay may have been more pronounced in Chicago, where children cried and grown-ups groped for words, but Jordan's retirement was major news in virtually every international capital, confirming that Jordan is the world's most famous and admired athlete. 
 While the Bulls owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, was comparing Jordan to Babe Ruth, Romanian television in Bucharest sought a more locally compatible cultural metaphor, ending a special report with the lament, "Basketball without Jordan is like ballet without Maya Plisetskaya," the legendary Bolshoi ballerina.
 
The Tour Stops Here
 In the United States, there were predictable expressions of praise, regret and understanding, and some surprising insights.
At the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., it suddenly struck a visitor from South Carolina that unlike, say, Martina Navratilova, who recently announced her retirement from singles tennis a year in advance, Jordan will have no farewell season.
"You know how sometimes people have a gift and you don't get to say thank you?" said Allen McCoy. "We didn't get a chance to say thank you."
It was a football player who focused on the special sense of loss to a generation of fans who have never known basketball without Jordan. "There's millions and millions of disappointed kids," said Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' linebacker, who also echoed the day's dominant sentiments.
"What more can he do?" Taylor said. "He's absolutely the best athlete to ever play organized sports."
 
 
A Question of Timing
 Like others, Taylor expressed admiration for Jordan's decision to walk away at the peak of his career. "No one could write a book or do a movie and do it better than this."
Maybe not, but encouraged by Jordan's refusal to rule out a comeback, some seized on the hope for a sequel.
At the Hall of Fame, Kenny Boucher, a Springfield resident, said he was sorry Jordan was going to retire, then added, "Maybe he won't for long."
The same hope was voiced by Magic Johnson in Geneva, Switzerland, where the former Los Angeles Laker is beginning an all-star tour.
"I think that Michael is a guy who probably wants to be left alone now," said Johnson, suggesting that Jordan would eventually return. "Maybe one year off and then come back to show everybody he's still king."
From all the hope that Jordan might some day resume his basketball career, there was an alternate line suggesting that Jordan might seek to become king of another hill.
"From what I've seen he's not ready for the tour yet, but it's amazing what you can achieve from desire and effort," said Payne Stewart, the professional golfer.
 
An Omen?
 Many basketball figures focused on Jordan's transforming contributions to the N.B.A. "His economic impact has been tremendous," said Charlie Grantham of the N.B.A. Players Association, describing Jordan as irreplacable.
George Raveling, head coach at Southern Cal, said Jordan might have given the public a hint about his thoughts not long ago in a commercial. "I reflect back to that Nike commercial where he is shooting by himself and wonders what it would be like if he wasn't Michael Jordan," Raveling said. "I wonder if that wasn't an omen of this whole event. Maybe there's more truth to that commercial than we realize."
Dean Smith, who coached Jordan at the University of North Carolina, endorsed his decision. "I personally think it's a good decision based on all he must go through and to certainly go out on top."
Phoenix Suns star Charles Barkley said winning a third consecutive N.B.A. title probably gave Jordan a sense of uniqueness after years of being compared with Magic Johnson and Larry Bird.
"I think Michael, once he won three championships in a row, in his mind that distinguished him above those guys, and there was nothing left for him to accomplish," Barkley said.
Even President Clinton weighed in, offering best wishes and adding, "We may never see his like again."
The President added that Jordan will be missed "in every small-town backyard and paved city lot where kids play one-on-one and dream of being like Mike."

HEADLINE: What Can Be Done for the New South Africa

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We commend the democratic sentiments of "South Africa, Outcast No Longer" (editorial, Sept. 26). Indeed, if Nelson Mandela's goal of helping to create a "united, democratic, nonracial and nonsexist country" comes to fruition, it will be an example not only for other states, but for the United States as well. 
 What concerns us is how this new country might be born, and who might want to abort such a birth. You state that a South Africa synonymous with "democracy, peace, human dignity and prosperity for all its people" will require "leadership and luck" and public investment.
Building a democratic South Africa will be long and arduous. Apartheid has left a terrible legacy. Blacks, and to a lesser extent Indians and coloreds, have been left out of the South African income pie. People of color have been marginalized in housing, education, health, access to wealth and in political power.
Whites, 15 percent of the population, own 87 percent of the land. Four white-owned conglomerates dominate the Johannesburg stock exchange. Blacks, who account for 75 percent of the population, own 1 percent of South Africa's businesses. Life expectancy and infant mortality rates for whites are comparable to Sweden's and for blacks to the poorest countries of the region.
How to turn this dismal picture around? Elections, it may be hoped, will bring relative peace and basic democracy, but they will not right the wrongs of centuries of racism and decades of apartheid. Outsiders should be asking: What kinds of economic programs and foreign investment will benefit the majority of South Africans? Who will participate in such decisions?
It is important to remember that in the years before sanctions and divestment became commonplace, foreign investment in South Africa helped a minority build and maintain its privileges, while a few large domestic and international companies profited. Little of this wealth trickled down to the majority. Blacks had no say where these investments went.
Without change in who has access to public and private credit, interest and pension funds, private sector and government contracts, public spending and asset ownership, little will change. If a new democratic government has austerity policies imposed upon it by international financial institutions, the aspirations of millions of South Africans will effectively be checked by an outside veto.
White South Africans attained high economic standing largely on the backs of blacks. Repentance is more than saying you are sorry, as President F. W. de Klerk has finally done. Archbishop Desmond Tutu says: "If you apologize for wrongs done, I have no way of judging the sincerity of your contrition . . . Deeds -- what you do after the apology -- is how this is judged. To say you are sorry means, almost automatically, that you make restitution."
The South African Council of Churches is stressing responsible reinvestment. It is calling on all South African and overseas investors to uphold worker rights; develop training and education programs; maintain safe and healthy working conditions; recognize representative unions and the right to strike; end all forms of racial, gender, political, religious and physical handicap discrimination; engage in environmentally responsible investment; invest in developing the productive capacities of all South Africans; uphold standards comparable to the best conditions in the relevant sector of the South African economy; work to empower black-owned businesses, and consult the communities in which they invest to develop social programs.
We need to be vigilant about those who would derail change. Evidence compiled by churches, the independent press, human rights groups and South African courts points to significant government involvement in the strife and violence racking township communities. People cannot speak and organize freely in some parts of the country. In the apartheid "homelands" of Bophuthatswana and KwaZulu, political activists and organizers fear for their lives.
For there to be free and fair elections next year, the international community must provide monitors of violence and the elections. Nelson Mandela's dream of a new South Africa is a call of hope, as well as a challenge to show our solidarity by our actions.
 
ERICH D. MATHIAS
Prog. Asst., Africa Office, Disciples
of Christ and United Church of Christ
New York, Sept. 28, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Poverty and Callousness in America

 BODY:
The Census Bureau released some ugly data this week: The number of poor Americans rose last year and is now higher than at any time since the 1960's. Some observers dismiss the new data, saying the increase wasn't large and that year-to-year changes aren't important.
The small increase wouldn't be very important -- except for the fact that last year's experience is part of a disturbing story that's been unfolding for a decade or more. The proportion of Americans living in poverty -- for a family of four, that means living on less than $14,335 in 1992 -- is now 14.5 percent, which is only slightly lower than it was in the 1960's. Poverty is not decreasing -- despite Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty, despite the economic boom of the 60's and despite the longest peacetime recovery ever during the 1980's. That's no statistical fluke. 
 There are many causes for chronic poverty, including sluggish productivity, persistent unemployment and sharp increases in the number of single-parent families. But the big villain is the steep slide in wages, adjusted for inflation, of the lowest-paid workers. That problem wasn't created by government and it won't be solved any time soon.
But government can extend a helping hand to the victims. Instead, Washington and state governments pulled back on welfare and unemployment benefits. More than 40 states, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, froze or cut back welfare benefits in 1992. This callous policy has hit children hardest. The richest country in history leaves nearly a quarter of its children poor -- including half its black children.
President Clinton's economic program offers some relief. The tax credit that he proposed and Congress passed will raise earnings of low-paid workers; his health care reform would extend coverage to millions of poor families. But more can be done. For example, the Federal program to provide emergency relief to the long-term unemployed expired this week and Congress is debating whether to extend it, though only to year's end.
For those who doubt what government can do, gaze north. Canada, like the U.S., stagnated during the 1980's; as here, low-paid workers in Canada suffered most of all. But in contrast to the U.S. pattern, poverty rates in Canada steadily declined -- testimony to its humane social welfare programs. The U.S. has the power to lift its citizens out of poverty; so far it has lacked the will.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Eric the Unemployed?

 BODY:
ERIC DICKERSON, the National Football League's second-leading career rusher, hasn't been waived after all by the Atlanta Falcons.
Tuesday night, Dickerson concluded he was being released after conversations with assistant coaches JUNE JONES and OLLIE WILSON. 
 Yesterday, the Falcons president, TAYLOR SMITH, and Coach JERRY GLANVILLE took turns labeling Dickerson's conclusion a "misunderstanding."
Both said he is welcome to remain with the Falcons, provided he accepts a role that will be further reduced beginning with next Thursday's game against the Los Angeles Rams.
"We told him his playing time wasn't going to be what he wanted," Glanville said. "That we were going to play the young guy, like we've been doing, and that the choice was his as to what he wanted to do. Needless to say, we were all shocked to read that he thought he had been waived. I think there was probably a misunderstanding." The 'young man' Glanville was referring to is ERRIC PEGRAM. (AP)

HEADLINE: U.S. Looking Ahead to Swell of Cuban Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Acting on reports that the Cuban economy is on the verge of collapse, the Clinton Administration is drafting contingency plans for dealing with a potential wave of Cuban refugees, officials say.
A new task force of representatives of about 40 different Federal agencies met on Tuesday for the first time to "look at possible U.S. responses" to a political crisis in Cuba. 
 "Cuban society has reached the state of total exhaustion," said a report submitted to the State Department by experts from Florida International University. "When Fidel Castro leaves power, Cuba will be bankrupted."
Administration officials said the task force was a "working-level" group and that its work would "not touch on the basic U.S.-Cuba relationship."
 But the creation of the group is the Administration's first step toward developing a long-term policy for responding to the instability facing President Fidel Castro, whose 35-year grip on power has been severely weakened by the collapse of Communism and the loss of his patrons in Moscow.
Included in the group are the National Security Agency staff, the State Department, the Defense Department, the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Coast Guard, the Federal Emergency Management Administration and the Agency for International Development.
"The focus will be on the kinds of scenarios that could produce a large 'out-migration' and other things would require a rapid response," said an official familiar with the planning who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Officials said they wanted to avert a crisis like the Mariel boatlift, which began when Mr. Castro freed waves of inmates from hospitals and prisons and allowed them to flee Cuba. The Carter Administration was ill prepared for the 125,000 refugees who sailed for the United States.
One Clinton Administration official involved in policy on Cuba said the group would take up a 1991 contingency plan developed by the Bush Administration as a starting point. The plan called for appointment of a coordinator of Federal efforts to deal with an exodus of Cubans; the interdiction of boats of refugees at sea; the detention of refugees in processing centers throughout the United States, and screening for illness and criminal records.
 
Cuban-American Pressure
 An official who attended the meeting said that various Federal agencies were asked to help update the 1991 report.
In recent weeks some Administration officials have complained that thinking about Cuba has been stunted by a desire to please the politically powerful constituencies of Cuban-Americans in Florida and New Jersey.
"People have been intimidated by the political pressure from taking out a clean sheet of paper and saying, what are our options," said an Administration official involved in Cuba policy. Some officials say that some kind of dialogue is needed with Mr. Castro or other political figures in Cuba if democracy is to be fostered there, despite the objections of many conservative Cuban-Americans to such contacts.
But, some officials say, a broader spectrum of views is emerging from Cuban-Americans that is allowing the Administration to start to expand its options.
Though the Administration has allowed American telephone companies to increase the volume of calls between the United States and Cuba and permitted more food and medicine to be sent to the island on a private basis, they say it is doubtful there will any significant easing of United States economic pressure on Mr. Castro's regime. "The tough part of the embargo is going to stay in place," said an Administration official involved in developing policy towards Cuba.
But American policy makers believe that with the collapse of the Soviet Union, which provided up to $1 million a day in subsidies to the Castro regime, the 32-year-old economic embargo has been transformed from a symbolic gesture into a blunt instrument that drives up the costs of Cuba's imports and further drains the country's meager foreign exchange reserves.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 8, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an Administration task force drafting contingency plans on Cuba misstated the day of its first meeting. It was Wednesday, not Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Whitman Plan to Cut Taxes: Experts Taking It Seriously

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
By most accounts, Christine Todd Whitman committed a colossal political blunder when she proposed a $1.2 billion cut in income and business taxes for the financially strapped state of New Jersey. The states' editorial pages have heaped scorn on her plan and, according to polls, 70 percent of the state's citizens -- including a majority of her fellow Republicans -- simply do not believe that she can deliver on her promise to cut taxes.
But there is more to Mrs. Whitman's plan than an outlandish notion -- even though her Democratic opponent, Gov. Jim Florio, promptly labeled it a "voodoo re-do," a reference to Ronald Reagan and supply-side economics. Mrs. Whitman is not promising something for nothing. 
 Unlike supply-side enthusiasts, who theorized that steep cuts in income tax rates would pay for themselves painlessly by spurring the economy, she says she intends to slash spending a dollar for every dollar of tax relief. She would follow the course of governors in other states who have struggled to turn back the rising tax tide.
The true test of Ms. Whitman's plan is precisely how she proposes to curb spending and finance the tax cut. And the task is even tougher than it appears. She says she is prepared to pare 4.5 percent from the current level of spending over the next 18 months, but, despite Governor Florio's doubling of the income tax, the next year's budget may already be $1 billion or more in the red.
"The challenge for her is to say more concretely how she can get there," said David Kehler, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey.
But many economists and state budget experts say the glib comparison to Reaganomics is misleading. They say that in some circumstances state tax cuts of similar scope have in fact curbed the growth of state government. And they say lower taxes and smaller government can improve a state's economic performance, provided that cutbacks do not jeopardize the quality of education or the state's infrastructure.
 
'Looks Very Doable'
 "From what I've seen of the plan, it looks very doable," said Patricia A. Woodworth, Michigan's state budget director. "Given the magnitude of the program and the amount that needs to be saved, it looks not dissimilar to the kinds of things we've achieved in Michigan."
"I don't know anyone believes you'd shake the foundations of government if you did this thing," said Harvey Rosen, the chairman of Princeton University's economics department and a specialist in public finance. "My attitude toward Whitman's spending reduction is the same as toward Gore's reinvention of government. If the political will is there, it can be done." He noted that New Jersey now spends more per citizen than most other states,
His colleague, David Bradford, who did a study on New Jersey's economy, said that a quarter-century ago, New Jersey was "well known as a state where it was good to do business." Increasingly, he said, "that's been reversed and nowhere more radically than by Florio."
To be sure, Ms. Woodworth is a political appointee in a Republican administration.
Professor Rosen headed the tax analysis office in the Reagan Treasury, and Professor Bradford was a member of President George Bush's Council of Economic Advisers. Both support Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts.
But regardless of political stripe, economists tend to agree that it makes no sense to assume facilely that in the 1990's things would work in a state capital as they did in Washington in the 1980's.
A 30 percent cut in income tax rates over three years may be, as one Whitman economic adviser put it, "Kemp-Roth dusted off." But the Whitman plan does not rely on rosy revenue assumptions. "I built in no supply-side revenue flows, no big spurts in income or revenue growth," said Lawrence Kudlow, who devised the Whitman proposal. Mr. Kudlow, chief economist for Bear Stearns, was a ranking aide to David Stockman, Mr. Reagan's first budget director.
 
Deficits Not Allowed
 In Washington, of course, the Federal tax cuts never held down Uncle Sam's spending, as Mr. Stockman and other proponents predicted they would. But Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany pointed out that as governor, Mrs. Whitman could not run a deficit even if she wanted to. New Jersey's Constitution forbids it.
New York's experience may be relevant. A budget official in New York credits Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's $2 billion tax cut in the late 1980's for curtailing the growth of government even though the final round of tax reduction was canceled when the recession hit. "The changes in the tax law and threat of future changes have served as a brake on spending growth," the official said.
And unlike President Clinton, the governor of New Jersey is armed with a line-item veto and clear authority to withhold spending.
"It's a question of political will," said Feather O'Connor Houstoun, who served as New Jersey's treasurer for eight years under Gov. Thomas H. Kean. The governor of New Jersey has remarkable power, she said. "The question of whether it's an exercisable control or not gets back to the reasonableness of what the money needs to be spent on."
 
Political Skills
 In that light, New Jersey voters have to judge whether Mrs. Whitman has the political will, and the political skills, to put through substantial cuts in state government, or whether, to the contrary, the benefits of keeping taxes and government about the same size as when Governor Florio took office outweigh the costs.
As for potential benefits, Mrs. Whitman argues that cutting taxes on personal incomes and businesses is the cure for the state's lagging job growth and an exodus of manufacturers. While experts say her claim that the tax cuts would create 450,000 new jobs is absurd -- that figure is more than the number of unemployed people in the state -- several said lower taxes could improve the economy's health.
Mr. Gold is skeptical of Mrs. Whitman's proposal because she has yet to outline specific cuts, but he pointed out that a similar tax cut program worked in Delaware. That state slashed its income tax rates in the early 1980's and again in the late 1980's.
Delaware's first round of tax cuts was as ambitious in magnitude as Mrs. Whitman's, reducing state revenues by roughly 3 percent the first year. Though Gov. Pete du Pont's plan was enacted while the economy was expanding, the actual cuts took place during a harsh recession. The state, which had run chronic deficits for a dozen years, balanced its budget partly with cuts and partly by dipping into a rainy-day fund.
"We did benefit, and the benefit was also perceived by those who kind of felt forced into supporting it," said Weston Nellius, then Delaware's Secretary of Finance. "The whole business climate of Delaware turned around." And its economy, weathered the recession better than surrounding states, he said.
Of course, it is hard to say whether something that worked in one state would work in another. While studies of tax changes at the Federal level suggest that their net effect is small, the few statistical studies of how changes in state income tax rates affect the states' economies have found that low tax rates promote growth, though how much growth remains unclear.
"It's easier to move from New Jersey to New York than it is to move from New Jersey out of country," said Professor Rosen. "Therefore, it makes it a heck of a lot more plausible that taxation can affect the level of activity in the state."
Cuts in business taxes -- including a corporate tax surcharge, a truckers' tax and a telephone tax -- account for about a third of the Whitman tax-cut proposal, although they have so far received little attention. Research studies have shown that businesses really do look at taxes in deciding where to locate. A new study, for example, has found that when foreign businesses locate in this country, they are very conscious of a state's tax environment. "It makes the story about growth more plausible," Mr. Rosen said.
 
Comparable Cuts
 According to Ms. Woodworth, the budget director, Michigan's budget was cut by a comparable amount, closing mental hospitals, double-bunking prisoners and imposing a state hiring moratorium and a pay freeze. The state did not, however, squeeze education spending.
In Massachusetts, Gov. William F. Weld, who refused to raise taxes to balance the budget, cut spending by 6.5 percent. "We didn't have the ability to give tax relief other than repealing the state sales tax on services and making sure that the scheduled income tax cut went through," said Dominick Slowey, assistant secretary for administration and finance. Spending was shifted toward infrastructure, job training and preventive health services, he said; this year the state is cutting business taxes.
At least one study has found that whether tax cuts help or hurt an economy can depend on how the budget is cut. If both taxes and benefit programs are cut simultaneously, the spur to income growth can be substantial. But if taxes are cut and so is spending on edcuation and infrastructure, growth can actually slip.
"One of the things that attracts employers to New Jersey is a well-educated work force and good infrastrucure," said Alan Krueger, a labor economist at Princeton. "I'd want to be assured that the cuts aren't going to affect those."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 9, 1993, Saturday

Both Mr. Rosen and Mr. Bradford belonged to Mrs. Whitman's Economic Recovery Council, but they attended no meetings and did not help draft the plan.

HEADLINE: A Higher Alcohol Tax Should Pay for Health

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I agree with the recommendation of President and Mrs. Clinton that there should be still more substantial taxes on tobacco products to pay for the health care for all Americans that they propose (front page, Sept. 23). 
However, it is difficult to accept their reluctance to tax alcoholic beverages more substantially. One argument in support of this inconsistent policy is that, while tobacco is harmful to health whether it is used moderately or excessively, alcohol in moderation is probably not harmful.
 But, logically, this argument should lead to recognizing the need for higher taxes on alcohol.
 Consider, for example, an additional tax of $1 a quart on hard liquor. At approximately 20 shots to a quart, the moderate drinker of, say, one or two shots a day would be taxed an additional 5 cents or 10 cents, hardly an onerous penalty compared with that for moderate smoking.
 More significant, the effect on the heavy drinker could only be beneficial. Either he or she would be forced to cut down on consumption or to contribute more to the medical expenses that are caused by excessive drinking, including those that are the result of drunken driving and other "accidents."
B. H. FRIEDMAN Wainscott, L.I., Sept. 27, 1993

HEADLINE: Whitman and Florio Spar in a Civilized Gubernatorial Debate

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
In a debate civilized in its tone but full of pointed attacks, Gov. Jim Florio, the Democratic incumbent, and Christine Todd Whitman, his Republican rival, sparred tonight before a statewide television audience.
The debate was the first time since the general election campaign began in June that voters statewide had the chance to compare the candidates side by side and to get more than the one-sided information that could be gleaned from either candidate's ads. 
 With two more debates to go, Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman each seemed more content tonight to poke at the other than to try to deliver a knockout blow before the audience in the Trenton studio of WPVI-TV of Philadelphia.
The format of tonight's debate, which was also broadcast on WABC-TV in New York, was not conducive to drawn-out slugfests between the candidates, but each tried to score points by questioning the other's leadership abilities, veracity and ethics.
 
Carefully Scripted Responses
 Whatever the question put to them by a panel of reporters based in New Jersey, Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman each reacted with carefully scripted responses intended to provide safe political ground and positions from which to launch an attack at the opponent.
That made for few surprises until the closing moments of the debate, when Mrs. Whitman tried to outmaneuver the Governor with a challenge that they declare a moratorium on negative campaigning during the last three weeks of what has become an increasingly nasty race.
"It's become very clear that we need to change the way we govern and the way we campaign," Mrs. Whitman said. "So I'd like to offer a challenge tonight. To date, Governor, you've spent almost $2 million in negative advertising on me. I propose that starting next week, we ban all negative ads, that from now forward it's you talking about your record and what you're going to do for the future, and me talking about my economic program for the state of New Jersey."
Mr. Florio initially ignored her challenge, but when pressed by one of the co-moderators he said: "I'm telling you we have not been having negative advertising. Taking about the record may seem negative to Mrs. Whitman. What we're talking about is the facts, and Mrs. Whitman is not comfortable with that."
After the debate, Mrs. Whitman's chief political strategist, Edward J. Rollins, said the offer was sincere, but he also indicated that the campaign was prepared to escalate the war of negative campaigning.
"We have offered the voters an opportunity and offered the Governor an opportunity to have a different type of campaign," Mr. Rollins said. "I hope he takes us up on it. But we reserve the right to fight the fight the way it's fought."
 
Debate Over, Battle Resumes
 The sharp blows that were missing from the debate began landing only moments after it ended, with both campaigns rushing to hand out news releases documenting the other side's "lies."
After the debate, the candidates stood on opposite sides of the studio platform, each surrounded by a throng of reporters.
"I'm very happy," Mrs. Whitman said. "It was an opportunity for once to be side by side with the Governor and when he starts his spin on things to be able to put my own right back on it and try to set the record straight."
Mr. Florio said the debate clearly showed the differences between him and Mrs. Whitman.
"The debate was a good debate," he said.
 
2 Debates Required by Law
 Tonight's face-off, sponsored by the New Jersey League of Women Voters, was the first of two debates required by law because both candidates have accepted public financing for their campaigns. The second is scheduled for Oct. 19, sponsored by the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce and to be broadcast live over WCBS-TV (Channel 2) in New York City, WCAU-TV (Channel 10) in Philadelphia and the New Jersey Network, the state-supported public television system.
The candidates have agreed to a third and final debate on Oct. 24 on WNBC-TV (Channel 4) in New York City.
Until tonight, when Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio have appeared at the same gatherings, they have taken pains to avoid face-to-face meetings. When circumstances have placed them at some event at the same time, one has waited out of sight until the other departed.
The debate opened with a reference to an issue seemingly more relevant to a Presidential debate: the fighting in Somalia. Mrs. Whitman offered condolences to the families of the two New Jersey soldiers killed there this week. Mr. Florio did the same, noting that he had called the families of the victims to extend sympathy for the state as a whole.
It was an early and deft example of how the power of incumbency helped Mr. Florio in the debate.
With 30 years in elected office, Mr. Florio clearly held the upper hand on questions of policy. But Mrs. Whitman was able to hold her ground, presenting herself from the opening question as an outsider who would change government in Trenton.
"I haven't spent the last 30 years running for office," she said. "That means that I have a standard that I work to; that's the ability to come home at night and tell my children they can be proud of everything I have done and said over the day."
The candidates were questioned by the panel of reporters -- Darlene Superville of The Associated Press, Nora Muchanic of WPVI-TV and David Navarro of WABC-TV -- along with the news anchors from each television station, Bill Beutel of WABC-TV and Jim Gardner of WPVI-TV, who acted as moderators.
Both candidates found themselves on the defensive early from questions that zeroed in on weaknesses in their campaigns. For Mrs. Whitman it was an economic plan short on specifics, in which she pledges to cut nearly $1.5 billion in taxes in the first three years of her administration. For Mr. Florio it was the record $2.8 billion tax increase he ushered in three years ago.
Pressed to give specifics on her tax-cut proposal, Mrs. Whitman gave Mr. Florio his clearest shot of the night when she said she would focus on government waste and cited as an example what she said was the State Department of Corrections' purchase of Adidas athletic shoes for prison inmates.
"There are plenty of ways to do it," she said. "I expect the Governor to say the world is going to end if we try."
Mr. Florio was swift to ridicule his opponent's response and plan.
"One and a half billion dollars of sneaker is a lot of sneakers," he said. "Tonight we hear the first degree of specificity -- Adidas sneakers are going to be cut."
But for every criticism of her plan, Mrs. Whitmanhad an assault on the Governor's tax increase.
 
'Deep Denial' on Taxes
 "I expect the Governor to be in deep denial about cutting taxes; he's never met a tax hike he didn't like," she said.
Each candidate was given a minute to answer questions and 45 seconds to rebut the opponent during the hourlong debate.
The most contentious moment of the evening came during a question over the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons. It is an issue on which the public rates Mr. Florio the strongest, and one he has tried to make a central theme of the gubernatorial race by portraying Mrs. Whitman as sympathetic to efforts by the National Rifle Association to overturn the ban.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. Jim Florio greeting each other at a Trenton television studio before their debate. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gonzalez Intensifies Battle With Fed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee, began a push today to change the Federal Reserve System so that the President would be given more power to appoint the central bank's officials.
Mr. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, focused in particular on the presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks, who are now chosen by boards dominated by local bankers and business executives. Calling the practice undemocratic, Mr. Gonzalez said these officials, who help shape the nation's monetary policy, should be named by the President. 
 Mr. Gonzalez has pressed such proposals before, and they have been perenially popular with many Democrats in Congress, who see the Fed as out of tune with the public's desire for faster economic growth.
But this time he is making his biggest push to turn the ideas into law. In the first of four days of Banking Committee hearings, Mr. Gonzalez was joined by several other Democrats, who agreed that Fed officials should represent the public and that Fed operations should be more open.
A bill introduced by Mr. Gonzalez would require the central bank to release detailed minutes a week after its policy-making meetings, instead of the vague summaries that are now released six weeks afterward.
He has called Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, to testify on Wednesday about the House and Senate proposals to change the Federal Reserve's structure.
Fed officials say Mr. Gonzalez's proposals could threaten the central bank's independence, and they warn that the financial markets might see them as weakening the Fed's ability to fight inflation.
Mr. Gonzalez sees things otherwise. "The changes I am proposing to the Federal Reserve System are quite modest," he said. "There is nothing to fear. I am not seeking to politicize the central bank nor take away its independence."
Two weeks ago, President Clinton sent Mr. Gonzalez a letter saying he was "disinclined" to support the proposal, saying the Fed was operating well. But some legislators say one of the many bills to change the Fed could squeeze through Congress.
Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, strongly backed Mr. Gonzalez's proposals, arguing that having the President appoint, and the Senate confirm, regional bank presidents would lead to more diversity by race and sex. Mr. Mfume released a study showing that only a small percentage of top officials working for the Fed and its banks are female, black or Hispanic.
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, testified in favor of his proposal to strip regional bank presidents of their votes on the Fed's main policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee. At each committee meeting, five of the Fed's regional bank presidents have votes, while the others are cast by the Federal Reserve Board's seven members, who are appointed by the President.
"Although most Government agencies, including the Fed, make extensive use of private citizens as advisers," Mr. Sarbanes said, "in no other agency is actual decision-making power vested in individuals who are formally accountable to private parties instead of to the public."

HEADLINE: Health Insurance Data Called Faulty

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The White House estimates of insurance costs for individuals and families in President Clinton's health plan were sophisticated guesses based on incomplete and largely outdated information. That is the conclusion of actuaries from several large accounting organizations who reviewed the estimating process for the Administration.
The actuaries said the estimates were probably as accurate as possible, given the surprising dearth of up-to-date information on medical costs for various groups. But health care experts warned that the nation should be aware of the uncertainty over future insurance costs as it debates how to extend universal coverage and overhaul the health care system. 
 The Administration estimates that the standard package of benefits it wants to guarantee for all Americans would cost an average of $1,800 a year for individuals and $4,200 for families, at projected 1994 prices.
 
Significant Figures
 These figures are central to the financial viability of the plan, in turn determining the size of the Government subsidies that would be required to help low-income people and small and low-wage companies pay their share of the premiums. The White House estimates that $80 billion in subsidies would be required in 1997.
If the premiums turned out to be understated, the subsidies would be higher and the burden would be heavier for taxpayers and businesses, with far-reaching political implications.
A group of actuaries and an economist from an accounting concern who were consulted by the White House said in interviews that the premiums had been estimated on the basis of correctly applied economic modeling. But several said the information available to construct the models was not fully current and comprehensive.
Richard Ostuw, the chief health care actuary of Towers Perrin, a large benefits consulting firm, said the outside advisers were still reviewing the premium numbers.
 
Estimates May Be Omitted
 Indeed, Richard Kronick, a senior White House health care adviser, said the current premium estimates would probably be omitted when the President sends the plan to Congress in a few weeks. He said the proposal might include only "the methodology for getting to the numbers."
The outside actuaries were called in last spring, after two Government health care agencies produced cost estimates that were tens of billions of dollars apart.
"Because of the nature of the health care industry and the many self-funded employer health plans, it is virtually impossible to collect the data," said John Bertko, an actuary who volunteered to review the process.
"It comes down to a leap of faith," said Linda Bergthold, a principal with William M. Mercer Inc., a benefits consulting firm, who spent four months as co-director of a White House group that developed the Clinton proposals. "Most people probably don't appreciate how difficult it is to get good numbers."
The latest comprehensive National Medical Expenditures Survey, for example, is six years old, so it does not reflect recent, far-reaching changes in health care, said Mr. Bertko, a partner in San Francisco with Coopers & Lybrand, a Chicago accounting firm.
Information about health spending in most states is even more outdated. The last detailed Government survey of the states was in 1982.
Although the Administration issued new state health spending numbers this week, experts said the information, which was pulled together from a variety of sources, including a hospital trade association, was not precise enough to be used in setting premiums.
The actuaries said the Administration also had relatively little hard information to help estimate the costs of covering people who are now uninsured. And they struggled to reconcile widely varying estimates of the cost of bringing low-income Medicaid recipients into the general health system.
The premium numbers have been criticized as low in comparison with what many employers now pay. But there are important differences between offering basic coverage to all Americans under the age of 65 and the plans that many employers now offer, the actuaries said.
For one thing, many of the uninsured are young and healthy, so their health costs would bring down the averages.
Even the 2.5 million people with health problems who have been rejected by insurers can be absorbed when their costs are spread across large groups, Mr. Bertko said. "Even in California, where costs are high," he added, "people who are considered uninsurable are only three times as expensive, on average, as other people."
The outside advisers did not challenge the $1,800 and $4,200 estimates, which were based on 1994 projected costs for traditional fee-for-service medical care, not for people in prepaid H.M.O.'s. Indeed, several said they felt reasonably comfortable with the results, given the many limitations.
But contrary to what the President seemed to imply in a carefully worded paragraph of his Sept. 22 address to Congress, the actuaries have not endorsed the overall financial assumptions in the White House proposal.
"The group will be providing a document, probably within the month, summarizing the process and what we looked at and the items we did not look at," said Brent Greenwood, a principal in Minneapolis with Tillinghast, a unit of Towers Perrin.
 
'Poetic License' Suggested
 Mr. Clinton said in his speech: "We gave these numbers to actuaries from major accounting firms and major Fortune 500 companies who have no stake in this other than to see that our efforts succeed. So I believe our numbers are good and achievable."
Ken Porter, chief actuary of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, suggested that the President may have been exercising "poetic license." The volunteer actuaries were "never asked to support the policy," Mr. Porter said. "They were looking for our expertise: did the numbers hang together?"
Last spring, when Government economists and actuaries were unable to make their estimates of future health costs match, Ira C. Magaziner, the chief White House health policy adviser, sent an S.O.S. to Mr. Ostuw of Towers Perrin, where Mr. Magaziner had worked for a time after selling his own consulting firm to Towers.
With help from the American Academy of Actuaries, a professional group, Mr. Ostuw enlisted five fellow actuaries and an economist, Jack Rodgers, who works in the Washington office of Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
Members of the group said they helped to reconcile a wide gap in estimates between two agencies, the Office of the Actuary of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, and the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research in the Public Health Service.

HEADLINE: A New Breed of Merger Banker

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Way back in the 1980's, when mergers were all the rage on Wall Street, the names of those involved in the deals occasionally eclipsed the companies that were being combined.
Today, even though business could scarcely be better -- last quarter was the busiest ever in terms of the number of announced transactions -- there is less focus on the personalities behind the deals. 
 For one thing, merger and acquisition fees contribute far less than they once did to Wall Street's bottom line. And the deals make more sense.
The Columbia Healthcare Corporation's plan to purchase the HCA-Hospital Corporation of America strikes many as a smart consolidation. Likewise, whether QVC Network Inc. or Viacom Inc. wins Paramount Communications, both have a lot to offer as potential partners.
As a result, brash young superstars have been supplanted by seasoned specialists, bankers who have spent years dealing with a particular industry, its economics, its people. Telecommunications, media, health care and chemicals, industries in which consolidation is crucial to long-term success, have been particularly busy.
Focusing on four bankers in a world that remains full of sizable egos is dangerous business. But these four were cited by a number of sources as being some of Wall Street's hottest hotshots.
 
John L. Garcia
Chemicals
 Unlike many investment bankers who get on-the-job training in the industries they cover, John L. Garcia, a managing director at Wertheim Schroder & Company, knew scads about the chemical business before he ever did his first deal.
A native of London, he holds an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business and a doctorate in chemistry from Princeton. Mr. Garcia, 37, also spent six years in a variety of jobs at ARCO Chemical before he ever got to Wall Street and another six as Wertheim's senior chemical industry analyst before he moved from research to corporate finance.
Now, after 18 months as a banker, Mr. Garcia said his background was proving invaluable. "It's a necessity to have industry expertise in investment banking," he said. "Because as the companies become more sophisticated themselves they can do the valuation work" once done by investment bankers.
Mr. Garcia is part of a 15-member group at Wertheim that covers the chemical industry worldwide. In the last year, Mr. Garcia said, his team participated in about 10 merger deals in the industry -- the largest was the recently announced sale of Texaco's chemicals division to Huntsman Chemical for just over $1 billion.
His detailed knowledge of the industry has helped pry loose clients who were otherwise spoken for by better-known investment banks.
"To the extent we are competing with a Goldman or a Morgan Stanley, firms that have senior old-line relationships, it is very hard for an investment bank like Wertheim to penetrate unless we have something really unique," he said.
That means young, aggressive bankers should be prepared to spend time learning the ropes.
"You need both the idea generation capability and the contacts," Mr. Garcia continued. "That usually means you have to pay your dues for 10 years before you get there. I don't think you will see 25-year-old whiz kids running industry groups."
 
 
Eduardo Mestre
Telecommunications
 When Eduardo Mestre left Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton in 1977 for Salomon Brothers, he was one of many bright young professionals who gave up the law to seek gold on Wall Street.
The plan was to have him ply Latin America for deals. His father had been a prominent Cuban businessman who brought television to the island in the 1950's, fled to Argentina in 1960 after Fidel Castro came to power and established another television network there.
But in 1982, the debt crisis exploded and put the Latin America plan on hold. Mr. Mestre, 44, struck out instead after what has proved to be a most dynamic industry: telecommunications.
He was barely out of the blocks when Salomon asked him to work with the group advising A.T.& T. on the divestiture of its local telephone companies. Mr. Mestre was hardly an expert, but back then the telecommunications business was still rather young, and virtually everyone else was in the same boat. Since then, he has participated in some of the biggest deals on record.
Salomon served as an adviser, for instance, to both sides in the recent, $650 million sale of Hauser Communications Inc. to Southwestern Bell, the first plunge by a Bell company into the cable television business. This summer, Salomon won a piece of the $17.6 billion sale of McCaw Communications to A.T.& T., serving as co-advisers to McCaw's independent directors.
"Six or seven years ago, companies hired bankers because they knew the technology of the deal," Mr. Mestre said. "They get hired today because they come up with a good idea or know their way around a particular industry not because they know about Delaware's takeover statute."
Now a co-head of domestic corporate finance at Salomon, Mr. Mestre shows little inclination to stop knocking heads with the competition. Jeff Williams, head of Morgan Stanley's telecommunications group, is probably his most formidable foe, he said.
"What I like about the telecommunications business is that it is truly global," he said, "and if you like to do deals, they tend to be large."
 
 
Enrique F. Senior
Media
 Enrique F. Senior has spent the last 20 years doing media deals at Allen & Company, the investment bank boutique of choice for the entertainment industry. But the way the industry is evolving, he acknowledged that someday there may be no deals left to do.
"The structure of the business is going to be clearly vertically integrated, global and concentrated," he said.
At the moment, Mr. Senior's firm is actively engaged in a battle that many would love to be waging: a battle between two would-be consolidators, Viacom and QVC, over Paramount. His firm is advising QVC, the hostile bidder.
Long an adviser to Viacom's chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, Allen & Company became available to QVC once Mr. Redstone turned instead to Smith Barney Shearson for advice.
Such scrambling to be part of an entertainment deal would have been almost unheard of back when Mr. Senior, a 50-year-old Cuban emigre, who attended Yale and the Harvard Business School, hopped from White Weld & Company to Allen & Company in the 1970's.
"Nobody was really interested in the movie companies," he said. "There was a feeling the accounting was suspect, that you couldn't trust it. And there was a lack of understanding of how the business worked."
To Mr. Senior, there are two keys to a good media deal: knowing the people and understanding the numbers.
Even as entertainment companies are ending up in fewer -- and bigger -- hands, Mr. Senior said he had few doubts that the worldwide frenzy over owning a piece of Americana would ebb.
"When you think about the demand for American entertainment and American-type things, it surprises you the impact this culture has around the world," he said.
 
 
Frederick Frank
Health Care
 When Frederick Frank started covering the health care industry 35 years ago as a young research analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the firm's interest in the area was so tepid that it lumped health care with chemicals.
"I told the head of the research department at the time, this doesn't make sense," recalled Mr. Frank, who volunteered to start following the drug companies.
Mr. Frank left for Lehman Brothers in 1969. And because he knew so much about the growing health-care field, he made a leap many young analysts dream of making: just three years later, he started doing deals -- not just writing about them.
Today, he heads a team of 26 professionals -- one of Wall Street's largest groups devoted exclusively to making deals happen in the health care industry. The group includes his wife, Mary Tanner.
The group has landed more than its share of business. For instance, Lehman advised Bristol-Myers on its merger with Squibb, and earlier this year, it helped Humana Inc. sever its hospital business from its health maintenance organization business.
Given the growing pressure to make the industry more efficient, Mr. Frank said he was confident more deals would follow.
"The industry is going through a sea change on an order of magnitude that has not been experienced in the 35 years I have been in the business," he said.
One might assume that it would take someone younger than Mr. Frank to keep up, and certainly at age 61, Mr. Frank is something of an anomaly in Wall Street's trenches.
But the constant travel, the deals, the contacts seem to be a tonic, not a grind. "I came into this industry vertically, and I'll go out horizontally," Mr. Frank said. "I expect to be continuing to do this for a considerable number of years."

HEADLINE: Business Leaders Voice Skepticism on Health Plan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 7

 BODY:
The chief executives of some of the nation's largest corporations expressed strong skepticism today about President Clinton's plan to overhaul the nation's health care system.
The executives predicted a 3 percent growth in the economy next year but warned that the cost of the health care plan could undermine such a fairly robust rate. 
 Several executives said they were concerned that the health care plan could result in lower-quality health care without controlling costs effectively, a contention that the Administration quickly denied.
"There's a real, genuine risk here of worsening health care," in terms of both quality and costs," said John W. Snow, the chairman, chief executive and president of CSX Corporation. "I don't pretend to have the answers, but frankly, I'm scared of the answers being proposed now."
The hostility of leaders of large corporations, gathered here for a meeting of the Business Council, a group of the chief executives of the nation's 100 largest companies, could represent a serious setback for President Clinton. The Administration has worked hard to tailor the health care plan to the liking of business people, and in fact it promoted the plan's beneficial effects for businesses.
The complaints from large businesses about their soaring health care costs have become louder in recent years. Administration officials have predicted that large concerns would save money under the plan because it would assume much of the cost of the health care of people who retired before the age of 65 and would put a cap on private health insurance premiums.
 
Dubious About U.S. Role
 But several executives were skeptical about the plan's financing, dubious about its cost-cutting measures and wary about the risks involved in giving the Federal Government a greater role in health care.
D. Wayne Calloway, the chairman and chief executive of PepsiCo Inc., warned that a proposed commission to review health care costs would have a level of flexibility and sympathy for business somewhere between "the wetlands commission and the I.R.S."
John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company, said that anyone who wanted a bigger role for the Government should, "go try to get your license renewed next week and see how it works."
Mr. Welch said his company's sales of complicated medical imaging equipment for hospitals had been hurt by the current debate over health care.
Walter V. Shipley, president and chief operating officer of Chemical Bank said economic forecasts would be more optimistic were it not for Mr. Clinton's health care plan and taxes increases in the budget passed this summer.
On a panel of seven executives from the council's executive committee, only Dennis Weatherstone, the chairman and chief executive of J. P. Morgan and Company, was sanguine about the health care debate that lies ahead. "Until proved otherwise, I'd like to be optimistic," he said.
But even Mr. Weatherstone was neutral on President Clinton's specific proposals.
The executives' milder criticisms of Mr. Clinton's health care plan focused on its possible effect on the Federal budget deficit. "While all of the reforms are important, it is a very big bite to take at one time," said Robert E. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. "And we're all rather skeptical about the capacity to pay for it."
Mr. Allen said corporate executives supported the general principles of the Administration's plan. He also said it was good for the nation to confront its health care troubles.
Victor F. Zonana, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said the criticism from business executives was "simply incorrect."
"The President's proposal will be extremely helpful to businesses and will allow them to rein in their health care costs, which have made many companies uncompetitive in global markets," he said. "And the financing of the President's plan is solid."
