HEADLINE: Bhutto Wins Plurality and Faces a New Struggle

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct.7

 BODY:
After battling for more than two years to regain the job that was taken away from her in 1990 on charges of corruption and incompetence, Benazir Bhutto appeared today to be on the brink of triumph to return as Prime Minister of Pakistan.
Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party captured the most seats in the nation's new 217-member Parliament that was elected on Wednesday, although she fell short of a majority and now faces the task of wooing small parties into joining her in a coalition government. 
 Her party won 86 of the 200 parliamentary seats that were up for election, compared with 72 won by the Pakistan Muslim League of her opponent, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif. But refusing to admit defeat, Mr. Sharif began a frenzied effort to recruit 22 independently elected parliamentarians to thwart Ms. Bhutto's comeback.
"Now the real game begins as to who forms the government," said Ayesha Jalal, a professor of history at Columbia University said in a telephone interview from New York. "I think she'll be able to form a government, but it will be a very weak government. The establishment -- the bureaucracy and the army -- will have a very strong hand."
 
An 'Unhappy Situation'
 That assessment was echoed by Sherry Rehman, managing editor of The Herald and a Bhutto supporter.
"It's a very unhappy situation," Ms. Rehman said. "If Nawaz Sharif or if Benazir had come up with a chance of forming a stable government, they would have needed a majority. Now we will see another unstable government. More power jockeying is what I see. There is no question of addressing the larger issues."
Since Pakistan was founded 46 years ago, political horse-trading has tarred the country's political process in a high-stakes bidding war involving huge cash payments, promises of ministerial posts and other acts of favoritism. Even so, Pakistan's history of coalition governments has been an unhappy one. And it seems certain that rather than returning to political stability, Ms. Bhutto's plurality victory insures more uncertainty for a country with desperate social and economic problems.
Ms. Bhutto herself had little to say today beyond complaining loudly and repeatedly about what she said were election irregularities.
"We are unhappy with the manner in which tampered electoral lists were provided in a majority of constituencies," she said in her home in Larkana, in the southern province of Sind. "Our voters were turned away."
 
Few Registered to Vote
 But teams of observers from 40 countries who watched Wednesday's elections at polling stations across the country reported no serious irregularities. Indeed, the general impression today was that the elections, which were carried out under military supervision, was the freest and fairest election since 1970, although one in which fewer than 40 percent of the country's registered voters cast ballots.
The elections pitted Ms. Bhutto against Mr. Sharif, both of whom made no secret of their intense dislike for each other. For more than two years after her dismissal from office, Ms. Bhutto waged a nonstop campaign against Mr. Sharif, a former industrialist from Lahore. She frequently asserted that Mr. Sharif conspired with Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who was President then, to drive her from office and rig the elections of 1990 that propelled Mr. Sharif into the prime ministership.
The prime ministership had since been single-mindedly pursued by Ms. Bhutto, the daughter of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, a tyrannical socialist who ruled Pakistan in the early 1970's and who was executed in 1979 after a military coup in 1977. And when elections were called in July, Ms. Bhutto describe them as a victory for her party.
Earlier this year, when Mr. Ishaq Khan dismissed Mr. Sharif from office on similar charges of corruption and incompetence, Ms. Bhutto sided with President Ishaq Khan. When the Supreme Court restored Mr. Sharif to office, senior members of Ms. Bhutto's party let it be known that they would even support a military coup if it drove Mr. Sharif from office.
 
The Glamour of Bhutto
 When the powerful military establishment forced the resignation of both Mr. Sharif and Mr. Ishaq Khan and ordered new elections in July, it was able to end the country's political and constitutional crisis that resulted in part from Mr. Sharif's battles with the President and from Ms. Bhutto's threats to march on the capital with hundreds of thousands of supporters.
The electoral achievement of Ms. Bhutto, a striking, almost glamorous woman in a deeply male-dominated society, appears to be testimony more to her phenomenal campaign personality before a mostly illiterate electorate than to any of her party's policy pronouncements. Indeed, there is little in Ms. Bhutto's campaign literature to distinguish her program from that of Mr. Sharif.
But some foreign experts say they believe that both Ms. Bhutto and Mr. Sharif, if he somehow manages to outwit his opponent in the search for parliamentary allies, will be constrained in their policies by the radical changes that have been introduced in the two-month-old administration of the interim Prime Minister, Moeen Qureshi.
After assuming office in July, Mr. Qureshi moved swiftly to expose political corruption, crack down on drug traffickers who had long been tolerated by the political establishment, jettison expensive and foolhardy government spending and introduce a measure of fiscal probity to government.
 
Farm Tax Is a Target
 Both Ms. Bhutto, 40, and Mr. Sharif, 44, have criticized Mr. Qureshi's policies, and Ms. Bhutto has said that she will repeal an agricultural tax that he imposed on rich landowners like herself.
"Moeen set a standard that is very difficult to withdraw from," said Paula R. Newberg, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who served as an election monitor in Pakistan. "He ran the place with a Cabinet of six people. If she lets the agricultural tax lapse, there are a lot of people in this country who will consider that the People's Party is still a prisoner of feudal interests."
Ms. Newberg continued: "This interim government came in initially to provide a bridge to a new government, but in the process undertook a series of policy initiatives which served to expose the political establishment as very self-interested, and rather uninterested in the plight of their own constituents. At the same time, it was designing a process for free, fair and direct elections to re-elect these same people. It leads one to ask what the prospects are."
Ms. Rehman of The Herald said the coming days were crucial to Ms. Bhutto's goal of forming a government, with Paraliament expected to convene this month and select a prime minister
"Nawaz Sharif seems very ready to go into battle," she said. "He seems to think he can form a government. This is not going to be easy for Benazir."
But despite clear signs of strain among her political advisers, Ms. Bhutto sounded confident this evening before leaving for Lahore. "The people have given their verdict," she said, "and they have given their verdict in favor of the Pakistan People's Party."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Debates of the 2 New Jersey Gubernatorial Candidates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a gubernatorial candidates' debate last night in Trenton between Gov. Jim Florio and Christine Todd Whitman, as recorded by The New York Times.
 
The Economy
Q. Mrs. Whitman, your economic plan calls for a 30 percent income tax cut over three years. Will the cuts be in human services, welfare? Will money for state colleges be on the block? Please tell us specifically what you plan to cut. 
 WHITMAN What we are talking about doing, it's 5 cents on the dollar. I have the ability, as the Governor does, to have a line-item veto, impoundment authority; and I have a willing legislature behind me, the leadership on both sides, who've done it before and are willing to do it again. Just by limiting the rate of growth of state government to 3 percent, instead of the almost double the cost of living increase that we've seen recently, you will save $500 million.
If you just keep the employees of this state so that if two them working in state government, both covered by family plans, instead of each having their own plan they get -- each have one plan, you save between $50 million and $70 million. The cuts are there to be made.
Q. Will you please be specific about where those cuts would come from? We haven't heard any details yet.
WHITMAN Well, Nora, there are two things. One is that I can look when I see things that -- numbers that tell me that $10,000 -- tens of thousands of dollars -- are spent by the Department of Corrections to buy Adidas sneakers for prisoners, those are the kinds of things we can cut. Department of Human Services spent over $200,000 last year for an executive search firm. Those are the little things.
The big things are cutting the rate of growth of state government, holding it in; and then we're going to get in and do a performance audit, use what's been done before -- this Governor's done some of it and I congratulate him on that -- but there are over $500 million in potential cuts and savings that haven't been implemented yet.
There is plenty of waste to do it. Republicans did it, and I expect the Governor to say the world will come to an end. He did that last time and it didn't.
Q. Well, Mr. Florio, if that's what you're going to say, you have ----
FLORIO Well, $1.5 billion worth of Adidas sneakers is a lot of sneakers.
WHITMAN Ten thousand.
FLORIO That's what you have to do --
WHITMAN Tens of thousands.
FLORIO In order to cut the budget in the way that Mrs. Whitman is talking about, this is the plan. Now, it's two sheets. The numbers don't add up one side to the other side. And it really is promising people pie in the sky without telling anybody where the dough is going to come from. I mean, what we're talking about is promising people 30 percent reductions. My understanding is now people in the cities are being promised a 50 percent reduction. The total amount of money that that costs is $1.5 billion.
No one is saying where the money is going to come from, although then now we're going to talk about cutting Adidas sneakers. This really doesn't make a lot of sense.
Q. Governor, Mrs. Whitman seems to have set much of the economic agenda with her pledge to cut taxes by 30 percent. That's what people are talking about. Your economic plans seem to be based on a $1 billion loan program through the Economic Development Agency for businesses and development agencies and for schools, some for businesses, some for development agencies, some for schools. Is this the plan of a visionary or is this the plan of a bureaucrat with a calculator?
FLORIO Well, my plan, as I said, is not sort of a magic wand on two sheets of paper. My plan is sitting on the runway up at Newark Airport -- Kiwi Airlines. Go talk to Bob Iverson, who is the C.E.O., who will tell you that but for the state loan guarantees that program, that whole airline would not have gotten off the ground.
My plan is the Rutgers University stadium that we are building, that Mrs. Whitman opposed. My plan is the Convention Center in Atlantic City that is being built right now, that Mrs. Whitman opposed. My plan is the Performing Arts Center. My plan is keeping the high level of credit rating that we have right now, which gives us the ability to go and invest in sewage treatment plants, to invest in transportation systems, to invest in the Jersey Shore.
Q. We're talking about cutting taxes.
FLORIO The idea -- the idea of cutting taxes is fine, but that's not what's happening here. Cutting taxes with no corresponding reductions -- you've got $1.5 billion in the hole. Tonight we heard the first degree of specificity forever. Adidas sneakers are going to be taken away from inmates, apparently. Well, you know, you've got to go to make up $1.5 billion.
Weathervane politicians really just won't cut it anymore. You can't tell people just what they want to hear by promising them anything.
Q. Ms. Whitman.
WHITMAN Well, I would expect the Governor to be in deep denial over tax cuts, because he's never met a tax hike he didn't like. The point is that every time we have seen -- and you look at the economic history of the State of New Jersey, and you look at the trend line, when you cut taxes you see jobs created.
He talks about the E.D.A. and says they're creating 20,000 jobs. That's wonderful. We lost 10,000 jobs in August alone. We've lost 280,000 jobs in the last three and a half years. We lead the nation in home foreclosure. It's the kind of thing that led to the opportunity I had to talk with someone just the other week who was sitting on his porch outside in the rain, because he couldn't go inside, it was too hot and he couldn't afford an air-conditioner, because he'd lost his job just a week before and they're trying to adopt a child. And he was scared to death for his future. This is what it's all about. It's about the people of the State of New Jersey.
 
Gun Control

 Q. Mrs. Whitman, earlier this year you reportedly told the owners of Gunarama, a Jersey City gun shop, you would consider legislation to legalize certain weapons now banned in the state. What weapons would you legalize and what is your position on the Brady Bill?
WHITMAN I support the Brady Bill and, contrary to what the Governor has been saying in his ads, I oppose assault weapons, and I opposed, and very publicly, the Republicans' attempt to override that. Where I have stood on this bill is, from the beginning, is that those people who acquired things like .22's, the kind of target and practice weapons that the Olympic team uses -- and they would be arrested if they were to land at Newark Airport with their guns from a competition -- those are the kinds of things that I believe people who got them legally should be grandfathered. It's a taking, that's all; it's a recognition of that. But I do not support assault weapons.
But we've got to understand that the problem of crime goes far beyond an assault weapon. There've been over 400,000 crimes committed since the assault ban went into effect, and less than one-tenth of 1 percent of those involved assault weapons. That doesn't mean we want them on the street. We don't want them on the street.
But if we think that alone is going to solve the problem of crime in the State of New Jersey, then we are being foolish. We have got to get beyond that. That's why I have called for three times, and you're in for a third-time violent offender -- that they go with no parole at that time. That we require people to serve 70 percent of their sentence. Right now, they serve an average of 20 to 25 percent of the sentence given them by the court. That we have judges that understand it's their responsibility to enforce the law, not to write the law. Those are the kinds of changes we need to make in order to affect the system.
Q. Governor Florio.
FLORIO She wants to grandfather all of the weapons that are out there. I don't know why anybody has a need WHITMAN Obviate Uzi's and AK-47's, Governor.
FLORIO For Tec-9's or any of those types of weapons. But we've been asking which weapons on the list do you want to put back into circulation. She called it a lousy law. She and the N.R.A. have been out just saying this is not a law that should stand; it should be changed. And the answer is the people of this state really don't believe that there is any need for assault weapons. You can't hunt with them. You know, it's illegal, always was illegal, to hunt with these types of weapons.
And, of course, this is not the answer to crime. But I'll tell you, it is a very, very serious concern to the policemen of this state. The Fraternal Order of Police and the P.B.A. statewide both endorsed me, in large measure because they know who it is that's been working very hard for the police persons on the beat out there now.
Q. I'd like to follow up so that we have a clear picture here. What are the weapons you would ban?
WHITMAN Ninety percent of them on the list. The only weapon I've talked about taking off at all would be a .22. But, quite frankly, that's not the issue. The issue is government taking without understanding that there is -- that there's people that have had them legally. But more importantly is the issue of crime itself. We have heard a great deal of verbiage and rhetoric out of this Governor about how important this is to solving crime. And yet juvenile crime is up. Juvenile homicide is up 42 percent; since 1989 it's gone up. Those are the things we need to get after. We need to stop these problems. Rape is up 6 percent statewide, and among juveniles it's up over 11 percent. Those are the kinds of issues that we've got to get at.
FLORIO When she says that she'll put .22's in -- go talk to the mother of the girl was killed in East Orange, N.J., with a Tec-.22, with a 50-round banana clip, which is a piece of junk. No legitimate sportsman needs one. Or the Marlin 60 with a 17-round tubular clip. All 17 rounds were pumped into five priests and two nuns down in Texas. These are weapons that real people know don't belong in our state.

HEADLINE: House and Senate Agree to Raise Fees for Grazing on Federal Land

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Breaking a decades-old deadlock over the management of public lands in the West, Democrats in the House and Senate today agreed to raise the fees that ranchers pay to graze cattle and sheep on about 260 million acres of Federal land in 16 western states.
The agreement appeared to represent an important political victory for Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who has staked his tenure on developing a new "land ethic" that puts protecting the environment on equal footing with developing resources. 
 The agreement, reached by a House and Senate conference committee that is considering the Interior Department's appropriations for the fiscal year 1994, gave Mr. Babbitt much of what he had sought on the grazing issue since taking office.
The agreement, which will be voted on next week, calls for raising grazing fees over the next three years to $3.45 from $1.86 for every cow and calf. Mr. Babbitt had originally asked for fees of more than $4.
 
Reflects Babbitt's Agenda
 But the rest of the agreement is almost identical to other measures Mr. Babbitt proposed. One provision would give the Government much more authority to restrict ranchers who are harming the land. Another would give the Government more ability to control and protect water on Federal lands. A third would give the Government control of pumps, tanks, fences and other permanent improvements to Federal lands by ranchers. A fourth would abolish grazing advisory boards, which are dominated by ranchers and exert enormous political influence over the management of public lands.
Democratic lawmakers said the agreement indicated that Mr. Babbitt had gained the upper hand in the political debate over improving the management of public lands. They said that breaking the impasse over grazing meant changes were also likely for mining, timber and other industries dependent on Federal lands.
"Today, Bruce Babbitt became Secretary of the Interior," said Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat who has been fighting for years to raise grazing fees and improve environmental conditions in the West. "If we had lost here, the public would have rightfully doubted our commitment to serious deficit reduction and true honest public land reform."
Republican lawmakers from the West denounced the pact, and aides to several Democratic Senators from Western states said their bosses were uncomfortable with it.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said: "I am deeply, deeply disappointed by this so-called compromise by the Democrats. No Republicans were part of it, and I fear it will result in unnecessary pain and economic suffering for thousands of New Mexico's ranchers and small townspeople."
 
An Issue Delayed
 Last spring, President Clinton dismayed Mr. Babbitt and environmentalists when he bowed to pressure from several western Democratic Senators and dropped from his budget package a host of proposals to end subsidies and raise fees for using public lands. The White House said it would reintroduce the measures, and just days after the budget package was narrowly approved by Congress, Mr. Babbitt announced he would pursue higher grazing fees and other changes in managing western lands.
The House has long sought higher grazing fees, while Western Senators have fought them. Last month, the Senate blocked Mr. Babbitt's proposals, creating a stalemate that was apparently resolved today.
Experts say if the agreement becomes law, it would represent one of the most important changes in Federal land management since grazing fees were introduced in 1906. Some 30,000 families hold permits to graze livestock on Federal lands.
The Sierra Club, which has sought such changes for years, today called the agreement a milestone in protecting the last great open stretches of land in the 48 contiguous states.
But cattlemen said the agreement would give the Government broad new powers to interfere in private family businesses across the West and would diminish the value of ranches and drive thousands of people off the land.
"They are in the process of destroying the lives of thousands of innocent people," said Al Schneberger, the executive director of the New Mexico Cattle Growers' Association in Albuquerque.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Stakes Claim to House Minority Leadership

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Accompanied by more than 60 Republican lawmakers, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia said today that he had more than enough votes pledged to insure his election as House Republican leader in the next Congress -- assuming he and most of his supporters win re-election next year.
Mr. Gingrich, who as the Republican whip holds the No. 2 position in the House, would replace Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, whose style has been more accommodating to Democratic Congressional leaders. Mr. Michel announced earlier in the week that he would not seek re-election. 
 Mr. Gingrich, a Republican from Georgia, said 106 of 175 Republican members had committed their votes to him. The representatives who turned up on the lawn in front of the Capitol to show their support included conservatives and moderates and members from all regions, but his principal opponent, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of Glens Falls, N.Y., did not concede. Mr. Solomon was traveling today and was unavailable for comment.
Unless there is an unexpectedly large turnover of Republicans in the House in 1994, Mr. Gingrich is likely to retain sufficient support to secure the job he claimed today.
 
Has Strong Freshman Support
 The core of Mr. Gingrich's support comes from the 48 Republican freshmen, 40 of whom are committed to him.
Mr. Gingrich promised aggressive leadership and, underscoring his desire to draw a sharp contrast with the Democratic Party, criticized the Administration's policy in Somalia.
He called for open hearings to investigate reports that the Administration had denied a request from an American military officer in Mogadishu for heavy armor, leading to the heavy combat casualties last weekend. "The commander in chief has a responsibility to be militarily competent," Mr. Gingrich said.
Mr. Gingrich describe a philosophical vision of what the Republican Party should stand for in Congress and how it should project itself to the electorate. He shied away from social issues like abortion and school prayer, which divided the party in last year's Presidential campaign, instead concentrating on economic issues.
Speaking on Mr. Gingrich's behalf, Representative Scott L. Klug, who represents a liberal district that includes Madison, Wis., and who supports abortion rights, said, "To those of us who have supported Congressional reform, Newt has been a tireless champion."
Representative John Linder, a conservative freshman from Georgia, praised Mr. Gingrich as "the principal idea man of our party."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Newt Gingrich announcing that he had more than enough votes to replace Representative Robert H. Michel as House Republican leader. Mr. Michel said he would not seek re-election. (Associated Press)

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1993

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 518 words

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Dip To Lowest Level in '93

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 9,000 last week, to the lowest level in more than nine months, the Government said today.
In other reports, the Commerce Department said the growth of Americans' per capita income accelerated in 1992, exceeding inflation in all but seven states. And the Federal Reserve said consumer borrowing rose $3.63 billion in August amid increases in credit card use and auto loans. 
 The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 320,000, the lowest since 317,000 laid-off workers filed claims in the week that ended last Dec. 26. It was the second straight decline and the seventh in 10 weeks.
The less-volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims, which analysts prefer to track because it more accurately reflects the labor situation, also fell. The average totaled 328,250, down from 328,750 in the period that ended on Sept. 25.
Analysts said the report suggested continued modest improvements in the labor market. Many are forecasting that more than 150,000 jobs were created in September, while the unemployment rate remained at 6.7 percent for a second straight month.
The Labor Department will release reports Friday on the September employment situation.
 
Per Capita Income Growth
 The report on per capita income showed growth of 4.9 percent nationally last year, up from 2.7 percent in 1991 when the economy was emerging from recession.
 The rate of growth in 1991 had been the slowest since 1961, when incomes increased just 2.5 percent, according to Rudolph E. DePass of the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.
But income growth last year still suffered from the sluggish recovery. It had risen 6.5 percent in 1989, the year before the recession began.
And the figures showed the lingering effects of the recession in California, which for the first time on record was not included among the 10 states with the highest incomes.
Per capita income is the annual total personal income of residents divided by a state's population on July 1. Personal income is the pretax income received by all persons, minus social insurance payments.
An inflation measure tied to the report increased just 3.7 percent last year, the lowest since a 3 percent advance in 1986.
Income growth outpaced price increases in all states except Florida, where it was up just 2.6 percent; Delaware, 2.7 percent; California and Hawaii, 2.9 percent each; Alaska, 3.2 percent; Maryland, 3.6 percent, and Wyoming, 3.7 percent.
States with the highest per capita incomes were Connecticut, $27,137; New Jersey, $26,969; New York, $23,842, and Massachusetts, $23,811. California, with $21,472, ranked 11th, the first time it had not been among the top 10 since the bureau began keeping records in 1929.
The states with the lowest per capita incomes were Mississippi, $14,128, and West Virginia, $15,332.
The gain in consumer borrowing in August was higher than many economists had expected. But July borrowing was revised downward, to a gain of $5.04 billion from about $5.1 billion.
